column2: LEXINGTON, S.C. - Rick Santorum has started using an unfortunate new metaphor to describe his position among the remaining candidates: Goldilocks and the three bears.

For those who follow copyright issues, cases of infringement are usually fought with civil lawsuits. Yet the operators behind the site Megaupload have been charged with criminal offenses, and four of them are being held without bail in New Zealand. What is different about Megaupload, and why have the authorities cracked down so hard on it?

Last season, Landry Fields took New York by storm, winning over Knicks fans almost instantly in his rookie year. He seemed to fit perfectly into the team's lineup, serving as a defensive cog in a first unit that was otherwise filled with offensive firepower.

This chart from Talking Points Memo shows what seems to be a reasonably sharp rise in Mitt Romney's unfavorable ratings among the broader electorate, much of which seems to have come since we last checked in on the issue just a week ago.
President Obama will not renominate his chosen candidate for assistant secretary of interior for parks and wildlife, who ran into a firm wall of Republican opposition in the Senate.
A blogger and a magazine editor are the first two adventurers to complete Damien Hirst's wacky spot challenge.
A look back on our reporting of the past week's highs and lows in finance.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. -- Charitable organizations that assist wounded American veterans received unexpectedly large windfalls Thursday at the Barrett-Jackson classic car auctions here, with help from the prominent motorsports figures Roger Penske and Mario Andretti.
All the fashion news of the week that's fit to reprint.

Nineteen times this political season, the Republican candidates for president have stood shoulder to shoulder on a stage, regardless of how much money they had raised or how many endorsements they had won, and passionately laid out for the voters the ideas and qualifications that they believe make them the best choice for the nation's highest office.

1/21/12 | Updated to correct Professor Babcock's academic affiliation.Amid broader discussions about the future of the American work force, the National Science Foundation has just released a comprehensive report on the state of engineering and science in America. There's a lot of meat in the report, but I found this chart to be particularly striking:

Last season, Rei Kawakubo used bridal lace in her men's collection; this time, she went for old-time pink roses on gray suiting, sweet polka dots and boxy shorts or culottes with jackets that evoked the classic Chanel cardigan. And the shoes came with little heels and socks with boldly colored ribbing, while the models wore Joan Jett wigs, at times with a beribboned bowler hat. All these elements felt warmly and securely Comme des Garçons, but perhaps the most appealing thing about the show today was the silhouette: longish and free at the waist, with those full shorts (or knee-length skirts) and, naturally, hairy calves before the splash of pink at the ankles. One impulse was romantic - Jane Eyre, I thought - the other punk.
A look at the day in sports, from the tennis courts in Australia to a World Cup skeleton race in Switzerland.

It is a political truism: fear is a major motivator for voters. And President Obama wants supporters to know that whoever emerges from the blood bath of the Republican primaries, that presidential nominee will be much farther to the right than Mr. Obama's 2008 opponent, Senator John McCain.
The Citadel Military College is an imposing political symbol on its own, but it also has engaged students who are deciding among the candidates.
Joel Robuchon has anounced the appointment of Christophe Bellanca as the new executive chef for L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon in the Four Seasons Hotel in New York.

This time of year, after a few weeks of post-holiday deprivation and perhaps a little too much foul weather, a bit of decadence may seem in order, at least for one meal. Why not treat yourself and your table mates to the one of the cold season's treats, and indulge in a fresh crabmeat salad? In this week's City Kitchen, we're making a deviled crab salad with slightly bitter chicory greens and a lemony, mustardy dressing, suitable for a fine first course or weekend lunch.
Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, called off a scheduled vote on the Protect IP Act, and House leaders took steps to slow legislation as well. Read more »
Whenever I write about the undertones (and sometimes overtones) of race in American politics, I get a lot of critical emails and Tweets, some reasonable, some pretty nasty.

5:11 p.m. | Updated "American Idol" may have officially crossed over from phenomenon to mere hit television show on Thursday, as the second outing of this year's edition fell a steep 27 percent in the ratings from its performance on the same night last year - and 44 percent from its number two years ago.
Citadel, the hedge fund behemoth that experienced losses of more than 50 percent during the financial crisis, has finally recovered.

Please click over to the SchoolBook blog to read a fantastic post from Anne Stone and Jeff Nichols about their unusual choice for a New Year's Eve activity with friends: they took the third-grade English language arts practice test one of their children took home over vacation.

In the undulating curve of expectations, hype and maneuvering that is Oscar season, "J. Edgar" has had a hard time catching on. Clint Eastwood's biopic, starring Leonard DiCaprio as Hoover and Armie Hammer as his associate and paramour, Clyde Tolson, might wind up being the Jon Huntsman of the awards race: it had high expectations - the Bagger started hearing about it last Oscar season, when Mr. Hammer, then making the rounds for "The Social Network," was cast - some glowing reviews and many of the right elements for prize glory, including a good back story.

The Wall Street Journal has hired Raju Narisetti, a managing editor of The Washington Post, to become managing editor of its online news properties, Dow Jones, the parent company of the Journal, announced on Friday.

Pulling the vending machines out of schools has long been something of a battle cry for parents concerned with childhood obesity. Many schools and districts rely on vendor contracts to finance extracurricular activities (in New York City, snacks sold in vending machines are limited in calories, fat and sugar content), while advocates worry that the omnipresent snacks will mean weight gain in students.
Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers questions from readers.

Danilo Gallinari is ready to come back to New York. It was Feb. 22 of last year when "il Gallo," one of most popular players during Coach Mike D'Antoni's tenure with the Knicks, was involved in the trade that brought Carmelo Anthony to New York.

There was a lot to get excited about at Valentino this morning. The accessories, for one, are stellar and studded: the season's new loafer, pictured here, is stamped on top with a large gold pyramid stud; the combat boot, another favorite, is ruffled in the front; the brogues come in patent leather with spiky metal toe caps (similar to the ones we just saw at the men's shows in Europe). Romantic, rose-embellished and decorated with bows and lace, the dresses and skirt looks are lovely and expertly tailored. Just what you expect from the Italian house - though it's the suit story made of nipped silk satin tuxedos and soft, tie-neck blouses that caught this editor's attention. Here, the rippling asymmetrical lapel on a blush-pink jacket flirts with Le Smoking without going all the way.
Etta James has died at age 73.
If you're looking for a simple meal, the egg is a good place to start, explains Martha Rose Shulman in this week's Recipes for Health.

Apple's free book-creation tool, iBooks Author, seemed too good to be true: it gives anyone the ability to easily lay out an interactive book with no programming required, slap it up for sale in Apple's iBooks Store and ideally make a quick buck. But hours after Apple released the software on Thursday, people noticed that they were not allowed to sell these books outside Apple's store.

More than 30 years ago, when the psychiatrist Dr. Peter Rabins and the psychologist Nancy Mace began working with dementia patients and their families at Johns Hopkins Hospital, they had to write and mimeograph (younger readers: look it up) small pamphlets to explain to them what was going on and what was to come.
January 20, 2012 - Just a day before the South Carolina primary, Nate Silver's latest projections show a shift in the lead.

Last week, The New York Times reported that transcripts showed top Federal Reserve officials were often laughing in 2006 as the housing collapse neared. The Daily Stag Hunt used Federal Open Market Committee documents to show that the laughter increased from 16.5 times a meeting in 2001 to 44 times a meeting in 2006. Read more », via Felix Salmon
Heaps of rusted metal, moldering bathroom appliances and stone steers' heads have found new homes.

Today's installment in my continuing series on the folly of America's refusal to abandon the death penalty comes courtesy of an article by Adam Liptak in The Times. As Mr. Liptak reported, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that just because someone messed up in the mailroom, you don't necessarily deserve capital punishment.

On Thursday night I happened to call a friend just before 10 p.m. and caught her a little tipsy - she had been out celebrating Rick Perry's ignominious withdrawal from the presidential race.

"X-Men: Schism" lands at No. 1 on the hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. When an international incident sends hatred of mutants into a new frenzy, Cyclops and Wolverine are divided in their response and cause a rift in the team. This collected edition contains the five issues of "Schism," written by Jason Aaron with each issue illustrated by a different powerhouse artist (Carlos Pacheco, Frank Cho, Daniel Acuna, Alan Davis and Adam Kubert). It also includes the standalone special "X-Men: Regenesis," written by Kieron Gillen and illustrated by Billy Tan, in which the other X-Men choose whether they will stand with Cyclops or Wolverine. The X-Men are synonymous with change, with the characters getting reshuffled into new teams every few years, so the fracture among the heroes may be temporary. (Particularly with a huge conflict with the Avengers coming right around the corner.)

Do you celebrate Australia Day, that country's national holiday, coming up on Thursday? If not, this would be a good year to start. With a mess of Australian meat pies to go and some shiraz or Foster's, you're all set. And for those pies, there is a new source in New York: Pie Face, the first American outpost of a down-under takeout chain.

Packed with writers, publishers, school kids and chief executives, the Jaipur Literature Festival can and has been described in many ways, from circus to the "front lines" of the fight against extremism.

C. has a problem perhaps too serious to be called a quandary. A few months ago, she says, her family received a flier from the local sheriff. A registered sex offender was moving to her street of small, single-family homes. Hers is a long street, though, and she expected the offender to be some distance away and easily avoidable.

Coda Automotive is supposed to start selling its electric sedan next month. On Friday, its parent company announced that it was also moving into a related line: stationary batteries for electricity storage.

The director M. Night Shyamalan - whose breakthrough film, "The Sixth Sense," told the story of a boy empowered to see and talk to the dead - was finally able to commune with a living buyer for his TriBeCa penthouse after more than a year, selling it for $9.5 million, the biggest sale of the past week, according to city records.

The streak is over. After 13-plus years, after 13 consecutive national championships, after 252 straight victories - the longest such run in college sports - the Trinity men's squash team has lost a match, to Yale.

PARK CITY, Utah -- It's an emotional strain for a filmmaker to bring a project to Sundance. The thrill of getting in is quickly followed by fear: What happens if nobody likes it? Now imagine what added emotions might be surging through a director whose film showcase's his son's disability.

1:55 p.m. | Updated BALTIMORE - House Republicans, undaunted by the payroll tax holiday debacle that dinged their conference last month, said Friday that they were considering using the Keystone XL Pipeline as a chip in the next round of negotiations over the tax break, as part of their overall efforts to push back against White House policies this year.

The daily work of government bureaucracy may not be as captivating to watch as Shiba Inu puppies or giant pandas sleeping. But the risk of boredom has not deterred tens of thousands from visiting a site broadcasting video from a Web camera trained on a cinderblock office in Madison, Wis., where state workers are processing signatures calling for the recall of the governor.

The giant silver globe that was suspended over the runway at Louis Vuitton made it clear from the moment we took our seats that we were in for quite a trip. Kim Jones, an Englishman in Paris, presented his stunning second collection for the luxury house. Exploring influences from both Tokyo and the City of Light, the clothes paid homage to the legendary fashion illustrator Antonio Lopez, an artist with links to both fashion capitals. Lopez's drawings were brought vividly to life in a group of graphic, patterned (and LV-monogrammed) blanket coats with coordinating scarves pinned at the neck. A vicuna double-breasted, belted coat (see Coming Soon: Belted Coats) worn with a mink scarf, kimono-style shirt and gray double-faced pajama trousers made references to both East and West in the most luxurious way possible.

PARIS - In my latest column, I look at the wines of Galicia, in the far northwestern corner of Spain, where the cool influence of the Atlantic is strong. For anyone expecting big, Mediterranean style reds, you'll have to look elsewhere.
The number of new passenger cars registered in the European Union declined 15.8 percent from 2007 to 2011. Registrations fell in 17 of the 24 European countries with populations over 1 million.

The Chinese New Year commences Monday, but some restaurants will jump-start their celebrations and offer special menus this weekend. At Masak, 432 East 13th Street (between First Avenue and Avenue A), in the East Village, a preview menu is offered today through Sunday, with items like arrowroot chips and roasted quail stuffed with rice, chestnuts, lotus seeds, kale and a salted duck yolk. A more extensive New Year menu is offered starting Tuesday. To celebrate the Year of the Dragon, Chinatown Brasserie, 380 Lafayette Street (Great Jones Street), in NoHo, will cook up dim sum specials, traditional Chinese fare and an assortment of desserts starting on Sunday. Culinary tours led by Adventure on a Shoestring this weekend include a walking tour of Manhattan's Chinatown at 1 and 3 p.m. with samplings of dumplings, pastries and ice cream. The tours will meet at the southeast corner of Canal and Mott Streets. The fee is $10 and does not include food. Call (212) 265-2663 for more information.

With a new James Bond film, "Skyfall," being released this fall, and Her Majesty's favorite cinematic spy franchise celebrating its 50th anniversary, an exhibition of Bond cars has opened at the National Motor Museum in Beaulieu in the south of England.

In the post-Al Franken, post-Robert Smigel, post-Tina Fey era of "Saturday Night Live," it is perhaps only its nerdiest and most obsessive viewers who have a favorite writer on that NBC late-night sketch show. But since joining the "S.N.L." writing staff for its 2008-09 season, John Mulaney has found himself a place in the hearts of completists and casual fans alike: a Chicago-born standup comic, Mulaney has gained recognition as a creator and writer of Stefon, the ultra-hip nightlife correspondent played in frequent "Weekend Update" appearances by Bill Hader; and for his own occasional riffs, delivered as himself from the "Update" desk. (Also joining him in this modern-day pantheon is his fellow "S.N.L." writer and Internet microcelebrity Mike O'Brien.)

Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier-fed streams.

Fans of Steven Spielberg probably know that the director got his start making films as a teenager. But did you know that the director of "War Horse" and "The Adventures of Tintin" also toiled as stage manager for "Guys and Dolls," "Brigadoon" and other theater productions at his high school in Phoenix? As our colleague Patrick Healy writes, "Backstage drama provided the first adrenaline rush of his career, he said, and always struck him as good material. So much so that, a few years ago, Mr. Spielberg began shopping around a television series set on Broadway, but he met with rejection from HBO (where he made 'Band of Brothers') and the broadcast networks." But Mr. Spielberg was not deterred and next month his idea comes to fruition with "Smash" on NBC. Read more »

After a man in an Afghan Army uniform shoots and kills four French soldiers, French President Nicolas Sarkozy announces the suspension of military operations in Afghanistan and consideration of an early pullout from the American-led coalition.

Exxon Mobil agrees to pay $1.6 million in penalties to the state of Montana for pollution caused by a pipeline break last summer that fouled dozens of miles of shoreline along the Yellowstone River. Of that amount, $300,000 is a cash fine and the rest is to go toward future environmental projects. Exxon says that more than 63,000 gallons of crude swept into the river. [The Associated Press]

I'm no great fan of snow or the groundhog, but one arrival I look forward to each winter is temple oranges - shiny, spongy to the touch and deeply rutted with pores, like a cartoonist's idea of an orange. I spotted a temple-like pyramid (a ziggurat?) of them the other day in front of Fairway on the Upper West Side.

The plot twist: Mr. Siegel's lawsuit may turn out to be more embarrassing for him than Ms. Greenfield's film.

At Yves Saint Laurent, Stefano Pilati stuck to slim dark tailoring with leather insets and flashes of silver on shoes. There was much black leather, which was based on motorcycle gear but given more polish and presented in ensemble. You can imagine people coveting pieces, especially some of the nicely shaped jackets, but the show didn't offer much direction.

Autism, as a psychiatric disorder, is defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, published by the American Psychiatric Association, which covers all mental health disorders for both children and adults. That definition matters - an official diagnosis of autism is what opens up access to services and treatment to many affected individuals, both children and adults.

Ryan Avent points out an important fact: if you look at total debt, public and private, the United States is doing better at deleveraging than countries that talk much more about the evils of debt than we do. I thought I would redo the calculation for the US so that I understood it. I focus on nonfinancial debt -- that's because money that banks owe to each other is more a reflection of the structure of the financial system than of the degree of overborrowing more broadly. The Supreme Court on Friday instructed a lower court in Texas to take a fresh look at election maps it had drawn in place of a competing set of maps from the Texas Legislature. The justices said the lower court had not paid enough deference to the Legislature's choices and had improperly substituted its own values for those of elected officials.

The Jaipur Literature Festival got off to a macabre start on Friday with organizers announcing that the Indian-born author Salman Rushdie would not attend the event because of a new assassination threat against him. Instead, Mr. Rushdie said he would address the event via a video link.

As I wrote in Friday's New York Times, the first round in federal court has gone to Entergy, the electrical power production company that does not want to shut down its Vermont Yankee nuclear plant. The state of Vermont has been seeking to close the plant when its initial 40-year federal operating license expires on March 21.

Friday's New York Times takes a look at two problems that could complicate ending the war in Afghanistan: the growing mistrust between Afghan soldiers and coalition forces and concerns by Afghan officials over clarity regarding peace talks between the United States and the Taliban.

Vikram S. Pandit, the chief executive of Citigroup, has been awarded about $3.7 million in stock from the bank, Bloomberg News reports, citing regulatory filings. Eleven other Citi executives also received stock grants. Read more »

Before the floods, Thailand produced nearly 45 percent of the world's hard disk drives, the ubiquitous storage devices of the digital age. It is now clear it will be months before production returns to normal, Thomas Fuller reports. Read more »

Few scientific explorations have captured the public's imagination like Robert Falcon Scott's expedition to Antarctica from 1910 to 1913. He and a team of scientists withstood incredible hardships  and perished before reaching home, but not before they had discovered a large number of zoological and geological specimens that greatly furthered scientific knowledge of the vast region. These included 2,109 different species of animals and plants from land and water, more than 400 of them new to science.
At 89, the architect Kevin Roche finds himself back in the spotlight with the opening this week of the renovated American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A further thought about the proper calculation of tax burdens on very high income Americans: if you remember past debates, it's kind of peculiar to see conservatives jumping up and down to say that Mitt Romney does too pay reasonable taxes if you include the profits taxes on the corporations in which he invests. Because if memory serves me, just a few years ago conservatives were denouncing the "flypaper theory" of tax incidence, arguing that much of the burden of corporate taxes really falls on labor, not on stockholders. Is it just my imagination?

Despite heavy interest, Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo are not currently working on a sequel to "Bridesmaids," as Ms. Wiig has said several times (and confirmed in our recent TimesTalk). But there is a follow-up of sorts to the hit comedy: "Bridesmaids," the porn version.

The awards season can go by so quickly. We're barely able to process the game of musical chairs that is the Critics' Choice Awards, and already we're headed to Sundance. That frigid film festival got under way last night, but before we turn our attention there, remember the Golden Globes? Five days ago? The Beverly Hilton, where the Globes were given out, was chockablock with afterparties on Sunday. Kenneth Branagh let us in on a few of their secrets. But in our Styles pages, Bee-Shyuan Chang explains the system in more detail: "As the night progressed, an unspoken pecking order emerged. Film stars drank and dashed off (perhaps to the Weinstein party). TV actors loosened up and lingered. Reality stars pitched a camp." Read more »

Anyone lamenting the dearth of surrealist literary salons in New York has only to stop by The Oracle Club, a new members-only workspace for artists and writers in Long Island City. Open since early December, the club is the result of Jenna Gribbon and Julian Tepper - a couple who live above the space and a painter and novelist, respectively - having asked themselves, one morning in October, "What would be the most amazing scenario we could imagine for ourselves?" The three-room space includes a library, a living room and an art studio, all decorated by Gribbon and Tepper. "It's Salvador Dali's house meets Whistler's Peacock Room meets Coco Chanel's house meets Cocteau's Chapel," Gribbon said. For monthly fees ranging from $50 to $175, members get a key; access to the space from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m., seven days a week; and a standing invitation to any readings or events held at the club. The interior is still evolving. "I'm looking for the perfect small kaleidoscope to put in the bathroom wall as a fake peep hole, so you think you're going to peep into the bathroom but it turns out to be a kaleidoscope," Gribbon said. "Everything in time," Tepper said.

The White House hopes that someday soon everyone will be able to monitor and control their home energy usage, and lower their monthly utility bills, with a few swipes on a smartphone app. At least that's the vision of the Green Button initiative, a recent White House effort to bring together the nation's utilities, energy consumers and private industry to develop Internet and mobile phone-style technologies and business models aimed at reducing energy consumption.

LONDON -- European banks must submit their recapitalization plans to their national authorities by Friday as the banks seek to increase their capital reserves by a combined 115 billion euros, or $147 billion.

DHAKA, Bangladesh - Earlier this month, Bangladesh's foreign minister chided the world's developed nations for failing to honor their pledge to help this low-lying, water-logged nation adapt to the effects of climate change. Of the $30 billion that poor countries were promised three years ago, just $2.5 billion have been disbursed. "Our achievements - social, economic, environmental - of the past decades" are at risk, Dipu Moni told the Guardian.

At the end of last year, I was looking over a list of Toronto's Best Albums of 2011 in the Toronto-based publication The Grid (full disclosure: I am from Toronto) when something struck me: The list of best albums from Toronto in 2011 could have easily doubled as a list of the best albums of 2011, full-stop.

Behavior that normally would get an audience member kicked out of a screening is welcome at movie sing-alongs. Throwing rice at "The Rocky Horror Picture Show." Hand-jiving at "Grease." Twirling in a dirndl at "The Sound of Music."

There is a revolution brewing in the way college students buy and read textbooks. And, perhaps surprisingly, it does not center entirely on Apple's announcement on Thursday about new textbook technology on iBooks 2.
Today's Times:

KABUL, Afghanistan - Coalition forces in Afghanistan are being killed in increasing numbers by the very Afghan soldiers they fight alongside and train, according to American and Afghan officers and a classified coalition report obtained by The New York Times. Most football fans have learned to hate the "prevent defense," a strategy that is employed when a team holds a lead late in the game. In theory, the strategy involves being willing to yield short completions to the offense in an effort to prevent a big gain. In reality, it seems to yield plenty of short completions -- but also its share of big gains as the offense takes advantage of the soft coverage. Hence the aphorism "the prevent defense only prevents you from winning."

India's Supreme Court said Friday afternoon that Vodafone Group was not liable for about $2.5 billion in back taxes (and interest and fees that would have brought the figure above $5 billion) related to its 2007 purchase of the Indian assets of Hong Kong's Hutchison Telecommunications International. The case has been closely watched by foreign investors and local businesses alike, who said before the decision that it could seriously impact investment in India in the future. For Vodafone, which has been expanding rapidly in emerging markets, with mixed results, the decision will free up cash which could be put towards further investment in India.

9 P.M. (13) ANNA BOLENA Anna Netrebko opened the Metropolitan Opera season with this portrayal of the final days of Anne Boleyn, the second wife of Henry VIII, in this opera by Donizetti. Ekaterina Gubanova performs the role of Anna's romantic rival, Giovanna (Jane Seymour); Ildar Abdrazakov is the cruel Enrico (Henry VIII); Stephen Costello (above with Ms. Netrebko) is Anna's first love, Lord Percy; and Tamara Mumford is the queen's devoted page Smeton. Since taking over as general manager of the Met in 2006, Peter Gelb has been angling to make Ms. Netrebko ''a house prima donna in the old-world sense: a first among equals,'' and he ''must have felt that his plan was working,'' Anthony Tommasini wrote about the September premiere of this production by David McVicar, conducted by Marco Armiliato and presented here by ''Great Performances at the Met.'' ''Ms. Netrebko sang an elegantly sad aria with lustrous warmth, aching vulnerability and floating high notes,'' Mr. Tommasini said, and she ''dispatched Donizetti's cabaletta, all fiery coloratura runs and vehement phrases, with a defiance that brought down the house.'' Yet ''Ms. Netrebko's Anna and the overall performance of the opera were not what they could have been,'' he added, calling her singing cautious, Mr. McVicar's sets uninventive and safe, and Mr. Armiliato's conducting routine. 3:30 P.M. (IFC) PAN'S LABYRINTH (2006) The Mexican-born Guillermo del Toro directed this political fable cum fairy tale, set in a dark forest in 1944 Spain, about a young girl whose fantasies are trampled by her stepfather's fascist politics. The film, in Spanish with English subtitles, received Academy Awards for cinematography, art direction and makeup, but it lost the Oscar for best foreign language film to ''The Lives of Others,'' from Germany. Ivana Baquero, right, plays the film's heroine, Ofelia, who longs to believe in fairies, princesses and magic lands; Doug Jones plays the woodland creature (a couple of them, actually) who charges her with three tasks. ''Fairy tales (and scary movies) are designed to console as well as terrify,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''What distinguishes 'Pan's Labyrinth,' what makes it art, is that it balances its own magical thinking with the knowledge that not everyone lives happily ever after.''

CROWLEY--Carola, 72, passed away on January 15, 2012 at her home in New York City. She was born in Brooklyn, NY on January 2, 1940 to the late Ambrose F. and Dorothy Dempsey Crowley. She is predeceased by brothers Donald and David Crowley and survived by her loving sister Suzanne Crowley Dowling of Garden City, NY, and eight devoted nieces and nephews and their families. She was a cum laude graduate of Vassar College's Centennial Class in 1961 and enjoyed a stellar career of 40 years Philips Norelco from which she retired in 2002. In recent years she served as Managing Member of LLC West Land Real Estate Management Firm at 635 Madison Avenue. Visitation will be at Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, 1300 Pleasantville Rd, Briarcliff Manor, NY, on Friday, January 20, 4pm-8pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 11am, Saturday, January 21 at St. Theresa's Church, Briarcliff Manor, NY. Interment private.

Bruce Springteen announced on his Web site Thursday that he would release a new album, ''Wrecking Ball,'' on March 6, and he released the lead-off single to whet the appetite of his fans. Called ''We Take Care of Our Own,'' the track is musically upbeat but alludes to the economic and political climate in the United States, with lyrics like ''Where's the promise, from sea to shining sea?'' The album will be the New Jersey rocker's 17th studio effort and features 11 new songs, the announcement said. It is the first Mr. Springsteen has recorded since the death of his friend and longtime saxophone player, Clarence Clemons, last year. Peter Pan is coming back to Broadway - though not the flying, singing Peter who audiences know well. Rick Elice's play ''Peter and the Starcatcher,'' which had a well-reviewed Off Broadway run at New York Theater Workshop last spring, will begin preview performances at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on March 28 and open on April 15, the producers of the show said on Thursday. Casting details will be announced later, though Christian Borle, who played the Captain Hook character Black Stache Off Broadway, said in a recent interview with The New York Times that he would not be reprising the role because of scheduling conflicts with his coming NBC series ''Smash.'' The show's other lead, the role of the nameless, homeless orphan boy who becomes Peter Pan, was played last spring by Adam Chanler-Berat (''Next to Normal''). He is about to depart his role as Mark in the Off Broadway revival of ''Rent.''

KABUL, Afghanistan -- American and other coalition forces here are being killed in increasing numbers by the very Afghan soldiers they fight alongside and train, in attacks motivated by deep-seated animosity between the supposedly allied forces, according to American and Afghan officers and a classified coalition report obtained by The New York Times. A decade into the war in Afghanistan, the report makes clear that these killings have become the most visible symptom of a far deeper ailment plaguing the war effort: the contempt each side holds for the other, never mind the Taliban. The ill will and mistrust run deep among civilians and militaries on both sides, raising questions about what future role the United States and its allies can expect to play in Afghanistan.

ROME - The trial of the American antiquities dealer Robert Hecht ended this week in Rome when a three-judge panel ruled that the statute of limitations on his alleged crimes - receiving artifacts illegally looted from Italy and conspiring to deal in them - had expired. The ruling draws the final curtain on a closely watched six-year-long legal drama that helped to alter collecting practices at American museums after Italian prosecutors charged Marion True, the former curator of antiquities at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, along with Mr. Hecht. Following Ms. True's indictment, many museums adopted policies that banned the purchase of ancient artifacts whose provenance was not clear.

LEVINTHAL--Elliott Elliott C. Levinthal of Palo Alto, California passed away on January 14th. He was born in Brooklyn on April 13th, 1922 and graduated from Columbia in 1942, received a M.S. from MIT in 1943 and a Ph.D from Stanford in 1949 under the direction of Felix Bloch. His dissertation, on the magnetic resonance of the hydrogen atom, was part of Bloch's Nobel Prize winning discoveries. In 1948, Levinthal, joined Varian as a founding employee and served as Research Director and Director of the company where he developed the NMR into commercial analytical and measurement instruments. In 1953 he founded Levinthal Electronics Products developing some of the first defibrillators, pacemakers, and cardiac monitors. He joined the Genetics Department of Stanford Medical School in 1961. He worked on the Mariner 9 Mars Orbiter missions and was Deputy Team leader of the Viking 1976 Lander Camera Team and made the film "Mars In 3-D". While at Stanford Medical School as both Assoicate Dean for Research and Director of the Instrumentation Research Laboratory he was involved in the use Artificial Intelligence in medicine. During a two year leave he served as Director of the Defense Sciences Office at DARPA. Later he became a Research Professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering and Director of the Stanford Institute for Manufacturing and Automation (SIMA), and then Associate Dean of Research at the School of Engineering. In addition to his academic roles, Levinthal was quite active in the creation of a number of Silicon Valley companies Levinthal was an active and generous philanthropist. At Stanford, he and his wife provided scholarships to students and were generous supporters of the humanities, including establishing the Levinthal Fellow's program in creative writing. Levinthal was also active in local and national politics. He had a great passion for travel, leading him to all seven continents. However, his greatest passion was his family. Levinthal is survived by his loving wife of 67 years, Rhoda, and four children, David (Kate), Judith (Randall), Michael, and Daniel, and seven grandchildren, Aaron, Leah, Asher, Adam, Zach, Katie, and Sam.

This year's Winter Antiques Show at the Park Avenue Armory offers the usual embarrassment of riches. Shining suits of knightly armor, mysteriously sensuous classical Indian stone sculptures, ceramics and red lacquer boxes from the Far East, sumptuous rugs, rare books and autographic documents, paintings and furniture from several centuries, jewelry, fancy early-American rifles and countless hard-to-classify oddities are displayed by 74 dealers from around the world. Many objects have fascinating stories to tell. Few are more intriguing than that of a desk built around 1870 by William Howard, a slave who worked for the pre-Civil War governor of Mississippi William McWillie on the Kirkwood Plantation in Madison County. After the war Howard stayed on the farm as a free man and produced this secretary decorated with more than 70 carved objects representing woodworking tools, drafting instruments, culinary utensils, bottles, a pistol, hands with pointing index fingers and three snakes. This marvel of homespun, autobiographical craftsmanship is at Tillou.

When you think about it, the phrase ''action movie'' is a bit redundant. Really, what else are motion pictures for? In the earliest days of cinema our ancestors were thrilled to behold images of galloping horses, hurtling trains and capering dancers. Though our entertainments are now more elaborate, our appetites are not so different. A large part of what we crave is action: running, jumping, fighting, driving, flying. Sometimes everything else -- plot, character, emotion -- can seem superfluous. This appears to be the working hypothesis behind ''Haywire,'' a cold and kinetic experiment in high-impact, low-concept genre filmmaking directed by Steven Soderbergh. Starting with a brawl in a rural roadside diner, the film, written by Lem Dobbs, proceeds through a series of expertly choreographed, meticulously edited scuffles and chases, set pieces threaded around a plot that seems almost defiantly preposterous and uninteresting.

STRAND--Fleur L. New York University physiologist Fleur L. Strand, whose research showed the impact of stress-evoked hormones on the peripheral nervous system, died of adenocarcinoma on December 23, 2011 in her home in Snowmass Village, Colorado. She was 83. Strand, who attended NYU as an undergraduate and graduate student, and served on the faculty until her retirement in 1997, was the first to show that stress-evoked hormones, such as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), could have a direct effect on the peripheral nervous system, independent of the classical role on the adrenal gland. Her novel findings were controversial, and it took a number of years for the scientific community to accept the concept of "neuropeptides"--classical endocrine peptide hormones that also act as important neuromodulators. Strand's seminal paper, "A possible direct action of ACTH on nerve and muscle," was published in the journal Neuroendocrinology in 1974. Additional work from Strand's research in lab rats indicated that offspring of women who smoke or are exposed to high levels of stress during pregnancy could have sexual problems later in life, such as reduced libido. Strand received her academic degrees from NYU, where she obtained a B.A. (1948) and M.S. (1950) in biology, and a Ph.D. in physiology (1952). She also attended the University of Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, South Africa in 1944. Strand received a National Institutes of Health fellowship to study at the Physiological Institute of the Free University in Berlin, where she first conducted her ground-breaking work on ACTH. Strand began teaching in NYU's Department of Biology in 1961. In 1980, she became the department's first female chair. She was the Carroll and Milton Petrie Professor of Biology at NYU from 1991 to 1997, and also a professor of neural science. Strand became a Fellow of the New York Academy of Sciences in 1976 and was elected Chair of the Board of Governors at the NYAS in 1987. She served as president of the board of trustees of the American Institute of Science and Technology and received numerous honors and awards throughout her career, including the American Medical Writers Award (1984) and Outstanding Woman Scientist of the Year from the New York Chapter of the Association for Women in Science (1987). The Fleur L. Strand Award, given by the American Physiological Society (APS), was established by her former graduate students in 2011 to recognize the achievements of a young physiologist, enabling the recipient to attend APS's annual Experimental Biology conference. Fleur Lillian Emanuel was born on February 24, 1928, in Bloemfontein, South Africa. She married Curt Strand, former chairman and CEO of Hilton International, in 1946. They had one daughter, Karen, who died in 2006. Fleur is survived by her husband Curt, and her brother Frank Emanuel of Cresskill, New Jersey. Donations may be made to the Fleur L. Strand Award of the American Physiological Society; The Fleur L. Strand Award, APS Business Office, 9650 Rockville Pike, Bethesda, MD 20814.

It wouldn't be an Edgar Allan Poe story without an unhappy ending. For the third year in a row an enigmatic fan who has visited the Baltimore grave of that macabre author has failed to materialize, and the custom of awaiting this visitor's arrival has come to an end. Since 2010, The Associated Press reported, Poe aficionados have been frustrated in their vigil for the Poe Toaster, a visitor who has come on the writer's birthday to Poe's final resting place at the Westminster Burial Ground; there, the Poe Toaster, dressed in black, with a white scarf and a wide-brimmed hat, would leave three roses and a half-full bottle of cognac at the grave. An uneventful stakeout on Thursday morning was the final time that devotees said they would wait before calling off the tradition.

A headline on Thursday with an article about a finding that bone density tests for osteoporosis can be delayed in women whose bones have already tested normal misstated the researchers' conclusions. As the article correctly noted, the study included only women who did not have osteoporosis at the outset, and those who developed osteoporosis did not undergo further screenings; the study did not suggest that osteoporosis patients could delay further tests.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an online protest of antipiracy bills in Congress misattributed a quotation. It was Nate Westheimer, executive director of the New York Tech Meetup -- not Anis Salvesen, a travel marketing manager -- who said: ''We've made our point. The next move is on them and if they don't respond, then we will keep at them.'' The article also misstated Ms. Salvensen's age because of information she provided. She is 33, not 34. And the article omitted a credit. Malia Wollan contributed reporting from San Francisco.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about disagreement among countries over whether to abolish the leap second omitted an element of the leap year cycle. The leap year adds a day to February in a familiar four-year cycle, as the article noted -- except in century years not divisible by 400. Thus, although 2000 was a leap year, 2100 will not be. The article also misidentified, in some editions, the point at which noon would strike at sunrise if the leap second is eliminated. That depends on the rate at which the Earth's spin slows down, which is not precisely predictable. Whatever the timing, the event would occur many thousands of years from now, but probably not ''more than 100,000 years from now.''

As the morning fog of Jan. 19, 1862, gave way to the haze of musket and cannon smoke around Logan's Crossroads, Ky., Confederate Gen. Felix Zollicoffer gingerly approached a regiment of Kentuckians. After imploring the Kentuckians not to shoot one of their own in the confusion of battle, one of the men - perhaps the unit's leader, Col. Speed S. Fry of nearby Danville - identified Zollicoffer, a Tennessean, as an enemy commander. There was a hail of lead and the white-coated Zollicoffer lay dying on the battlefield. He was the first Confederate commander to die in battle in the Western Theater, but far from the last.

My Sunday column returns to education, and the importance of teaching as a way to improve education outcomes. I think education is, in the long run, the most important challenge America faces and the one where we're in greatest difficulties. If we want to maintain economic competitiveness and chip away at poverty, we simply have to improve high school graduation rates and college attendance -- and that in turn will depend on an overhaul of the entire education system, starting with early childhood education.

Alex Ferguson, marking his 25th season as Manchester United's manager, turned 70 on Dec. 31. A former player, he began coaching in 1974 with East Stirlingshire in Scotland, which gave him £2,000 (about $3,100) to acquire five players. His 1999 United team won three titles, sweeping championships in England's Premier League, F.A. Cup and the Champions League. Fox will televise United's game against Arsenal at 11 a.m. Eastern on Sunday, the first live Premier League match on that network. In Claire Bloomfield for the British online magazine Sabotage Times, Ferguson recently reflected on how the game, and his job, had changed over the years. Read the interview here.

Just days ago, Mitt Romney appeared to be on a glide path to the Republican nomination. Coming off a big victory in New Hampshire and an apparent win in Iowa, he had just received the endorsement of Jon M. Huntsman Jr., and had as much as a 23-point lead in some national polls of Republican voters. He also led in South Carolina polls, sometimes by double digits, and attacks by Republican rivals on Mr. Romney's tenure at Bain Capital did not appear to be harming him.

PARK CITY, Utah - For the films screening here, the crew from "Your Sister's Sister" might have been the most relaxed. Not only did the film already have distribution, a rarity at this year's buyer-ready festival, but it came with a lot of good buzz from its premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival in September. That's where IFC picked up the film, a largely improvised comedy about a depressed guy (Mark Duplass), his best friend (Emily Blunt) and her sister (Rosemarie DeWitt), with plans to release it this summer. So the movie, directed by a Sundance favorite, Lynn Shelton ("Humpday"), was not in competition here. But Ms. Shelton nonetheless felt it was important to show it.

Cloud services market themselves as legitimate ways to store content online. But they are inherently ideal for anyone looking to illegitimately upload and share copyrighted video and audio files, report Nicole Perlroth and Quentin Hardy of the The New York Times. Most companies rarely, if ever, inspect individual files to see if the material they store on behalf of users violates copyrights. Read more »

Pier Luigi Foschi, the chief executive of Costa Cruise, told the German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung that the Costa Concordia did not gash her hull on underwater rocks, but hit "rocks which protruded from the sea." CHARLESTON, S.C. -- The latest survey of likely voters in Saturday's Republican primary suggests that Mitt Romney has lost the advantage he once held. In Clemson University's Palmetto Poll, 32 percent support or lean toward Newt Gingrich and 26 percent back Mr. Romney. The six-point difference between the candidates is within the poll's margin of sampling error, which is plus or minus five percentage points for each candidate.

RUSH--Alvin, 77, passed away at home in Old Westbury, NY on January 20 surrounded by his family. He was a loving, supportive husband, father, grandfather and friend. He is survived by his loving wife, Marilyn, his five children, Stephen, Larry, Richard, Gregory, Allison, their spouses, Cheryl, Susan, Jennifer and Jeanine, his 12 grandchildren, and his brother Jeffrey. He graduated from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and spent his real estate career building Rush Properties in Rockville Centre and Great Neck, NY. He was an avid art collector, traveler, and general lover of life. He was committed to many important charities supporting Jewish and health-related causes. Funeral services will be held Monday morning at the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation at 11:30am. Please direct any donations in his memory to AIPAC or United Jewish Appeal.

The Yankees avoided arbitration with outfielder Brett Gardner by agreeing to a one-year contract worth $2.8 million in Gardner's first year of arbitration eligibility. Gardner played 149 games in left field for the Yankees and hit .259 with a .345 on base percentage, almost 40 points lower than his .383 O.B.P. the year earlier. He also scored 87 runs, 10 fewer than the year before, but his 49 stolen bases were a career high and were tied for the American League lead.

KAPLAN--Dr. Saul, 79, passed away peacefully on January 19, 2012 from lung cancer. A graveside service will be held Sunday morning at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, NY. He will be missed.

An article on Friday about the increased killings of American and other coalition forces in Afghanistan by Afghan soldiers who fight alongside them and are trained by them omitted credit for a news organization that had first reported on a classified military study about this trend. The Wall Street Journal reported it on June 17, 2011. The article also referred incompletely to the military study's secrecy. While it was classified, as the article reported, it was first distributed in early May 2011 as unclassified and was later changed to classified. (The Times learned after publication that a version of the study has remained accessible on the Internet.)
GOLDBERG--Lisa Ellen Who lit the world, still lights our lives. John, Katie, and Jed

EVNIN--Fay, born Fay Dayan, April 21, 1916, in Harrogate, England, passed away peacefully in her home after sundown on January 18, 2012 (24 Tevet). She was surrounded by family and friends for several days before her passing, and her loving attendant Elizabeth was by her side. Fay, the beloved matriarch of her family, was the dear wife of the late Oscar Evnin and the late Alexander Penchassoff. She is survived by her daughter Tatiana Ruth Dayanoff, son-in-law Thomas J. Newt Gingrich's presidential candidacy is on the upswing in South Carolina, if Intrade, a popular online market for political bets, is any indication. Mr. Gingrich's chances of winning the primary jumped to 66 percent on Jan. 20, from 7 percent on Jan. 18. Mitt Romney's chances took a precipitous fall, to 34 percent on Jan. 20 from 93 percent on Jan. 18.

8 P.M. (Lifetime) DREW PETERSON: UNTOUCHABLE (2012) In this drama adapted from real events, Rob Lowe portrays Drew Peterson, a former Illinois police officer accused of killing two of his wives. Cara Buono plays his third wife, who was found dead in an empty bathtub during their bitter divorce. Kaley Cuoco, above with Mr. Lowe, plays the 17-year-old he has been sleeping with, soon to be his fourth wife, who also disappears. Mr. Peterson insists that she left him for another man and unwittingly draws the attention of the news media to his past and present, professing his innocence while announcing his engagement to a 23-year-old woman. He is currently in a detention center in Joliet, Ill., awaiting trial. 8 A.M. (IFC) VOLVER (2006) Three generations of Spanish women (led by Penélope Cruz, below, in an Oscar-nominated role, as Raimunda, a hardworking mother pulled in all directions by terrible events) cope with life's joys and travails in this movie from Pedro Almodóvar, influenced by telenovelas and Hollywood weepies. Among those Raimunda spends her time consoling are her teenage daughter (Yohana Cobo); her sister Sole (Lola Dueñas), who tries to mask her loneliness behind good cheer; her elderly aunt (Chus Lampreave); and her sorrow-filled neighbor (Blanca Portillo). Carmen Maura is her mother, who seems to have returned from the dead. ''To relate the details of the narrative -- death, cancer, betrayal, parental abandonment, more death -- would create an impression of dreariness and woe,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''But nothing could be further from the spirit of 'Volver,' which is buoyant without being flip, and consoling without ever becoming maudlin. Mr. Almodóvar acknowledges misfortune -- and takes it seriously -- from a perspective that is essentially comic. Very few filmmakers have managed to smile so convincingly in the face of misery and fatality.''

New York City Opera's orchestra ratified a three-year contract on Thursday that provides for deep cuts but also a new labor-management committee to deal with fund-raising, planning and artistic matters. An agreement had been reached earlier this week, ending a lockout and nearly a year of bitter negotiations. Tino Gagliardi, the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents the orchestra players, said in a statement that they agreed to ''deep concessions'' in hopes of raising City Opera ''from the ashes.'' The financially pressed company has moved out of its home at Lincoln Center to present a sharply reduced season in several theaters around New York. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A new play titled ''Modern Terrorism'' has been selected for the 2012 Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award, a generous theater prize that provides $50,000 to the author - in this case, Jon Kern - and an additional $100,000 toward the production costs for the play's premiere. Trustees for the foundation of the writer and director Arthur Laurents (''West Side Story,'' ''Gypsy'') and his partner of 52 years, Tom Hatcher, announced the selection of Mr. Kern on Thursday; he is a graduate of the Columbia University master's program in playwriting as well as the University of Chicago. A spokeswoman for the foundation said a few theaters have expressed interest in producing the play, which she described as ''a dark comedy about the difficulties of being a terrorist in the 21st century.'' The theater that mounts the play will receive the $100,000 grant to defray the production costs.

From Douglas Sirk to Todd Haynes and now to the stage of the 2012 Williamstown Theater Festival: that's the journey to be taken by ''Far From Heaven,'' a musical adaptation of Mr. Haynes's 2002 film of the same name, which starred Julianne Moore and Dennis Quaid. The musical will feature a book by Tony-winning playwright Richard Greenberg (''Take Me Out'') and music and lyrics by Scott Frankel and Michael Korie (''Grey Gardens''). Michael Greif (''Rent'') will direct.

A prominent art collector has sued the dealer Larry Gagosian, claiming that he sold a 1964 Roy Lichtenstein painting from her collection without her consent. The suit, filed Wednesday in state court in Manhattan, is part of a tangle of art deals that led to two earlier lawsuits against the dealer in federal court, one of which Mr. Gagosian settled for $4.4 million last year, according to court papers. In the new suit, the collector Jan Cowles, 93, claims that in 2008, her son, Charles Cowles, a New York art dealer who was in desperate financial straits, transferred a Lichtenstein painting, ''Girl in Mirror,'' to Mr. Gagosian to sell, even though Mr. Cowles did not own the painting and had no permission from his mother to sell it. The suit contends that Mr. Gagosian later fraudulently claimed that the painting was damaged and sold it to an unnamed collector for $2 million, less than its market value, taking a $1 million commission on the sale. The suit, which asks for punitive damages of $10 million, accuses Mr. Gagosian of ''such wanton dishonesty as to imply criminal indifference to civil obligations, with reckless disregard of Mrs. Cowles's rights.''

1/20/12 | Updated with elaboration on loan terms and comment from Republic Bank and Jackson Hewitt. This is the last tax season that any banks will be offering ''refund anticipation loans,'' according to the National Consumer Law Center. The loans, called R.A.L.'s in the industry, are short term, repaid with a borrower's income tax refund. Typically, the loans carried fat fees and were marketed through tax-preparation outlets to lower-income borrowers who wanted fast cash. Recent action by federal regulators means that just one bank, the Republic Bank & Trust Company of Louisville, Ky., is offering the loans this tax season. But it won't be doing so next year, under a settlement with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. (It's possible that some smaller payday lenders, which until recently haven't had much federal oversight, may still offer some version of the loans.) This year, according to the consumer law center, filers who get a $1,500 refund anticipation loan from Republic through the Jackson Hewitt tax preparation chain will pay $61.22, which translates into an annual percentage rate of 149 percent for a 10-day term.

Wall Street stocks and profits took a beating in 2011. But there is one corner of the Street that took a lighter hit: the compensation paid to chief executives. Three big banks disclosed on Friday what their top executives will receive in deferred stock for their work in 2011. Such stock is expected to make up most of their bonus as banks are increasingly paying employees more in deferred stock. Those awards to top bank executives are coming as lower-level employees are finding out that their own bonuses will be much smaller than a year ago.

The concept is similar to the online lodging service Airbnb, except you're renting parking spaces instead of a room.

Think you might want to go to the Super Bowl? To get the lowest price on the resale market, you may want to wait until the last minute. Data from the resale site StubHub.com for the past two Super Bowls indicates that prices spike just after the conference championship games, once fans know if their team has advanced. Prices then fall, precipitously, as game time nears and sellers become nervous about being stuck with unsold tickets.

A blogger and a magazine editor are the first two adventurers to complete Damien Hirst's wacky spot challenge. Before the much publicized retrospective of the British artist's spot paintings opened at all of Larry Gagosian's 11 galleries around the world -- two in London, three in New York, one each in Paris, Rome, Hong Kong, Athens, Geneva and Beverly Hills, Calif. -- on Jan. 12th, Mr. Hirst announced that anyone who visited every location before the show closes on Feb. 18 would win a Spot print personalized by the artist. So far, officials at the gallery said, 726 people had registered to take the challenge, a requirement to be a winner.

TRUEBLOOD--Paul. Passed peacefully on January 16, 2012. A native of Evansville, Indiana, educated at Memorial High School and Northwestern University, Paul spent most of his life in New York City. Paul Trueblood was an accomplished musician, composer, musical director, arranger and vocal coach. Upon arrival in New York City, Paul's talent was welcomed in a theatrical world and he worked with Mary Martin, Elaine May and Mike Nichols. He went on to lengthy collaborations with lyricist, Alan Jay Lerner, legendary director, Joshua Logan and the prolific partnership of Betty Comden and Adolph Green. He toured the world with Marianne Faithfull and appeared at Carnegie Hall with Michael Feinstein. Along the way, he has been musical director/pianist for Elaine Stritch, Dorothy Loudon, Helen Gallagher, Carol King, Matthew Broderick, Diane Keaton, Julie Wilson, Nancy Dussault, and Jose Ferrer, among many others notables. In October 1989, he appeared at the White House with Judy Kaye. He was a Master Teacher at the Cabaret Symposium of the O'Neill Theater Center and the annual Cabaret Conference at Yale University. Paul also helped young performers prepare and perform their cabaret shows. His compositions have been performed in Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center, Radio City Music Hall and cabarets everywhere. He leaves behind his sister Rosann Hoehn and her family.Funeral Service will be Tuesday, January 24, 2012. Ziemer Funeral Home, 800 S. Hebron Ave., Evansville, IN 47714. Memorial contributions may be made to Memorial High School, 1500 Lincoln Ave, Evansville, IN 47714 or St. Benedict Cathedral, 1328 Lincoln Ave., Evansville, IN 47714. Condolences may be made to the family online at www.ziemerfuneralhome.com
TYNER--Joan Martin. We will deeply miss the charm and grace of our friend, Joan Martin Tyner and extend our deepest condolences to Victoria, Christopher and Sandra. Betsy and Bill Herman

FOR spring, Victoria Beckham is introducing a half-canvas version of her signature shopper. Featuring an extra-large open interior, a rigid body and short, strict handles, this bag is the antithesis of the season's ubiquitous mini-pack and is, most likely, a lot more functional. Clean with modern finishes (light gold hardware, single-zipper pouch inside) and not a logo in sight, the canvas shopper is available with tan, orange, yellow or navy leather. Get ready to literally hold everything. Victoria Beckham Shopper, $1,850. Available in mid-February at net-a-porter.com or victoriabeckham.com. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

DANIEL ARSHAM is two parts artist, one part architect. As a founder, with Alex Mustonen, of the design firm Snarkitecture, he has made his mark in the public realm with projects like ''Goal Posts,'' which commemorates the former Miami Orange Bowl, and ''Dig,'' an exhibition and performance at the Storefront for Art and Architecture in New York. Meanwhile, his art practice is thriving with collaborations with Merce Cunningham, Hedi Slimane and Jonah Bokaer. And his first solo show at the Ohwow gallery in Los Angeles -- ''the fall, the ball, and the wall'' -- opened on Friday. The ''ball'' in the title refers to his recent and final collaboration with the Merce Cunningham group and includes one of Mr. Arsham's huge hanging Pixel Clouds. The ''wall'' alludes to Mr. Arsham's befuddling sculptures, which appear to ooze from the surface of the wall. And the ''fall'' relates to structures that seemingly defy the laws of nature. ''I'm trying to create a space where the architecture appears to be in movement,'' he explained, ''as if it is in the process of forming or deforming itself.'' JOHNNY MISHEFF

THE fashion and design worlds are looking back to the Renaissance and the Victorian era for guidance on discovering a new aesthetic for today. An example of the melding of the old and the new was seen at the opening Jan. 12 in Boston of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum's $114-million glass addition, set 50 feet away from the original and connected by a glass walkway. Anne Hawley, the museum's director, in a dress suggesting a gown in a John Singer Sargent painting, stood at the ''new'' end of the walkway, greeting the 350 guests. In the old museum, Sargent's 1888 portrait of Mrs. Gardner stood guard over her magnificent and eccentric creation.

KHATAMI--Sayyid A.,Died peacefully at home in New York City on Friday, January 13, 2012 after a brief illness. Abul Khatami was born just outside Isfahan, Iran. The estimated date is 1918 due to the lack of birth records. His first memory there was surviving a cholera epidemic from which his mother died. He moved to Isfahan with his father, a religious leader, and they shared a home with a large extended family. His open-minded father had him educated at an English school, Stuart Memorial College. He excelled at math, and graduated early in order to teach there. He subsequently graduated from the University of Tehran. Later, Abul was drafted into the Iranian army, and in the chaos that followed the British sponsored coup against the pro German Shah of Iran (Reza Shah Pahlevi) in 1941; he briefly became acting police chief of Tehran. These circumstances ultimately led to his emigration to the United States. Just after WWII Abul embarked on a journey around the world by sea, finally arriving in San Francisco in 1947, and continuing on to New York, where continued his studies in English and Asian cultures at Columbia University. He completed his Masters degree at the Asia Institute, where he met another student, Marie Hoguet. They were married in 1951 and moved to Chicago where Abul pursued doctoral studies at the University of Chicago. After his return to New York, he became a U.S. citizen, and an anthropology teacher at the American Museum of Natural History, working with Margaret Mead. Abul and Marie raised their four children in Manhattan. Abul is survived by Marie Norton of Manhattan, Jim Khatami of San Francisco, Renee Khatami of Manhattan, Jessie K. Wallen of Del Mar, California, and grandchildren Christopher Khatami, Patrick Norton, Sophie and Emme MacArthur, and John and Jim Wallen. He was buried in Easthampton, New York with his late wife. Contributions may be made in his memory to The Explorers Club, where a memorial will be held at a later date. East or West, it doesn't matter now because you are in paradise. We will miss your wisdom, poetry, laugh, and love.

The director M. Night Shyamalan - whose breakthrough film, ''The Sixth Sense,'' told the story of a boy empowered to see and talk to the dead - was finally able to commune with a living buyer for his TriBeCa penthouse after more than a year, selling it for $9.5 million, the biggest sale of the past week, according to city records. Mr. Shyamalan's 7,000-square-foot, four-bedroom apartment, at 45 Walker Street, first hit the market in the fall of 2010 with an $18.5 million price tag. After six months with little action, Mr. Shyamalan switched brokerage firms, moving to Raphael De Niro at Prudential Douglas Elliman from Brown Harris Stevens. Several price cuts later, Mr. De Niro was able to close the deal.

A 54-year-old woman sat quietly as the chiropractor worked her neck the way she had so many times before. Suddenly a pulsing, whooshing noise thundered in the woman's left ear. It reminded her of the sound of her heart when she had an echocardiogram years earlier -- but this was much, much louder. The chiropractor stopped immediately, but the noise did not. The Patient's Story

SCHOEN--Estella Jane, 40, of Brooklyn, on November 20, 2011. Born in New Orleans, Louisiana, Estella attended the Holland Hall School in Tulsa, Oklahoma, and graduated from Oberlin College, where she met the love of her life, Steve Salett. Before Estella and Steve were married in 2001, Estella received her law degree from the University of Minnesota, (Magna Cum Laude). Estella and Steve moved to New York and she began her legal career. After a clerkship for the Honorable Harold Baer, Jr. of the Southern District of New York, Estella became an Associate with Patterson, Belknap, Webb, and Tyler. A talented litigator, Estella helped lead a successful class action suit onbehalf of mentally disabled New Yorkers to help them to fully utilize the subway system. Throughout her life Estella was active in protecting the welfare and rights of women, children, and the disadvantaged, which included working in child welfare before law school and as an appellate lawyer for Children's Law Center in Brooklyn. For the last three years, Estella has been a Professor of Legal Writing at Brooklyn Law School and most recently successfully launched her own firm advising entrepreneurs. Skilled and authoritative in her legal judgments, Estella was an outstanding attorney, but the role she most valued was that of a loving wife and mother of two daughters, Amelia born in 2005, and Jessie in 2007. She is survived by parents Patricia Weymouth Schoen, John Garic ("Chick") Schoen, Jr.; brother Garic Jesse Schoen; grandparents, J. Garic Schoen and Susan D. Schoen; and husband, Steve Salett, and daughters Amelia Jane Salett and Jessie Mae Salett, to whom she devoted the enduring spirit of her life. Friends, colleagues, and loved ones will carry the memory of Estella as a young woman who radiated outward beauty, inner strength and dignity. Fierce in love - powerful in intellect - protective and principled, Estella will be remembered as a unique and irreplaceable individual. A memorial service and celebration of Estella's life will be held on January 29th at 3:30pm at Old First Reformed Church, 729 Carroll St Brooklyn, Brooklyn.

THINK of it as an oil painting -- an oil painting so big that a broom can serve as a brush. ''You use the tools you have to,'' said Gerard Higgins, 50, of Floral Park, N.Y., who paints 15 to 20 advertising wall murals every year. A household broom came in handy when he and his frequent collaborator, Brad Marshall, 56, of Rego Park, Queens, had to devise a large-scale reproduction of chalk strokes on a blackboard. Though sign painters outline images in advance, a surprising amount of their brushwork is free-form and impromptu.

For seasoned ice climbers, the many cliffside springs and waterfalls banking the south fork of the Shoshone River (above) near Cody, Wyo. -- about 50 miles east of Yellowstone National Park -- have long been popular. Now novices and anyone unfamiliar with the valley can get a toehold in the ice with new guided expeditions. For the first time, two outfitters operating in the Shoshone National Forest have received permits from the United States Forest Service to lead commercial climbs through April 1. Both Jackson Hole Mountain Guides (jhmg.com) and Southwest Adventure Guides (mtnguide.net) will take beginners and up on daylong outings to the ice falls. Private outings are $350 to $395, and $200 to $260 per person for two, including most equipment.

Five months ago, the Rev. John Foundation team from Kampala, Uganda, seemed poised to become the first team from Africa to play in the Little League World Series. But less than three weeks before a scheduled game against Canada in South Williamsport, Pa., Uganda's players were denied travel visas after irregularities were discovered in some birth certificates. The Ugandans were replaced by a team representing Saudi Arabia, which lost to the Canadians, 6-5.

The cover article on Jan. 8 about 45 places to go in 2012 contained errors in the entries for 4, 20, 34 and 37, about London, space, Ukraine and Chiloé Island, Chile. The Charles Dickens Museum in London is now open; it is not reopening in time for the author's 200th birthday, Feb. 7. Because of an editing error, both the Waldorf-Astoria hotel and Heathrow Airport were described as being east of London; they are west of the city. The location of the spaceport from which Virgin Galactic flights into space will depart is about 55 miles north of Las Cruces, N.M.; it is not in Las Cruces. Ukraine is a co-host of the Union of European Football Associations Championship, not the host. And a wind turbine project in Chiloé Island, Chile, is expected to produce three times the island's power needs; it will not triple the island's power needs.

The oldest building on the South Rim of the Grand Canyon is the national park's newest overnight accommodation. Built as a stagecoach stop in 1890, the two-room Red Horse Cabin (above) was moved nearby to the head of the canyon-descending Bright Angel Trail in 1902 by Ralph Cameron, an entrepreneur who went on to become a senator. The cabin was used as a tourist hotel and, later, a post office. It dodged demolition in 1935 and was repurposed as a guest cottage, part of the newly built Bright Angel Lodge (grandcanyonlodges.com). For the past 40 years it served as a storage facility for the resort.

WHEN it comes to health care, most liberals are committed above all to ensuring that every American has insurance. In their view, the greatest achievement of the health care reform act passed under President Obama is to finally erase the moral stain of the United States' being the only major developed country without universal coverage. But we also hold the questionable distinction of having the world's most expensive health care system -- what about cost control? For many liberals, that just sounds like a cover for heartless conservatives who care only about cutting benefits and not about helping people in need. But liberals are wrong to ignore costs. The more we spend on health care, the less we can spend on other things we value. If liberals care about middle-class salaries, public education and other state-funded services, then they need to care about controlling health care costs every bit as much as conservatives do.

The production version of the Fisker Karma plug-in hybrid visited The New York Times Wednesday evening and was offered for a brief test drive that amounted to a modest victory lap for the long-delayed performance sedan. The Karma finally reached dealers and its first customers late last year, albeit at a price roughly $20,000 higher than its initial projections. The test environment, Times Square, was less than ideal, but I spent enough time in the Karma's cockpit to note what the car didn't do: rattle, shake or, aside from some uneven panel gaps, exhibit the telltale signs of a hasty spin through the production line at the Valmet Automotive plant in Finland where Karmas are built.

Grandchildren Dr Anne-Marie Anagnostopoulos at Harvard's BIDMC and Dr. Shaw Robert Natan at Tuft's St. Elizabeth Medical Center, Dr. Peter Philip Reese at the University of Pennsylvania and Dr. Najanin Moghbeli at Pennsylvania Hospital, Dr. Anne Harriet Reese and Dr. Scott Veirs at University of Washington. Great-grandchildren Alexandra Hruby Anagnostopoulos Natan. Liam, Roya, Cora, Cyrus Reese. Siblings John, Aliki, Lila Hadjitoliou. Theodora Anagnostopoulou Papapostolou. Attended French Catholic Nuns Gymnasium in Salonica. Advanced courses in Piano, Painting, French, German, English. Accompanied husband, the first Commercial Counselor at the Royal Greek (Hellenic) Embassies in Washington, DC, London England 1957-1966 and the United Nations Conferences on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva Switzerland 1954 and 1956. She devoted herself to her son and granddaughter, especially during the illness and death of Dr. Marilyn Ann Hruby in 1980. She also served with great pleasure as a mother, grandmother and great-grandmother to Madelaine and her own children and grandchildren as listed above. She enjoyed the house in Spetses Island, her New York apartment and particularly her penthouse garden in Athens. "Manoula", you will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held in Athens on February 12, 2012. In lieu of flowers please donate to a charity of your choice.

Six of the world's largest hotel companies have collaborated to create a Web site that allows travelers to search listings and then book rooms directly on hotel sites, effectively cutting out middlemen like Expedia. The site, Roomkey.com, is owned by Choice Hotels International; Hilton Worldwide; Hyatt Hotels Corporation; InterContinentalHotels Group; Marriott International; and Wyndham Hotel Group, part of the Wyndham Worldwide Corporation. The companies own more than 50 hotel brands. The site will also include results from other hotels as well. Best Western International was the first commercial partner to sign up since the site's introduction last week.

MELBOURNE, Australia -- Though he is nearly 10 years removed from his last Grand Slam title, Lleyton Hewitt pushed his way back into the business end of a major tournament, reaching the second week of the 2012 Australian Open with a surprising four-set win over the Canadian Milos Raonic. Hewitt beat Raonic, the No. 23 seed and popular dark-horse pick, by the score of 4-6, 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-3 in three hours and six minutes, falling to the ground after match point as the roaring crowd jumped to its feet.
