The movies often keep fashion designers in duds, as we saw at Miuccia Prada's fall men's show in Milan and a few days later at Rick Owens in Paris. But these designers approach the imagery very differently. Ms. Prada cast a bespoke formality over her suits and fur-collared coats, and to complete the total illusion of individuality (and royalty), she put some leading character actors in her show: Willem Dafoe, Gary Oldman, Tim Roth. But before her audience got to see those great mugs, she included models with mustaches and more bulk than the usual runway tadpoles. Afterward she told journalists that the show was a parody of male power.

They could hire 3,000 people overnight. What U.S. plant can find 3,000 people overnight and convince them to live in dorms? JENNIFER RIGONI, Apple's worldwide supply demand manager until 2010, on the advantages of using foreign plants. [20]

ANYONE lamenting the dearth of Surrealist literary salons in New York has only to stop by the Oracle Club, a new members-only work space for artists and writers in Long Island City, Queens. Open since early December, the salon is the result of Jenna Gribbon and Julian Tepper -- a couple who live above the space and a painter and novelist, respectively -- having asked themselves, one morning in October, ''What would be the most amazing scenario we could imagine for ourselves?'' The three-room space includes a library, a living room and an art studio, all decorated by Ms. Gribbon and Mr. Tepper. ''It's Salvador Dalí's house meets Whistler's Peacock Room meets Coco Chanel's house meets Cocteau's Chapel,'' Ms. Gribbon said. For monthly fees ranging from $50 to $175, members get a key; access to the space from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m., seven days a week; and a standing invitation to any readings or events at the club. The interior is still evolving. ''I'm looking for the perfect small kaleidoscope to put in the bathroom wall as a fake peephole, so you think you're going to peep into the bathroom, but it turns out to be a kaleidoscope,'' Ms. Gribbon said. ''Everything in time,'' Mr. Tepper added. The Oracle Club, 10-41 47th Avenue; theoracleclub.com. ABBY AGUIRRE

CRAWFORD--John Charlton, composer, pianist, professor, beloved father and husband, died on January 5, 2012, at age 80 in his 23rd year of Parkinson's disease in Cambridge, MA. Born the son of academic parents in 1931 in Philadelphia, he was gifted in music and languages. He graduated from Germantown Friends School and the Yale School of Music, and received his Ph.D. from Harvard. He studied composition with Nadia Boulanger in Paris on a Fulbright Fellowship, and further with Paul Hindemith, Quincy Porter, Walter Piston, and Randall Thompson. Harvard awarded him its Boott Prize in choral composition, and its Paine Traveling Fellowship for the study of Arnold Schoenberg's vocal expressionism in Vienna. He and his wife, Dorothy Lamb Crawford, subsequently wrote the first book in English on Expressionism in Twentieth-Century Music (Indiana Univ. Press, 1993), and became performing partners in recitals of a wide range of twentieth-century music for soprano and piano. He taught at Amherst and Wellesley Colleges, and at the University of California, Riverside. His choral compositions were widely performed by such groups as the New England Conservatory Chorus, the Amherst, Harvard, and University of Virginia Glee Clubs, Chorus Pro Musica (Boston), Incarnation Concerts (New York), the Madrigal Singers of both UCLA and the University of Illinois, the St. Louis Chamber Chorus, and the Swarthmore College Choir. His instrumental music has been played by the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, the Sequoia and Brandeis String Quartets, and the Hartt Chamber Players, among many other groups. His one-act farcical opera, Don Cristobal and Rosita, on a text by Federico Garcia Lorca, was considered "keenly atmospheric" in the Boston Globe review of its premiere at Wellesley College in 1970. Another critic, in the Wellesley Alumnae Magazine, mentioned Crawford's "fine ear for words and a genuine lyrical gift, already apparent to those who know his oratorio [based on T.S. Eliot's] Ash Wednesday, or his many songs...a lively sense of humor, and...a keen instinct for dramatic pacing." This opera gained performances in Los Angeles and Riverside; his Oratorio was performed at Wellesley College by the Wellesley College Choir and Harvard Glee Club; his Viola Concerto was presented by the Cleveland Chamber Orchestra and the New England Philharmonic; and his Magnificat has been performed countless times. Following his retirement from UC Riverside, where he was chairman of the music department and director of the university's Festival of Contemporary Music, John Crawford returned to Cambridge MA, where he enjoyed participating in the area's rich concert life. He was a member of the Harvard Musical Association, served on the Board of the Lili Boulanger Memorial Fund, and heard his Viola Concerto conducted in its premiere by conductor Richard Pittman with the New England Philharmonic and Bayla Keyes as soloist. He is survived by his son, Peter R., daughter-in-law Glorietta, daughter, Susan P., his granddaughter, Venise, and his wife of fifty-seven years, Dorothy, for whom he composed the opera Don Cristobal and Rosita (1970), Two Shakespeare Sonnets (1969) for soprano and piano, and Calvaries of Love (1980), a dramatic song cycle for soprano, clarinet, cello, and piano on texts and letters of Emily Dickinson. There will be a musical memorial for Dr. Crawford later in 2012.

KAVALER--Arthur R, 91, died at home on January 18. Beloved husband of Lucy for 62 years, father of Roger and Andrea. Journalist and editor for 50 years, President of Schnell Publishing Co and Publisher & Editor-in-Chief of Chemical Marketing Reporter, 1972-1990. Climbed Mayan pyramids, collected archaeological artifacts and played tennis until age 70. Services: Sunday, January 22, 11:30am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, New York.

7:30 P.M. (13) PHIL OCHS: THERE BUT FOR FORTUNE Inspired by Woody Guthrie, Elvis Presley and even John Wayne, Ochs, above, one of the most politically active singer-songwriters of his generation, created folk-protest songs emblematic of the 1960s, among them ''I Ain't Marching Anymore,'' ''Power and the Glory'' and ''The War Is Over.'' Unyielding in principle and unbending in artistic vision, he spiraled into depression after the assassinations of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy in 1968 and committed suicide in 1976 at 35. ''American Masters'' begins a 26th season with this documentary from Kenneth Bowser, who chronicles Ochs's life through interviews with Joan Baez, Tom Hayden, Sean Penn and Pete Seeger. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley interviews the Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum in the wake of the South Carolina primary. THE leafy, winding streets of the upscale Gaziosmanpasa district in the Turkish capital of Ankara have long provided respite from the crowded boulevards of the city center. Home to many of the city's consulates and embassies, the neighborhood has gone from a staid diplomatic hub to Ankara's choicest destination for an evening out, thanks to a dozen new restaurants and cafes that have opened over the past few years. While a proliferation of seafood restaurants suggests an ''anything Istanbul can do, we can do better'' chip on the shoulder of this landlocked city, the new options also reflect Ankara's increasing financial and political importance. ANNA LOUIE SUSSMAN

THE BIG PROFILE: JOHN MULANEY By Dave Itzkoff

''Not for Vampires Only'' (Jan. 15), about New Yorkers who buy or rent apartments for their darkness and quiet, prompted comments -- not all of them from readers who embrace the dark. We moved from Washington Square, where every concert in the park took place in our apartment. (Guests would say, ''Can you turn down the music?''; we would say, ''It's coming from outside.'') Now we live happily in the back of a tall Midtown building, facing north, looking out over the backyards of town houses (there's a skyline view if you stand close to the window, with the tip of the Chrysler Building visible). We painted the walls golden yellow, so it's always sunny. Outside, the corner of 34th and Park is blaringly noisy all day and night. Inside, it's our fourth-floor cabin in the woods.

FREHSE--Robert M. Robert M. Frehse, Jr.,who was executive director of the Hearst Foundations for nearly three decades, died January 20, in New York. He was 86. Frehse was a consultant to the Hearst Foundations since he retired in June 2007, after serving as executive director since 1979. The Hearst Foundations are composed of the William Randolph Hearst Foundation and The Hearst Foundation, Inc. Both Foundations are independent private philanthropies operating separately from Hearst Corporation. They were established in the mid-1940s by William Randolph Hearst and are guided by the same charitable mission, which reflects his philanthropic interests: education, health, social services and culture. In a joint statement, George R. Hearst, Jr., and William R. Hearst III, presidents respectively of The Hearst Foundation and William Randolph Hearst Foundation, said: "For 37 years Bob Frehse devoted his working life to the Hearst Foundations. We are grateful for his service, the many relationships he has nurtured and for the high standards of philanthropic management that he put in place. They will serve the organizations for years to come." "As the leader of the Hearst Foundations for nearly three decades, Bob was responsible for enabling important, high-quality programs and services for some of the country's most deserving organizations," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation and chairman of the Foundations' Gift Committee. "He touched so many people's lives. Our thoughts go out to his family." Frehse first joined the Hearst Foundations in 1975 as director of administration and assistant treasurer, and in 1978 was promoted to vice president and managing director. He was named executive director four years later. Prior to Frehse's tenure at the Foundations, he spent more than 20 years with Citicorp, principally with Citibank's overseas divisions, where he spent 15 years in Latin America and the Caribbean, two years in Hong Kong and the balance in the head office in New York. In his final position with Citicorp, Frehse was manager of marketing coordination for the Asia Pacific and the Western Hemisphere of the Citicorp Subsidiary Group. He was a founding board member of both Grantmakers in Health and the National Foundation Financial Officers Group. Frehse also served as chairman of the board of the Better Business Bureau Foundation in Washington, D.C., and received the Dean's Medal from Tulane University's School of Public Health & Tropical Medicine. Born August 22, 1925, Frehse grew up in Detroit. He was a graduate of Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill., and the American Graduate School of International Management in Phoenix. In World War II, Frehse was a Lieutenant JG in the United States Navy. He is survived by his wife Dale; sons, Robert M. Frehse, III, John W. Frehse, Sr., and William Ladd Frehse; daughters-in-law, Susan Satterfield and Jessica Santostefano; grandson John W. Frehse, Jr.; sister Rosemary Geist; and many nieces and nephews. The funeral service will be held on Saturday, January 28, at 11am, at The Reformed Church of Bronxville, 180 Pondfield Rd., Bronxville, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Camp Westminster, a Christian camp founded by Frehse's father in 1925 (17567 Hubbell Ave., Detroit, MI, 48235, 313-341-8969). Checks can be made to "Camp Westminster" with "The Frehse Fund" in the memo section.

United States defender Ali Krieger tore ligaments in her right knee in the Americans' 14-0 win over the Dominican Republic on Friday night, an injury that will most likely keep her from playing in this summer's London Olympics if the Americans qualify. U.S. Soccer announced the injury Saturday in Vancouver, where the United States is playing in the Concacaf Olympic qualifying tournament.

When LeBron James left the Cavaliers, the devastation was supposed to be complete. But in the second season after his departure, they are doing something that few expected: winning. At the end of last season, things seemed especially bleak in Cleveland. Not only was James gone, but the team had traded for the aging point guard Baron Davis, whose contract had more than $30 million guaranteed. Cleveland finished the season at 19-63, with 42 fewer wins than the season before.

Giants at 49ers 6:30 p.m. Line: 49ers by 2.5 Quarterbacks selected first in the N.F.L. draft often lead their teams to the Super Bowl. Eventually. The path is rarely straight and is often unpredictable. Eli Manning's journey started with a draft-day trade, but it then became rather direct: a few solid seasons, then one magical year of upsets and comebacks in 2007. Manning has since borne the ceaseless criticism of those who believe that for a quarterback to achieve adequacy (let alone greatness), every pass must be a 30-yard laser to a receiver's back shoulder, in the corner of the end zone, in the fourth quarter, against the 1985 Chicago Bears. Manning shrugged off the criticism and maintained a level of near-excellence, and he has returned to the brink of the Super Bowl. Skeptics are grudgingly acknowledging his merits, though a stomach bug has Manning too busy nibbling crackers and sipping ginger ale to enjoy the accolades.

The Mets will be honored on the franchise's 50th anniversary at the Baseball Assistance Team's annual fund-raising dinner Tuesday in Manhattan. B.A.T. helps former players and baseball employees who have fallen on hard times. The Hall of Famer Tom Seaver will be among the many former Mets and other players at the dinner. Seaver, 67, holds the team's career records for pitching victories (198) and strikeouts (2,541). He and his wife, Nancy, own Seaver Vineyards on Diamond Mountain in Calistoga, Calif. In a recent phone conversation, he spoke about wine, baseball and the Mets.
Theater Steven McElroy

SCHENCK--Andrea Rosemary Murphy Moar, Died by accidental drowning on January 13, 2012 at the age of 55 years in Cancun while on vacation with her husband. Professional actor (stage name Andrea Moar) on television (ABC-TV "All My Children," where she played the role of Carrie that consistently generated high "Q ratings"; the series "Rituals"; guest appearance on the "Molten Steele" episode of the "Remington Steele" series). She played the role of "fast blond in the sporty barbeque grill" in the award winning (for comedy) commercial for Kraft Kansas City Barbeque Sauce; appeared in an American Express commercial, and played roles in nearly 60 plays. Andrea was a unique, enthusiastic, passionate, caring person and devoted, loyal friend with a generous spirit and a vibrant, engaging personality. She had a zest for life and loved animals. She kept reminding people that "life is not a dress rehearsal!" She was an avid tennis player who won the New Jersey High School state individual championship. She was a gifted amateur photographer and was keenly interested in jewelry and gemology. She coauthored a novel with her brother, "The Griffon Trilogy: Part I" that was released in July 2001 (Pub-Booklocker). Born in Dayton, Ohio, she was raised in Princeton, New Jersey, and graduated from Princeton High School and Davidson College in North Carolina. Married in 2005 to Carlos H. Schenck, MD of the Minnesota Regional Sleep Disorders Center and Prof. of Psychiatry at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. Andrea, daughter of the late Paul Daniel Murphy, Jr, MD, a psychiatrist, is survived by her husband Carlos, her mother Dimitria Sarhanis Murphy, former ballet dancer of the Metropolitan Opera in New York City; her sister Sheila Murphy Moar and husband James Moar, residing in St. Paul, MN, and their children Amanda and Zachary; her brother Douglas Paul Murphy, MD, (Associate Professor of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at Virginia Commonwealth University), residing in Ivy, VA and wife Elaine, and children Kali and Max. Andrea was a direct descendant of Captain James Lawrence, who coined the famous naval battle cry during the War of 1812, "Don't give up the ship!" Andrea will be dearly missed by many people around the country and the world. Memorial donations can be directed to the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis (Memo line: "Actor Training Program" with Andrea's name).

SIENKIEWICZ--John Casimir, Age 78, passed away unexpectedly at his home in Loblolly, Hobe Sound, FL on January 3, 2012. Born in Center Bridge, PA on October 8, 1933, and raised in Doyles- town, PA, John was the son of Casimir A. Sienkiewicz, a prominent Philadelphia banker and Chairman of the Central Penn National Bank and Jane Patton Sienkiewicz, a nurse. John attended The Loomis School (Loomis-Chaffee) prior to graduating from Princeton University in 1955 where he served as President of his class and remained a valued advisor throughout his life. Playing varsity football his senior year, John won the award for Most Improved Player. John served in the United States Navy from 1955 to 1957 aboard the USS Hancock rising to the rank of Lieutenant. In 1958, he joined Hutchinson, Rivinus & Co. of Philadelphia as an insurance salesman. In 1965, John became a Partner of the firm which was later acquired by Alexander and Alexander International. In time, John became President and Chief Executive Officer of International Operations of Alexander and Alexander, which was known as the largest international insurance brokerage firm in the world. After their acquisition by Aon Risk Services, John remained an active Vice Chairman. John lived most of his life in Princeton, NJ with his wife of 50 years, Patricia Davis Sienkiewicz. John was a loving, strong, and supportive husband, father and friend. His passions included golf, philanthropy, and travel. John was a member of Pine Valley Golf Club, Seminole Golf Club, and many others. He was an active member of the United States Seniors Golf Association. John was widely philanthropic, giving generously to many organizations. Most notable, was the University Cottage Club at Princeton where he served as Chairman of the Board for ten years. John was predeceased by his wife Patricia and his brother Bur Sienkiewicz. He is survived by his sons Mark and Peter, his second wife Maisie Barlow Sienkiewicz, his brother Michael Sienkiewicz and wife Marika, his sister-in-law Jone Sienkiewicz and many more family members and friends who loved him dearly. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his honor for student aid to: Casimir A. Sienkiewicz Scholarship, American International College, 1000 State Street - Box 10-L, Springfield, MA 01109. A Celebration of Life Service is being planned for June 2012 in Princeton, NJ.

THE metallic cap toe, one of the more noteworthy accessories trends to surface during the men's shows in Europe, was first spotted on both a lace-up oxford and a boot at Grenson, a design leader in the very traditional world of British shoemaking. Next up, a new collection by Patrick Cox for Geox, which featured a boot as well as a double monk-strap dress shoe with an athletic sole and a bright, shiny capped toe. Very Mr. Roboto. Finally, Claire Malcolm, the Hardy Amies designer, chose oxfords with nickel toes by Mr. Hare, a relative newcomer on the old English shoe scene, to show with the clothes. The elaborate cutouts were a heavy-metal tribute to the Deco aesthetic of the Busby Berkeley film ''Gold Diggers of 1933.'' Though all these shoes get some positive reinforcement from their shiny caps, they're far from construction-site steel toes. Watch your step. BRUCE PASK

An opinion essay on Jan. 15 about the prevalence of anxiety disorders erroneously attributed a distinction to the anti-anxiety drug alprazolam, or Xanax. It was the only psychiatric medication among the top 15 -- not the top 25 -- prescription drugs in the United States in 2010. A subheading accompanying the article also referred incorrectly to Xanax prescriptions. The medication was prescribed 46.3 million times in the United States in 2010, as the article correctly noted -- not to 46 million people.

COOPER--Frank, husband, father, talent agent, and one of Hollywood's living legends, four months short of his 100th birthday, May 21, 1912, passed peacefully on January19, 2012 at his home in Encino, CA. He had been married to one woman, his adored Sylvia, a professional sculptor and former vice-president of the Jewish Federation, for nearly 75 exciting years. He is survived by Sylvia and their three children: Jeff (with wife Dee Jay); neurosurgeon Martin (with wife Shelley); and New York theatrical talent manager and broadway producer, Pamela; six grandchildren; three great-grandchildren; many friends; and dozens of clients who remember Frank as a man who became their agent and, over time, their trusted friend, ally, and advisor. He will be missed and remembered by all who are the better for having been part of his world.

The swagger, the anti-intellectualism, the boots, the bullying -- the only good news is that they didn't work for Mr. Perry as well as they did for his predecessor as governor turned presidential candidate.

RUSH--Alvin, 77, passed away at home in Old Westbury, NY on January 20 surrounded by his family. He was a loving, supportive husband, father, grandfather and friend. He is survived by his loving wife, Marilyn, his five children, Stephen, Larry, Richard, Gregory, Allison, their spouses, Cheryl, Susan, Jennifer and Jeanine, his 12 grandchildren, and his brother Jeffrey. He graduated from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and spent his real estate career building Rush Properties in Rockville Centre and Great Neck, NY. He was an avid art collector, traveler, and general lover of life. He was committed to many important charities supporting Jewish and health-related causes. Funeral services will be held Monday morning at the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation at 11:30am. Please direct any donations in his memory to AIPAC or United Jewish Appeal.

In late December 1861 Abraham Lincoln issued a directive that, had it been vigorously pursued, might have brought the Civil War to a rapid end: An order, via Gen. James Ripley, the Army's ordnance chief, for 10,000 Spencer repeating rifles. Because Ripley resisted the order for months and did nothing to help put the rifles into volume production, initial deliveries didn't start until about a year and a half after Lincoln first tested the rifle. Consequently, Union soldiers had to fight with less efficient weapons, handicapping them and greatly lengthening the bloody conflict.

Pressed Juicery in Los Angeles began as a labor of love. When the co-founder Carly Brien's mother got ill, she and her friends Hayden Slater and Hedi Gores decided to change career paths (from public relations, production and full-time motherhood, respectively) and create something healthful and positive. At the time, Los Angeles was lacking a juicery that used a hydraulic press, a machine that squelches an entire fruit or vegetable into a pulp, extracting three to four times more than an average juicer. After yoga class one day, Slater found the perfect spot for one: a 22-square-foot broom closet adjacent to the Brentwood Country Mart. Today, Pressed is a thriving business - a second location (in a truck) opened in Malibu last summer, and at the end of last year Slater and friends brought a storefront to West Hollywood. The juicery also takes orders online and delivers nationwide to loyals who can't live without its Greens 2 (a blend of kale, spinach, romaine, parsley, cucumber, celery, apple and lemon), Detox 2 (pineapple, green apple and mint) and Almond Milk (almonds, dates, vanilla bean, sea salt and filtered water).

In 1807, a New Jersey schoolgirl named Mary Antrim embroidered a farm scene with silk thread on linen. On Sunday, Sotheby's in New York sold her view of livestock, picket fences and clapboarded outbuildings for $1.07 million (the top estimate had been $120,000), setting an auction record for a needlework sampler. The sale contained 198 lots from the collection of the needlework historian Betty Ring. Of all the colorful pastoral views at the Sotheby's showroom, Mary Antrim's piece "stood out in a unique way as a folk art statement," said the dealer David Schorsch, who bought it for an undisclosed client. The auction's other top prices were in the low six figures and shared by the specialist dealers Stephen and Carol Huber and Amy Finkel. A quarter of the Ring material did not sell, especially images of veiled mourners and gravestones sewn in memory of deceased relatives. The buzz in the field this week, Mr. Huber said, is that "the memorials all died."

Perhaps the most astounding thing about Etta James's voice was how it traveled so freely in so many different musical circles, and that was again the most evident aspect of the tributes given to her over the weekend. On Saturday morning, she was featured on a rhythm-and-blues radio program; later that day, on a rock 'n' roll show. On Sunday morning, jazz radio was claiming her as one of their own, and she was even plastered all over the touch screen of the treadmill at my gym. And that seemed the most appropriate format, because no matter what James sang - R&B, rock, blues, jazz, pop - her voice was one that got your blood pumping.

The rap group 2 Live Crew, which set off a fierce debate over freedom of speech with its graphic sexual lyrics in the 1980s and early 1990s, plans to reunite and begin touring, The Associated Press reported. For months now, even as the rest of the conservative commentariat has gradually resigned itself to the existing presidential field, the Weekly Standard's Bill Kristol has continued to pine - publicly, unstintingly, immune to either embarrassment or fatigue- for another candidate to jump into the race. He's dreamed of Mitch Daniels, touted Chris Christie, talked up Paul Ryan and Marco Rubio, name-dropped Jeb Bush, and circled back to Daniels once more. He's quoted poetry on behalf of his cause - Yeats, and (with some revisions) Andrew Marvell. He's endured snark from the Huffington Post, eye-rolling from Slate, mockery from New York Magazine. But he's continued undeterred -- and in the wake of Newt Gingrich's South Carolina victory, he was back at it again, throwing out a link to "a new online petition was launched Saturday night ... at runmitchrun.com."

With Oscar nominations about to be unveiled tomorrow, now is a good time to look at what can seem like the annual dissension over the choices that wind up on the best documentary feature shortlist. Glaring omissions like "Hoop Dreams," "Crumb" and "The Thin Blue Line" have been routine in the past, and this year the absence of "The Interrupters" (from the director of "Hoop Dreams") and "Senna" also set tongues wagging. The Bagger's colleague John Anderson looks at the race over the years and notes that "the Academy tends to favor inspiring stories about struggle and triumph." He adds that that is unlikely to change much, even taking into account the recent rules changes instituted by the documentary branch of the Academy. "Tougher films, complex documentaries about challenging subjects, will be at a disadvantage against films that make voters feel good, or at least ennobled, when they vote for them." Read more »

Five smart, greedy and mean pirates find themselves on a boat with 100 gold coins. The pirates are ranked according to seniority, from 1 to 5, the most senior being ranked 1. Here is the deal: the most senior pirate must make a proposal for splitting the coins among the pirates, including herself (no fractional coins!). If her proposal has at least 50 percent acceptance (she votes, too), she is fine; otherwise, the other four pirates throw her into the shark-infested sea. The remaining pirates play the same game, starting with a proposal from the next most senior pirate, that is, the pirate ranked 2.

The New England Patriots are back in the Super Bowl, despite the best efforts of their opponents and the preferences of millions of fans who are weary of their mix of arrogant excellence and excellent arrogance. The Jets tried to beat them with rhetoric, the Denver Broncos with an Elvis-strength cultural juggernaut, the Baltimore Ravens with everything but a healthy kicker. But nothing could stop Bill Belichick and Tom Brady from returning to the Super Bowl for the fifth time in 11 seasons. Judging by the chip-shot field goal the Ravens missed at the end of the Patriots' 23-20 A.F.C. championship game victory, New England is again augmenting its considerable skill with some timely doses of good luck, the way it did in its rise to dominance a decade ago.

FREHSE--Robert M. Robert M. Frehse, Jr.,who was executive director of the Hearst Foundations for nearly three decades, died January 20, in New York. He was 86. Frehse was a consultant to the Hearst Foundations since he retired in June 2007, after serving as executive director since 1979. The Hearst Foundations are composed of the William Randolph Hearst Foundation and The Hearst Foundation, Inc. Both Foundations are independent private philanthropies operating separately from Hearst Corporation. They were established in the mid-1940s by William Randolph Hearst and are guided by the same charitable mission, which reflects his philanthropic interests: education, health, social services and culture. In a joint statement, George R. Hearst, Jr., and William R. Hearst III, presidents respectively of The Hearst Foundation and William Randolph Hearst Foundation, said: "For 37 years Bob Frehse devoted his working life to the Hearst Foundations. We are grateful for his service, the many relationships he has nurtured and for the high standards of philanthropic management that he put in place. They will serve the organizations for years to come." "As the leader of the Hearst Foundations for nearly three decades, Bob was responsible for enabling important, high-quality programs and services for some of the country's most deserving organizations," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., CEO of Hearst Corporation and chairman of the Foundations' Gift Committee. "He touched so many people's lives. Our thoughts go out to his family." Frehse first joined the Hearst Foundations in 1975 as director of administration and assistant treasurer, and in 1978 was promoted to vice president and managing director. He was named executive director four years later. Prior to Frehse's tenure at the Foundations, he spent more than 20 years with Citicorp, principally with Citibank's overseas divisions, where he spent 15 years in Latin America and the Caribbean, two years in Hong Kong and the balance in the head office in New York. In his final position with Citicorp, Frehse was manager of marketing coordination for the Asia Pacific and the Western Hemisphere of the Citicorp Subsidiary Group. He was a founding board member of both Grantmakers in Health and the National Foundation Financial Officers Group. Frehse also served as chairman of the board of the Better Business Bureau Foundation in Washington, D.C., and received the Dean's Medal from Tulane University's School of Public Health & Tropical Medicine. Born August 22, 1925, Frehse grew up in Detroit. He was a graduate of Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill., and the American Graduate School of International Management in Phoenix. In World War II, Frehse was a Lieutenant JG in the United States Navy. He is survived by his wife Dale; sons, Robert M. Frehse, III, John W. Frehse, Sr., and William Ladd Frehse; daughters-in-law, Susan Satterfield and Jessica Santostefano; grandson John W. Frehse, Jr.; sister Rosemary Geist; and many nieces and nephews. The funeral service will be held on Saturday, January 28, at 11am, at The Reformed Church of Bronxville, 180 Pondfield Rd., Bronxville, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Camp Westminster, a Christian camp founded by Frehse's father in 1925 (17567 Hubbell Ave., Detroit, MI, 48235, 313-341-8969). Checks can be made to "Camp Westminster" with "The Frehse Fund" in the memo section.

The New England Patriots are back in the Super Bowl, despite the best efforts of their opponents and the preferences of millions of fans who are weary of their mix of arrogant excellence and excellent arrogance. The Jets tried to beat them with rhetoric, the Denver Broncos with an Elvis-strength cultural juggernaut, the Baltimore Ravens with everything but a healthy kicker. But nothing could stop Bill Belichick and Tom Brady from returning to the Super Bowl for the fifth time in 11 seasons. Judging by the chip-shot field goal the Ravens missed at the end of the Patriots' 23-20 A.F.C. championship game victory, New England is again augmenting its considerable skill with some timely doses of good luck, the way it did in its rise to dominance a decade ago. The Giants have the power to halt the Patriots in their tracks. But at what cost? The Giants upset them four years ago in Super Bowl XLII and beat them in Week 9, 24-20, but those story lines have already been ground into an unpalatable paste. (Remember, the Green Bay Packers stood in as surrogate Patriots just two games ago, giving us an early round of flashbacks to 2008.) If the Giants can endure two weeks of talk about destiny, miraculous helmet catches and David versus Goliath Redux - if any of us can endure them - they can once again become that rarest of rare breeds: lovable, victorious underdogs from New York.

RANDALL--Dr. James, 94, retired psychoanalyst, passed away at home in Philadelphia on January 18, 2012. Born in London in 1917, Jimmy was predeceased by his sister and six brothers. He proudly served in the British army during WWII in the 4th Queen's Own Hussars RAC; and as a Chindit in Burma and India with the 45th Reconnaissance Regiment. Released from H.M. Forces with the rank of Captain in 1947, he went to Israel in 1948, volunteering in the Israeli army in support of the War of Independence. Returning to London, he resumed his medical studies at St. Bart's Hospital, specializing in tropical diseases. He was a physician at the Hospital for Tropical Diseases, London; and spent a year as ship's surgeon on the "City of Exeter" traveling between England and South Africa. In 1956 he met and married Aileene Hall (nee Fearnley) and together they emigrated to America, settling in New York City, where they lived until 2009. An intern at St. Luke's Hospital and working at Bellevue Hospital and various small clinics throughout the city, Jimmy soon made the decision to resume his studies once again, changing specialty from Tropical Medicine to Psychoanalysis. He was active in private practice until 2003 and was a past president of The American Society of Psychoanalytic Physicians, as well as a devoted member of The Royal Society of Medicine. Jimmy is survived by his wife of 55 years, Aileene, his children Angela, Suzanne, Denise and Alan and their respective families, and numerous nieces and nephews. He was a gentleman, a doctor, and a warrior to the end. He will be sorely missed.

12:30 P.M. (TMC) CAIRO TIME (2010) In this film by Ruba Nadda, Patricia Clarkson plays Juliette, a magazine writer on her first trip to Egypt, and Alexander Siddig (above, with Ms. Clarkson) is Tareq, a local resident who shows her the views she has promised to save for her husband, a United Nations official delayed in Gaza. ''What gives this delicate, decorous movie its distinctive throb of melancholy sensuality is less the humdrum possibility of adultery than the intimation of a three-way entanglement involving the man, the woman and Cairo,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''The film itself is perhaps a bit too cautious, preferring diffidence and indirection to overt emotion,'' he added. Still, ''the time does pass agreeably enough, and if 'Cairo Time' does not amount to much, it does evoke a wistful state of feeling and a complicated city with enough skill and sensitivity that you wish it had dared more.'' 7:30 A.M. (Fox Movie Channel) SONS AND LOVERS (1960) Jack Cardiff directed this adaptation of the D. H. Lawrence novel about the joy, sorrow and frustration that grow out of a strong bond between a mother (Wendy Hiller) and son (Dean Stockwell) in a northern England coal town, not unlike the one where Lawrence grew up. ''Oddly enough, the powerful passions that race and foam through the original tale, which shocked and dismayed a lot of people when it was published in 1913, do not surge up in the picture,'' Bosley Crowther wrote in The Times. ''The strong possessiveness of a mother's love for a son, transferred to him from his father, comes through as a hot, but essentially lavalike, strain of attentiveness and jealous affection untouched by the thrust of Dr. Freud.'' The film received seven Oscar nominations, including best director for Mr. Cardiff and best actor for Trevor Howard as the discarded father, a miner who wed above his social class. Freddie Francis won for best cinematography, which Mr. Crowther called ''picture poetry.''

This is why Hollywood keeps churning out sequels: The fourth movie in Sony's ''Underworld'' vampire series, ''Underworld Awakening,'' was an easy No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend, taking in about $25.4 million despite winter storms that kept business light in parts of the United States. Solid ticket sales for ''Underworld Awakening'' were fueled by turnout for higher-priced Imax screens. Even so, this 3-D movie will need to perform well overseas to justify its cost of about $70 million, sharply higher than the budget for ''Underworld: Rise of the Lycans'' in 2009. ''Red Tails,'' a period action drama inspired by the Tuskegee airmen, finished a surprisingly strong second, with an estimated $19.1 million in ticket revenue, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. The movie was also expensive: George Lucas spent $58 million to make ''Red Tails'' and spent another $35 million to market it, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

MOGADISHU, Somalia -- A senior foreign commander fighting with Shabab Islamic militants was killed in an American drone strike a few miles south of the capital over the weekend, according to Shabab officials. The Shabab officials held a news conference to publicize the attack, identifying the commander as Bilal al-Barjawi, 27, a close associate of a Qaeda leader killed last year in Somalia. They said he was of Lebanese descent and had grown up in West London. British authorities denied that he was a British citizen.

Wall Street's legal challenge to a regulatory crackdown met a procedural obstacle last week, when a federal appeals court dismissed the case. The lawsuit, directed at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's new restrictions on speculative trading, will now move to a lower-level court, delaying a decision on the legitimacy of the regulatory overhaul.

A film review on Dec. 16 about ''Corman's World: Exploits of a Hollywood Rebel,'' a documentary about Roger Corman, using information from the film, misstated the number of movies Mr. Corman has directed. It is approximately 50, not ''something like 400.'' That number includes his credits as a producer. This correction was delayed for research.

On a recent Thursday night I stood motionless and perplexed on the dance floor of a San Francisco club. As I looked around, 300 or so people danced and darted back and forth to a free open bar while laser lights shot overhead. Cellphones glowed, like a video of luminescent jellyfish, as people snapped pictures and slung moments of the evening onto dozens of social networks. What made the evening so perplexing was that the party I was attending celebrated Path, a mobile social network that just two months earlier was essentially written off in Silicon Valley. If the company held a party back then, people would have assumed it was a going-out-of-business sale. Now, after rebooting to positive reviews from the blogosphere, Path is again the talk of Silicon Valley. Some are even proclaiming that the company could be ''the next Facebook.''

There was no must-have toy of Christmas 2011 - for youngsters, anyway. For adults, tablet computers and e-readers were the gifts of choice, judging by a new report that indicates the number of adults in the United States who own tablets and e-readers nearly doubled from mid-December to early January.

It looks like the holidays were very big for the iPhone. According to a new research report from Nielsen, there were so many purchases of iPhones around the holidays that Apple sharply whittled down the market share lead of Android smartphones in the United States by the end of the year. When Nielsen surveyed a group of consumers in October -- a panel of 25,000 people -- 61.6 percent of those who had gotten a smartphone within the past three months said they bought an Android device, while only 25.1 percent got an iPhone.

Roger Federer's straight-sets win over Bernard Tomic was filled with long stretches of inspired play from both players. Unlike Rafael Nadal's drubbing of his countryman Feliciano Lopez, which looked like a foregone conclusion early in the first set, the Federer-Tomic match had tense moments throughout, as Federer had to play at his sublime best to beat the rapidly improving Tomic. Federer's tactical variety flummoxed the young Aussie, who, at 19, is already a master tactician. Tomic's genius lies in his ability to out-think his opponent, to hit shots that disrupt rhythm and decision-making ability and to anticipate how and where his opponent is going to hit the ball. He seems to gather information on whom he is playing, then get inside the player's head and break him down with guile, creativity and uncanny anticipation.

Keenan Kampa, a member of the Boston Ballet and a rare American to attend the Vaganova Ballet Academy in St. Petersburg, Russia, is joining the Mariinsky Ballet. The Mariinsky said Ms. Kampa, 22, was becoming the first American in its ranks. She starts June 2012. The announcement follows the news last year that David Hallberg was joining the Bolshoi Ballet, the first American to become a principal dancer there. Ms. Kampa, from Reston, Va., attended summer programs at the Boston Ballet and American Ballet Theater in New York as well as master classes at the Kennedy Center. The Mariinsky said she was also the first American to receive a degree from the Vaganova, a storied school that produced George Balanchine, Vaslav Nijinsky, Rudolf Nureyev and Anna Pavlova, among other prominent dancers. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

LESSER--Samene W. Beloved wife, mother and friend, Samene Webber Lesser passed away on January 21, 2012 after a prolonged illness. Born in 1930 in Kansas City, Mo., she moved to New York City immediately after graduating with honors from Washington University in St. Louis. It was ten days before her 21st birthday and she never looked back. She embraced New York and counted her blessings that she could live in what she knew to be the greatest city in the world. There she began a career in advertising and public relations. Married in 1955 she spent the next 56 years with her beloved husband, Joe. They have two wonderful daughters, Amy and Sharon. She lit up a room with her giggle and smile and entertained everybody with her command of literature, history and pop culture. She is the treasured grandmother of Jack, whom she absolutely and utterly adored, and a cherished aunt to numerous loving nieces and nephews. She was preceded in death by her siblings Sam, Joe, Rhona and Deborah. She was interested in every aspect of her children's lives and supported their dreams. She was an exceptionally witty and brilliant writer. Dear friend and adored patron of local shops and storefronts dotting the Upper East Side, her much-loved neighborhood. Loyal and passionate supporter of The New York City Ballet, The New York Philharmonic, Carnegie Hall, progressive social causes and service organizations. She was also a universal mom to legions of her children's friends. She loved her friends, including Clare, Susan, Ruth, and Doris; Jack's father, Matt; Mardi Grant; her family; old movies; "Law & Order"; and Simon and Garfunkel. She had an extraordinary memory for dates, people and conversations, and she will be our extraordinary memory for the rest of our lives. The funeral service is Thursday, January 26, 2012 at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell -The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the New York City Ballet or the Coalition for the Homeless.

Nearly five years after he earned his second World Series ring, Doug Mirabelli has another big win. This month, an arbitration panel ruled in favor of Mr. Mirabelli, the former Boston Red Sox catcher, in his dispute with one of Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch's top financial advisers. WATSKY--Claire Master. Born May 29, 1929, in Brooklyn, died January 16, 2012, at home, in Mamaroneck, NY, after a brave yearlong battle with cancer. She is survived by Harold, her devoted husband of over 60 years; her older son, Rick; her younger son, Andy, and his wife Chiharu, and their children, Amy and Cy. Claire lost her own parents while just a young girl, and was raised by her aunt and uncle. She graduated from Brooklyn's Erasmus High School, and received her B.A. in History from Hunter College. After her young sons entered school, she undertook graduate studies at Teachers College, Columbia University, earning an M.A. in Vocational Counseling. From the start of her professional life in 1968, Claire focused on helping people realize and apply to their careers their life's unique experiences and abilities. She began as a career counselor at Rockland County Guidance Center, then at the YWCA, where she became Director of the Vistas for Women program. She served as Associate Dean, and then Dean, of Iona College's School of General Studies. She continued her work, and closed her career, with AARP, in a leadership volunteer role. She forged lifelong friendships with her genuineness, directness, and intelligence, both emotional and intellectual. She is remembered by her children as a loving mother, and as their greatest advocate and supporter; by her grandchildren, as selfless, caring, and kind. Her husband cherishes the memory of their many years together as partners in family and travel, and treasures the values they shared. All miss her deeply. A memorial service will be held Friday, January 27th, 2pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York 10552.

There has been much debate about the Russian-ness of Stravinsky, who lived and worked away from his native country for most of his life. In a program called ''Stravinsky Outside Russia,'' on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, the conductor Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra offered selections that reflected both Stravinsky's Russian heritage and the aesthetics of his adopted homelands. During a preconcert lecture, an audience member asked Mr. Botstein whether Stravinsky could be considered eclectic.

Lionsgate's movie adaptation of ''The Hunger Games'' does not arrive in theaters until March 23 - still too far away for analysts to predict ticket revenue. But if spiking sales of the books are any indication, Lionsgate's marketing efforts are whipping up a five-alarm box-office fire. About 9.6 million books in Suzanne Collins's ''Hunger Games'' trilogy were in circulation in the United States when Lionsgate started production on its adaptation of the first novel in the summer, according to figures from Scholastic, which published the works.

Mitt Romney enters Florida on Monday wounded by his political collapse in South Carolina and facing a central challenge for his candidacy: How to regain the initiative after being forced for weeks into a defensive crouch. In the days before Florida's primary on Jan. 31, Mr. Romney will need to confront the potential breakdown of two pillars of his campaign: that he is the most electable (in exit polls, South Carolina voters saidNewt Gingrich was) and that he is the favorite of those who care about the economy, a title that polls show also went to Mr. Gingrich in the voting on Saturday.

That is more or less the presentation Apple made on Thursday, but it is a song that has been sung before. Nearly three years ago, in May 2009, Amazon said much the same thing when it came up with the Kindle DX, a souped-up e-reader.

Many other sites also went dark or, like Craigslist, displayed a similar message before continuing to regular content. So, which Web sites benefited the most from an increase in traffic away from Wikipedia? They included Bing and Answers.com, potential competitors, as well as sites with a narrow focus, like Biography.com or the Internet Movie Database, above, a handy place to look up the name of Audrey Hepburn's character in ''Charade'' (Reggie Lampert). Maybe the old guard in enterprise software is firing back at the social media upstarts. At least one, Tibco, is using the best ammo it has, boring old business data. Don't scoff. 5:40 p.m. | Updated She can always depend on the kindness of strangers (and her thriving film career), but Cate Blanchett will be ending her tenure with the Australian theater company for which she starred in an acclaimed production of ''A Streetcar Named Desire.'' The Sydney Morning Herald reported that Ms. Blanchett and her husband, Andrew Upton, would exit as the co-artistic directors of the Sydney Theater Company at the end of their term in 2013, after a run that brought the company international attention, praise and profits. Ms. Blanchett, the Academy Award-winning star of ''The Aviator,'' was seen as a surprisingly high-profile choice when she and Mr. Upton became the company's co-artistic directors in 2009, but their productions, including ''Uncle Vanya'' and ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' were widely respected. The company's ''Streetcar,'' directed by Liv Ullmann and starring Ms. Blanchett as Blanche DuBois, was widely praised; reviewing its production at the BAM Harvey Theater in Brooklyn, Ben Brantley wrote in The New York Times, ''Ms. Ullmann and Ms. Blanchett have performed the play as if it had never been staged before.'' The Morning Herald said that the Sydney Theater Company turned a profit of $607,167 in 2009 and a profit of $919,860 in 2010 after previous years of losses. Patrick McIntyre, the company's general manager, said that Ms. Blanchett and Mr. Upton's time there ''has been a great success,'' and that a new artistic director was being sought to plan a 2014 program.

WEXLER--Jacqueline. The Hunter College community is profoundly saddened by the loss of our former President and inspiring mentor. A visionary leader, during her nine-year tenure she oversaw the transfer of the Bellevue School of Nursing to Hunter and helped launch the Brookdale Center on Aging, the Schools of Health Science, the Women's Studies program, and many other initiatives that have had a lasting impact at the College. A superb negotiator and diplomat, Wexler skillfully guided Hunter through New York City's financial crisis in the 70s. Her indomitable spirit lives on at Hunter. We are proud to have a Wexler still grace our halls, Jacqueline's grandson, David, Hunter College student. Our deepest condolences to Paul, Wendy, Wayne and the entire family. Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College Klara Silverstein, Chair, Hunter College Foundation

The 10th anniversary concert of the Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra couldn't encompass all the ambitions of this remarkable New York institution, even in two generous sets on Friday night that kicked off the group's two-night appearance at Symphony Space. The orchestra, founded and directed by the pianist Arturo O'Farrill, spent its first five years as a resident ensemble at Jazz at Lincoln Center. Now it's independent. Its 18-piece lineup preserves the sound of the great old Latin dance bands, a demanding repertory in itself. But Latin jazz in New York City has always had a progressive, experimental side, fusing with bebop in the 1940s and sparking innovations through the next decades. The orchestra continues that mission, welcoming new compositions that fling wild dissonances and abstruse rhythms into the mix. It also embraces music from across the Americas, old and new, playing all of its diverse material with the same precision and fire it brings to a mambo workout.

The Agnieszka Radwanska-Victoria Azarenka match was a textbook case of how aggressive play and offense beats risk-averse defense in big matches. Although Radwanska took the first set, winning an error-filled tiebreaker 7-0 as Azarenka self-destructed, the rest of the match was a clinic in power tennis dominating a more conservative game plan. Azarenka began to take the ball early and move Radwanska mercilessly from side to side. The normally stingy Radwanska (she committed only 3 unforced errors in her fourth round win over Julia Gorges) began to crumble as Azarenka's heavy groundstrokes found their mark. Radwanska made 31 unforced errors in the match, and gradually wore down under Azarenka's constant pressure.

The Shanty, a new bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that I reviewed this week, serves a whiskey cocktail they call the Lonesome Hero. It's a terrific drink: an old-fashioned variant made with cherry liqueur and the Czech herbal bitters Becherovka. Yet ordering one feels a little bit like getting the salmon at Peter Luger. That's because the Shanty - for the moment, at least - is mostly about the gin. The bar is an annex of the New York Distilling Company, which has been producing two types of gin since November. They're not the only people to do the micro-distilling thing in the borough (there's also the Kings County Distillery and Breuckelen Distilling in Sunset Park), but they're the first with their own bar. The Shanty is clearly more than a gin joint, and no one will push you to order the company's products. But after admiring their gorgeous German-made pot still through a window onto the distillery floor, it's hard to choose something made elsewhere. This week, they have started distilling the rye that will be ready for bottling a year from now. They already have a great drink to use it in.

Cass Bird's photographs are instantly recognizable: her subjects always look mischievous, and like they are having just a little too much fun. Whether it's a teenage model, her own children or the actor Viggo Mortensen (whom she photographed for the cover of T Magazine), Bird consistently manages to get the people she shoots to let their guard down so that the images ultimately reflect an integral part of her own personality: the hyperactive goofball. In her work for the Gap, Wrangler, Urban Outfitters and numerous magazines, Bird's aesthetic is best described as "young, carefree, loving life and you're so jealous," and her influence radiates throughout popular photography.

The Weather Channel Companies, which owns the Weather Channel, replaced its leadership on Tuesday, and named the digital advertising veteran David Kenny its chairman and chief executive.Mr. Kenny will start immediately. Michael J. Kelly, who had been the chief executive since 2009, will become a special adviser to the company and an adviser to Bain Capital, the private equity firm that co-owns the company with the Blackstone Group and Comcast's NBCUniversal.The surprise change signaled a desire on the part of the co-owners to expand the Weather Channel's digital and mobile businesses more quickly. Through mobile apps and Web sites like Weather.com, the company sees an opportunity to have a much bigger international footprint."Six and a half billion people need information about weather," Mr. Kenny said in an interview Tuesday after addressing the company's staff in Atlanta.Mr. Kenny also said that the company would make more investments in long-form programming - part of a gradual move away from live weather news and toward taped weather-related reality shows."Now that people can get the information they need for their forecast off the Web, and certainly on their mobile phone, that gives us more license to do more long-form on the cable channel," he said. The channel remained committed to live news during severe weather, he added.Mr. Kenny, a member of the board of directors of Yahoo, was the president of Akamai until he stepped down last October. He was previously the co-founder of VivaKi, a digital agency that is part of the Publicis Groupe.In a statement, the three co-owners of the Weather Channel said that Mr. Kenny's experience "gives him a deep understanding of the TV and digital business, and he has the leadership experience and vision to drive global initiatives across all platforms."Mr. Kelly, similarly, had a digital media background when he was hired two and a half years ago.Mr. Kenny said he was initially recruited to join the board of the company, and was later asked by the board to consider the chief executive position."What I've long stood for is convergence," he said. "I think you'll see us find better ways to run the Weather Channel as one company, really organized around our hundreds of millions of users."NBCUniversal and the private equity firms have owned the Weather Channel since 2008.

I'm not really your drive-across-America type -- more of a train-through-India or Bolivia-by-bus kind of traveler. But I've long wanted to do a road trip in Texas. For someone like me, who has never lived west of the Hudson, it's perhaps the most fascinating state in the nation. It's vast without being empty, associated with powerful American symbols like cowboy boots and pickup trucks and high school football, carries more than half our border with Mexico, has at least a claim on the nation's best barbecue (not to mention all that Tex-Mex), and has a long, complicated and fascinating history. It's at once as American as apple pie and as alien as another planet.

Alison Price Becker has always created a cozy, irresistibly romantic atmosphere in her restaurants, most notably at Alison on Dominick (remember those sexy blue banquettes?). For her highly anticipated return to the Manhattan dining scene with Alison Eighteen, a Flatiron spot that opens softly tomorrow (officially next Tuesday), Price Becker asked Payton Cosell Turner and her husband Brian Kaspr to create a wallpaper that depicts all of her favorite things. The result is a toile print of hand-drawn and hand-screened caricatured animals, scenes of New York and Price Becker herself. It's cheeky and fresh - the colors are eggplant and red (the original black and white drawing is shown above), not her usual navy blue color scheme. There are images of wind turbines to represent sustainability, a dog reading Page Six, people falling in love, hanging out, markets, food, flowers and Price Becker's mascot - a chicken with a wineglass on her head. "This is about having pure fun, and a night on the town," she says.

Many (although far from all) adult adoptees are frustrated by their lack of access to their biological past. Arriving in Paris Wednesday night, I went straight from Charles de Gaulle airport to a trés Parisienne apartment off Place de la Republique for the designer Alexandre Mattiussi's cocktail-party-as-fashion-presentation for Ami. Though Champagne and cigarettes abounded, this was no chic Rive Gauche affair; more like the Williamsburg-on-the-Seine scene of Rue Oberkampf or, as our in-the-know illustrator Richard Haines said: "So Bushwick L train/Morgan stop." So true. It was an über-groovy crowd - hard to discern the models from the viewers - and a perfect welcome to the final leg of the European fashion show season. What's more, it heralded the arrival of this new French sportswear brand, following the model of A.P.C., with its cult following and affordable prices. Quirky outfits like short leather bombers and trim tweed coats layered over colored sweaters and clashing untucked shirts (with the odd floral or plaid here and there) felt more like great personal style statements than forced fashion. A bright-eyed bearded fellow wore a tee with a floralized bearded fellow on it, along with a harvest-colored houndstooth vest, matching carrot-cut pants (imagine a slightly dropped crotch with full legs that narrow at the cuff) and a tonal, double-breasted plaid coat; an amusing outfit with Parisian charm that had me at "Bon soir."

CARACAS, Venezuela - Cacique Tiuna, the Socialist housing commune being built here shows just how the government is planning to leverage housing to its advantage ahead of the presidential election in October. In 1807, a New Jersey schoolgirl named Mary Antrim embroidered a farm scene with silk thread on linen. On Sunday, Sotheby's in New York sold her view of livestock, picket fences and clapboarded outbuildings for $1.07 million (the top estimate had been $120,000), setting an auction record for a needlework sampler. The sale contained 198 lots from the collection of the needlework historian Betty Ring. Of all the colorful pastoral views at the Sotheby's showroom, Mary Antrim's piece ''stood out in a unique way as a folk art statement,'' said the dealer David Schorsch, who bought it for an undisclosed client. The auction's other top prices were in the low six figures and shared by the specialist dealers Stephen and Carol Huber and Amy Finkel. A quarter of the Ring material did not sell, especially images of veiled mourners and gravestones sewn in memory of deceased relatives. The buzz in the field this week, Mr. Huber said, is that ''the memorials all died.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The rap group 2 Live Crew, which set off a fierce debate over freedom of speech with its graphic sexual lyrics in the 1980s and early 1990s, plans to reunite and begin touring, The Associated Press reported. The group's former leader, Luther Campbell, said at the Sundance Film Festival in Utah that the rappers, whose hits like ''Me So Horny'' drew fire, would get back together. ''I just can't wait to start practicing,'' he said. Mr. Campbell, who is 51 and is also known as Luke, visited the festival to promote his appearance in a short film, ''The Life and Freaky Times of Uncle Luke.'' 2 Live Crew popularized the booming hard-driving sound of Miami bass music and was an inventor of ''booty rap,'' which depended on simple, explicit chants and up-tempo grooves, according to the All Music Guide. A federal judge in Florida ruled that the group's 1989 album, ''As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' was obscene, making it a hot commodity among rap fans, but that ruling was later overturned by a federal appeals court.

Mr. Gingrich at one point was asked about his contributions to the conservative movement. In answering, he omitted his long history as a self-described liberal ''Rockefeller Republican'' during much of his early adult life and career. Mr. Gingrich instead cited his work for Barry M. Goldwater, the conservative Republican presidential nominee who lost in a landslide in 1964. But at the time, by his own description, Mr. Gingrich was a liberal to moderate Republican, though he would later become widely renowned among conservatives for his role in the party's takeover of Congress in 1994 for the first time in 40 years. Nelson A. Rockefeller was, of course, the Republican governor of New York who lost to Mr.Goldwater in the party's primary in 1964 and was the standardbearer of the party's moderate wing. In a 1989 interview with the Ripon Society, a moderate Republican organization, Mr. Gingrich said, ''There is almost a new synthesis evolving with the classic moderate wing of the party -- where, as a former Rockefeller state chairman, I've spent most of my life -- and the conservative/ activist right wing.'' In 1992, when asked whether President George Bush would ''revert to Rockefeller Republicanism'' if he were re-elected, Mr. Gingrich said: ''Bush has never been a Rockefeller Republican. I have been. In 1968, I was for Rockefeller because he was the most pro-integrationist Republican candidate.''

I admit to being jealous of my sons for growing up in a time when vaccines spared them miseries like the measles, mumps and polio scares that marred my childhood. But I'm most envious of their freedom from the dental decay that forced me to spend countless miserable hours with my mouth propped open while the dentist did his best to stay on top of rapidly rotting teeth. By my mid-20s, I had already lost one molar and all four wisdom teeth, and every remaining molar had been restored with fillings.

FREHSE--Robert M.,Jr., The Rockefeller University mourns the passing of our longtime friend Robert Frehse, who served for nearly three decades as executive director of the Hearst Foundations. A guiding light in New York's philanthropic community, Bob will be remembered for his wise leadership and his dedication to many causes, including medical research and education. At Rockefeller, he was instrumental in creating the William Randolph Hearst Endowed Scholarship Fund for the Tri-Institutional MD-PhD Program, which the University sponsors with its neighbors, Weill Cornell Medical College and the Sloan-Kettering Institute. The mission of this nationally renowned program is to train physician-scientists who are able to bridge the gap between laboratory research and clinical medicine. Over the past 20 years, the Hearst Scholarship has supported ten physician-scientists in training. Bob loved young people and believed strongly in investing in our future scientific leaders. He also fostered inter-institutional ties, bringing together faculty and administrators in a common purpose. With everlasting gratitude to Bob, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Dale; to their sons, Robert M. Frehse, III, and John W. Frehse, Sr., and to the entire Frehse family. Russell L. Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Paul Nurse and Torsten N. Wiesel, Presidents Emeriti Olaf Andersen, Director, Tri-Institutional MD-PhD Program Marnie Imhoff, Vice President

An article on Jan. 11 about a report on malnutrition in India misstated the scope of a major finding of the report. The DealBook column last Tuesday, about the private equity executive Paul S. Levy's defense of the industry, included a quotation from Mr. Levy in which he misstated the number of bankruptcies among companies acquired by two private equity firms, the Gores Group and Sun Capital Partners. In the last three years, 19 companies acquired by Sun Capital have filed for bankruptcy protection; none acquired by the Gores Group have done so in that period. It is not the case, as Mr. Levy said, that ''20 or 30'' of the companies acquired by the two firms have filed for bankruptcy in the last three years.

9:45 p.m. | Updated BOSTON - Senator Scott P. Brown and Elizabeth Warren, his likely Democratic opponent, agreed Monday on a plan to try to stop outside groups from running attack ads in their high-profile, high-stakes race. But while they labored over a mutually acceptable agreement, the hardest part - trying to enforce it - comes now. The agreement requires each side to donate to a charity of the other's choosing whenever a third-party ad is aired supporting them or attacking their opponent. Both parties will also sign letters to outside groups and to television station managers, calling on them to stop running ads in the race.

Alzheimer's disease, with its inexorable loss of memory and self, understandably alarms most of us. This is especially so since, at the moment, there are no cures for the condition and few promising drug treatments. But a cautiously encouraging new study from The Archives of Neurology suggests that for some people, a daily walk or jog could alter the risk of developing Alzheimer's or change the course of the disease if it begins. For the experiment, researchers at Washington University in St. Louis recruited 201 adults, ages 45 to 88, who were part of a continuing study at the university's Knight Alzheimer's Disease Research Center. Some of the participants had a family history of Alzheimer's, but none, as the study began, showed clinical symptoms of the disease. They performed well on tests of memory and thinking. ''They were, as far as we could determine, cognitively normal,'' says Denise Head, an associate professor of psychology at Washington University who led the study.

The collapse of a billboard along the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway on Jan. 13 has turned the city's attention again to the presence of highway billboards: how many are legal, how many are safe and what are they doing there in the first place? What is beyond doubt is how much of an impact billboards have on the cityscape.

Somali pirates cannot seem to stay out of the news. As another fashion season gets underway, the conversation about the relevancy of the runway show continues. Anna Kushnerova and Romain Brau, the duo behind RA, Antwerp's premiere fashion boutique/art gallery/book shop/restaurant, have a firm stance on the issue. "We find the format static and boring," says Brau. And to drive the point home, at RA's new Paris outpost, which opened on the Rue de la Corderie in the third arrondissement this week, designers who share their beef with the industry's standard method of presentation will get a chance to act on their frustrations - sometimes literally. Along with selling luxury fashion such as eveningwear from Serkan Cura and millinery by Nasir Mazhar - a switch from the Antwerp shop, which focuses on avant-garde labels like Siki Im and Bless - Kushnerova and Brau will provide alternatives to formulaic runway shows in the form of theatrically-inspired fashion happenings. "When we started in Antwerp, the idea was to create a comfortable personal space for ourselves and our community," says Kushnerova, who along with Brau was a fashion design student at Antwerp's Royal Academy before embarking on a career in retail. "With this, we have a more precise vision - we want to really explore the idea of production-based fashion exhibits with music and scenery." The pair worked with stage and lighting designers, including a scene painter from the Brussels Opera, to create the shop's dramatic interior, which references the art and décor of the 1920s and '30s. The first designer to tread the boards, so to speak, at RA's fashion theater was the Belgian-born Cura, who has worked for the corset maker Mr. Pearl and the designer Jean-Paul Gaultier, and played with the idea of backstage and onstage. "Part of the collection was shown on dolls," says Brau.

It's entirely possible that, just a few weeks ago, you sang the fine old tune "Auld Lang Syne" to welcome the New Year. You might still puzzle over the lyrics, no matter how many times you've sung it, and you might not know that the man responsible for the song as we know it is Robert Burns, the Scottish poet who was born on this day in 1759. "Robert Burns and 'Auld Lang Syne,'" a lovely little exhibition at the Morgan Library and Museum, can take care of explaining the lyrics; seeing it would be a great way to kick off your celebration of Burns Night, the Scottish holiday marking the birth of the Scottish poet behind the song.

The effect, for spring, was sweet, not sultry. Pastel dresses were entirely covered in tulle flowers, metallic embroideries and crystal beading. The Hermès collection, described as having a palette of "colorful blacks, dark harmonies," was a quiet show that grew on me the more time I had to reflect on it. Luxurious materials, and leather - always a feature of the house and certainly a trend this show season - were beautifully represented in belted calfskin coats, slim serge trousers, and suits in colors like ebony, licorice, plum and black. Signature printed ties were noticeably absent, replaced with dark, solid neck wear and collared shirts buttoned all the way up. The look that stuck was simple but clever: a carbon-colored evening suit paired with a black crew-neck knit and a dark patterned scarf that came draped under the lapels (attached with a hidden zipper to keep it in place all evening long). It was a chic and sexy runway look - easy to envision on handsome young actors on red carpets everywhere.

We've just published an article that looks at how the new nexus tax laws affect affiliate marketing companies and the retailers that use their services. In the realm of musical excavation, even experts can come to the wrong conclusions. In the Feb. 10 episode of "Michael Feinstein's American Songbook," the PBS series that follows Mr. Feinstein, the entertainer and musical preservationist, as he rummages through old musical archives, the discovery of an unpublished Irving Berlin song was to be announced. The song, titled "So Will I," which was recently copyrighted by the Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization, which administers Berlin's publishing but had no record of the song, has since been found to have been composed in 1926 by the team of Lew Brown and Cliff Friend and published by the Berlin company. A bouncy, wistful breakup song, it was recorded in 2005 by Ian Whitcomb on his album "Sentimentally Yours."

For less than the cost of café con leche and an order of churros, music lovers in Madrid can take in a top-notch concert at the Festival Internacional de Improvisación Hurta Cordel, an annual celebration of experimental and improvised music started in 1996. From Wednesday through Jan. 29, La Casa Encendida will charge four euros admission to see performances by legends like the avant-rock guitarist Fred Frith and free-jazz pianist Alexander von Schlippenbach alongside shows featuring up-and-coming artists from Spain and abroad. (Tickets are also available on www.entradas.com.)Moving across genres like free jazz, contemporary classical and experimental electronica, the musicians push past more mainstream definitions of music, each in his or her own way. The festival lineup includes a collaboration between the established British improvisers Michael Fischer, John Edwards and Mark Sanders, as well as a concert by 2|2code, an Australian-Spanish duo that treads the line between music and conceptual art. 2|2code creates ambient surround-sound mash-ups drawn from sources as varied as classic Hollywood films, amateur news footage, and speeches by George W. Bush.

D'OENCH--Russell G. (Toby) on January 23. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the untimely death of our partner, colleague and friend, Russell (Toby) D'Oench, III. Toby passed away Monday night from complications related to his treatment for cancer. He was 58 years old. A partner at Skadden since 2000, Toby was an extraordinary lawyer whose breadth of skills enabled him to do most anything. A member of Skadden's Financial Institutions Group, Toby handled mergers, acquisitions, equity offerings and other transactions involving public and private investment management firms, broker-dealers and related businesses. In 1977, the same year he graduated from Wesleyan University, Toby founded the North Star Fund, a nonprofit organization that supports grassroots groups fighting for equality, economic justice and peace. He served as the organization's executive director until 1983. Toby attended Columbia Law School ('92), where he was both a James Kent Scholar and a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, and clerked for Judge Eugene Nickerson of the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York before entering private practice. Toby is survived by his wife, Tani, his daughter, Miye, and his son, Robin.
