DAVOS, Switzerland - The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation said Thursday that it had stepped up its commitment to an international fund to fights AIDS and other diseases, pledging an additional $750 million to the organization. Bill Gates, co-chairman of the foundation, the world's largest charitable organization, said the group would make the money available immediately, aiming to close a gap in financing of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria that is the result of cutbacks in support from various governments.

SIENKIEWICZ--John Casimir, Age 78, passed away unexpectedly at his home in Loblolly, Hobe Sound, FL on January 3, 2012. Born in Center Bridge, PA on October 8, 1933, and raised in Doyles- town, PA, John was the son of Casimir A. Sienkiewicz, a prominent Philadelphia banker and Chairman of the Central Penn National Bank and Jane Patton Sienkiewicz, a nurse. John attended The Loomis School (Loomis-Chaffee) prior to graduating from Princeton University in 1955 where he served as President of his class and remained a valued advisor throughout his life. Playing varsity football his senior year, John won the award for Most Improved Player. John served in the United States Navy from 1955 to 1957 aboard the USS Hancock rising to the rank of Lieutenant. In 1958, he joined Hutchinson, Rivinus & Co. of Philadelphia as an insurance salesman. In 1965, John became a Partner of the firm which was later acquired by Alexander and Alexander International. In time, John became President and Chief Executive Officer of International Operations of Alexander and Alexander, which was known as the largest international insurance brokerage firm in the world. After their acquisition by Aon Risk Services, John remained an active Vice Chairman. John lived most of his life in Princeton, NJ with his wife of 50 years, Patricia Davis Sienkiewicz. John was a loving, strong, and supportive husband, father and friend. His passions included golf, philanthropy, and travel. John was a member of Pine Valley Golf Club, Seminole Golf Club, and many others. He was an active member of the United States Seniors Golf Association. John was widely philanthropic, giving generously to many organizations. Most notable, was the University Cottage Club at Princeton where he served as Chairman of the Board for ten years. John was predeceased by his wife Patricia and his brother Bur Sienkiewicz. He is survived by his sons Mark and Peter, his second wife Maisie Barlow Sienkiewicz, his brother Michael Sienkiewicz and wife Marika, his sister-in-law Jone Sienkiewicz and many more family members and friends who loved him dearly. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in his honor for student aid to: Casimir A. Sienkiewicz Scholarship, American International College, 1000 State Street - Box 10-L, Springfield, MA 01109. A Celebration of Life Service is being planned for June 2012 in Princeton, NJ.

GIEGERICH--Lester R. 96. FINANCIER Lester Ralph Giegerich of Darien, who developed some of the first shopping centers in California, died in the early morning of Tuesday, January 17, at Norwalk Hospital. He was 96 and still active in his real estate development and management business until the last two weeks of his life. Born May 22, 1915, he was raised in New Providence, NJ. "Les" Giegerich went to the University of Pennsylvania on full scholarship and graduated from the Wharton School of Commerce & Finance in 1940. He then moved to Missouri where he met and married Betty Louise Bradley of Kansas City in 1941. He served as a World War II Air Force flight instructor for five years at Kelley Field in Texas where he rose to the rank of major. After the war, Mr. Giegerich worked for Merrill Lynch in Kansas City followed by four years with Traveler's Insurance Co. as assistant manager of the City Mortgage Loan Department. He then moved on to head up the Mortgage Loan & Real Estate Department of Teacher's Insurance & Annuity Association in New York City from 1950-54. He was a pioneer in the sale and leaseback transactions and mortgage banking with his partner Sidney M. Barton of New York. In 1960 he started his own company, the Giegerich Co., in Westport, where he lived with his wife and two daughters. During his 60 years as one of the country's most active experts in leasebacks, Mr. Giegerich developed some of the first shopping centers in California with partners Earnest W. Hahn, Linn C. Alexander and Gerry L. Moss -- all pioneers in the industry. One of his earliest projects was the Spanish-styled La Cumbre in Santa Barbara. Not only did his company develop shopping centers, but it also financed numerous office and industrial buildings throughout the U.S. Additionally, the Giegerich Co. conducted a mortgage banking business through 1986. In 1977, after his first wife died, Mr. Giegerich married Lillian Ransco Roney of Darien, formerly of Rochester, NY, and moved to Darien. In Fairfield County, Mr. Giegerich served on many boards including the Westport YMCA, the Westport Library, the Norwalk Housing Association, and the Maritime Aquarium. He was a generous donor to these organizations as well as the Westport Saugatuck Congregational Church, the Norwalk Hospital and the University of Pennsylvania. Known affectionately as Mr. G. in his office, Les Giegerich was a humanist, always interested in people and their lives. An inspiration to all, he was generous with his time and talent. Drawing from his innate common sense and wide perspective, Les was an educator; he was known to offer advice to many, particularly to those who were just starting out in their careers. Open-minded with many interests, Les lived life fully. He travelled to all the continents (at least twice) and had few wonders of the world left to see. He read widely, and especially loved history books and biographies. His athletic abilities lasted into his early '90s during which he still enjoyed skiing, tennis and swimming, but above all, golf. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, Lillian Giegerich; his sister, Marion Snyder of New Providence, N.J.; his two daughters, Brenda K. Giegerich of Westport, CT and Marsha G. Torkelson of Mill Valley, CA.; his step-daughter Joan Roney of New York City and his step-son John Roney of Darien; three grandchildren, Justin Torkelson, Bretton Torkelson and Eloise Giegerich and two newly born great-granddaughters Mia and Elle. Memorial donations may be made to Norwalk Hospital's Whittingham Cancer Center at norwalkhospitalfoundation.org or by calling 203-852-2216.

The Yankees announced the signing of Hiroki Kuroda, a right-handed starter, and also agreed to a one-year deal with reliever Boone Logan to avoid arbitration. Kuroda, 36, agreed to a one-year deal worth $10 million, but it was not completed until he passed his physical. Kuroda spent four seasons with the Los Angeles Dodgers and was 13-16 with a 3.07 earned run average in 32 starts last season, establishing career bests in wins, E.R.A., games started, innings pitched (202) and strikeouts (161).

Both Miles Davis and Edith Piaf were maverick, contrarian performers, even more esteemed after their deaths than during their lifetimes, so it makes sense that they should now be recognized simultaneously with stamps issued in their honor. The United States and France announced Thursday that both countries would issue separate stamps this year to commemorate the artists and their music. The stamps show both performers in characteristic poses: Davis, the jazz trumpet player who died in 1991, arched back with his instrument to his lips, and Piaf, the singer who died in 1963, with her hands dramatically extended. In the United States the stamps will be part of the Forever series, which are equal in value to the prevailing first-class letter rate; as part of the same program the writer O. Henry, the actor Jose Ferrer, the entertainer Danny Thomas and the magazine publisher John H. Johnson will also be honored this year.

Top officials and economists from outside Europe warned of complacency and presented a much more pessimistic view of the European crisis on Saturday in Davos than has been heard in previous days. While many European leaders and businesspeople have argued that the risk of a catastrophic breakup of the euro zone has declined, leaders of other regions said the crisis still had the potential to sow global misery. "I've never been as scared as now about the world," said Donald Tsang, chief executive of Hong Kong. He said the effect on the world financial system is unpredictable. "We do not know how deep this hole would be when the whole thing implodes on us," he said. Read the full article»

It's in part about the way Ethiopia's heightening repression has resulted in the imprisonment and abuse of journalists, including two Swedes who are now serving an 11-year prison sentence in awful conditions. My sense is that Ethiopia's Prime Minister Meles Zenawi thinks that imprisoning those Swedes will intimidate and silence the international press corps -- and I want him to realize that he's dead wrong. That's also why I went after him by Twitter at Davos.

MIAMI - Carmelo Anthony is shutting himself down for at least a few days to rest a sore ankle and a painful wrist, having conceded that his erratic play was hurting the Knicks' cause. He missed Friday night's game against the Miami Heat and will miss Saturday's game in Houston.

Across the waiting room in the doctor's office, a woman is generously showering each page of last month's Newsweek with wet coughs. Her expression is a dutiful one, like that of a priest sprinkling holy water upon his congregation; occasionally she flips back to bestow a second layer where the first might have been too thin.

Last October, in Foshan, China, a 2-year-old girl was run over by a van. The driver did not stop. Over the next seven minutes, more than a dozen people walked or bicycled past the injured child. A second truck ran over her. Eventually, a woman pulled her to the side, and her mother arrived. The child died in a hospital. The entire scene was captured on video and caused an uproar when it was shown by a television station and posted online. A similar event occurred in London in 2004, as have others, far from the lens of a video camera.

Victoria Azarenka thoroughly outplayed Maria Sharapova in Saturday's Australian Open final. The spirited Azarkena had superior hands, better footwork and near-perfect shot selection as she withstood Sharapova's blistering pace with astonishing ease. How did Azarenka handle Sharapova's big game? And why did Sharapova struggle when Azarenka attacked?

In March 2008, the Detroit Tigers signed a lumbering slugger to what was then the fifth-largest contract in baseball history. His physique and conditioning were suspect, prompting skeptics to warn that he would become a defensive liability and that his hitting might tail off. But Dave Dombrowski, the club's general manager, brushed aside such concerns and gave him an eight-year, $152 million deal.

A federal judge ordered New York State on Friday to move its primary elections for Congressional races to June from September, creating a major complication for the state's election calendar. The judge, Gary L. Sharpe of Federal District Court in Albany, ruled in a suit brought by the federal government that said a September primary would not allow sufficient time to get absentee ballots to military voters for the general election. The decision could mean that some New Yorkers might be asked to vote on four separate days this year.

From across the room with the volume too low, it sounded like ''Baseball Plishka.''

Requiring a minimum down payment of 20 percent, or even 10 percent, on home loans would push many creditworthy borrowers into higher-cost loans or out of the mortgage market entirely, a new study says. It will be Sarastro's host versus the Queen of the Night and her minions at Cowboys Stadium. The stadium, the home of the Dallas Cowboys, will open its gates for a free simulcast of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' on April 28, the Dallas Opera and the football team said on Thursday. In a statement, the Cowboys' executive vice president for brand management, Charlotte Anderson, called it a ''distinctive event.'' Dallas Opera's general director, Keith Cerny, called it a ''game-changing'' collaboration. The production comes from the Lyric Opera of Chicago. Officials said the opera would be shown on the ''world's largest high-definition video board structure,'' which consists of four screens suspended over the field. The largest, according to the statement is 72 feet tall and 160 feet wide. There was no mention of cheerleaders or whether missed notes would be subject to instant-replay review. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MAISONROUGE--Jacques, 87, passed away at home in Paris on January 25, surrounded by his family. He is survived by his wife, Francoise, their five children, Christine, Florence, Sylvie, Francois and Anne-Sophie, their spouses and partner, Xavier, Vincent, Robert, Ketty and Sophie, their eleven grandchildren and their spouses, and their ten great-grandchildren. He instilled his high sense of duty, hard work and ethics to his family, and took great pride in their achievements. He was thrilled to have started a family now living in France, the US, the UK, and even China. His lifelong love of the United States was born in occupied France. In 1948, after graduating from the prestigious Ecole Centrale des Arts et Manufactures, he joined IBM, and he and Francoise moved to the US for what would be the first of four long stays there. His career at IBM spanned 36 years, and would culminate in his becoming Chairman and CEO of IBM World Trade Corporation, and a member of the Board of IBM Corporation. A true French patriot, he was a champion of French-American friendship, and a passionate supporter of Europe. In parallel to his business career, he was a tireless promoter of "world peace through world trade". After retiring from IBM in 1984, he continued to serve on a number of boards, including those of L'Air Liquide and Philip Morris. In 1986, he was called to duty by the French government, and served as Director General of Industry. He served on the boards or as president of a number of philanthropic organizations involved in economic policy making, management, education and health. Most notably, he was President of his alma mater, the Ecole Centrale, and of the American Hospital of Paris. In 1999, he was made a Knight Grand Officer of the Legion of Honor, the highest order in France. He was a Knight of Malta (GM), and the recipient of honors from many countries where he had made his mark. He was particularly proud to have been invited by the Society of the Cincinnati to become an honorary member. Members of the Society are descendants of the officers of the Continental Army and Navy and their French counterparts who served in the Revolutionary War. The funeral service is at Saint-Louis des Invalides Cathedral, in Paris, on Monday, January 30, at 10:30am.

(Lifetime) THE PREGNANCY PROJECT (2012) In this film based on real events, Alex Vega, above, plays Gaby Rodriguez, an 18-year-old high school student from Washington State who pretended to be pregnant to explore the prejudices and presumptions surrounding teenage pregnancy. In a unanimous vote on Friday, the California Air Resources Board, known as CARB, affirmed a major expansion of its Advanced Clean Car rules. According to CARB's projection, the program would result in an additional 1.4 million zero- and near-zero-emission vehicles on the state's roads by 2025. Under the plan, 500,000 of those vehicles would be battery-electric or fuel-cell models that produce no tailpipe emissions. The rest would be plug-in hybrids that qualify as transitional zero-emission vehicles. The recommendation had wide support from environmentalists and many automakers before the vote.

Michael Morpurgo's novel ''War Horse'' was published in 1982. Over the next 25 years, about 50,000 copies were sold. ''It simply was not a book that anyone really knew about or cared about,'' the author once noted in an interview. But since the release of Steven Spielberg's Oscar-nominated film version in Britain two weeks ago, the book has sold more than 60,000 copies there, BBC News reported. The novel, about a farm boy and his beloved horse enmeshed in the horrors of World War I, was made into an award-winning play using puppets in 2007. Egmont Press, the publisher of the novel, said it had sold about 950,000 copies between the opening of the play and last fall. The play is still running in London and New York, and productions are planned for Melbourne, Australia, and Toronto. This week the film was nominated for six Academy Awards including best picture. Movie versions, of course, always boost book sales, but the burst of interest in this case has enabled the book to monopolize the No. 1 sales spot in Britain for the past couple of weeks.

The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson has demanded a meeting with the head of the Recording Academy to talk about deep cuts to Grammy Award categories this year that some musicians have complained discriminate against certain ethnic groups. With the awards ceremony two weeks away, Mr. Jackson expressed his dismay over the cutbacks in a letter to Neil Portnow, the president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, and raised the possibility of protests.

At midday Friday, William M. Daley, a former commerce secretary and the son and brother of Chicago mayors, passed the baton as White House chief of staff to Jacob J. Lew, the former budget director. Mr. Daley, who resigned after a bumpy year in the job, got a standing ovation at the daily morning meeting of senior White House advisers, reflecting the personal popularity of a man who nonetheless never fully fit in with Mr. Obama's insular inner circle. And he reciprocated by providing deep-dish pizza, cheesecake and Garrett's popcorn - all culinary favorites from his beloved Chicago, where he now returns - to be served all day from the White House mess.

The Yale School of Drama announced on Monday that Jeanie O'Hare, the company dramaturg for the Royal Shakespeare Company, would succeed Paula Vogel as chair of the Yale playwriting department beginning July 1. Ms. O'Hare, 49, is not a playwright, but in her R.S.C. position since 2005 she has advised, coached and edited dozens of playwrights who were developing work for the British theater company on commission. She has also worked as literary manager for Hampstead Theater in London and in the artistic offices of the Royal Court Theater, and is a sculptor and fiction writer.

PARIS -- Thérèse Delpech, one of France's leading foreign policy analysts and intellectual historians, died on Jan. 18 at her apartment in Paris. She was 63. The cause was a stroke, said Bruno Racine, a friend and head of the French National Library. She had been ill for some time, dealing with a disease that she did not disclose to her friends.

SEMANS--Mary Duke Biddle Trent, a lifelong philanthropist and civic leader in North Carolina, died on January 25, 2012, in Durham. She was 91. She devoted herself to education, children's services, health care and the arts, and her compassion for others helped shape and sustain significant programs and institutions across the Carolinas and the nation. She was born into a family of industrialists and philanthropists. Her grandfather, Benjamin Newton Duke, his brother, James B. Duke, and their father, Washington Duke, were involved in many business ventures, the most significant of which were the American Tobacco Company and Duke Power Company, now Duke Energy Corporation. Over the years, they were the chief benefactors of Trinity College in Durham, NC, which later became Duke University. In 1924, James B. Duke established The Duke Endowment in Charlotte, one of the largest private foundations in the country and the largest foundation in the Southeast. Mrs. Semans carried on the family legacy through her own foundations and philanthropic work. She was a Trustee of The Duke Endowment for 55 years, and served as its first female Chairman from 1982-2001. After 2001, she continued serving as Chair Emerita. She also served as a Trustee of many educational institutions in the Carolinas, including Duke University, Davidson College, Shaw University, Louisburg College, Converse College and the University of North Carolina School of the Arts. She was instrumental in establishing the Duke University Museum of Art, which became the Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University, and the museum's Great Hall bears her name. Mrs. Semans was born in New York City. Her parents were Mary Duke Biddle, the only daughter of Benjamin Duke, and Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle Jr., a General in the United States Army. Her mother was a noted philanthropist who carried on the family's support of Duke University and her father held several high-level government posts, including Ambassador to Exiled Countries during World War II and Ambassador to Spain. Apart from a childhood in New York City, Mrs. Semans lived most of her life in Durham. She attended the Hewitt School in New York and then enrolled in the Woman's College at Duke University at age 15. In 1938, she married Josiah Trent, a surgical intern who would become the chief of Duke Hospital's division of thoracic surgery. Dr. Trent died of cancer after 10 years of marriage. As a young widow and mother of four girls, she ran for a seat on the Durham City Council and became the first woman elected in 1951. She served as mayor pro-tem from 1953-55. She married James H. Semans, a Duke University surgeon and urologist, in 1953. In their 52 years of marriage, they had three children. Mrs. Semans, along with her husband, took active roles in public service. In the 1960s, they helped lead the establishment of the University of North Carolina School of the Arts, the nation's first state-supported conservatory for the arts. Mrs. Semans served as a Trustee of the school for more than 20 years. Mrs. Semans also served on the board of the Mary Duke Biddle Foundation, established by her mother to support arts, educational and charitable initiatives in North Carolina and New York City. In 1971, the couple received the North Carolina Award for their contributions to the fine arts. The couple also received the National Brotherhood Award from the National Conference of Christians and Jews for distinguished service in the field of human relations. Dr. Semans died in 2005 at age 94. Mrs. Semans served on the boards of the Executive Mansion Fine Arts Committee; the North Carolina Museum of Art; the North Carolina Symphony; the North Carolina Center for World Languages and Cultures; the Kenan Institute for Ethics at Duke University; and the National Humanities Center. She also served as chairman of the Governor's Study Committee on Vocational Rehabilitation and was a member of the National Citizens Advisory Commission on Vocational Rehabilitation, appointed by President Lyndon B. Johnson. Mrs. Semans also served as a member of the board of directors of First Union Corporation. In 1986, she received one of the first two University Medals for Distinguished Meritorious Service at Duke. Her honorary degrees came from Duke, Campbell University, Davidson College, Elon University, Furman University, N.C. Central University, North Carolina Wesleyan College, Pfeiffer University, Shaw University and UNC Chapel Hill. Mrs. Semans received many other honors and awards including the National Governors Association Distinguished Service Award for her support of the arts; a Citation for Distinguished Public Service presented by North Carolina Citizens for Business and Industry; the Humanitarian Freedom Award presented by the Durham Chapter of Hadassah; the North Carolina Philanthropy Award; and the North Caroliniana Society Award. She received the Meritorious Service Award from the North Carolina Hospital Association in 2006 and in 2009 she was inducted into the North Carolina Women's Hall of Fame. Mrs. Semans is survived by seven children: Mary Trent Jones of Abingdon, VA; Sarah Trent Harris of Charlotte, NC; Dr. Rebecca Trent Kirkland of Houston, Texas; Barbara Trent Kimbrell of Sullivan's Island, SC; Jenny Semans Koortbojian of Durham, NC; James Duke Biddle Trent Semans of Chapel Hill, NC; and Beth Semans Hubbard of Los Angeles, CA; 16 grandchildren and 29 great-grandchildren. A funeral service is planned for 2pm, Monday, January 30, at Duke Chapel. Funeral services are being handled by Howerton & Bryan Funeral Home. Memorials may be made to the Semans Art Fund, c/o University of North Carolina School of the Arts; the Duke Medicine Heart Center; the Duke Medicine Pulmonary Division Fund; Josiah Charles Trent Memorial Foundation Endowment, c/o Duke University; or the Frank Neelon Fund for Literature in Medicine, c/o Triangle Community Foundation.

A basement bar and pool hall where a bright neon sign touts ''$1 Massage'' is the last place you'd expect to find a home-schooled classical string ensemble. News Corporation is said to be in advanced talks to hire Lex Fenwick as the chief executive of Dow Jones, filling a six-month vacancy created when the publisher's top executive resigned amid the phone-hacking scandal in Britain. Mr. Fenwick is the founder and chief executive of Bloomberg Ventures and the former chief executive of Bloomberg L.P. He would leave his current position to lead Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, Barron's and the Dow Jones Newswires, according to people familiar with the discussions who would not comment publicly because the negotiations were continuing.

D'OENCH--Russell Grace, III (Toby). Our lives have been immeasurably enriched by our friendships with Toby. He touched every one of us with his thoughtfulness, generosity of spirit and sense of fun. Shared adventures stretched from the Lawrenceville School to a wonderful array of ski slopes, operas and ice rinks. He adored his family, and we are all grateful that Toby brought his beloved wife, Tani, and their son and daughter, Robin and Miye, into our lives, as they will be forever. Toby was a model of courage, humility and optimism. Our families join together to celebrate his extraordinary life. With love from Sally P. Sword and the Irwin, Crary and McDonough families.

An increase in the number of students who qualify for free tutoring this year has led New York City to narrow its eligibility requirements, cutting off services to more than 3,500 students and offering them exclusively to those in the poorest households. Currently about 54,000 city students take part in federally funded tutoring, offered to them at no cost, because they attend schools that have failed for two years to make adequate progress under the No Child Left Behind law. The number of these schools is growing nationwide. It doubled in New York City, where higher standards on state tests led many more schools to fall below the law's threshold and where the number of children eligible for the tutoring has soared.

PESCATELLO--Michael C.,67, of Tiburon, California passed away on January 22, 2012 from complications related to esophageal cancer. He was born in New York on March 29, 1944. Mr. Pescatello earned a B.A. degree from Gettysburg College and a J.D. degree from Vanderbilt University School of Law. Mr. Pescatello was a Senior Vice President at Northern Trust. He was Managing Director and Chief Fiduciary Officer of the Northern's Bay Area Region. He was with Northern Trust since 1988 when they opened the first offices in California. Mr. Pescatello was a member of the State Bars of California and New York. Prior to joining Northern Trust, he was an associate with the New York firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Later he was a Vice President in the Trust & Investment Division of Crocker National Bank. Mr. Pescatello was also active in the investment syndication business, serving in an executive capacity with several national syndication firms. Mr. Pescatello was a Director of the Marin Theater Company (Mill Valley, CA) and a Trustee of both the Hanna Boys Center (Sonoma, CA) and The Agawam Council (Raymond, ME). He was also a member of the National Advisory Board of Vanderbilt University School of Law. Mr. Pescatello was also a life member of the University Club of New York. When he joined in 1971 he believed that he was their youngest member at that time. Michael and his wife Kiki loved to travel and each year found them in a new location in Burma, in cooking school in Tuscany, riding elephants in India or on the beach at Kona, Hawaii. Michael was well known for his wicked sense of humor and his sometimes inappropriate neckties. He is survived by his wife of 34 years, Carolie (Kiki) Pescatello, his mother, Edith Pescatello of Scarsdale, New York, his sisters, Mary Lewis and Marjorie Miller and his brother Paul Pescatello. Mr. Pescatello was predeceased by his brother Edward Pescatello and his sister Anita Beddard. He will also be fondly remembered by his many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations to charities of your choice or to one of Michael's would be appreciated. (Hanna Boys Center, Post Office Box 100, Sonoma, CA 95476 or UCSF Foundation, Thoracic Oncology Program, Regan Botsford, 220 Montgomery Street, 5th Floor, San Francisco, CA 94104. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date.

PATTERSON--Evelyn "Evie" Byrd, nee Hawkins, died on Saturday, January 21, in Sewanee, Tennessee, a victim of pulmonary fibrosis. Born in New York City on February 26, 1931, she was educated at Chapin School, Smith College (B.A. 1952), and Radcliffe College of Harvard University (A.M. 1955). She taught classics at Wheaton College, Massachusetts, in 1959-60. She married William Brown Patterson, a fellow graduate student at Harvard, in 1959. They lived for many years in Davidson, North Carolina, where he taught history at Davidson College, until he joined the faculty of the University of the South in Sewanee in 1980. In 1983, she was appointed Director of the Slide Library of the Art Department there and continued in that position until she retired in 1998. A Eucharist in celebration of her life will be held at Otey Memorial Church in Sewanee on Saturday, January 28, at 12 o'clock noon. She is survived by her husband, Dr. William Brown Patterson of Sewanee; her son, Dr. William Brown Patterson of Ruston, Louisiana; three daughters, Evelyn Byrd Donatelli of New York City, Lucy Patterson Murray of Augusta, Georgia, and Emily Patterson Higgs of Sonora, California; her brother, Eliot Dexter Hawkins of New York City; her sister, Alice Clarkson Van Tuyl of Middlebury, Vermont; ten grandchildren; and many nieces and nephews. Contributions may be sent to Episcopal Relief & Development, 815 Second Ave., New York, NY 10017, or via: www.er-d.org.

SOMACH--Barbara Joan (nee Siegel), age 79, died on January 25, 2012. Loving mother of Brian Moss and Cara Londin, cherished mother-in-law of Joy and Robert. Glowingly proud grandmother of Samantha, Zachary, Josh and Dillon. Beloved wife of Martin (deceased). Fabulous friend to so many, especially in Great Neck, NY and Siesta Key, Florida. Dr. Somach was an amazing educator and scholar having honed her craft at New York University, Brooklyn College and Bank Street College of Education. She applied her vast knowledge and passion for children and education as a skilled Professor of Early Childhood and Elementary Education at Queens College (CUNY), administrator of a program at Long Island Jewish Hospital for disabled children, dedicated mentor and patron for the CLASP after-school program in the Great Neck School system and published author on various education-related topics. Barbara will be remembered for her compassion and friendship, her many original songs and poems in honor of major milestones and celebrations, a fierce dedication to completing the Sunday NYT crossword puzzle and her love of the arts and of travel. Funeral services Sunday at 11:30am, Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck.

WEXLER--Jacqueline. A woman of faith and great love for Paul and the family, she was a powerful force for good in our world. She enriched the lives of many and had the courage, passion and zeal for excellence to help make everything better. Her business acumen and strength captivated chief executive officers and fellow board members of the largest corporations and universities in our country. Her perceptive leadership was always tested with exceptional results. She was a great friend and will be greatly missed. Barbara and Ira A. Lipman

LoMONACO--Thomas G. Born March 27th, 1922 in Brooklyn NY, to Jerome LoMonaco and Maria Puglisi, passed peacefully on January 21, 2012. A successful tenor as a young man, and a well-known teacher of international singers, Dr. LoMonaco provided the music scene with a succession of rich and beautiful voices. His teaching was special not only for the superb technique he imparted, but also for his wisdom, insight, and humor. His legacy consists not only in many successful singers, but in voice teachers who continue to pass on his techniques to another generation. He is survived by his wife Ilka and his brother Paul. A memorial service will be held at the Chapel of the Holy Innocents, Bard College, 30 Campus Road, Red Hook, NY on Tuesday, March 27th at 2pm.

New federal rules giving consumers more information and flexibility when they book air travel took effect this week. Travelers, for instance, can now change or cancel a reservation within 24 hours and receive a full refund without penalty. The rule applies only if the reservation was booked at least a week in advance of the flight's departure.

President Obama's State of the Union address on Tuesday underwhelmed by one significant measure: with 37.8 million television viewers, it was the least watched of the three he has delivered since 2010. And according to a new analysis of viewing patterns during the speech, interest was on the decline from the beginning. More than a quarter of the people who started watching on network television at 9 p.m. Eastern tuned out within the first five minutes - before the president even began speaking.

DAVOS, Switzerland -- In the lofty atmosphere of Davos during the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, a spontaneous debate about the state of the world can break out anywhere - even in a snow-covered parking lot with ski slopes in the background. That is where Flurina Marugg and Peter Real squared off Friday. Ms. Marugg wore a ''no new fighter jets'' button on her headband. Mr. Real sported a knitted hat with the Davos ski area logo.

A Madison Avenue art dealer, Robert Scott Cook, has been charged with defrauding a client of 16 artworks by Picasso, Manet, Matisse, Renoir and others worth more than $4.2 million, the United States Attorney's Office in Manhattan announced on Thursday. Over a period of six years Mr. Cook, the principal of Cook Fine Art, secretly sold watercolors, drawings and photographs to galleries and auction houses behind the owner's back, according to the attorney's office. The F.B.I.'s assistant director in charge in New York, Janice K. Fedarcyk, said the charge ''is that Mr. Cook is a crook.'' If convicted he faces a maximum of 20 years in jail and a $250,000 fine. The attorney's office did not identify the client, but this past summer Courthouse News reported that a man named George Ball had filed suit against Mr. Cook and his wife in Manhattan federal court, in which he accused Mr. Cook of taking $5.3 million he got for selling works by Matisse, Picasso, Egon Schiele, and Wassily Kandinsky owned by Mr. Ball.

Nederlander Presentations announced on Sunday that it would stage a new production of the four-time Tony Award-nominated musical "Jekyll & Hyde." The show features music from the composer Frank Wildhorn, who has struggled with a string of flops, including two short-lived 2011 productions, "Bonnie & Clyde" and "Wonderland." Although "Jekyll & Hyde" is arguably the most well-known of Mr. Wildhorn's works, with an original run on Broadway lasting more than three and a half years, the show failed to turn a profit before it closed in 2001. Constantine Maroulis ("Rock of Ages") will play both central characters; the book and lyrics are by Leslie Bricusse. The producers are aiming for a spring 2013 arrival on Broadway after a 25-week national tour scheduled to begin on Oct. 2 in San Diego.

Ah, Florida. The state looms large in Republican politics, not just because its primary on Tuesday will involve the largest, most diverse electorate yet. Republicans in Florida played kingmaker to Senator John McCain when he won its primary in 2008, but Barack Obama ultimately won the general election. DAVOS, Switzerland -- When I set out to report at the World Economic Forum, I imagined it might be difficult to find technology-related stories. It turns out, I was a tad wrong. What do Bill Belichick, Tom Coughlin, Sean Payton and Jim Harbaugh have in common? They ranked among the top eight N.F.L. coaches in aggressiveness on going for it on fourth down this season. That shouldn't be a huge surprise. Those four coaches are highly respected and very successful. And if there is one thing all N.F.L. statistical analysts agree on,  coaches should go for it on fourth down more often.

LOS ANGELES -- The Directors Guild of America honored a bespectacled filmmaker for his love of classic Hollywood cinema, and he was a Frenchman: Michel Hazanavicius won the prize for best feature from the organization, whose choices usually dovetail with the Oscars. (Pundits quickly called it: "The Artist" will win best picture at the Academy Awards.) On Saturday night, Mr. Hazanavicius beat out Martin Scorsese, Woody Allen, Alexander Payne and David Fincher.

Traversing the Bundelkhand region, traditionally considered the stronghold of Mayawati, chief minister of Uttar Pradesh, the journalist Revati Laul finds that the elephant - the symbol of the Bahujan Samaj Party (B.S.P.) - has lost its draw. In a piece titled "Dalit and the dominoes" in Tehelka, Ms. Laul analyzes the reasons behind this shift in perception and how it might affect the outcome of the state assembly elections scheduled for February. With devastating drought and farmer suicides growing at an alarming rate in her voter base, disgruntled farmers from the dalit, or untouchable, caste have begun to voice their discontent. Ms. Laul speculates that this might mean that the B.S.P. will not sweep Uttar Pradesh with the sizable majority it achieved in 2007, leading to instability in the state and a possible harbinger to an era of coalition politics.

For the first time since the Iranian nuclear threat emerged in the mid-1990s, at least some of Israel’s most powerful leaders believe that the conditions for an Israeli assault have been met.
Missing the big game means having restaurants (and more) all to yourself.
Jayne Ann Krentz, whose paranormal romance “Copper Beach” hits the fiction list at No. 8, is an ardent defender of her genre, arguing that romances are by nature feminist and subversive.

Snapshots from the life and training of a flyweight hoping to be among the first women boxers to compete in the Olympics.

LIPPINCOTT--Rosemond, 97, on January 16, 2012, at Mayflower Place Nursing Center, West Yarmouth, MA. Born Summit, NJ, to Dr. Henry M. and Mary O'Reilly. Kent Place School, '32; Wellesley College, '36. Predeceased by husband Job H. Lippincott. Resided Chatham, NJ, 1937-77; Nantucket, MA, 1977-85; and thereafter on Cape Cod. She was a generous volunteer in all her communities. Kent Place trustee, alumnae secretary; President, Cape Cod Wellesley Club. Survived by daughter Sara Lippincott, Pasadena, CA; son Job H. Lippincott III (wife Catherine), Cuyahoga Falls, OH; two grandchildren, five great- grandchildren. Burial was private. Donations in her name may be made to Development Office, Wellesley College, Wellesley, MA 02481, or Development Office, Kent Place School, Summit, NJ 07902.

The competition to be the N.B.A. Development League's equivalent of the film character Crash Davis may soon be on, with reports that the former N.B.A. guard Rafer Alston is looking to sign with one of the league's teams. Should he land a deal, Alston would become part of a growing list of familiar veterans in an often unfamiliar league.

GRUENFELD--Martin, age 83, passed away on January 27, 2012 after a brief illness. Beloved father, grandfather and brother. He is survived by his children Marlene Malmut, Jeffery Gruenfeld and Hedy Simpson and four grandchildren. Passionate about life, Martin was a Holocaust Survivor. He owned Southdown Supermarket in Huntington, NY with his brother Jack. He will be missed by all.

ULANOFF--Edwin Sinclair, Born 1925, passed away on January 26th in Del Ray Beach, FL from complications due to Alzheimer's. Ed grew up in Flatbush, Brooklyn and attended James Madison High where he began a lifelong dedication to sportsmanship and teamwork as Captain of their tennis team. From 1943-1945 Ed served in World War II as an Air Force Bombardier. Upon returning home he continued his education at Penn State earning his teaching degree and playing football. After graduation, he began his life-changing career in education being a dedicated advocate for so many students. He pioneered Midget Football in the US where he coached The Green Hornets. He also coached his Creston basketball team to the district championship. In 1955, he realized his greatest dream and passion and became came Owner and Director of Crane Lake Camp, in the Berkshires. He started the camp with his brother Stanley and sister-in law Tooty. He ran Crane Lake with his beloved wife Barbara for over 45 years. After retiring from teaching he partnered in the travel business with future son-in-law Arthur Singer and working side by side with his daughter Robin. Throughout all this he continued to build and create an amazing and flourishing Crane Lake Camp until 1998 with his expertise, guidance, vision, and love. He created a magical place where everyone who entered was changed forever. Crane Lake Camp was a place where memories and dreams became a reality. Edwin Sinclair Ulanoff, a handsome, vibrant, warm and generous man who spent his life as a Physical Education coach, a teacher, a guidance counselor and a camp owner. His motivation, encouragement, sense of humor and dedication helped shape the lives of others throughout his life. He lived life to its fullest. Ed is survived by his loving wife, best friend, and partner of 50 years Barbara, children Robin, Barry, Stuart and Lauren, sons-in-law Arthur and Todd and daughter-in-law Paula. His brother Stanley, sister Leona and sister-in-law Tooty. Grandchildren Zach, Rachel, Will, Amanda, Michelle and Casey, and many adoring extended relatives, pets, and life-long friends. He will rest alongside his parents Samuel and Minnie and his paternal grandparents Harrison and Rose Ulanoff. Funeral services are at the Riverside Memorial Chapel - 180 West 76th St., at 11am, Sunday, January 29, 2012.

''What did we learn today? Things are bad, and they're not improving at the rate that they want them to improve.'' Kevin Logan, chief United States economist at HSBC, talking about the Federal Reserve Board. The Fed said last week that in an effort to spur growth, it would extend by 18 months the period that it plans to hold down interest rates. ''This is all about transparency.'' Sean Kane, co-founder of Safety Research and Strategies, an auto consulting firm, after it filed a freedom of information lawsuit to get a federal agency's records of its investigation into the unintended acceleration of a Toyota Prius last year.

SOMACH--Barbara Joan (nee Siegel), age 79, died on January 25, 2012. Loving mother of Brian Moss and Cara Londin, cherished mother-in-law of Joy and Robert. Glowingly proud grandmother of Samantha, Zachary, Josh and Dillon. Beloved wife of Martin (deceased). Fabulous friend to so many, especially in Great Neck, NY and Siesta Key, Florida. Dr. Somach was an amazing educator and scholar having honed her craft at New York University, Brooklyn College and Bank Street College of Education. She applied her vast knowledge and passion for children and education as a skilled Professor of Early Childhood and Elementary Education at Queens College (CUNY), administrator of a program at Long Island Jewish Hospital for disabled children, dedicated mentor and patron for the CLASP after-school program in the Great Neck School system and published author on various education-related topics. Barbara will be remembered for her compassion and friendship, her many original songs and poems in honor of major milestones and celebrations, a fierce dedication to completing the Sunday NYT crossword puzzle and her love of the arts and of travel. Funeral services Sunday at 11:30am, Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck.

Global Entry, a program that allows low-risk travelers entering the United States to bypass Customs agents and be screened at kiosks instead, will expand and become permanent. The news was recently announced by President Obama as part of a series of actions by his administration intended to increase travel and tourism to the United States. Global Entry was created as a pilot program in 2008, and is administered by United States Customs and Border Protection, part of the Department of Homeland Security. Currently, United States citizens, legal permanent residents and foreign travelers from some countries are eligible for pre-approval.

An article last Sunday about Jeremy Gleick, a student at the University of California, Los Angeles, who devotes an hour a day to self-learning, misstated the length of time he has been doing this. It has been two and a half years, not four. The article also misidentified his major. It is bioengineering -- not engineering and neuropsychology.

LINDSAY--Robert Van Cleef (Rod) of Manhattan, NY, and Wellington, FL, and former President of J.P. Morgan & Co., Inc. and its principle subsidiary, Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died peacefully of complications from pneumonia at the age of 86 in West Palm Beach, FL, surrounded by family, in the hospice wing of Good Samaritan Hospital. He died just after the stroke of midnight, Friday, January 20, 2012. Born just after the stroke of midnight, January 1st, 1926, Rod was the son of George Nelson Lindsay and Florence Eleanor Vliet Lindsay of New York City and Oyster Bay. The youngest of five, he attended Buckley School and graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, NH in 1943. He served in the U.S. Merchant Marine and the U.S. Army Transportation Corps, enlisting when he was seventeen. Upon his return, he attended Yale University, where he majored in Spanish Literature. He graduated from Yale in 1949 and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. In 1950, Rod wed Nancy Adams Dalley, the beautiful sister of his close friend Larry Dalley. He was the devoted father of daughters Cammy (Robert E. Justice) and Tinker Lindsay, and son Robert D. Lindsay (Teresa Elms Lindsay); beloved grandfather of Jon and Drew Warkentin, Thomas and Dorothy Beatty, and Roddy, Pitch, Alec and Duncan Lindsay, and delighted great-grandfather of Adeline and Daisy Pidduck. Rod was predeceased by his wife, Nancy, three older brothers, George Nelson, John Vliet, and David Alexander Lindsay, and his older sister, Eleanor Lindsay Schieffelin. He maintained close connections until his own death with his widespread extended family. In 1949, Rod joined J.P. Morgan & Co., Inc., where he spent his entire career. He became a Vice-President in 1960, and Senior Vice-President in 1969. In 1973, he was named General Manager of Morgan Guaranty's London Offices. Elected Executive Vice-President in 1976, he returned to New York. In 1978 he became Chairman of the Executive Committee and a Director of the holding company. In 1980, he was elected President. He retired in 1986 to pursue his many other interests. Rod served as a Director of Russell Reynolds Corporation, Chubb Corporation, Fluor Corporation, First Hudson Valley Bank, J.P. Morgan (Suisse) S.A. and as U.S. Adviser to Unibank Denmark AlS, Copenhagen. He was a member of the International Council of Insitut European d'Administration des Affaires (INSEAD), the Conference Board, the International Monetary Conference, and the Council of Ditchley and Cooperation Ireland. Rod gave generously of his time to numerous nonprofit organizations. He was Chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, served for twenty years as the Director of the New York Philharmonic Society and six years as Chairman of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. He was Treasurer of the Long Island Biological Association and a founding board member of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. He was a trustee of the ASPCA, the National Board of the Smithsonian Associates, Cooper Union, East Woods School, and St. Paul's School. He served as Treasurer of the Downtown Lower Manhattan Association, and founding director of the New York City Development Corp. Purebred dogs played a prominent role in Rod's life. He and Nancy were very active in the dog show world, breeding and showing Basset Hounds and Bloodhounds out of their Lime Tree Kennels. Rod served as President and longtime AKC Delegate for the American Bloodhound Club, and President of the Long Island Kennel Club. In addition, Rod was the longest standing member of the Westminster Kennel Club - a member since 1959 and served as president of the WKC from 1969-1972. He also served as vice resident four times, as vice chair of the show committee, and as Chief ring steward for many years. He was a trustee of Westminster Kennel Foundation, which he helped to create. In 2011, the Westminster members awarded him its prestigious Sensation Award for his contributions to the club. Rod had numerous other interests, including jazz, chamber music, fly-fishing, opera, travel, carriage driving, show jumping, art collecting, horse breeding, reading, and collecting first editions of authors such as E. Phillips Oppenheim and Ludwig Bemelmens. Rod was a faithful member of the Episcopal Church, and a loyal parishioner wherever he lived. A student of both history and human nature, Rod avoided politics, but was active in his older brother John's eight-year tenure as Mayor of New York. Yet all of these passions paled in comparison to his devotion to his wife, Nancy, to whom he was married for fifty-eight years. During their long, full life together, they set up households all over the world, moving over a dozen times. Wherever they landed, their home quickly became a magnet for great food, drink, music and conversation among multi-generational friends from every walk of life. In 2008, Nancy succumbed to a brain tumor, which she had valiantly fought for a decade. Rod remained devoted to her and her care even as he fought Parkinson's Disease for the better part of fifteen years himself. Following her death he moved back into Manhattan one last time to revisit the vibrant city where he was born, reacquainting himself with jazz at Dizzy's, mussels at La Mangeoire, and Shepherd's Pie at Parnell's, and organizing various gatherings and reunions at his much loved Yale, Links and Leash Clubs. Rod's modest demeanor belied his many talents. He was a brilliant thinker, consummate storyteller, and voracious reader, and routinely completed the Times Sunday Crossword puzzle in record time, in ink. A true Renaissance man, Rod displayed a rare combination of intelligence, loyalty, humility, humor and practicality. He had impeccable judgment regarding people, places and things, without ever being judgmental. He died peacefully and painlessly, looking forward to rejoining his beloved Nancy. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY, at 11am on Saturday, March 3rd, 2012. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH 03301; The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023; or The Westminster Kennel Foundation, 149 Madison Ave., Suite 402, New York, NY 10016.

IN Milwaukee, a city best known for its blue-collar roots, an artistic side is starting to emerge, particularly in an area known as the Third Ward. In the mid-19th century, the port city was known for its high volume of wheat trade before becoming a machine shop for the world. Immigrants -- mostly Italian and Irish -- settled in the Third Ward, thanks to its proximity to the city's docks and factories. In 1892, a huge fire destroyed most of the neighborhood. Though it made a modest comeback over the next decades as the city's Little Italy, by the 1960s, expressway construction through the area sent many of its remaining residents packing. Led by the Historic Third Ward Association, revitalization efforts over the past few years have transformed the district into a cultural magnet. Galleries now share blocks with design boutiques, trendy cafes and a public market. And a boardwalk that runs along Milwaukee River, a continuing project that saw a major portion completed in 2005, gives the area a distinctly European flair. STEPHANIE DAVILA
LOEWENTHAL--Wynn, died at age 84, retired Publicist for Warner Bros films. We treasure the memories. Love, Erica, Peter & Max.

Here's a reader's comment on Patrick Healy's article about ''Smash,'' a new prime-time soap on NBC that focuses on Broadway. ''Mr. Healy's article has it that ' ''Smash'' is the best shot for the theater capital to reveal itself to the rest of America.' Having sampled the 'Smash' pilot via on demand, I'd encourage the rest of America to consider renting 'Every Little Step,' the 2008 documentary about a Broadway revival of 'A Chorus Line.' It's a much more compelling look at the Broadway musical.''

STABLER--Robert Coleman, 76, of Skillman, New Jersey, died January 20 at home after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Mary; children Julie Hull (Tom), Ted (Martha Embrey), Larry (Betsy), Peggy Fischer, and Peter (Martha); ten grandchildren; his sister, Elizabeth; and brother, George. He graduated from Yale University in 1955 and earned a PhD. in Theoretical Physics from Cornell University in 1960. Mr. Stabler worked for Ford Aerospace in Newport Beach, David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, Smith Barney in New York, and Penvest Company in Princeton. He dedicated much of his time to research in theoretical physics and published several papers in Physical Review Letters. An avid outdoorsman, Mr. Stabler had a love of the mountains and the home he built in Breckenridge, Colorado, where he and Mary lived from 1997 to 2009. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Princeton Hospice Program at Princeton HealthCare System Foundation.

The Dukes London hotel has created several initiatives catering to women, including 19 new Dutchess Rooms (one is shown above) with fresh flowers and size-appropriate slippers and robes, and female staff members who are escorts at check-in. As a result, the hotel says, bookings by women have surged 30 percent in the last two months. The program is part of a trend. The 180-room Georgian Court Hotel Downtown Vancouver has created an Orchid Floor -- a women-only floor of 18 rooms with flat irons, yoga mats and beauty products. In Copenhagen at the 814-room Bella Sky Comwell, the 20-room Bella Donna floor is available to female guests by an elevator key card.

Because of an editing error, an essay last Sunday about education in the digital age referred incorrectly to Derek Bok. He served as president of Harvard until 1991, so he was not the immediate predecessor of Lawrence Summers, who took office in 2001. (Neil L. Rudenstine preceded Mr. Summers.)

HOWARD--Barnaby J. The son of a British lord, who grew up to be a pilot with the British and United States Navies during World War II and later a farmer in Southern Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) before returning to America to set up a successful investment company (CAIMS), died December 18 at home in Orange Park, FL at age 86 after a courageous battle with multiple myeloma. Educated at the storied schools of Eton, Trinity College, Cambridge and Harvard, his adventurous life would lead him from the isle of Colonsay, Scotland to Africa, France, Canada, and the United States. In seeking his fortune overseas, he lived in the tradition of his great-grandfather Donald Smith who left Scotland in the 19th century and became one of the great figures of Canadian history. He is survived by his wife, Evie, two brothers, Euan, Lord Strathcona and Mount Royal of Great Britain, and Jonathon Howard of Sweden; two daughters Elizabeth de Laperouse and Sarah Thomasson, both of St. Louis, MO; five step-children from the Bishop family: Janie Putnam of Bedminster, NY, Nat Bishop of Barrington, RI, Cindy Dickey of Philadelphia, PA, Priscilla Henry of Sewickley, PA, and Linda Moody of Wellesley, MA; 18 grandchildren, four great-grandchildren, and numerous nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his son AlanHoward and his sister Didon Faber. Memorial services will be held at Grace Episcopal Church, Orange Park, FL on February 4 and at Holy Trinity Church, London, England on March 16, 2012. Visit www.barnyhoward.com for more about his life and favorite charities.

4:29 p.m. | Updated TAMPA, Fla. - NBC News is asking that the Romney campaign remove from its ads any references to material from the network in response to a new commercial that consists almost entirely of old footage of its former news anchor, Tom Brokaw, reporting on Newt Gingrich's legal troubles. The ad, which uses a 1997 clip from the day Mr. Gingrich was found guilty by the House of ethics violations, prompted a terse statement from Mr. Brokaw on Saturday in which he expressed concern that his work was being used for political purposes he never intended.

HALPER DICKSON--Sari. January 30, 2009. Three years. An extraordinary mother, wife, sister and daughter. Sorely missed, needed and adored by Zachary (4), Aleksander (6) and Diana (8), John, Shauna and Barbara. She is our song.

Wearing the automaker's new corporate face, the Ford Fusion Nascar Sprint Cup racecar was unveiled at a news conference by Ford and Nascar Tuesday afternoon at Charlotte Motor Speedway. The car will be campaigned in 2013, making its race debut at the Daytona 500 in February of next year. Ford tried Tuesday to set the Fusion apart from other factory-team racecars in the series, which tend not to resemble the production vehicles on which they're nominally based.

A biographical note last Sunday with the Q&A column, in which Yolanda Edwards discussed her experience traveling with a child, included incorrect information from Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia about Ms. Edwards's position with the company. She is executive editor at Martha Stewart Living magazine, not an editor-at-large for the company. The note also referred incompletely to her association with momfilter.com. She is a co-founder of the site, not just a contributor.

GRUNSCHLAG--Rosi. Steinway notes with profound sorrow the passing of the eminent pianist, Rosi Grunschlag on January 15th in New York City. Rosi was born in Vienna and studied at the State Academy of Music together with her sister Toni, who died almost exactly five years ago. Rosi came to the United States in 1939. It was in 1940 that Olin Downes, the distinguished critic of The New York Times heard the sisters play at Steinway Hall and encouraged them to pursue a career as duo-pianists. Their playing was characterized by a seamless blending of two distinct personalities which produced a complete musical unity. Their programs showed a wide range of styles from the classical repertoire to compositions by contemporary composers. Some works were written especially for them. A documentary entitled "Toni & Rosi," an account of their long life together is scheduled to be broadcasted on Sunday, January 29th on BBC4 Television. Rosi will be greatly missed and long remembered by her family, friends and students.

More than a century after men first boxed in the modern Olympics, women will finally get a shot, when their sport makes its Olympic debut at the London Games this summer. For American hopefuls, the next step in the long gantlet of getting there takes place a couple of weeks from now outside Spokane, Wash., at the U.S. Olympic Team Trials. Twenty-four women will compete; three will survive. Those three -- one boxer each from the flyweight (112 pounds), lightweight (132 pounds) and middleweight (165 pounds) divisions -- will then advance to the Women's World Championships in May in Qinhuangdao, China. The top eight in their weight classes there will take their fight to London. Olympic bouts will consist of four two-minute rounds, compared with three three-minute rounds for the men. Tiara Brown, one of the trialists on these pages, probably speaks for her fellow contenders when she says: ''I'm not a girl boxer. I'm just a boxer. I'm not doing this for women. I want to be treated the way the guys are treated. Not special because I'm a girl.''

A picture caption on Page 11 this weekend with the 36 Hours column, about Birmingham, England, reverses the identification of a bar scene at the Bull's Head and the Rag Market, a collection of retail stalls. The Rag Market is at the left and the Bull's Head is at the right.

An entry in the ''What's on Today'' television highlights last Sunday for a documentary about the folk singer Phil Ochs misidentified the WNET program on which it was shown and which was starting its 26th season. It was ''American Masters,'' not ''American Experience.''

MATES--Harriette Katzenberg died January 23, 2012. Devoted wife of 64 years to Jack. Loving mother of Mary-Anne, Judy and John and six grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Ruvo Brain Center of the Cleveland Clinic.

ALISON PRICE BECKER has always created a cozy, irresistibly romantic atmosphere in her restaurants, most notably at Alison on Dominick. (Remember those sexy blue banquettes?) For her highly anticipated return to the Manhattan dining scene with Alison Eighteen, a Flatiron district spot that will open on Tuesday, Ms. Price Becker asked the artist Payton Cosell Turner and her husband, Brian Kaspr, to create a wallpaper that depicted all of her favorite things. The result is a toile of hand-drawn and hand-screened animal caricatures, New York food scenes and Alison herself. There are images of wind turbines (to represent sustainability), a dog reading Page Six, people falling in love and hanging out. And there's Alison's mascot: a chicken with a wineglass on her head. It's cheeky and fresh. The colors are eggplant and red (the original black-and-white drawing is shown here). ''This is about having pure fun and a night on the town,'' she said. Alison Eighteen, 15 West 18th Street. JULIE EARLE-LEVINE

PROCTOR--Shizu, 99, on January 24, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Aunt of Ron Sakai and Norm Ohama. Shizu was a Educator and World Traveler. A service will be held in Rancho Palos Verdes, CA, followed by interment in Green Hills Memorial Park.

''My first Tod's piece was a Gommini loafer,'' said Jefferson Hack, a founder of Dazed & Confused and editor of AnOther and AnOther Man magazines. ''Diego invited me to have it made to my personal specifications,'' he added, referring to Diego Della Valle, the chief executive of Tod's. And so it began. One trip to the company's headquarters in Le Marche, Italy, and Mr. Della Valle, the chief executive, was asking Mr. Hack to design a capsule collection that would bring the British Mr. Hack's subversive-cool aesthetic to the storied Italian house. The collection -- featuring seven styles (four for women, three for men), including sea blue suede lace-up ankle shoes and patent leather slipper flats -- ''breaks with convention and is untethered to the formal codes of dress or casual attire,'' Mr. Della Valle said by way of explaining the capsule's name: No-Code. ''If I had to choose only one style, it would be the lace-up.'' As for Mr. Hack? He favors the slipper. ''This is fresh to me,'' he said. Tod's No-Code lace-up shoes, $545. At Tod's, (212) 644-5945. EDWARD BARSAMIAN

An article last Sunday about the popularity of Tulum, Mexico, as a vacation destination for fashion industry figures contained an outdated reference to Ambra Medda, who was married there at the Posada Margherita. She runs a design consulting agency in New York; she is no longer the director of Design Miami, a job now held by Marianne Goebl. The article also contained an outdated reference to Camilla Nickerson, a guest at the Casa Magna hotel in Tulum. She is a contributing editor at Vogue; she no longer works at W. And a caption with five pictures misidentified several of them. The pictures with their correct captions can be seen in a slide show at nyti.ms/wfuis9.

COLE--Benjamin S. Benjamin S. Cole (Ben) passed from this life at the age of 87 on January 4, 2012 at his home in Boston, Massachusetts in the loving arms of his wife of forty-one years, Rose Marie Cole (nee Cupit); surviving from his previous marriage are his three sons Jonathan, Daniel and William Cole, and two daughters Louise Nicollet and Virginia Starr Cole; as well as eleven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Mr. Cole was born on June 28, 1924 to Rachel and Louis Cohen in Brooklyn, New York where he graduated with honors from Boys' High School and at the age of sixteen was director of the radio show "Student Workshop". During his junior year at university, Ben enlisted in the US Army. He graduated from Officer Candidate School in the late summer of 1944 and proudly served as a Lieutenant under Colonel Guinn Goodrich in the 18th Tank Battalion of the Eighth Armored Division. Ben was awarded the Bronze Star for his service in the Battle of the Bulge and served for another eighteen months in the occupation, after which, he returned to his studies and graduated with honors from New York University. Ben was a visionary and an entrepreneur all his life, with an intuitive knack for recognizing human potential. During his early years, after the war, he worked as a labor arbitrator for several companies. In the 1950's he founded US Transfer, an executive search firm. Later in the decade, he went on to found Cole & Associates, which started as a management consulting firm. Ben broke new ground in the field of management consulting by focusing on family-owned businesses, though he later branched out into the broader arena of management counseling, while continuing the search activities. Another division, Cole Surveys, was started in the early 1960's. Cole Surveys revolutionized data gathering and analysis for bank officer compensation by developing and adopting database management techniques through the use of early computing. The annual release of the Bank Officer Salary Survey was awaited with anticipation and considered the "compensation bible" of the industry garnering the business of all the top one hundred US banks and thousands of others in the United States and abroad. A successful enterprise, Cole & Associates, Inc. was acquired in 1975 by the Wyatt Corporation. The framework of the acquisition exists today as part of Towers Watson Data Services. Ben served as a Director and Vice President of Wyatt, and President of the acquired entity, while continuing to lead important compensation consulting engagements until 1989, when he retired. Unlike many, Ben looked at retirement as just another opportunity to engage his entrepreneurial thinking. First, he started Ben S. Cole Financial Incorporated (Cole Financial) serving as a consultant in corporate governance to many major banking institutions in the United States and abroad. Additionally, he saw the breakdown of the Soviet Union, and its return to a Russian Federation of states as a frontier filled with promise. To enable his vision, he founded, and was CEO and Chairman of Cole Management Incorporated (CMI), a Boston-based investment company aimed at investing in and growing businesses in Russia and other countries of the former Soviet Union. Through CMI, he served on a blue ribbon panel appointed by the office of the Mayor of St. Petersburg to consider major infrastructure projects for the city. At the request of Mayor Sobchak, Ben developed a restructuring plan for the Bank of Leningrad in connection with its privatization one of the first bank privatizations in the Soviet Union. Mr. Cole began investing in Russian entities in the early 1990's. Most importantly, he participated in investments in Russia's technology sector, including investments in Yandex, CompTek International and InfiNet Wireless Ltd. At Yandex, the leading internet search company in Russia, he was a non-executive director from 2000 2012 and served as the Chairman of their board of directors from 2000 until July 2008, when he became Chairman Emeritus. Upon learning of Ben's passing, Arkady Volozh, CEO of Yandex, wrote, "As one of our founding directors, Ben was a guiding force for our company. We will greatly miss his leadership, business acumen and friendship. Our hearts go out to Ben's wife, Rose and his family." Ben was a man of great faith and boundless energy, compelled to make a positive contribution to the world. He had a profound and endearing effect on others. Ben's great warmth and vision, fun loving, compassionate, tenacious and loyal disposition made him a great mentor, advocate and friend. Ben loved fine art, music and literature. He had a beautiful voice and blessed many with his singing. His passion for life, for humanity itself was boundless. He never stopped challenging himself and serving others. A private Burial Service with military honors was held at Mount Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, MA. A Memorial Service to honor Ben's life is planned, date to be announced. In honor of Ben's profound wish, please make donations to fund pancreatic cancer research, c/o The Benjamin S. Cole Charitable Foundation - PRIA, Citizens Bank, Michael J. Dasaro, 28 State Street, Boston, MA 02109. Friends and family are encouraged to share memories and condolences online at www.legacy.com.

TOPPER--Charlotte, beloved wife of David and cherished mother of Gail and Susan, died peacefully on January 26 at 84. Her class, beauty, intelligence, humor and warmth will be missed and forever in our hearts.

During a visit to a high school English class in the Bronx, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg revealed his love for the John le Carre classic, ''Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy.'' His literary leaning even inspired a rare trip to the cinema to catch the new movie version of the book. Read the related article.
WEISSMAN--Alisha. "One sees clearly ONLY with the heart. Anything essential is invisible to the eyes". Arlene & Robert

David Shrigley is a master of the incompetent line. An English artist based in Glasgow, he has made photographs, sculptures and animations, but he's best known for hauntingly funny drawings, rendered in an exquisitely unsteady freehand. His output is prolific: his drawings, in addition to appearing in galleries and museums, festoon T-shirts and greeting cards; he wrote the libretto for an opera about cooking; he has published dozens of books and released a spoken-word CD. But lately he has been under particularly intense pressure to produce. In February, London's Hayward Gallery will mount a major survey of his work. To stuff the show with new art, he says, he had to trick himself into thinking he wasn't actually making art at all. In a spiral notebook, he jotted down 180 ideas for 180 pieces. WOLFMAN--Bernard. Public Memorial Service on February 3, 2012 at 3pm, Caspersen Room, Langdell Library, Harvard Law School.

Dick Tufeld, who possessed one of Hollywood's most often-heard disembodied voices, especially from the 1950s through the 1970s, announcing or narrating television shows like ''Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea'' and commercials for products like Mr. Bubble bubble bath and Gallo wine, but who was best known for his electronic intonations as the robot in the loopy science-fiction series ''Lost in Space,'' died on Sunday at his home in the Studio City section of Los Angeles. He was 85. The cause was congestive heart failure, his daughter Lynn said.

To the Sports Editor: The fans of the Indianapolis Colts and Peyton Manning are extending a warm welcome to the fans of the Giants and Eli Manning. You are traveling to friendly territory. We wish you the best in the coming Super Bowl and hope you have a repeat of the championship game in 2008.

ELBERG--Gail. The All Stars Project is deeply saddened by the passing of one of our foremost groundbreakers, Gail Elberg. Gail devoted her life to organizing in poor communities to bring about positive social change. Born in Brooklyn in 1948, she became a VISTA volunteer on the Fallon Indian Reservation in Nevada. In the 1970s, in the midst of New York City's devastating fiscal crisis, she was a pioneer organizer of the New York City Unemployed and Welfare Council. This 10,000-member union of the poor was the first to seek collective bargaining rights for welfare recipients. Later, she would focus her extraordinary organizing talents on creating an award-winning volunteer program for the All Stars Project. She involved thousands of people from all walks of life, rich and poor and everyone in between; providing them with creative opportunities to give back to the city's most disempowered and disadvantaged communities. Gail was a powerful public advocate for volunteerism, serving on the boards of the NY Association for Volunteer Administration and the Association of Leaders in Volunteer Engagement. Under her direction, the All Stars volunteer program won the National Points of Light Award and was designated by Mutual of New York as the best volunteer site for working people. A tireless champion of the underdog, Gail battled a brain tumor for two and a half years, showing the same boundless energy and optimism with which she lived her life. Her incredible community organizing skills, her keen intelligence and her offbeat sense of humor made her admired and loved by everyone she touched. She will be so deeply missed. Gabrielle L. Kurlander President and CEO All Stars Project, Inc.
PESCATELLO--Michael C. Great counselor and a lifelong friend. Our deepest sympathy to his family, especially his wife Kiki. Carlton and Florence Asher

An article last Sunday about the effect of big-time sports on college life misstated part of the name of an honor society that has 17 members from Ohio State. It is the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, not the National Academy of Arts and Sciences.

CAMELO--Jairo (Jay), 41, passed away suddenly on January 18, 2012. Born in Bogota, Colombia and raised on Staten Island, Jay attended the High School of Art and Design, received his Bachelor of Architecture degree with honors at Pratt University, and was the recipient of the Pratt National Talent Search Award. He was a devoted husband to wife Semra and father to three year old son Kaan, a loving son to mother Betty, brother to Sandra, Diana and Monica and families. A senior architect with Michael Neumann Architecture, Jay was respected and loved by all who worked with him. He was a compassionate and humorous friend, a talented award winning designer, and a passionate dancer and soccer player. The funeral was held privately. In lieu of flowers, the family respectfully asks that donations be sent to the "Trust For The Benefit of Kaan Camelo," MNA, 127 West 24th St., 7th Floor, NY, NY 10011.

When Thomas Holton began visiting the Lam family in 2003, he was struck by how much life they fit inside their 350-square-foot apartment on Ludlow Street in Manhattan. Three small children, their parents, relatives and friends, a bathtub in the kitchen, with clothes racks above the table. It was a jumble that fascinated him for its grit, warmth and can-do optimism. But as Mr. Holton got to know the Lams, he became less interested in their square-foot compromises and more intrigued with them as individuals, not only as immigrants. ''It became much more a story about any family,'' said Mr. Holton, 42. ''It didn't matter that they were Chinese. It became much more about life in general and the dynamics of a family.''
