HAZARD--Donald Thomson, formerly of Chappaqua, NY, died January 15, 2012 after a brief illness. Born in 1928 in Providence, RI, he graduated from Brown University in 1950. He worked for IBM for 34 years, retiring as a Director of New Product Development. He enjoyed sailing, skiing and golf. He is survived by his wife Barbara, and sons Steven (Loree) of Newburyport, MA, David (Stephanie) and Scott (Lucy), both of New Canaan, CT, a brother Robert (Cleo) of North Kingstown, RI, and two grandchildren. A private service was held at Christ Church in Exeter, NH on Saturday, January 21, 2012. Donations/tributes may be made in his honor to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation at http://www.pulmonaryfibrosis.org.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Israel's Improbables,'' Jan. 26: Kiryat Shmona's soccer players helped the town overcome conflict and unite Arabs and Israelis in rallying behind them as they rise to the international stage as a championship team. Tying in the history of the city and its team's fortunes enabled me to connect on a human level with the people in a place so often described in terms of politics and strife. I think that the world can learn from the unity fostered among citizens of this town. Arik Legman

KRANIK--John Robert. The Kranik family lost a cherished husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle and hero on January 25, 2012. John Robert Kranik lived his life with no regrets and will forever be remembered as the consummate father, loving husband, thoughtful friend, accomplished businessman, skilled athlete, continuous learner and world traveler who lived every single day to its fullest. John was born on January 30, 1941 in Jersey City, NJ to John Bolislaw Kranik and Mary Agnes Kuzniar. He received a Bachelor of Science degree in mechanical engineering from Newark (N.J.) College of Engineering in 1967, and a Master of Science degree in solid mechanics from Syracuse University in 1972. John joined IBM in Poughkeepsie, NY in 1967 as an Associate Engineer. He was appointed to management in 1976 as a Development Engineer, and progressed quickly through the engineering ranks, holding numerous senior management positions. John achieved the second Invention Achievement Award plateau and holds four United States patents. He received two Outstanding Innovation Awards and is the author of several published articles. In 1993, John was assigned by IBM to Sematech in Austin, TX, where he served as Director of Total Quality. He later worked for MKS Instruments as Senior Director of Worldwide Accounts and Manager of the Austin office until retirement in 2007. John was preceded in death by his parents, John and Mary Kranik and his first wife Sandra V. Kranik. John is lovingly survived by his wife, Melanie Kranik of Austin, TX; his children: John R. Kranik, Jr. of New York, NY; Bryan H. Kranik and his wife Christy of Austin, TX; James David Walker and his wife Vicki of Atlanta, GA; and Carrie M. Walker of Germantown, MD. In addition, John (Papa) is survived by his three, precious grandchildren whom he adored: Hudson Beau Kranik, Hannah Veronica Walker, and Morgan Riley Walker. John's sister and brother-in-law, Dorothy and James Lynch, survive in Bayville, NJ. He is also survived by his nieces Susan Mazzara and her daughter Stacy of New Jersey and Virginia Smith of New Mexico. Tim Smith, John's nephew, survives in North Carolina. A Funeral Mass will be held at 10am on Tuesday, January 31st, 2012 at Emmaus Catholic Church in Lakeway, TX. Private family burial at Forest Oaks Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, the Kranik family would like to request that donations in John's memory be made to the ALS Association South Texas Chapter, 8600 Wurz- bach Rd. Ste. 700, San Antonio, TX 78240. The family would like to thank their wonderful friends and family for the continuous love and support. Services by Weed-Corley-Fish Lake Travis, 411 Ranch Road 620 South, Lakeway, TX 78734. (512) 263-1511. Obituary and memorial guestbook available online at www.wcfish.com

Howard Cross played the most games at tight end in Giants history (207) and was a member of their 1990 Super Bowl team. The position will be in the spotlight Sunday in Super Bowl XLVI, as the Giants try to stop New England's Rob Gronkowski and Aaron Hernandez. Cross, 44, retired in 2001 after 13 seasons with 201 receptions, 17 touchdowns and countless important blocks.

The Streetscapes column on Jan. 15, about the construction of the multilayer Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in the 1940s, misidentified the officials who dealt with similar construction issues on part of the East Side Drive in Manhattan in the 1930s. It was the Manhattan borough president, Stanley Isaacs, and his staff -- not Robert Moses, who was involved in some of the park areas surrounding the East Side Drive.

ZALKIN--Leonard. Died on January 25, 2012 at home in New York City at the age of 99. Beloved Husband of the late Rosalind Zalkin for over 71 years. Adored father of Linda Z. Redding and the late Kenneth G. Zalkin. Devoted father-in-law of Janet L. Zalkin and Roy N. Redding. Proud grandfather of Garret A. Baum and his wife Karen Baum, Courtney J. Avichouser, Austin L. Zalkin and his wife Dr. Victoria K. Zalkin, and Justin L. Zalkin. Also surviving are four great-grandchildren: Makena and Hunter Avichouser, Jordon and Alex Baum; and two nieces and two nephews. AS the owner of Brook Landscape, Brook Klausing gets his clothes dirty almost daily. But that's not to say he doesn't think about what he wears. ''When I meet with new clients, I want to make sure they understand what they are going to get,'' he said. ''What I wear should say that their garden will be timeless, clean and organic with a modern undertone.'' Still, moving between the office and urban landscapes requires ''rugged clothes that hold up to the abuse'' -- waxed jackets, dark pants that obscure hand wipes, and boots that can be worn year round and that are high enough to keep dirt out. Mr. Klausing stands by the sweatshirt, like the one he's wearing here from the new Japanese-designed brand 8.15 August Fifteenth, for being the most versatile piece in his work wardrobe. Worn over a collared shirt, it has the put-together look of a knit sweater, but it's much more durable and easier to wash, and it's always shovel-ready. ''I never want to look too pretty to jump in and make something happen,'' he said. The 8.15 August Fifteenth sweatshirt, $165, is sold at Odin New York, 328 East 11th Street; (212) 475-0666. Oliver Spencer shirt, about $165; (212) 475-0079. Levi's Made and Crafted chinos, $225. Available at Brooklyn Denim; (718) 782-2600. JASON RIDER

JAQUINET--Eleanor Romig. Dennis, Massachusetts Elli Romig Jaquinet, 81. Born New York, NY, October 3, 1930, passed away at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Friday January 6, 2012. Elli graduated from Mount Holyoke in 1952, and from Harvard Graduate School of Education in 1956 with her Masters in Education. She taught at American College For Girls at Robert College in Istanbul, eventually becoming Dean of Women. She also was Dean at Pine Manor, and at Douglas College, Rutgers University. Elli had a full life spending time between Turkey, Switzerland, Cape Cod, and The U.S. Virgin Islands. She is predeceased by her husband, Louis E. Jaquinet of Aubonne, Switzerland and Dennis, a diplomat with The International Red Cross; her parents, the Rev. Dr. Edgar F. Romig and Ella D. Romig; and her two brothers, the Rev. Dr. Edgar D. Romig and the Rev. David W. Romig. A memorial service will be held this summer on the Cape. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be sent to: Cape Cod Council of Churches, Box 758, Hyannis, MA 02601.

Love, jealousy, petty resentments, rank social climbing and untrammeled ambition -- the novel has it all. A review on Jan. 15 about ''The Map and the Territory,'' a novel by Michel Houellebecq, misstated the surname of a real-life artist who is one of the subjects of a portrait painted by the book's fictional protagonist. He is Damien Hirst, not Hirsch.

An article in some editions last Sunday about an exhibition of Patti Smith's photography at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, in Hartford, Conn., misstated the cause of death for Ms. Smith's husband, Fred Smith. It was heart failure, not cancer. The article also referred imprecisely to Ms. Smith's life in the 1980s. While ''she lived through the beginning of the AIDS epidemic in New York,'' she did so in the sense of living through that experience, which included the death of her friend Robert Mapplethorpe; she did not physically live in New York. (She lived outside Detroit during that decade.)

DURING the Armani couture show the other day, I kept glancing across the runway at Jessica Chastain. Probably many people were, and all with the same thought: does she see a dress she might like to wear to the Oscar ceremony? No doubt Mr. Armani will be happy to make her something. Ms. Chastain learned she had been nominated for ''The Help'' just before the show started. People around her applauded. Maybe in all the excitement everything looked blurry. The process of picking a dress for the Oscars is a mystery to me, and I'm glad no one ever asks me for advice. I'd tell an actress to wear an incredibly simple Yohji Yamamoto dress, something chic but completely under the radar -- and, well, even I know that would never fly on the red carpet. Stylists have to deal with the politics of top houses (and a fair number of unsolicited offers), and, equally, houses have to deal with stylists and stars who often have quite different agendas. I'm not sure why we don't see more couture at the Oscars, though I'm told it's because the houses don't want to make something so costly if an actress and her stylist aren't willing to commit to a dress.

Kevin H. White, a four-term mayor of Boston who came to national prominence for shepherding the city through years of racial violence and economic stagnation -- and for a decadelong federal investigation into corruption in his administration -- died Friday night at his home in the Beacon Hill section of Boston. He was 82. His family announced his death through a spokesman, George Regan. Mr. White had been treated for Alzheimer's disease since 2003.

Wilmington. Binghamton's 67-59 defeat at Maine left it the only winless team in Division I, with an 0-20 record.

PEDOWITZ--James. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of James Pedowitz, beloved husband and father, admired for his commitment to strengthening the Jewish community. We extend our condolences to his wife, Mary; their children and their spouses, Larry and Kathleen Pedowitz, Dinah and Robert Einhorn, and David and Faith Pedowitz; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

PESCATELLO--Michael C.,67, of Tiburon, California passed away on January 22, 2012 from complications related to esophageal cancer. He was born in New York on March 29, 1944. Mr. Pescatello earned a B.A. degree from Gettysburg College and a J.D. degree from Vanderbilt University School of Law. Mr. Pescatello was a Senior Vice President at Northern Trust. He was Managing Director and Chief Fiduciary Officer of the Northern's Bay Area Region. He was with Northern Trust since 1988 when they opened the first offices in California. Mr. Pescatello was a member of the State Bars of California and New York. Prior to joining Northern Trust, he was an associate with the New York firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Later he was a Vice President in the Trust & Investment Division of Crocker National Bank. Mr. Pescatello was also active in the investment syndication business, serving in an executive capacity with several national syndication firms. Mr. Pescatello was a Director of the Marin Theater Company (Mill Valley, CA) and a Trustee of both the Hanna Boys Center (Sonoma, CA) and The Agawam Council (Raymond, ME). He was also a member of the National Advisory Board of Vanderbilt University School of Law. Mr. Pescatello was also a life member of the University Club of New York. When he joined in 1971 he believed that he was their youngest member at that time. Michael and his wife Kiki loved to travel and each year found them in a new location in Burma, in cooking school in Tuscany, riding elephants in India or on the beach at Kona, Hawaii. Michael was well known for his wicked sense of humor and his sometimes inappropriate neckties. He is survived by his wife of 34 years, Carolie (Kiki) Pescatello, his mother, Edith Pescatello of Scarsdale, New York, his sisters, Mary Lewis and Marjorie Miller and his brother Paul Pescatello. Mr. Pescatello was predeceased by his brother Edward Pescatello and his sister Anita Beddard. He will also be fondly remembered by his many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations to charities of your choice or to one of Michael's would be appreciated. (Hanna Boys Center, Post Office Box 100, Sonoma, CA 95476 or UCSF Foundation, Thoracic Oncology Program, Regan Botsford, 220 Montgomery Street, 5th Floor, San Francisco, CA 94104. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date.

D'OENCH III--Russell G.,(Toby), of New York City, (1953-2012) died of complications related to multiple myeloma on January 23, 2012. Toby was a partner at the law firm of Skadden Arps in New York City, where he worked in the Financial Institutions Group, specializing in mergers and acquisitions and private equity fund management businesses. Skadden colleagues and staff knew him for his legal acumen and caring personality. His career at Skadden came in mid-life after extensive work in the non-profit sector. He was associate director of the Center for Constitutional Rights and founder and longtime staff member of the North Star Fund. Toby also played a leadership role in the creation of the Funding Exchange, a national network of grassroots, social justice foundations. Beloved husband and father, he is survived by his wife Tani Takagi, his son Robin T. D'Oench and his daughter Miye E. D'Oench of New York City; and sister Ellen Ruimerman of Connecticut and brother Peter D'Oench of Florida. He will be remembered by family and close friends for his quiet wit, sharp mind, generosity, and love of his children's passions, hockey and film. A private memorial service is planned. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The D'Oench Family Fund at North Star Fund (checks payable to North Star Fund), 520 Eighth Avenue, Suite 2203, New York, NY 10018-6656.

NOT unlike the three gas stations on the same block that magically adjust their prices in unison, Bonhams, Gooding & Company and RM Auctions all went into the Scottsdale auction week with consistently high presale estimates in their catalogs. Yet for the most part, the cars sold within, and often even exceeded, those ambitious estimates. It wasn't just the top of the collector car market that did well. The middle of the market and the entry level showed strength, too -- enough that it's difficult to peg exactly where the entry level is these days. Here are five examples that offer some context to the trends seen in Scottsdale this year. All prices include the buyer's premium.
The Road to Woody Allen, National Treasure By Adam Leff and Richard Rushfield

What a week it was for Tim Thomas, hockey's most consistently incandescent goalie. At the end of it, rumors were flying that Thomas's days with the Bruins - the team he led last season to the Stanley Cup - are numbered. It all began Monday when Thomas, whose political beliefs were not widely known, boycotted the Bruins' visit with President Obama at the White House. Instead Thomas released a brief statement on his Facebook page that began, ''I believe the Federal government has grown out of control, threatening the Rights, Liberties, and Property of the People.''

JAQUINET--Eleanor Romig. Dennis, Massachusetts Elli Romig Jaquinet, 81. Born New York, NY, October 3, 1930, passed away at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Friday January 6, 2012. Elli graduated from Mount Holyoke in 1952, and from Harvard Graduate School of Education in 1956 with her Masters in Education. She taught at American College For Girls at Robert College in Istanbul, eventually becoming Dean of Women. She also was Dean at Pine Manor, and at Douglas College, Rutgers University. Elli had a full life spending time between Turkey, Switzerland, Cape Cod, and The U.S. Virgin Islands. She is predeceased by her husband, Louis E. Jaquinet of Aubonne, Switzerland and Dennis, a diplomat with The International Red Cross; her parents, the Rev. Dr. Edgar F. Romig and Ella D. Romig; and her two brothers, the Rev. Dr. Edgar D. Romig and the Rev. David W. Romig. A memorial service will be held this summer on the Cape. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be sent to: Cape Cod Council of Churches, Box 758, Hyannis, MA 02601.

GRANT--Hugh Andrew Jr.,of New York, NY passed away on January 25th, 2012. Born in Bradford, PA to Susan L. and Hugh A. Grant. Graduate of Georgetown Prep School and Georgetown University. A trustee of the Convent of the Sacred Heart New York, NY, the United States Trotting Association and the Trotting Horse Museum & Hall of Fame. He served as president and chief executive officer of the Hambletonian Society. He is survived by his wife Patricia, his children Leslie Grant Ritten (Peter), Caroline Grant Porter (Josh) and H. Andrew Grant III (David), sister Kathleen G. Flintoft and two granddaughters Brett Ritten and Elsa Porter. Family will receive friends on Monday from 5-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Memorial services Tuesday 1:30pm at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Head & Neck Cancer Research Program at Mt. Sinai Medical Center New York, NY or Georgetown Preparatory School in Garrett Park, MD.

9 P.M. (ABC) A SMILE AS BIG AS THE MOON (2012) John Corbett, above, stars as Mike, a high school football coach and special-education teacher who takes a class of disabled students to NASA's Space Camp, in this Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation, based on the memoir by Mike Kersjes. Mike's inspiration: Ben (Peter ten Brink), a boy with Down syndrome who dreams of becoming an astronaut. Jessy Schram plays Robynn McKinney, a fellow teacher who helps Mike buck the opposition of school administrators. And Cynthia Watros is Dr. Deborah Barnhart, the Space Camp official who is skeptical that Mike's class will be able to hold its own with some of the brightest science students from across the country. The cast includes young actors with Down syndrome, autism and learning disabilities. 9 A.M. And Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, responds to the State of the Union address.

A children's event listing in the New Jersey Calendar in some editions last Sunday misstated part of the name of a celebration at the Hunterdon Art Museum in Clinton today. It is Hunterdon Museum's 60th Anniversary Community Celebration, not ''Morris Museum's 60th Anniversary Community Celebration.''

CAN film and theater live happily together in the same room? It's not as if they haven't had a long relationship already, with each regularly borrowing stories and stars from the other. But now these separate but equal art forms are attempting to practice cohabitation. As in many relationships, only half of the couple is truly equipped to make the effort. Film, after all, is recorded action and exists mostly in two dimensions (even when it's 3-D), which means it can't invite live theater into its world. On the other hand, there's nothing to stop theater artists from setting up a projector and showing a movie onstage, letting live performers interact with, or ignore, their two-dimensional equivalents.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Bruins' Stanley Cup M.V.P. Declines Team's Visit With Obama,'' Jan. 24: Tim Thomas's refusal to accompany the Boston Bruins to the White House reminds me of a similar decision I had to make. In 2005, I was the New Mexico Teacher of the Year. All of the state teachers of the year, along with those from United States territories, were invited to the White House to meet President George W. Bush. I opposed nearly everything that he did as president. Yet out of respect for my school, my state and my colleagues, I elected to go. (I did wear a Clinton button hidden under my jacket.)

The signature high-fashion look for this winter is now clearly established: leggings or narrow trousers; ankle-high boots with chunky heels and platform soles that give weight to the base of the silhouette; and a short jacket or fingertip-length coat. The look was established by the wearers rather than a single fashion designer, and often has a haberdasher or tomboy feeling. You can see it in profusion on the sidewalks in the early morning on women heading to work.

CASTELLANO--Peter Maurice 62, passed away at his home in Atlantic Beach, FL on January 24, 2012 after a lengthy illness. Peter was born on February 14, 1949 in Brooklyn, NY to parents Michael and Elyane "Lana" Castellano. He attended St. Sylvester's Roman Catholic Grade School where he also served as an altar boy at Sunday masses. He attended Thomas Jefferson High School. Peter found his calling as a professional photographer when he was just a boy and his Uncle Charlie gave him a camera. This sparked his creative interest in photography and he pursued that as a career, which spanned over 35 years. Peter became a well-known fashion photographer both in Europe and the United States in the 1970's. He studied under Guy Bourdain and Gustav Petersen and was touted as the "next Scavullo" in the early 1980's. He worked with some of the finest art directors in the business. Rowan Johnson, Juan Ramos and Antonio Lopez were among his early mentors. He also collaborated on a book with famed science fiction writer, Arthur C. Clarke. During Peter's years as a professional photographer, his editorial work included French Elle, The Sunday Times in London, Vogue and Viva to name only a few. Peter's love of fishing, animals, nature and science fiction were well known to his close friends and family. He often remarked, "Any day I'm fishing is a great day. Period." Peter is survived by his wife, Bettina McMahon Castellano, sister Michele Scaglione, brother-in-law Vito, his niece, Danielle Mayol and her husband, Gerardo, his great niece, Sabrina Mayol and his dog Click. He is predeceased by his parents. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: ASPCA: www.aspca.org, (212) 876-7700. American Liver Foundation: www.liverfoundation.org or American Liver Foundation, (212) 668-1000.

Last October, in Foshan, China, a 2-year-old girl was run over by a van. The driver did not stop. Over the next seven minutes, more than a dozen people walked or bicycled past the injured child. A second truck ran over her. Eventually, a woman pulled her to the side, and her mother arrived. The child died in a hospital. The entire scene was captured on video and caused an uproar when it was shown by a television station and posted online. A similar event occurred in London in 2004, as have others, far from the lens of a video camera. Yet people can, and often do, behave in very different ways.

Despite losing its first Edition hotel in Waikiki, Hawaii, to a different management company last summer, Marriott International says it has plans to open new Edition hotels in five major cities. In addition to the openings, already announced, of the former Berners Hotel in London and the former Seville Hotel in Miami, which Marriott owns, construction has begun on two Edition properties in Bangkok and Abu Dhabi. They will be owned by various partners and managed by Marriott.

IN the hunt for innovation, that elusive path to economic growth and corporate prosperity, try a little jazz as an inspirational metaphor. That's the message that John Kao, an innovation adviser to corporations and governments -- who is also a jazz pianist -- was to deliver in a performance and talk on Saturday at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Jazz, Mr. Kao says, demonstrates some of the tensions in innovation, between training and discipline on one side and improvised creativity on the other.

A brilliant teacher, a wonderful man. There will be a memorial service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Kenneth Goldstein Scholarship Fund at the Graduate School of Journalism.

Across the waiting room in the doctor's office, a woman is generously showering each page of last month's Newsweek with wet coughs. Her expression is a dutiful one, like that of a priest sprinkling holy water upon his congregation; occasionally she flips back to bestow a second layer where the first might have been too thin. The man sitting next to me is browsing a copy of Men's Health. When the nurse calls his name, he smiles and offers me the magazine. I recoil. Touching its communal pages would be the equivalent of having unprotected sex with multiple strangers in a Porta-John. I manage a terse, ''No, thank you,'' then immediately begin to worry that he thinks I refused it because I'm illiterate. Or maybe he thinks I'm not simply illiterate but also stupid, that I thought illiteracy was actually a medical condition and that instead of going to an adult education center I came to the doctor's office. Next time someone offers me a magazine in a doctor's office, I decide, I'll decline by saying, ''I've already read that one.''

MELBOURNE, Australia - Playing like riverboat gamblers, Leander Paes of India and Radek Stepanek of the Czech Republic upset the defending champions, Mike and Bob Bryan of the United States, 7-6 (1), 6-2, to win the Australian Open doubles title. Cutting off service returns with abandon, the underdogs played risky, all-out tennis with the verve usually assigned to the Bryans, breaking their opponents' serve only twice but hitting nearly twice as many winning shots, 41 to 22.

He is survived by his great friend and former wife, Daphne Brooks Prout, four daughters: Diana Cherot, Daphne Cook, Rosamond Warren, Phyllis Prout, five grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren and his brother William W. Prout. He is also survived by his wife, Diane Neal Emmons, four Stepchildren, one foster daughter, and two step-grandchildren. His sister, Virginia Prout Nulsen, predeceased him. He is greatly missed by his family and numerous friends, as he misses his family, friends, numerous projects and his beloved ocean. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, February 18, 2012, at 3pm, at The Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, Cambridge, MA. Gifts may be made in Dr. Prout's memory to the Curtis Prout, M.D., '41, Fund for Teaching Primary Care at Harvard Medical School, c/o Matthew Durno, 401 Park Drive, Suite 22 West, Boston, MA 02215.

LOS ANGELES -- However disheartening the circumstances that lead a business to declare insolvency, we consumers tend to register the brightly colored signage heralding a going-out-of-business sale and think primarily one thing: I can get stuff dirt cheap. With Saab's recent bankruptcy and liquidation woes, the Internet has been ablaze with reports of consumers buying Saabs at pennies on the krona. Even the collection of the Saab Heritage Museum, consisting of more than 100 cars and such choice artifacts as the 1947 prototype that spawned an entire car company, was secured for a relative song this week.

HEYMAN--Ira Michael, Chancellor of the University of California (1980-1990) and Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution (1994-1999) died at his home in Berkeley, CA, on November 19, 2011 of emphysema. Born in New York City in 1930, Mike attended Horace Mann in the Bronx, graduated from Dartmouth College (1951) and Yale Law School (1956), served in the Marine Corps and clerked for Supreme Court Justice Earl Warren. Mike taught Property Law and City and Regional Planning at Boalt Hall at The University of California from 1959. In 1974 he became Vice Chancellor and in 1980 Chancellor of the University. He raised enrollment of underrepresented minorities, established private fund raising as a campus priority, and led a major reorganization of the biological sciences. As the 10th Secretary of the Smithsonian, Mike organized that institution's 150th anniversary celebration, raised funds for many projects including the National Museum of the American Indian and managed a controversial exhibit of the Enola Gay. In retirement, Mike taught and served on boards including the Presidio Trust and the Citizens' Stamp Advisory Committee. A detailed obituary was published in this paper on November 28th. Mike is survived by his second wife, the former Elizabeth Diringer Nelson, his son James and three grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his first wife Therese Thau Heyman and a son Stephen. Donations can be made to the I. Michael Heyman Project at Berkeley Law or the Ira Michael Heyman Memorial Scholarship Fund, University Relations, 2080 Addison Street, Berkeley, CA 94720-4200. Those wishing to donate online may do so by going to the Give to Cal website and searching under "Heyman." A Memorial Service will be held at 4:30pm in the auditorium at International House at UC Berkeley on Monday, February 27, 2012.

TUESDAY'S PUZZLE - One of the nice things about the Celebrity Guest Solver feature, other than giving me the opportunity to work with some truly brilliant minds, is that it gives me a bit of a break. A chance to put my feet up, if you will, and let someone else do the heavy crossword lifting for a change. It's asking a lot, because these are busy people who obligingly take the time out of their busy schedules to solve and write about the puzzle for your entertainment. And because they usually have a book to plug.

Abraham Lincoln, what does he know? A house divided against itself can stand, and will do so for decades, no sweat. Berlin, Nicosia, Jerusalem - heck, even Kansas City: all are cities that have been split in two by borders. All are still around. But if being split down the middle doesn't mean the end of the world, it ain't fun either. A house divided is a house of pain, with degrees of inconvenience varying from administrative annoyance to frequent lethality.

A month before the first shots were fired at Fort Sumter, the Philadelphia Examiner editorialized, "If we intend to have a national naval force worthy of our power and pretensions, we shall have to ... build iron-cased vessels. ... Before the end of the year, France will have eight and England six. ... How many are we to have?" At that moment, most of the country's ranking naval officers would have answered "none," for they were uniformly skeptical of both the need for and the practicality of "ironclads." To John Lenthall, the Navy's chief of construction, equipment and repair, the very idea was a "humbug."

Take a look at the numbers in the inner black circle above. This clockwise arrangement of 1, 2, 3, 1, 3, and 4 has an interesting property. With it you can count all the numbers from one to seven in order in the following way. You go around the circle reading each number and if it is in counting sequence starting from one, you count it and move on. If it is not in counting sequence, you are allowed to add as many consecutive numbers as needed to make it so.

Helen Gurley Brown, the former editor of Cosmopolitan, has given a $30 million donation to Columbia and Stanford Universities to help them start a center for media innovation, Brian Stelter reports on Media Decoder. The center would be housed on both campuses, representing "the increasingly important connection between journalism and technology, bringing the best from the East and West Coasts," the schools wrote. The center will be named for Ms. Brown and her late husband, David Brown. An $18 million portion earmarked for the Columbia Journalism School was the largest donation in its history. POMONA, Calif. -- Dean Moon, who died in 1987 at age 60, established a small production shop behind his father's restaurant in the Los Angeles suburb of Norwalk in 1952. Moon Equipment would become one of the most recognized and respected names in the hot-rod and drag-racing cultures, in part for its unmistakable logo: two goggling eyes casting a sidelong glance, a design Mr. Moon first toyed with in his high school typing class.

The soprano Angela Meade won the Beverly Sills Artist Award, a $50,000 prize for singers from ages 25 to 40 who have already appeared in featured roles at the Metropolitan Opera, the company said on Monday. Ms. Meade, 34, made her Met debut as Elvira in Verdi's "Ernani" four years ago and will appear again in the role on Thursday in a new run of the opera. The award was endowed by Agnes Varis, a Met managing director, and her husband, Karl Leichtman. Ms. Sills died in 2007. Previous winners include Nathan Gunn, Joyce DiDonato, Matthew Polenzani, John Relyea, Susanna Phillips and Isabel Leonard.

When you think of proponents of green energy, the Saudi oil minister may not be the first person who comes to mind. But in a speech on Monday in London, Ali al-Naimi, the minister from OPEC's leading member nation, had a lot to say about renewable energy and global warming.

Jennie Somogyi, a principal dancer at New York City Ballet, tore the Achilles' tendon in her right foot during a performance Saturday night and will be out for the rest of the season, the company said on Monday. It was the second major injury for Ms. Somogyi since early 2004, when she tore a tendon in her left foot during a show. She battled back then, undergoing reconstructive surgery and extensive physical therapy before returning to the stage after 18 months. Rob Daniels, a City Ballet spokesman, said Ms. Somogyi would have surgery on Tuesday.

Gustavo Dudamel and his orchestra, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, will give the first New York performance of the oratorio "The Gospel According to the Other Mary" composed by John Adams next season, Lincoln Center said on Monday. The concert was announced as part of the Great Performers 2012-13 lineup, which will include two concerts devoted to Brahms by Valery Gergiev and the London Symphony Orchestra.

NBC's coverage of the 2012 N.F.L. Pro Bowl drew a decent number of fans on Sunday as the American Football Conference defeated the National Football Conference 59-41, though not nearly enough to dominate the overall broadcast network ratings. NBC was No. 1 in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic segment, according to preliminary overnight Nielsen estimates, and it finished second in total viewers with 10.7 million, just behind CBS (11.4 million). Those two networks were close enough in total viewers that NBC might yet squeak by when the final numbers are released. "Undercover Boss" had the largest audience for CBS, at 13.1 million total viewers. On ABC, "Once Upon a Time" continued to perform well - especially for a freshman drama - with its highest audience total since November (10.8 million).

Museums often make news by raising their admission prices. (The Metropolitan Museum of Art's recommended admission went to $25 from $20 last year; the Museum of Modern Art, whose fee is not recommended but mandatory, also rose to $25 from $20.) It's much rarer - in fact, almost unheard of - for a museum to get attention by reducing its prices. But the New Museum for Contemporary Art - which raised its admission fee recently to cover higher operating costs for the highly participatory show of the work of Carsten Höller - has decided to lower it. Before the show the fee for adults was $12, which was raised to $16 for the Höller show. It has now been set at $14. The museum continues to offer free admission every Thursday evening from 7 to 9 p.m. and to anyone under 18 at all times. The museum's next exhibition, its second Triennial, titled "The Ungovernables," opens Feb. 15.

The polling in Iowa and New Hampshire was volatile, but it generally reached something of a consensus in the day or two before the elections there. There was somewhat more diversity in the South Carolina polls, but some of that was because Newt Gingrich's surge there was very rapid, meaning that the exact timing of the poll made a fair amount of difference.

Jazz Age American music and a celebration of the 200th anniversary of Wagner's birth will be among the highlights of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's 2012-13 season. Jacques Lacombe, in his third year as music director, will lead 16 weeks of traditional classical programs, four pops programs in Newark and New Brunswick and three family concerts. Opening night, on Sept. 28, will feature the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and include Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue." The program also features "Remembering Gatsby: Foxtrot for Orchestra," by John Harbison, a New Jersey native, that is part of the orchestra's New Jersey Roots Project. During the season the orchestra will also perform music from Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," "Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg" and "Parsifal." More information about the season is available here.

Britax Child Safety is recalling 14,220 child restraints because the shoulder harness may not hold the child, according to a document posted Saturday on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. A further 3,600 seats are being recalled in Canada.

ZocDoc, an oddly named Web service for scheduling appointments with doctors, started in New York in 2007 and has been growing at a torrid pace. Last week the company added Seattle, its 14th metropolitan market in the United States.

Petula Clark's cloud-breaking voice first entered my life when, as a nursery schooler, I begged my parents to buy me her big new hit single, "Downtown." So it seemed appropriate that I spent Friday night, the 47th anniversary of the song's run at No. 1, hearing her sing it at Feinstein's at Loews Regency, during her first extended New York engagement in decades. Appropriate, but also odd. As much of a pop milestone as "Downtown" was, who in 1965 would have imagined that Clark would still be singing it, at a swank Park Avenue cabaret no less, almost 50 years later? Probably not even Clark herself.

"We're not just The Villages," opined reporters for The Tampa Bay Times in a list of unconventional campaign stops for Republican candidates. Florida is so much more than retirees and snowbirds (though they are a big part of the equation, to be sure). It's the most populous primary state yet, mired in a housing bust after a population boom that drove the latest rotation of its exaggerated economic cycles. Its political campaigns are primarily waged over the air, while developers, farmers and corporations wage constant battles over the water, be they the Everglades or Florida's 1,197 miles of coastline.

The global food crisis has dragged on so long now that is beginning to seem less like a crisis and more like a permanent state of affairs. Prices did take a dip late last year, owing to bumper harvests. "Often the attention to details makes all the difference," says the Dolce & Gabbana co-designer Stefano Gabbana, referring to the design of his and Domenico Dolce's newest spring bag, which hits stores this week. Structured and clean, with a handle made for elbow-hooking and a padlock made of gold metal (speaking of details), the style comes in three sizes and is available in a variety of materials, from aluminum foil to straw and python, and in a range of gorgeous colors (pastels, primaries) and finishes (metallic and matte). For the minimalist, the classic leather style suits best. For the quirky carrier, a metallic picnic purse version is perfect. And, for the vintage-inspired, a dainty woven version like this one in dusty rose does the trick. Pick your poison.

Two Sunday Reviews ago, I wrote about the long history of "Porgy and Bess" as a prism through which African-Americans have viewed their own history. I am a relatively recent devotee of what I like to think of as the "real" "Porgy and Bess," the full-length opera. (So far as I can tell, there is only one performance of the opera ever recorded on DVD - a 1993 Trevor Nunn production with Simon Rattle conducting, released in 2001.) Like most people, I came to "Porgy and Bess" through some of the many popular recordings of its famous songs. Indeed, I received several e-mails questioning my sanity for writing about the opera without mentioning two of the most famous recordings: the Ella Fitzgerald-Louis Armstrong version, and the equally sublime Miles Davis recording.

Over the weekend, "The House I Live In," Eugene Jarecki's heart-heavy investigation into the American war on drugs, nabbed the grand jury prize for documentary at the Sundance Film Festival. Mr. Jarecki's other movies include "The Trials of Henry Kissinger," about you know who, and a 2005 grand jury prize winner, "Why We Fight," about the American military industrial complex. Notably, one of this year's jury members was Charles Ferguson, whose documentaries include "No End in Sight" and "Inside Job," and who, like Mr. Jarecki, has a methodological gift for transforming boatloads of information into both political arguments and eminently watchable narratives.

The Southern Environmental Law Center, a Virginia-based nonprofit legal advocacy group, has released its 2012 list of the Top 10 endangered places in the Southeast, environmentally speaking. While the list changes from year to year, certain places like the Chesapeake Bay remain a top concern -- and issues like pollution from coal-fired power plants and the protection of public lands and old-growth forests are recurring themes. At 13, an age when most boys want to learn the guitar, Gary Marcus, decided he wanted to be a scientist. Twenty-five years later he had become one of the country's best known cognitive psychologists, with major papers and three general-interest books on the workings of the human mind and a position running New York University's Center for Language and Music. And he wanted to play the guitar. He said he had no rhythm, but spent his sabbatical finding a way to learn to play the guitar and wrote a book about his effort, discussed in this New York Times article last week. Dr. Marcus agreed to answer readers' questions about the fears and challenges of learning new skills as an adult. Here are his responses.

Sunday night's chapter of "The Good Wife," titled "Another Ham Sandwich," was like a highlight reel -- an agglomeration of the sort of too-good-to-be-true moments that are usually rationed, two or three to an episode. Alicia saying to Will, as the grand jury considered indicting him, "So use me." The ever smug David Lee telling Will: "That's how a pro does it. You're welcome." The final, reassuring reveal that Kalinda was working a long con on the prosecutors rather than selling out Will, followed by Dana slapping an impassive Kalinda in the courthouse. A classic David Lee-Eli Gold confrontation. Peter finally snapping and admitting to Alicia that this entire plot line was driven by his anger over her affair.

MUSTALISH--Wanda, born in Detroit MI, April 4, 1918, formerly of Iselin, NJ, died peacefully in her sleep Friday January 27, 2012 two months shy of her 94th birthday. Predeceased by her husband Anthony Mustalish (died 2000) and her parents Mitchell and Sophia Machnowski of Lvov, Poland, she is survived by her loving children Drs. Anthony C. and Elayne Mustalish of New York, NY, Paula and Michael Salzano of Cape Coral, FL and Dr. Roger W. and Sue Mustalish of West Chester, PA and grandchildren Rachel, David, Peter, Michael, Paula and her husband Alan. She was always so loving, positive and energetic, we were truly fortunate to call her Mom. We will miss her. In lieu of flowers, and to honor her memory, donations to the Mustalish Endowment, a student scholarship in Health Sciences, are invited. Please make checks to WCU Foundation-Mustalish Endowment, and mail to: West Chester University Foundation, P.O. Box 541, West Chester, PA 19381.

Liam Neeson does it again: ''The Grey,'' the latest in a line of successful action thrillers featuring that 59-year-old star, was No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend, with an estimated $20 million in ticket sales. The movie, about a group of oil drillers in Alaska who become hunted by wolves, was made outside the studio system and acquired for $5 million last summer by Open Road Films, an upstart distributor backed by the multiplex operators AMC Entertainment and Regal Cinemas. Last week's first-place film, ''Underworld: Awakening'' (Sony Pictures Entertainment), was second with about $12.5 million in ticket sales, lifting its two-week total to $45.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. The comedy ''One for the Money,'' starring Katherine Heigl in an adaptation of Janet Evanovich's best-selling novel, was soft but better-than-expected in third place, taking in about $11.8 million. The African-American military adventure ''Red Tails'' (LucasFilm via 20th Century Fox) was fourth, with an estimated $10.4 million in sales for a two-week total of $33.8 million. Continuing Summit Entertainment's dismal track record with non-''Twilight'' movies, the studio's ''Man on a Ledge'' bombed in fifth place, taking in about $8.3 million; the movie cost about $42 million to make.

Memorial service will take place on Monday, January 30, 2012, at 2:15pm at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

Service Tuesday, January 31, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Mount Sinai Heart or the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

Liam Neeson's latest film, ''The Grey,'' about a wilderness battle between plane crash survivors and a pack of wolves, led the box office this weekend (right). In many of his most successful films, like ''Clash of the Titans,'' above, where he portrays Zeus, and ''Batman Begins'' or ''The A-Team,'' the good vs. evil battles have featured a comic-book sensibility. Mr. Neeson's critically acclaimed films, like ''Kinsey'' (2004, gross of $13 million) or ''Michael Collins'' (1996, $20 million) have not been box-office giants, except, of course, for ''Schindler's List.'' SHELLY FREIERMAN

After a hurricane, homeowners check nervously to see if their insurance will cover all of their damages. With the European financial crisis still threatening a trail of defaults, United States banks are betting that their insurance is going to pay out. Five large American banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, have more than $80 billion of exposure to Italy, Spain, Portugal, Ireland and Greece, the most economically stressed nations in the euro currency zone, according to a New York Times analysis of the banks' financial disclosures.

An article in some editions on Friday about the closings of two of New York's musical mainstays misstated the surname of an owner of one of the businesses, the performance space Southpaw, in Brooklyn, and, because of an editing error, also misstated its size at one point. The owner is Matthew Roff, not Roth, and Southpaw's space is 7,500 square feet, not 5,000 square feet.

Joseph Mattioli, who gave up his Philadelphia dental practice, bought a spinach farm off Interstate 80 in northeast Pennsylvania in 1960 and transformed it into Pocono Raceway, one of the primary stock-car racetracks in the country, died Thursday in Allentown, Pa. He was 86 and lived at the raceway, in Long Pond, Pa. His grandson Brandon Idgalsky, who is now the chief officer of the raceway, confirmed his death.

A critic's notebook article on Friday about the New York Guitar Festival, which was founded by David Spelman, misspelled part of the name of another festival, in Urbana, Ill., that he has overseen. It is the Ellnora Guitar Festival, not Ellinora.

ProPublica, the nonprofit news organization known for its investigative journalism, is about to expand its e-book efforts. Following in the digital footsteps of The New Yorker, The New York Times, Politico, Vanity Fair and Cosmopolitan, ProPublica will release its work in e-book form, this time through Open Road Integrated Media, the two companies are expected to announce on Monday.

Wonderment and sorrow course through the songs of Antony Hegarty, who leads Antony and the Johnsons. Those are immense emotions, and on Thursday night he performed in a place to match their scale: Radio City Music Hall. A towering backdrop was often illuminated by lasers; his band members were supplemented by a 60-piece orchestra. He had chosen his most contemplative songs, with sustained melodies like lullabies grown operatic, carrying lyrics to proclaim and repeat revelations: ''I need another world/This one's nearly gone.'' Mr. Hegarty, draped in a white garment -- part diva dress, part Jesus robe -- stood at center stage, alone until the orchestra was revealed late in the concert. There he poured out his uncanny voice: a preternaturally sustained, androgynous croon, steeped in melancholy and awe. I've never heard a Radio City audience keep so silent during ballads.

D'OENCH--Toby. The Havens Relief Fund Society mourns the death of our colleague and friend, Russell ("Toby") G. D'Oench, III. Toby was a compassionate, courageous and generous leader, and we will miss him very much. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family.

WAINFELD--Benjamin MD, "Beno", 91, died peacefully at home on January 27, 2012. Son of Abraham and Yetta, beloved husband of Eugenia for 61 years, father of Michael (Maria) and Danielle (Vincent), and grandfather of David, Alexandra, Stephanie, Remy, and Tina. Ben loved Opera, classical music, and the theatre, was fluent in five languages, traveled the world, and enjoyed his boat and the beach. A true member of the greatest generation, he served in the Army in WWII, graduated from Brooklyn College, and the University of Geneva School of Medicine, and after a brief time in private practice, went on to become Director of Outpatient Services at Coney Island, Maimonides and Brookdale Hospitals and Professor of Environmental Health at SUNY-Downstate. An active member of the PNHP, APHA, and the Hermann Biggs Society, he worked tirelessly to improve access to health care for all. He will be missed very much.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the Costa Concordia shipwreck in Italy on Jan. 13 overstated what is known about a person who was told on the telephone by the ship's captain, Francesco Schettino, that his superiors at Costa Cruises had ordered him to deviate from his planned course, according to a leaked transcript of the conversation, which took place while the captain was in police custody. No details about the other person in that conversation have been confirmed. It is not the case that Captain Schettino was talking to an ''unidentified official from Costa Cruises.''

PARK CITY, Utah -- It's not subtle: in his forthcoming movie, ''This Must Be the Place,''Sean Penn resembles Robert Smith, the goth frontman of the Cure. The resemblance was intentional; the Italian director Paolo Sorrentino, known for the political biopic ''Il Divo,'' idolized the Cure growing up and decided to make his English-language debut about a rich, depressed '80s rocker married to a no-nonsense woman (Frances McDormand) who's a firefighter. ''He's a child, and she's the man of the family,'' Mr. Sorrentino explained, adding that the story was based on his own relationship and also that of Mr. Smith, who has been married to the same woman since he was 16. Iggy Pop was another source of rock inspiration, and David Byrne supplies music and makes a cameo. Mr. Penn even sang a Cure-like song in the movie, but the scene was cut because his co-star for the scene, a dog, didn't behave, Mr. Sorrentino said.

WARREN--Jessica Van Rennselaer Despard Warren, of Essex, Massachusetts, loving wife of the late Samuel Warren, died at 87 after a long illness, at her home on January 26th. Mrs. Warren was a passionate reader and sharp wit who worked for environmental causes and education all her life. She leaves behind her sister Katherine Page of New Jersey and a brother, Clement L. Despard of Connecticut, her sons, Samuel, Henry, Hugh, Andrew, her daughter, Jessica Bennet, and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations made in her memory to the Essex County Greenbelt Assoc. 82 Eastern Avenue, Essex, MA 01929 would be appreciated. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, Beverly Farms, MA at noon on April 21, 2012. Information, directions, condolences at www.campbellfuneral.com

MANISCHEWITZ--Lillian P.,98, on January 27, 2012, a woman of dignity, intelligence and grace, beloved by all who knew her. She is pre-deceased by her husband, D. Homai Vyarawalla, a photojournalist celebrated in India for chronicling the country's march toward independence and capturing enduring images of world figures like Mohandas K. Gandhi, Ho Chi Minh and American presidents of the mid-20th century, died on Jan. 15 in Vadodara, in west India. She was 98. Hospital officials said she had been under their care for respiratory ailments when she died after falling from her bed and fracturing a thigh bone.

(OWN) OPRAH'S NEXT CHAPTER Oprah Winfrey travels to Haiti with the actor Sean Penn (above, with Ms. Winfrey, center) nearly two years after the earthquake that devastated the capital city, Port-au-Prince, killing 316,000 and leaving a million homeless. She learns about his work with the J/P Haitian Relief Organization, which has housed more than 20,000 of the displaced. She also speaks with an American teenager who runs an orphanage; a Haitian woman who is working to rebuild her country through art; and the fashion designer Donna Karan, who has created business opportunities for local artists. 8 P.M. Ajit Jain, a top lieutenant at Berkshire Hathaway, is on the short list of candidates to succeed Warren E. Buffett, Berkshire's chief executive. Mr. Jain has landed on another, less desirable list: He is a potential witness in the insider-trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta.

As polls showedMitt Romney pulling far ahead ofNewt Gingrich in Florida, both campaigns have begun looking ahead to a period of campaigning that is likely to look and feel very different. Nevada will hold its Republican caucuses on Saturday, four days after Florida's primary. On Sunday, Mr. Romney's campaign boasted that he had received the endorsement of The Las Vegas Review-Journal, which called him ''a Washington outsider, not a capital insider.''

Is there evidence that this is actually happening?

''Most of my life I went to parties and heard a little groan when people heard what I did,'' says Robert Tibshirani, a statistics professor at Stanford University. ''Now they're all excited to meet me.'' It's not because of a new after-shave. Arcane statistical analysis, the business of making sense of our growing data mountains, has become high tech's hottest calling. There are billions of bytes generated daily, not just from the Internet but also from sciences like genetics and astronomy. Companies like Google and Facebook, as well as product marketers, risk analysts, spies, natural philosophers and gamblers are all scouring the info, desperate to find a new angle on what makes us and the world tick. Computing has become cheap and available enough to process any number of formulas.

12:46 p.m. | Updated MELBOURNE, Australia - The tennis marathon has already been redefined, in all likelihood for good, by John Isner's victory over Nicolas Mahut in the opening round of Wimbledon in 2010.

DAVOS, Switzerland -- When I set out to report at the World Economic Forum, I imagined it might be difficult to find technology-related stories. It turns out, I was a tad wrong. I would have had more luck finding a snowless Alpine mountain in the winter than finding people discussing a topic that did not involve technology. After a year that has included the social media-fueled protests of the Arab Spring and Occupy Wall Street, global Internet privacy legislation and billions of dollars in technology stock offerings, tech and social media have not only entered the building, they are the walls holding it up.

Exxon Mobil said on Sunday that it had agreed to sell its Japanese subsidiary to TonenGeneral Sekiyu, a major refinery operator in Japan, for about $3.9 billion, as part of a revamping of the oil giant's operations in that country. Under the terms of the deal, Exxon will sell a 99 percent stake in the subsidiary, ExxonMobil Yugen Kaisha, to TonenGeneral. Exxon will in turn shed most of its controlling stake in TonenGeneral, keeping a 22 percent interest in the Japanese refiner.

GOLDSTEIN--Kenneth, passed away January 27, 2012. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Beloved father of Marianne and Gordon. Professor Emeritus, graduate school of Journalism, Columbia University. A brilliant teacher, a wonderful man. There will be a memorial service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Kenneth Goldstein Scholarship Fund at the Graduate School of Journalism.

DeBIASI--Ralph. It is with great sorrow that the Leviton Manufacturing Company, Inc. notes the passing of its Board of Directors member and former CFO, Ralph DeBiasi. Ralph DeBiasi served the company as a loyal employee for 57 years and was instrumental in the growth of the company. He was both a dear friend and confidant to both Harold and Shirley Leviton and the entire Leviton family. He will be missed by us all. Our sympathies go to his son Ralph, Jr. and daughter Adele and their families. Lovingly Submitted, The Leviton Family, Leviton Board of Directors and The Leviton Company
DARLINGTON--Henry III, devoted teacher, dies at 60. Memorial to be announced. Gifts: Church of the Ascension, PO Box 271, Lake Clear, NY 12945.

OTTAWA -- It began with a puzzling and grisly discovery in 2009: a car submerged in a 19th-century canal lock with the bodies of three teenage girls and a middle-aged woman inside. On Sunday, the father, the mother and a brother of the girls were each convicted of four counts of first-degree murder. The verdict concluded a complex, three-month trial in which prosecutors described the crimes as ''honor killings.'' The defendants -- Mohammad Shafia, 58; Tooba Yahya, 42; and their son Hamed, 21 -- and the victims belonged to a family of Afghans who had moved to Canada two years before the crime, in June 2007, under a program for affluent immigrants. Both the woman in the car, Rona Amir Mohammad, and Ms. Yahya were married to Mr. Shafia.

Quvenzhane Wallis, 8, cemented her status as the It Girl of this year's Sundance Film Festival on Saturday night, as ''Beasts of the Southern Wild,'' starring Ms. Wallis as a poor Louisiana girl named Hushpuppy, took the festival's top grand jury prize. ''Beasts of the Southern Wild,'' directed and co-written by Benh Zeitlin, (and headed to theaters courtesy of Fox Searchlight), also won a prize for cinematography. ''I hope this movie is a flag that goes up to tell producers to allow filmmakers to be as wild as they could be to direct a film,'' Mr. Zeitlin said as he accepted the award in Park City, Utah.

An article on Thursday about the men's basketball team at Murray State, the only unbeaten men's team in N.C.A.A. Division I, misstated the team's colors. While children attending a taping of a weekly radio show with Coach Steve Prohm were wearing blue and white Murray State apparel, they were not wearing ''the team's colors,'' which are blue and gold.

Here's what working with Steve Albini can do for your band, as evinced by ''Attack on Memory'' (Carpark), the strong new album by the Cleveland outfit Cloud Nothings. Like a preset mode in ProTools or other recording programs, there is an Albini sound: the drums hit with a certain crispness, and there's a mild claustrophobia to the proceedings. Mr Albini, who engineered the new album, can only give the Albini. Here's what working with Steve Albini will not do, or cannot do, for your band, as evinced by the sweaty Cloud Nothings performance at the Studio at Webster Hall on Thursday night. On record there are confines and boundaries, but onstage there aren't, and whatever concision Cloud Nothings achieved on this album was often threatened by its interest in extended, ineffectual instrumental passages.

An article on Wednesday about the public viewing of Joe Paterno's casket in State College, Pa., on Tuesday described incorrectly the tickets for his public memorial service on Thursday. They were free; they were not ''sold out'' by Tuesday.

Nederlander Presentations announced on Sunday that it would stage a new production of the four-time Tony Award-nominated musical ''Jekyll & Hyde.'' The show features music from the composer Frank Wildhorn, who has struggled with a string of flops, including two short-lived 2011 productions, ''Bonnie & Clyde'' and ''Wonderland.'' Although ''Jekyll & Hyde'' is arguably the most well-known of Mr. Wildhorn's works, with an original run on Broadway lasting more than three and a half years, the show failed to turn a profit before it closed in 2001. Constantine Maroulis (''Rock of Ages'') will play both central characters; the book and lyrics are by Leslie Bricusse. The producers are aiming for a spring 2013 arrival on Broadway after a 25-week national tour scheduled to begin on Oct. 2 in San Diego. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

LOS ANGELES -- The Directors Guild of America honored a bespectacled filmmaker for his love of classic Hollywood cinema, and he was a Frenchman: Michel Hazanavicius won the prize for best feature from the organization, whose choices usually dovetail with the Oscars. (Pundits quickly called it: ''The Artist'' will win best picture at the Academy Awards.) On Saturday night, Mr. Hazanavicius beat out Martin Scorsese, Woody Allen, Alexander Payne and David Fincher. At the Directors Guild, all five hopefuls are given plaques and get to make speeches before a winner is announced. Mr. Scorsese received a standing ovation just walking up to the podium. Mr. Allen sent a funny taped message explaining why he didn't go -- bad at mingling, he said: ''I don't hold up in person.'' He added that awards-wise, the DGA honor fit ''somewhere between the top, the Nobel Prize, and the bottom, the Republican primary.''

D'OENCH--Toby. The North Star Fund community deeply mourns the loss of our visionary co-founder, mentor and friend. Our hearts are with his beloved Tani, Robin, and Miye in the days ahead. We also send condolences to his esteemed Skadden colleagues. In building support for North Star Fund, Toby lived out his core dedication to equality, economic justice, and peace. We are forever inspired by his wisdom, warmth, and integrity, and pledge to carry on now in his honor.

As the country prepares for this year's presidential election, political devotees have been following the nuances of every debate, caucus, straw poll and primary. A new application for Facebook users, however, is intended to encourage those who are not as engaged to talk about the election issues that are most important to them. The new app was created during a 24-hour ''hackathon'' this month with engineers from Facebook and representatives from the advertising agency R/GA, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, at Facebook's Manhattan headquarters. The goal was to create a social application that could share users' political views on digital billboards in Times Square.

GANZER--Keith M.,passed away January 29, 2012 in his home under care of his family and friends. He is survived by his loving wife Marjorie, his daughter Haley, his parents Charlotte and Martin, and his sister Andrea. Keith bravely battled colon cancer for six and half years. A memorial service will be held to celebrate is life on Febuary 5th, 2012 at 2pm, Plaza Jewish Community, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY.

Smartphones and tablets are squeezing data networks. And because of the limited amount of the frequency spectrum available to expand wireless services, the nation may face a data network shortage in the coming years. AT&T thinks the government is the problem. The nation's No. 2 wireless carrier, after Verizon Wireless, isn't happy that the Federal Communications Commission objected to its merger with T-Mobile. The company harshly criticized the governmental agency on Thursday for its strict regulations on spectrum. The F.C.C. disputes some of the carrier's claims.

LONDON -- It was a dark and stormy afternoon when I ventured into the old building with the twisting staircases, on one of those London side streets that always seems to be in different places when you look for them. Oh, I knew what I was in for: screams, gunshots, a whistling psychopath, fraught minutes in the dark and rigid postures of fear. But I hadn't come to St. Martin's Theater to be frightened or even stimulated. I was there for comfort. Well, that and the chance to pay my respects to a woman who had given me bountiful comfort since my childhood: Agatha Christie, whose play ''The Mousetrap'' was just about to begin its 24,655th performance. Hundreds of thousands before me, starting before I was born, had followed this same path, making a cheerful pilgrimage to a mecca of sanitary murder.

Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about the United Nations investigation into allegations of sexual abuse of minors by its police officers in Haiti referred incompletely to the size of the United Nations peacekeeping force there. While there are indeed ''more than 3,500 peacekeepers in Haiti,'' the total number is about 11,000. (The number of police officers in the peacekeeping force is about 3,500.)

Greg D. Andres, a senior Justice Department official, is leaving the government to join the law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell, according to two people with direct knowledge of his move. TOPPER--Charlotte, beloved wife of David and cherished mother of Gail and Susan, died peacefully on January 26 at 84. Her class, beauty, intelligence, humor and warmth will be missed and forever in our hearts.

Investigators have determined what happened to nearly all of the customer money that disappeared from MF Global around the time of its bankruptcy last Oct. 31, but have not publicly disclosed their progress, fearing that doing so might cripple efforts to recover the cash and pursue potential wrongdoing, people briefed on the investigation said.

MF Global's chief risk officer is set to tell Congress on Thursday that he did not sound the alarms about the firm's risky wagers on European sovereign debt until July, about three months before the firm collapsed into bankruptcy.

The Asia Society is set to open two new buildings - at roughly $50 million each - first in Hong Kong next week, and then in Houston in the spring. "By the year 2050, more than 50 percent of the world's gross domestic product will come from India and China," Vishakha N. Desai, president of the society, told our colleague Robin Pogrebin. And Ms. Desai added: "We're going from Pax Americana to possibly Pax Pacifica. This is a century when America will be a very important player, but not the player. There is a different balance of power in the world." Read more »

Suspended from her position in December, the commandant of the United States Army's drill sergeant school is currently under investigation for an undisclosed personnel issue. Command Sgt. Maj. Teresa L. King was the first female commandant of the school, a somewhat high-profile position that is the source for the Army's pool of drill sergeants. These soldiers, who are typically men, are responsible for training thousands of new recruits each year. Sergeant Major King, known for her keen attention to detail and dogmatic demand for discipline, was named commandant in 2009. Since then, she has enjoyed some well-deserved popularity, including being named to Oprah Winfrey's O Power List, as well as an appearance in the October 2010 issue of O, The Oprah Magazine.

Some Singaporean food shouts for attention, some speaks more softly. Masak in the East Village, the subject of this week's $25 and Under column, serves the latter. Throughout the week, we will be ranking the Giants' 1934, 1938, 1956, 1986, 1990 and 2007 N.F.L. championship teams in various categories. The 1920s teams are not included because of severe differences in the game and the league. In this installment, we rank the running back tandems, whether they are rotations, committees, or old-fashioned three-back attacks. For the teams of yesteryear, "tailbacks" who acted as de facto quarterbacks are counted in the mix.6. 1934 Giants: Harry Newman had a short, modestly distinguished career as a 179-pound A-formation tailback (by today's standards, a Tebow). He led the league in nearly every passing category in 1933, but in 1934 he threw just one touchdown and 12 interceptions, statistics that were almost as bad then as they are today. Ken Strong was an All-Pro fullback/defensive back for both the Giants and the Staten Island Stapletons, then an N.F.L. team, and Strong rushed for 431 yards and 6 touchdowns. His best years were behind him by 1934, though he stayed with the Giants as a placekicker until after World War II. The third member of the backfield was Wee Willie Smith, who played just one season in the N.F.L. (He is not to be confused with the legendary basketball player of the same name.) You do not have to be an expert in 1930s football to realize that a backfield with one player who played just one season and another who played just three seasons belongs low on any all-time list.

Technology has caught up to the imagination of Alan Lomax, the folklorist and ethnomusicologist whose life's work was collecting traditional music from cultures across the world, Larry Rohter reports in Tuesday's New York Times. Long before the Internet existed, Lomax wanted to create a "global jukebox" for the material he had found. Now, 10 years after his death, his archive -- amounting to about 5,000 hours of sound recordings, 400,000 feet of film, 3,000 videotapes, 5,000 photographs and piles of manuscripts -- is being digitized so that it can be accessed online. About 17,000 music tracks will be available for free streaming by the end of February, and later some of that music may be for sale as CDs or digital downloads.

The move to patrol the area, located in the northwestern region of Xinjiang, comes amid concern about religious extremism in the heavily Muslim area, state media reported Monday.
A coroner in Warrington, England, ruled that Gary Speed, coach of Wales’s national team, might have killed himself accidentally.
The Kennedy family transferred ownership of the main home in their compound in Hyannis Port, Mass., to the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate on Monday.
Jim Caldwell, the former Indianapolis Colts coach, was hired Monday by the Baltimore Ravens to be their quarterbacks coach.
The Court of Arbitration for Sport said it planned to publish its verdict in Alberto Contador’s doping case on Feb. 6 but left open the possibility that it would change the day.
The Detroit Tigers’ Victor Martinez had microfracture surgery to repair the medial and lateral meniscus in his left knee and will need a second operation in six to eight weeks.
A nuclear reactor at a northern Illinois plant shut down Monday after losing power, and steam was being vented to reduce pressure, according to officials from Exelon Nuclear and federal regulators.
Remains from a Siberian cave and faster, cheaper technology are helping scientists draw a complex new picture of human origins.
The vast collection of music, film, videotapes and photographs collected by the folklorist and ethnomusicologist Alan Lomax is being digitized for wider dissemination.
A look at the $66 million Signature Center, home of the Signature Theater Company.
Letters to the editor.
Letters to the editor.
Signature Theater Company’s new home is one of the most ambitious new cultural complexes in New York in decades.
New albums include “Making Mirrors” from Gotye, “Crazy” from Candy Dulfer and “Galaxy” from Jeff Lorber Fusion.
Many who swept into office last year with aggressive plans to cut spending and curb union powers are sounding less confrontational after a backlash from constituents.
Royalty from South Africa, Sri Lanka and India goes incognito to seek romance in England, on “Undercover Princes,” on TLC on Tuesday.
An early tribute to Philip Glass, who is turning 75, took place at Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday night.
Rick Santorum, a Republican presidential candidate, stayed off the campaign trail to be with his daughter Isabella, who received a diagnosis of Trisomy 18, a chromosomal disorder, at birth.
The diamond holds a different allure for those studying the history of the Earth.
A paper on a theory of immunity led a doctoral student from Moscow to groundbreaking work in the United States.
In Katherine Boo’s new book, the striving, perpetually sparring families of a slum in Mumbai come to life.
Newt Gingrich flew to five different campaign stops in Florida on the day before voting began.
A vast majority of babies are female, but the disparity fades as a factor by the time green turtles are old enough to breed.
An Archaeopteryx fossil was microscopically examined for pigment clues, which were compared with cells of living birds.
The rapper Too Short, preparing to release his 19th album, arrives from Oakland, Calif., loaded with earthy, profane insights.
A technique called image defocus, which blurs the background while sharpening the prey, shows how far to pounce.
Miami City Ballet is performing “Viscera,” a new ballet by the rising British choreographer Liam Scarlett.
The London Handel Players make their New York debut with works by Johann Joachim Quantz, the great flute virtuoso, and Frederick the Great, the Prussian king and talented amateur flutist.
A drug that helps the effects of eye-dilating drops fade faster exists, but is no longer sold in the United States.
Yazaki agreed to a $470 million fine for engaging in three price-fixing and bid-rigging conspiracies that began as long ago as 2000, the Justice Department said.
Where improv and stand-up rule, troupes like Harvard Sailing Team and teams from the Upright Citizens Brigade bring new life to sketch comedy.
The vote underscored deep divisions in an organization created to help Africa overcome its old colonial divides and increase its power on the global stage.
Companies, governments and nonprofit organizations are releasing money, access to databases and outreach efforts to counter diseases such as leprosy and guinea worm.
The league’s commercial will review the evolution of the game’s rules and equipment and note its hopes for improved safety.
On a tiny NPR radio station in Connecticut, two writers share their belief that something will eventually sour for the Giants because much has gone wrong in the past.
A frenetic little industry has taken root in New York City based on finding and publicizing the once-and-future homes of just about anyone with name recognition.
Donors are pinning their hopes on several devices being tested in efforts to increase speed and reduce pain.
The bloc, however, still showed few signs of producing a comprehensive solution for the sovereign debt crisis or a credible plan to revive fragile economies.
Three people living with hemophilia talk about how the condition affects their lives.
A trove of wax cylinder phonograph records contains the only known recording of Otto von Bismarck.
The case could come down to who the jury decides was the mastermind of what prosecutors called an international crime that defrauded nearly 30,000 investors over more than 20 years.
On Monday, demonstrators added to their camp at McPherson Square even though the National Park Service had instructed them to remove their gear.
For protection, mammals generally rely on teeth, claws, muscles, keen senses or quick wits. Every so often, however, a mammalian lineage discovers the wonders of chemistry.
The appeals panel’s ruling, a victory for the United States, said that China distorted international trade through dozens of export policies on raw materials.
A concept that didn’t seem to need naming until quite recently.
With declining insurance reimbursements, more doctors are expanding their practices to include things like breast augmentation and liposuction paid for out-of-pocket by patients.
The lawyer for Police Chief Leonard Gallo said the chief was stepping down so the town in Connecticut would not be distracted as it tried to rehabilitate its image.
The Kunduz Province authorities say that a woman, 22, was strangled by her husband and mother-in-law three months after she gave birth to a third girl.
Kyle Flood agreed to replace Greg Schiano as the Rutgers football coach after Florida International’s Mario Cristobal reportedly turned down an offer.

In an effort to regain public trust, the Senate voted Monday to take up a bill that would prohibit members of Congress from trading stocks and other securities on the basis of confidential information they receive as lawmakers.
Residential segregation in metropolitan America has been significantly curtailed in the last 40 years, according to a study by two economics professors.
Starbucks, the popular American coffee retailer, plans to open its first store in India in September through a joint venture with Tata Global Beverages.

As Syrian forces pushed rebels back from strongholds near Damascus on Monday, world diplomats converged on the United Nations to try to press President Bashar al-Assad to leave office through a Security Council resolution.
If you haven’t see it already, find a replay of Novak Djokovic’s epic victory over Rafael Nadal, a match for the ages.
The Russian Foreign Ministry announced Monday that it had convinced Bashar al-Assad’s government to start informal negotiations in Moscow with representatives of the opposition.
With a new poll showing him with a commanding lead in Florida, Mitt Romney hammered Newt Gingrich a day before the primary even as rivals turned their attention to later contests.
Shares in New York declined on renewed pessimism over the European debt crisis, but the major indexes cut their steepest losses of the day.
A woman who worked in the finance offices of the Archdiocese of New York was arrested on Monday, accused of channeling funds for nonexistent services to accounts she controlled.
Americans socked away their increased income last month, a departure from their behavior in 2011, when consumers tapped savings to spend.
The Americans are being protected from potential arrest by the Egyptian authorities as part of a politically-charged probe into the activities of four American-backed nongovernmental organizations.
Despite what appears to have been a disaster averted, the incident highlighted China’s continuing struggle against contamination of its waterways.
Pressure is building on Lisbon, and nations like Greece and Spain continue to reel.
Novak Djokovic had a troubling autumn after winning the U.S. Open and sustaining an injury during the Davis Cup, but he roared back to beat Rafael Nadal in the final of the Australian Open.
Iran’s foreign minister was reported on Monday to have offered to extend a three-day visit to his country by United Nations inspectors.
Belgium was paralyzed by a national strike Monday as unions, angry at austerity measures, timed their protest to coincide with a one-day meeting of European Union leaders in the capital, Brussels.
The Sudanese military said on Monday morning that it freed 14 kidnapped Chinese workers who were captured over the weekend by Sudanese rebels.
