Updated, 4:20 p.m. | Low-level arrests for marijuana possession in New York City increased for the seventh straight year in 2011, according to a study released Wednesday -- despite a September memorandum from the police commissioner that reminded officers to follow the letter of the law and not arrest people with the drug unless they have it in plain view. Though arrests dropped significantly after Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly's memorandum, an increase of over 6 percent during the first eight months of the year more than offset the decline, according to the analysis, conducted by a Queens College sociology professor and released by the Drug Policy Alliance, an advocacy group critical of police marijuana-arrest policies.

You may not know how to pronounce Proenza Schouler, but you do know that Fashion Week is for everyone, if only as a state of mind. Not to sound like ''The Secret,'' but dress the part, be the part. Think about it: a statement coat, something simple and slimming since there is never room to take it off on those silly gilded chairs; good jeans for weekend shows; and a few standout accessories to catch the eye of a street photographer. You're practically sitting in the front row, aren't you?

TANNING--Dorthea. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Dorothea Tanning. Her life as an artist began as a young Surrealist in New York but continued along a boldly independent path. Tanning discovered Dada and Surrealism in 1936 at MoMA's landmark exhibition Fantastic Art, Dada, Surrealism, an experience that she described as transformative. With her husband of thirty-four years, Max Ernst, she shared artistic adventures in New York, Arizona, Paris and the south of France. Best known as a painter and sculptor Tanning began late in life a remarkable second career as a writer and poet. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family and friends, especially her niece Mimi Johnson. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

FIGHTING BACK Philip A. Falcone, below, the head of Harbinger Capital Partners, took Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, to task for accusations about his lobbying efforts on behalf of LightSquared, his start-up wireless venture. As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Mr. Grassley has led a Congressional investigation into Mr. Falcone and LightSquared, seeking documents to determine why the Federal Communications Commission granted the company a crucial waiver. AZAM AHMED

The drug maker Pfizer said Wednesday that it was recalling packets of birth control pills because some had been packaged incorrectly, potentially causing women to take an inadequate dose and possibly become pregnant. The recall involves about a million packets, although only about 30 may actually have been affected, the company said Wednesday in a prepared statement.

MACK--Stuart A.,54, died on January 26, 2012. Attorney admitted to practice in 1984 New York State, graduate of SUNY Buffalo and New York Law School 1983. Defender of the penniless and lost causes. He won a major legal victory against the New York State Liquor Authority defending the rights of the famous Stonewall Bar to allow nude dancers in App. Div. 1st, 2006. He will be greatly missed by his numerous friends. Christopher Lynn, Esq.

GIVEN the surprising popularity of sneakers among the fashion set -- did every blog make note of Phoebe Philo taking her Céline runway bow in white trainers? -- this could be the season when high heels begin to look, er, flat. And note the stellar selection of designer sneaks in the shops: diamond prints from Lanvin, leather cutouts from Martin Margiela and zip-up high-tops from Pierre Hardy, among the many new choices. These studded styles from Miu Miu are worthy follow-ups to the line's heavily photographed glitter looks from last season. Miu Miu canvas and patent-leather sneakers with metal cap toes, $495 at miumiu.com.

Morgan Stanley, which has not had much joy in a rough year for Wall Street, had reason to celebrate on Wednesday. As the lead underwriter on Facebook's initial public offering, the firm will reap not only millions of dollars in fees, but more important, the bragging rights that come with what bankers described as a once-in-a-generation event.

Television viewers won't find out for several weeks whether Megan Hilty wins the leading role in a fictional Broadway musical about the life of Marilyn Monroe on the new NBC series ''Smash.'' But in another, more tangible sense, she has already landed a part made famous by that cinema bombshell, as Lorelei Lee in the coming Encores! production of ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes'' at New York City Center. Press representatives for Encores! said on Wednesday that Ms. Hilty would play the diamond-loving showgirl, portrayed by Carol Channing in the original 1949 Broadway musical and by Monroe in Howard Hawks's 1953 film adaptation. The musical, which features a book by Anita Loos and Joseph Fields, music by Jule Styne and lyrics by Leo Robin, will run at City Center from May 9 through 13, and will be directed by John Rando.

SHAMES--Frances. May 8, 1912 - January 29, 2012. Beloved sister of Sidney and Harold, the late Ethel and Ann (Weiss), nieces and nephews, Joan Berkowitz (Ira), Leila Maude (Alan), Mitchell (Jane), Kenneth, Howard (Chris), Barbara Livenstein, Harry Livenstein, Risa Silverston (Neil), and nine grand-nieces and nephews. Graduate of Morris High, attended CCNY. Director, Death Benefits Jury, NYS Worker's Compensation Board. WWII Staff Sergeant, Woman's Auxiliary US Marine Corps. Avid reader, Penn South Book Club, English History buff. Supporter veteran, social, hospital and progressive causes. Sophisticated sense of humor when asked about her longevity advice at 90th birthday at Tavern-on-the-Green: "At the Fountain of Youth in St. Augustine, FL, I was offered a cup full of water, I drank TWO." Tribute to FRANCES SHAMES FUND, Penn South Program for Seniors, 290 9th Ave. New York, NY 10001

The postholiday lull in new record releases is over, and as new recordings flood the market seven new albums showed up in the Top 10 of the Billboard 200 chart this week, led by Tim McGraw's ''Emotional Traffic,'' which sold 68,000 copies and landed in the No. 2 slot, Billboard reported. The top of the chart belonged to Adele once again. Her juggernaut album ''21'' remained at No. 1, selling 116,000 copies. But Drake's ''Take Care'' (No. 9) and the most recent installment of the Kidz Bop franchise (No. 6) were the only other holdovers in the Top 10 from last week.

An obituary on Saturday about the organist Gerre Hancock misstated one of his responsibilities at St. Thomas Church in Manhattan. He directed the church's choir and its music program, but not its choir school.

LOS ANGELES - ''21 Jump Street,'' based on the '80's television series about back-to-high school cops, but now with Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum in lead roles, will have its premiere on March 12 at the South by Southwest festival, the organization announced in unveiling its feature film program on Wednesday. Janet Pierson, producer of the festival's movie portion, noted ''a kind of aggressiveness, a boldness, risk-taking'' in 130 feature films that will screen between March 9 and March 17 in Austin, Tex. Ms. Pierson pointed, for example, to ''Dollhouse,'' an Irish film, from the writer-director Kirsten Sheridan, about five street kids who create havoc after breaking into a suburban Dublin home. Several documentaries in the program look at Los Angeles and the raucous past of its music culture. Those include ''Sunset Strip,'' about the history of that iconic portion of Sunset Boulevard, and ''Uprising: Hip Hop & the L.A. Riots.'' Celebrity figures in ''$ellebrity,'' a documentary by the star photographer Kevin Mazur, and in ''Decoding Deepak,'' also a documentary, in which Gotham Chopra examines his famous father, Deepak. The festival earlier announced that it would host the premiere of ''The Cabin in the Woods,'' a long-awaited horror film directed by Drew Goddard and written by Mr. Goddard and Joss Whedon. In all, programmers reviewed 1,957 feature-length submissions, including 1,387 from the United States, and 570 from abroad, the festival said. The full feature film program is listed here. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The schedule for the 12th edition of the Film Comment Selects festival, Feb.17-March 1, was announced Tuesday by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. The 32-film lineup features films that are previewing before their theatrical runs as well as some that might have been overlooked. Highlights will include a screening of Kenneth Lonergan's ''Margaret,'' ranked No. 20 on Film Comment's Best Films of 2011 poll, and Joshua Marston's ''The Forgiveness of Blood,'' a thriller about a feud in the Balkans. There will be several appearances by filmmakers and actors, including Sara Driver, James Franco and Paul Rudd. Tickets go on sale at the box office and online Thursday. Screenings will be held at the Walter Reade Theater, at 165 West 65th Street. More information is available here.

Coloradans are not New Yorkers -- they come to the mountains for scenery, wildlife, recreation and peace and quiet. ELLEN BAUDER,a leader of Roar Inc., a group opposed to a project by the artist Christo that would drape nearly six miles of the Arkansas River in southern Colorado with fabric. [A12]
International PROTESTERS BECOME VOTERS

9 P.M. (HBO) THE UNION (2011) When Elton John and Leon Russell met in 1970, Mr. John was on the verge of stardom with a self-titled album and a Top 10 hit, ''Your Song.'' Mr. Russell, who had played with Phil Spector and the Rolling Stones and written standards like ''A Song for You,'' was already rock 'n' roll royalty. Nearly four decades later Mr. John (above left, with Mr. Russell) was listening to Mr. Russell's greatest-hits album when he broke down in tears. Despite not having seen or spoken to Mr. Russell in more than 35 years, he was determined to reconnect with, and bring renewed attention to, this man who had been a strong musical influence. The result was ''The Union,'' their 2010 album of country-tinged collaborations like the Grammy-nominated ''If It Wasn't for Bad,'' whose creation was captured by the director Cameron Crowe. Shot during recording sessions at Village Studios in Los Angeles, the documentary, which opened the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival, weaves in concert footage of the men throughout their careers. 2:30 P.M. (Showtime) LARS AND THE REAL GIRL (2007) Lars, a sensitive loner (Ryan Gosling, below), forms an emotional bond with Bianca, a life-size sex doll, and soon she's attending school board meetings and being invited to dinner by well-meaning townsfolk. Paul Schneider and Emily Mortimer play Lars's incredulous brother and sister-in-law, who suggest that he and Bianca attend counseling. Kelli Garner is Margo, the real woman who catches Lars's eye -- though he would never cheat on Bianca. Mr. Gosling received a Golden Globe nomination for best actor; Nancy Oliver got an Oscar nomination for her screenplay. ''It's part comedy, part tragedy and 100 percent pure calculation, designed to wring fat tears and coax big laughs and leave us drying our damp, smiling faces as we savor the touching vision of American magnanimity,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times.

If you have ever wondered just how robust your computer is under the hood, Microsoft has a built-in feature included in Windows Vista and Windows 7 that measures the hardware's capability. Dubbed the Windows Experience Index, the tool analyzes several of the computer's hardware components to generate a ''base score.'' Microsoft says these base scores can be taken into consideration when buying programs to run on the machine. To see how your computer ranks, go to the Start menu to Control Panel. In the Control Panel's search box, type ''performance'' and click the resulting Performance and Information Tools link. Microsoft has more detailed information on evaluating base scores and improving the computer's performance here.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Saturday about plans by the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine to bring a second residential tower to its Morningside Heights campus misstated the status of the project. The cathedral and a developer have signed a memorandum of intent; they have not ''signed a lease agreement.'' The article also misstated the position held by Brad Taylor on Community Board 9, which represents the area, and misstated the provenance of items at the site, which already has a residential tower, called Avalon Morningside Park, completed in 2008. Mr. Taylor, an architect who opposes the planned tower, is a co-chairman of the board's parks, waterfront and recreation committee; he is not president of its landmarks committee. The construction sheds at the site are left over from a previous project; they were not ''left over from the Avalon project'' and there are no trailers there.

Because of an editing error, a picture credit on Wednesday with an article about Mitt Romney's victory in the Florida primary misidentified the photographer. Chip Litherland -- not Todd Heiseler -- took the photograph of Mr. Romney and his supporters celebrating his win.

SCHULTZ--Richard E. 1940-2012. Dear husband of Judith, cherished father of Kevin and Carrie Schultz, Cynthia and Anthony Hornig, and the proud and doting grandfather of Ryan and Rachel Schultz. Richard was a wonderful friend and colleague to so many, and will be missed and remembered as a remarkable and generous man. He was a dedicated mentor and humanitarian, providing opportunities to countless people. Richard was the Founder, President and CEO of Triad Securities, a Wall Street based full-service brokerage firm founded in 1976. Richard was a graduate of Baruch College (1962) and Forest Hills High School (1958). A man with a strong sense of family, Richard will remain forever in the hearts of those who loved him. In lieu of food or flowers, please make a donation to your favorite charity.

THE allure of a custom-made suit -- with every detail, from the sleeve length to the fit of the armhole, shaped to the exact contour of your body -- is what draws many tourists to Hong Kong and its famous tailors. But you don't have to go halfway across the world to be fitted by a Hong Kong tailor. Henry Alford traveled just a few blocks from his Manhattan apartment to see what the fuss was all about. Keith Bradsher, the Hong Kong bureau chief for The Times, offers some advice for those shoppers who want to go straight to the source. (Both articles are on Page 2.) And in Critical Shopper (Page 4), Jon Caramanica goes to SoHo to check out Suitsupply, which takes the superstore approach to custom-made suits.

ANYONE who has been to more than a handful of fashion shows knows that lugging an enormous bag is the mark of a standee. These chic iPad cases are tweaks on last season's must-have bag, the portfolio clutch. They have room for tickets, and with your tablet you can watch shows, tweet and read reviews, all while waiting for another show to start. Susie Lau, a k a Susie Bubble (left), has the look down. Stash any other loose bits in your coat pockets. It's the neighborly thing to do.

ATEYEH--Elaine (nee Khouri) 88, of Brooklyn, New York died February 1, 2012. Elaine was born on January 27, 1924 in Brooklyn, NY. She spent an adventurous and happy childhood growing up in Shanghai, China and graduated from SAS, the Shanghai American School. She was also a graduate of Fontbone Academy in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Her husband of 51 years, Edward C. Ateyeh, predeceased her in May 2001. Survived by her children, Michele of Manhattan, NY and Edward C. Ateyeh, Jr. and his wife, Elizabeth of Austin, TX. She is also survived by her two beloved grandchildren, Courtney Shields Ateyeh and Edward C. Ateyeh III of Austin, TX. Elaine, who passionately enjoyed the world of opera and classical music, will be deeply missed by her many dear friends, her extended family and the community of St. Mary's Antiochian Church. A wake will be held on Friday, February 3 at 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm at McLaughlin's Funeral Parlor, 9620 3rd Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday, February 4th at 9am at St. Mary's Antiochian Church, 8101 Ridge Blvd., Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to St. Mary's Antiochian Church, 8101 Ridge Blvd., Brooklyn, NY 11029.

ROSENWASSER--Lenore, died peacefully at home on January 31. Loving daughter of Ruby and Frances Dorfman. Beloved wife of Alan for 58 years, mother of Janet and Steven (Kelli Sager), grandmother of Ruby. Services at Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, noon Friday. Burial at Wellwood Cemetery.

DAVIS--John H.,passed away January 29th, 2012. Survived by his sister, Maude S. Davis and his dear friend, Sohodra Nathu. Mr. Davis first book was on his family, Bouvier, followed by books on the Guggenheim, Kennedys and Gambino crime family. Services will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Saturday, February 4, followed by a military burial at Woodlawn Cemetery.

Old Jedediah Spalding fell dangerously ill at his Connecticut home in early 1862. Word of his condition traveled hundreds of miles south and soon reached his son, Capt. J. Lewis Spalding, at Camp Barnes, located on the Virginia side of the Potomac River opposite Washington. On Feb. 6, Spalding requested a furlough to go home and care for his father. He had not been home in months; an energetic and ambitious young man, he had been busy rising through the military ranks. But his career would be a rocky one.

For an aspiring journalist like me, Boston in the early 1970s was nirvana. The Boston Globe was fat and sassy, with great characters like the idiosyncratic columnist George Frazier and the two-fisted sportswriter Will McDonough. The Boston Herald, a great working class paper, had not yet descended into shrill tabloid-hood. Boston Magazine published long, serious articles in between the "Best Doctors" and "Best Restaurants." The two alternative weeklies, The Boston Phoenix and The Real Paper, were thriving; their alumni-Paul Solman, Joe Klein, Laura Shapiro, Janet Maslin, Jon Landau, David Ansen, Renee Loth, Mark Leibovich and so many others-included some of the best journalists of their generation.

Since the Super Bowl matchup was decided a couple weeks ago, the spread on Sunday's game between the Giants and the Patriots has bounced around three points. It's been a long time since I studied statistics and probability (and maybe I never did, depending on how you define "study"), but it seems to me that this betting line is saying a few things. First, it'll be a close game. Second, one of the two teams is likely to have kicked a field goal at some point to get its final lead. Or third, if one team is trailing toward the end of the fourth quarter, it might well get a chance to kick a field goal to tie or win the game. Lastly, and this, really, is the red zone I'm driving toward: Everything will probably just come down to, in Peyton Manning's memorable words, an "idiot kicker."

We entered the indoor facility in Clifton, N.J., excited about our preparation for another professional season. We left heartbroken, feeling as if we had nothing to play for. In the instant I saw the e-mail that W.P.S. 2012 would not be taking place, my motivation was zapped. I had a lump in my throat. In late 20th-century Japan, tradition and radical innovation co-habitated perhaps more closely than ever before. Budget travelers took advantage, checking into capsule hotels where accommodations were more like stacked drawers (albeit expertly-designed drawers) than rooms. But these subcompact dwellings, like the Nakagin Capsule Tower, built in Tokyo in 1971 by Kisho Kurokawa, are more than just design oddities: they are manifestations of utopian urban planning theories hatched a decade earlier, when a generation of Japanese architects sought to brand their ultramodern solutions to problems such as overpopulation and the limitations of the aquatic frontier. After discarding several Japanese concepts that translated along the lines of "replacing old with new," "eternal return" or "constant change," they settled on an international term (well, an English one) and called their practice "Metabolism."

The broadcast networks took an all-hands-on-deck approach to the first night of February sweeps on Thursday and gave television viewers a full slate of new content. Based on preliminary Nielsen ratings, the top choice was once again "The Big Bang Theory" on CBS as it finished with a higher rating than "American Idol" in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for the third week in a row.  The good news for Fox was that "Idol" at least momentarily put a stop to its recent ratings slide, down only slightly among adults 18-to-49, and even gained back total viewers when compared to last week with an average of 17.1 million. It was still down 28 percent in the 18-to-49 category from the same Thursday episode last year.

"Romeo and Juliet: The War," which Mr. Lee co-wrote with Terry Douglas, ends up at No. 7 on both the hardcover and paperback graphic books best-seller lists. Sister Sledge Sues Over Digital Royalties: Numerous artists, from Eminem to Rob Zombie, have sued record companies in recent years over how royalties are computed for digital music. Sister Sledge, the disco-era rhythm and blues group ("We Are Family"), is the latest to argue that a label -- in this case, the Warner Music Group -- has violated the terms of its contract by counting downloads as sales rather than as licenses, which pay higher royalties, The Hollywood Reporter notes. The lawsuit, which seeks to be granted class-action status, was filed in Federal District Court in San Francisco; the four Sledge sisters were joined by the actress and singer Ronee Blakley.

Some N.C.A.A. rules are so stupid that even the N.C.A.A. admits they are stupid. Earlier this week, it put the University of Nebraska on "probation" for two years, and fined it $38,000 for what the N.C.A.A. described as a "major" violation of the rules. Apparently for some years the university bookstore had been giving the school's athletes not just the books that were required for their courses, but also the books that their professors recommended as helpful reading for their classes. Incredibly, the organization that insists on calling college football players "student athletes" does not allow them to get anything but the required books under the terms of their scholarships. Giving them the recommended books is against the rules.  Although my "stupid rules" contest is going to run into next week-and we've gotten some great entries!-this one is going to be hard to top. Truly, it defies belief.

At the Waverly Inn last night, friends and editors celebrated the five-year anniversary of the New York label Ohne Titel with its designers, Flora Gill and Alexa Adams. Hosted by John Demsey, the president of Esteé Lauder Cosmetics, and M.A.C., the intimate affair in the Waverly's fire-warmed back room was billed proudly as an opportunity for Gill and Adams to thank and honor the many stylish women who have inspired and supported their label over the years. Among those in attendance were Paper Magazine's Kim Hastreiter, the T contributor Lynn Yaeger, Cecilia Dean and Michelle Harper. The odd man out - and a delightful surprise to see at the room's elegant, ranunculus-full tables - was Antony Hegarty, the lead singer for Antony and the Johnsons. Calm and gracious (with less than two weeks before their fall 2012 runway showon Monday, Feb. 12 at Milk Studios), Gill and Adams gave guests an evening as refreshing and hip as their recent collections. "Now, it's just about the details," said Gill about what's left to do before Fashion Week starts. Cheers to that.

Throughout the major industrial countries, long-term growth rates have been falling, and they may keep doing so. The latest forecasts by the International Monetary Fund point to slow growth over the next two years in most major countries, and to a shrinking economy in Italy. If the I.M.F. forecasts prove to be accurate, Italy’s economy will be smaller at the end of 2013 than it was 10 years earlier. The charts show 10-year cumulative annual growth rates for gross domestic product in seven countries. The nominal figures show growth before inflation is considered; the real numbers show the rates after adjusting for inflation. G.D.P. growth is typically presented in real terms.

Alberto Alessi, the managing director of Alessi, the Italian manufacturer of high-design objects for the home, must have caffeine in his blood. His maternal grandfather, Alfonso Bialetti, invented and produced the first stovetop espresso pot, the Bialetti Moka Express, in the 1930s. The octagonal aluminum coffeemaker became - and remains - an Italian kitchen staple and a cultural icon.

BOGATCH--Florence, passed away on February 1, 2012. She was the most loving, caring, kind person who always put others before herself. Her passion and spirit will live on forever in all those whose hearts she touched. She is survived by her loving husband Harry; her wonderful children Alan and Amy, Linda and Warren; her adoring grandchildren Ross and Caryn, Keith and Marissa, Laura and Bryan, Randi, Daniel and Jordan and her adorable great-grandchild Luke. She was the loving daughter of Rebecca and Albert and loving sister of George and Ray Hyman and Marilyn.

2:54 p.m. | Updated The man charged with trying to kill a plainclothes New York police officer was ordered held without bail on Thursday at Brooklyn Criminal Court, where a prosecutor characterized the shooting as a ''heinous'' act committed by an ''evil'' man. With dozens of police officers in attendance, the man, Luis Ortiz, 21, stayed silent during the proceeding. Afterward, his lawyer, Eric G. Poulos, insisted that his client was not guilty of shooting the officer, Kevin Brennan, 29, of New Hyde Park, N.Y.

KELLEY--Mike. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with deep sadness the loss of Mike Kelley. Mike has been a touchstone, a poignant conscience for us. His iconic More Love Hours Than Can Ever Be Repaid and The Wages of Sin, purchased from the 1989 Biennial, is one of the most - admired works in the Museum's collection. Even as we mourn his death, we look ahead, knowing that his vision will guide our future understanding of contemporary art. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his brother George Kelley. ATEYEH--Elaine (nee Khouri) 88, of Brooklyn, New York died February 1, 2012. Elaine was born on January 27, 1924 in Brooklyn, NY. She spent an adventurous and happy childhood growing up in Shanghai, China and graduated from SAS, the Shanghai American School. She was also a graduate of Fontbone Academy in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Her husband of 51 years, Edward C. Ateyeh, predeceased her in May 2001. Survived by her children, Michele of Manhattan, NY and Edward C. Ateyeh, Jr. and his wife, Elizabeth of Austin, TX. She is also survived by her two beloved grandchildren, Courtney Shields Ateyeh and Edward C. Ateyeh III of Austin, TX. Elaine, who passionately enjoyed the world of opera and classical music, will be deeply missed by her many dear friends, her extended family and the community of St. Mary's Antiochian Church. A wake will be held on Friday, February 3 at 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm at McLaughlin's Funeral Parlor, 9620 3rd Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral Mass will be held on Saturday, February 4th at 9am at St. Mary's Antiochian Church, 8101 Ridge Blvd., Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to St. Mary's Antiochian Church, 8101 Ridge Blvd., Brooklyn, NY 11029.

The Disruptions column on Jan. 23, about Silicon Valley's perceptions of the value of social networking companies, misstated the amount and estimated current value of an early investment in Facebook by Peter Thiel, the co-founder of PayPal. It was $500,000, not $100,000, and its current value is estimated at $2 billion, not $1 billion, based on an upper range value of $100 billion for Facebook.

SAYLES--Maria Agripina Popescu, September 20, 1918- January 28, 2012. Born in Romania to Dumitru Popescu, a head of the Romanian Orthodox Church and Elena Staaiculescu. Maria arrived on Ellis Island in 1950. She resided in NYC, Stockton, NJ, Houston, TX, Pagosa CO, Santa Fe, NM and La Jolla, CA, where she died of natural causes. She was married 44 years to Philip A. Sayles Jr., a former Senior Vice President of the Macy's Corp. She is survived by her daughter Carina C. Sayles and her grandchildren Wells and Olivia Hartman. Maria was a member of the Daughters of the King of the Episcopal Church and active in the Institute for International Education, the Houston Ballet, the Alley Theater, and the Santa Fe Museum of Art. Memorials may be made to The American Boychoir.americanboychoir.org

6:11 a.m. | Updated LONDON - Glencore International, the biggest commodities trading company in the world, has approached the mining company Xstrata about a takeover, a long-anticipated deal that would create a company with a market value of about $80 billion.

Showtime is staying in the business of shame, lies and other bad behavior. The cable network said on Wednesday that it is ordering additional seasons of its new series ''House of Lies,'' as well as veteran shows ''Shameless'' and ''Californication,'' both of which have seen their audiences increase. ''House of Lies,'' which stars Don Cheadle and Kristen Bell as ruthless management consultants, drew more than 1 million viewers for its Jan. 8 debut, surpassing the premiere episode of Showtime's acclaimed new drama ''Homeland.'' Meanwhile, Sunday's most recent broadcast of ''Shameless,'' which stars Emmy Rossum and William H. Macy as members of a deeply dysfunctional working-class Chicago family, drew 1.4 million viewers, topping the highly promoted premiere of rival HBO's new series ''Luck.'' Ratings for ''Californication,'' which stars David Duchovny as a promiscuous novelist, are also up 10 percent over its previous season, Showtime said. Production on new episodes of all three naughty shows will begin in Los Angeles later this year. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

No matter how you slice the numbers for this year's best-picture nominees, they look the same: dismal. The year's nine nominees, according to the charts from boxofficemojo.com, have taken in about $546 million at the domestic box office to date, down 56 percent from the $1.234 billion that had been taken in by this point by 10 nominees last year.

Claremont McKenna College gave too much authority over reporting test scores to a single individual without proper controls, the college's president, Pamela B. Gann, said Thursday in her first interview since it was revealed that Claremont McKenna had submitted manipulated SAT data to ratings agencies for six years. The misreporting occurred because ''a sole person had too much authority over reporting,'' Ms. Gann said. People with knowledge of the matter identified that person as Richard C. Vos, a vice president and dean of admissions at the college who resigned last weekend.

Not everyone on Wall Street is giddy over Facebook's initial public offering of stock. A group of private exchanges has popped up in recent years to accommodate a fast-growing trading market in the private shares of the Internet companies like Twitter and LinkedIn. Facebook has driven much of this growth, emerging as the most actively traded private company by a wide margin.

Fresh off his strong win in Florida, Mitt Romney received more good news from a new poll in Nevada that showed him with a wide lead over Newt Gingrich just days before the state's caucuses. The poll, conducted by Cannon Survey Center at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas for the Las Vegas Review-Journal and 8NewsNow, found Mr. Romney supported by 45 percent of likely caucusgoers, compared with 25 percent for Mr. Gingrich, 11 percent for Rick Santorum and 9 percent for Ron Paul. About 1 in 10 say they are still undecided.

INDIANAPOLIS -- DeMaurice Smith, the executive director of the N.F.L. Player's Association, held his organization's annual news conference Thursday afternoon. He smiled often and seemed in the mood to celebrate. This was, of course, far different than last year's version. Smith spoke of the labor peace the N.F.L.P.A. reached with the league before the season started and said he would not change anything. He thanked the members of his executive committee, including Tony Richardson, the retired fullback, who Smith said had ''played for 47 years.'' Smith even got emotional at times and at least once referred to himself in the third person.

ROUSSEAS--Stephen W.,Dexter M. Ferry Jr. Emeritus Professor of Economics at Vassar College, and, as he was affectionately known by family and friends, "the world's greatest authority," died on February 1, 2012, at age 91, in Poughkeepsie, NY. Born on January 11, 1921 in Scranton, PA, he was the son of the late William and Lillian Rousseas. He graduated from Columbia with a B.S., 1948; A.M., 1949; Ph.D., 1954. He taught at Columbia University, the University of Michigan, Yale University, Cornell University, New York University, and Vassar College where he was very much respected by his students. He is the author of The Death of Democracy: Greece and the American Conscience, Monetary Theory, Capitalism and Catastrophe: A Critical Appraisal of the Limits of Capitalism, The Political Economy of Reaganomics: A Critique, and numerous articles and reviews. A friend of Andreas and Margaret Papandreou, the Greek political figure and his wife, he was very active in American organizations supporting Papandreou after the 1967 coup d'etat in Greece. Survivors include his beloved wife, Claude Rousseas (nee Chauvierre); brother and sister-in-law, Peter and Stella Rousseas; brother-in-law John Gabriel; cousin Florence Zaneteas; nephews Phillip, William, Dean, William, and Stephen; nieces Anne, Pamela, Cynthia, and Lynn; and was a great great uncle to many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his brother and sister-in-law, Anargeros and Violet Rousseas; and his sisters, Athena Gabriel and Panayota Karamanena. Visitation will be held on Saturday, February 4, from 2-5pm at Timothy P. Doyle Funeral Home, 371 Hooker Ave. Poughkeepsie, NY.

An article on Tuesday about a trademark infringement lawsuit by the University of Alabama against the artist Daniel Moore, who paints the Alabama football team in action, misstated the name of the court that heard an appeal in the case on Thursday. It is the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta, not the Alabama Appeals Court. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the university's charge against Moore at one point. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, Moore was sued for trademark infringement, not copyright infringement.

SCHULMAN--Herbert, M.D.,age 83, died on January 7, 2012, from complications from a fall. He leaves his devoted wife Phyllis, sons Andrew (Peg) of Bedford, NH and Ted (Sandy) of Washington, DC, and five adored grandchildren. Graduated Princeton 1949 and SUNY Downstate Medical 1953. Practiced psychiatry for 50 years in NYC. Hastings-on-Hudson, Westchester County Medical Center, and U.S. Army. He moved to an assisted living facility in DC in 2009. He donated his body to medical education and research. Donations in his honor can be sent to Howard University College of Medicine, Dept. of Anatomy, 520 W St. NW, Washington, D.C., 20059 Attn: Ms. Karine Sewell.

ALBANY - The state ethics commission, meeting behind closed doors this week, named a top aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo as its executive director, raising questions about its independence from the executive branch and its commitment to transparency. The new executive director, Ellen N. Biben, is a respected former deputy in the Manhattan district attorney's office, and she has also served as a deputy under Mr. Cuomo in the attorney general's office and as his inspector general, a job she is giving up. Her years of service to Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, are leading some lawmakers to question privately how vigorously she will pursue inquiries into corruption in the executive branch, or whether she will focus more on the Legislature.

What can Siri help you with now? The voice-activated operator built into Apple's iPhone 4S can assist you with landing a book deal and perhaps even with filling that void in your soul where a human romantic partner should go. That's the premise, anyway, of ''Siri & Me,'' a new work of fiction by David Milgrim that will be published in the fall by the Blue Rider Press imprint of Penguin Group and whose acquisition was reported by Publishers Marketplace.

Angelo Dundee, the renowned trainer who guided Muhammad Ali and Sugar Ray Leonard to boxing glory, died on Wednesday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 90. His death was announced by his son-in-law, James Coughlin, who said Dundee had recently been treated for blood clots.

Since 1948, every president with an approval rating that wasat least a few points above 50 percent has won re-election. Every president more than a few points below 50 percent has lost. President Obama is now hovering in between, as were Gerald Ford in 1976 (who lost), Harry S. Truman in 1948 and George W. Bush in 2004 (who both won). DAVID LEONHARDT

Former Ohio State football coach Jim Tressel has landed a new job, and it's taking him back to the origins of his career. Tressel is the new vice president for strategic engagement at the University of Akron, according to The Columbus Dispatch and The Akron Beacon Journal, returning to the school where he started his collegiate coaching career as a graduate assistant in 1975. The Akron Beacon Journal reports Tressel will earn $200,000 per year in the non-athletics position.

FELSEN--David. Beloved Dad, Zadie and "Alter Zadie". It is hard to believe he is gone one year today. Remembered, missed and loved always. His generosity of spirit lives on. With love, from his family

STEIN--Arthur, of New York City and Amagansett, NY, February 2 in Manhattan, at age 81. Son of the late Estelle (Roth) and Morris Stein, Arthur was born in 1930 in Weehawken, NJ. Proud alumnus of the Brown University class of 1952, Arthur served in the U.S. Army during the Korean War, and was stationed in Japan, where he became fluent in Japanese. At age 29 Arthur founded a leading company in the point-of-purchase display business. Arthur was an international competitive backgammon player, painter, and avid reader of history. He was a lifetime member of the Art Students League of New York and a former member of the Board of Trustees of the Art Barge at the Victor D'Amico Institute of Art in Amagansett. A lifelong athlete, Arthur was an original member of the East Hampton Tennis Club. Arthur is survived by his loving wife of 21 years, Jane Cranston of New York, NY, his brother Larry Stein of Cave Junction, OR, his son Jonathan Stein of West Palm Beach, FL, his daughter Allison Stein of Santa Monica, CA, his daughter-in-law Mary Stein Pollard of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, and his grandchildren Samantha, Danny, Jacob, and Jessie Claire. Services will be held Friday, February 3 at 11:00am, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Family is receiving visitors Friday 7-9pm and Saturday 2-4pm at 1000 Park Avenue, New York. Donations in Arthur's honor may be made to Brown University.
7:19 p.m. | Updated Goldman Sachs has been battling a seemingly never-ending barrage of negative publicity since the financial crisis.

WASHINGTON -- Unpopular and divided, the once mighty House Republicans are laboring to repair their image and frame a new agenda. Absent for now is a big, contentious docket similar to last year's, which included the goal of writing new health care legislation to replace the Obama administration's law. A long-promised overhaul of the tax code seems out of reach. When Representative Eric Cantor, the Virginia Republican and majority leader, issued a memo this week laying out the body's initial legislative agenda, a centerpiece was a modest tax cut for small businesses.

The question of where ''American Idol'' will finally settle in the ratings this season was not answered Wednesday, as television's one-time powerhouse continued to lose viewers. Even worse, the percentage of viewers it lost, compared with the same night last year, was the biggest so far this season. In the ratings that most matter to Fox - viewers between the ages of 18 and 49 - ''Idol'' was down 34 percent from the Wednesday one-hour edition last year. That eclipsed the 25 percent loss it has been averaging for the previous episodes this season.

10:30 A.M. (Nickelodeon) MIKE THE KNIGHT This new computer-animated series invites preschoolers into an enchanted medieval world of castles, dragons and trolls while teaching about friendship, loyalty and determination as they follow the adventures of Mike, a knight in training, above left. His motto is ''Be a knight, do it right,'' which he accomplishes with the help of his trusty steed, Galahad, and the friendly dragons Squirt and Sparkie. The series, which will be broadcast weekdays at noon starting Monday, was created by Alexander Bar (''Lunar Jim'') and written by Marc Seal (''Bob the Builder''). 2:25 P.M. (Sundance) PARIS (2008) Romain Duris plays Pierre, a dancer at the Moulin Rouge who is awaiting a heart transplant that could save his life. Juliette Binoche is Élise, his older, divorced sister, a social worker who moves into his apartment with her three children to care for him -- and in the process opens his eyes to the city's possibilities. A subplot follows the romantic misadventures of a history professor (Fabrice Luchini) who becomes so besotted with a beautiful student (Mélanie Laurent) that he sends her anonymous text messages, some in cyberspeak -- ''U R awesome. I'm 2 hot 4 U.'' -- and others quoting the love poetry of Baudelaire. ''In 'Paris,' Cédric Klapisch's sumptuous Gallic comedy, the camera, whether surveying the landmarks from on high or peering out of an apartment window at the passing parade, becomes a surrogate for a first-time visitor to the City of Light,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''Both a Parisian answer to Woody Allen's 'Manhattan' and a multicharacter mosaic in the mode of Robert Altman's 'Short Cuts,' the movie sprawls invitingly across the screen like a glowing Impressionist painting.''

HOLBY--Aase-Grethe, passed away peacefully in her daughter's home in New York on Thursday morning January. 26th of natural causes. She was 91 years old. Aase was born January 17, 1921 in Oslo Norway. Her father died when she was seven, leaving her mother and five children without a livelihood, but her mother managed to keep her home and raise her children through the Depression. In 1941 Aase graduated from Oslo Handels Gymnasium (Business School). She had dreamed of being a fashion designer, but with the Germans now occupying Norway, she went to work for the Norwegian Government-in-exile, serving in the Resistance. She assisted in her Austrian-Jewish brother-in-law's escape from Norway and thereafter, posing as a young mother, she took Norwegian-Jewish children to safety over the border into neutral Sweden. While working for the Resistance in Trondheim in 1943, she was awoken in the middle of the night by the Germans and imprisoned in a concentration camp in Norway, where she spent the next 18 months of her life. Released in 1944 to be followed, she escaped into Sweden and worked for the Norwegian Embassy in Stockholm. She was transferred in 1945 to England, celebrating VE-Day with the British, and then onto the Norwegian Embassy in New York. Aase was offered a job in the newly formed United Nations, which was then laying plans to move to New York, (the first Secretary-General was Norwegian) but opted instead for family and homemaking, marrying in 1947 and moving to Larchmont, NY. Her beloved husband Warren B. Holby was a founding partner of Merritt & Holby - a firm building post-war housing developments in Westchester County, later developing office parks and Rye Ridge Shopping Center - the first Shopping Center in the eastern United States. While raising her family in Larchmont, Aase was active in many local organizations, including Planned Parenthood of Westchester, Larchmont Women's and The Newcomer's Clubs, was a Trustee of Larchmont Avenue Church and Chairman of Larchmont Assembly. Aase and Warren also enjoyed their home in Ludlow, VT, where she was a devoted volunteer for Skiing with the Blind. Aase was active in all things Norwegian. She served as Chair of the American-Scandinavian Society-Social Comm, a director of Scandinavian Seminar and an active contributor at the Norwegian Seamen's Church. Aase and Warren traveled to Norway annually in their later years, both to Oslo and the mountain log-home. Warren passed away in 2002. Aase is survived by her four children: Grethe Holby Elgort of New York, Kristin C. Holby Darnell of Larchmont, NY, W. Barrett Holby Jr. of Warren, RI and Wegard D. Holby of Upper Black Eddy, PA; and eleven grandchildren: Sophie, Warren and Ansel Elgort; Duncan, Phoebe and Camilla White; Robin and Will Holby; and Sara, Kate and Jack Holby. On January 17th Aase celebrated her 91st birthday with her family. May she rest in peace after her eventful, adventurous, extraordinarily happy life, full of love. Funeral Services will be held Saturday, February 4th at 1:30pm at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, New York. Memorial gifts may be sent to New Life, 66 Clinton St. 2nd Flr., New York, NY 10002; or The Children's Village-Development, 1 Echo Hills, Dobbs Ferry, NY 10522.

Facebook has driven much of this growth, emerging as the most actively traded private company by a wide margin.

HAWES, Rosilla Hornblower. Died on January 27, 2012 at the age of 100. Most beloved mother of Lynden B. Miller, cherished mother-in-law of Leigh M. Miller and adored grandmother of Gifford, Marshall, Ethan, and Christian Miller, their wives and eight great-grandchildren whose lives she enriched with her kind, loving and generous nature and her wide-ranging knowledge of literature, public affairs and history. She was born in New York City in 1911 and attended the Chapin School and Vassar College, class of 1933. She was married in 1935 to Alan R. Breed who died in 1954. In 1979 she married Alexander B. Hawes who died in 1995. She lived in Washington, D.C. for many years before returning to her native New York almost a decade ago. Her New York roots went way back in New York history. Her ancestors ranged from Susannah Rutgers Marshall, a businesswoman in 18th century New Amsterdam, the Architect, Henry Rutgers Marshall, to Judge William B. Hornblower of the New York Court of Appeals, as well as many other New York architects and lawyers. Her family for many generations believed passionately in public service, and dinner conversation when she was growing up always centered on current events and politics. After Vassar, where she majored in sociology and economics, she worked at the National Consumers League, an organization dedicated to helping women in the workplace founded by Frances Perkins. From long family tradition, she was always a passionate Democrat and, as she put it, "a New Yorker to the bone," so she delighted in the public careers of her two grandsons, Gifford Miller, former Speaker of the New York City Council, and Marshall Miller, Chief of the Criminal Division at the United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York. Though not a gardener herself, she was proud of her daughter, Lynden B. Miller, Public Garden Designer, in her role of beautifying the city they both loved. For those lucky enough to know her, she personified a LADY: elegant, gracious, thoughtful, tactful and sympathetic to everyone she met. She spent her life cherishing the many people she loved and supporting New York City causes and institutions like The New York Botanical Garden, The New York Public Library and The Community Service Society. Contributions in her memory could be made to any of those organizations.

As the political attacks on Mitt Romney's record at Bain Capital have intensified, many have wondered when the private equity industry would try to mount a full defense of its practices. Now, after months of quiet complaining, some buyout defenders are punching back. Hamilton E. James, the president of the Blackstone Group and one of the highest-ranking titans of the private equity industry, spoke in full-throated support of the business on Thursday, the same day Blackstone reported its fourth-quarter earnings.

There was little to be learned at Madonna's news conference Thursday other than the fact that the pop star does not regularly watch football, is recovering from a strained hamstring and is a fan of Victor Cruz's salsa dancing. In 20 minutes of mostly light-hearted banter, the star of this year's Super Bowl halftime show made many references to her roots in the Midwest (including saying that this was probably her father's favorite of her many career moves) and frequently gave questioners a hard time if they asked something silly or unanswerable.
LOS ANGELES RABBI MARVIN HIER is in the home stretch of a seven-and-a-half year tour through the Talmud, day by day, page by page. He is also mulling his Oscar ballot.

An obituary on Tuesday about the record producer Larry Butler, using information from his family, misspelled the given name of one of his survivors and the surname of another. His daughter is Schanda Olsson, not Shanda, and his sister is Ava Chopp, not Chop.

Throughout the week, Mike Tanier will be out and about and filing dispatches from the Super Bowl city. INDIANAPOLIS -- As corporations, advertisers, and promoters compete for national attention in the days leading up to the Super Bowl, some made-for-the-news-media events start to resemble pu-pu platters. If one attraction does not draw a crowd, three tangentially related ones surely will. The combination of theformer Giants receiver Amani Toomer, an 18-foot-high ice sculpture of the Manhattan skyline, a MetLife chief marketing officer and a Firefighters Museum two miles from the downtown hub of Super Bowl activities sounds like the brainchild of a mad scientist experimenting with a Random Event Generator. Scheduling the entire event at dawn adds a sublime touch. Surreal as it all sounds, the folks at MetLife really did unveil their nine-ton ice sculpture, which depicts the Statue of Liberty, the Empire State Building, the MetLife Building, MetLife Stadium and Snoopy, in the parking lot of the Indianapolis Firefighters Museum at 6 a.m. Thursday, with Toomer on hand to add a bit of star wattage.
GAMBERT--Gry, 59, on January 30, 2012. Beloved wife, mother, svigermor, farmor, friend; founder, Baltimore Dharma Group. Memorial on February 2, 2012 at 1pm.

HENRICHS--Patricia Collins. Beloved mother, grandmother, artist and friend, died peacefully on January 29, near her family in Boston, MA. She had endured a prolonged illness with courage and humor. Pat was born November 24, 1934 in New York to Vincent Collins and Rose Gilheany Collins. She attended Marymount High School, Manhattanville College in Purchase, and graduated from the Pratt Institute. Art was a joy and an essential for her throughout her life; her fine pen and ink drawings illuminated a number of books, and won a citation at the 2005 New England Book Show. She is survived by two daughters and sons-in-law: Maud and Andrew Cabot of Boston and Beata and Josh Lieb of Los Angeles and four grandchildren: Henry and India Cabot, Gus and Charlotte Lieb, and her former husband, Marshall Henrichs of Littleton, MA.

COHEN--Robert B.,86, died peacefully on February 1, 2012 at his home in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Harriet Brandwein, cherished father of James and his spouse Lisa, and devoted grandfather of six, Samantha, Robert II, Justin, Michael, Alexander and Jacqueline. He is also survived by his sister Rosalind Stone. He was predeceased by his son Michael and daughter Claudia, and his sister Betty Fast. Robert was a long time Owner and President of Hudson News, the largest airport retailer in the country and major wholesale distributor of magazines and books. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on Friday, February 3, 2012 at The Bergen Performing Arts Center, 30 N Van Brunt Street, Englewood, NJ at 11:30am.

Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band will perform during the Grammy Awards ceremony on Feb. 12, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences said Thursday morning. Mr. Springsteen, who is not nominated this year but has a new album, ''Wrecking Ball,'' slated for release in March, joins a lineup of performers that includes Jason Aldean, Blake Shelton, Rihanna, Foo Fighters, Katy Perry and Paul McCartney. In mid-2012, Mr. Springsteen and the E Street Band will begin their first tour since 2009 including a number of dates in the New York area. In March, Mr. Springsteen and his band will also perform at the Apollo Theater in Harlem at a special concert to be broadcast on SiriusXM, that radio network announced this week. The concert on March 9 will mark the first time Mr. Springsteen has played that hall with the E Street Band and is intended to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the satellite radio network. It will be broadcast live on channel 20, which is devoted to Mr. Springsteen's music.

-After a 32-year run, the Oak Room, the fabled supper club and cabaret at the Algonquin Hotel on West 44th Street in Manhattan, will no longer operate when the hotel reopens in May after an extensive renovation, the Algonquin's general manager, Gary J. Budge, announced on Thursday. He cited declining audiences in spite of ''top-notch performers.'' In its three decades the Oak Room was the venue of choice for artists like Andrea Marcovicci, who celebrated her 25th season at the club at the end of last year, as well as Karen Akers, KT Sullivan, Sandy Stewart and Bill Charlap, Steve Ross, and Barbara Carroll, who established a successful Sunday jazz brunch series. The club also gave important exposure to younger performers like Maude Maggart and Emily Bergl.
CORNWELL--Bruce, of Brooklyn, filmmaker, died at home on January 26 at 89 years. Memorial, 24 March, 2pm First Church 124 Henry St. Brooklyn. bkcfilms.com

ROSENWASSER--Lenore, died peacefully at home on January 31. Loving daughter of Ruby and Frances Dorfman. Beloved wife of Alan for 58 years, mother of Janet and Steven (Kelli Sager), grandmother of Ruby. Services at Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, noon Friday. Burial at Wellwood Cemetery.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, and her close relationship with a well-connected lobbyist, Emily Giske, misstated Ms. Giske's marital status. She is married to Anne Washburn, who was also pictured; Ms. Washburn is not her ''partner'' in the context of domestic partnerships.
Images from a new exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

WARD--Jane Downing. Jane Downing Ward, of Richmond, Va., Vero Beach, Fla., and Wellfleet, Mass. passed away peacefully on January 31, 2012. A native of Hingham, Mass., she graduated from the University of New Hampshire in 1948. An avid gardener, Jane was a former president of the Providence Garden Club of Pa. and the Garden Club of America. She also served as chair of the Philadelphia Flower Show. She had a gift for finding the best in each person she met and making them feel special and appreciated. Jane is lovingly remembered by Charles G. Ward Jr., her husband of 62 years; sister, Gail Hewitt; sons, Chuck, David and Matt; daughters-in-law, Donna, Sharon and Mary; 10 grandchildren and five nephews and nieces. A memorial service will be held at her summer home on Cape Cod. In lieu of flowers, a memorial contribution can be sent to McKee Botanical Garden, 250 U.S. 1, Vero Beach, Fla. 32962
Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday about the Nobel Prize-winning poet Wislawa Szymborska misstated the pronunciation of her given name. It is vees-WAH-vah, not VEES-mah-vah.

The City Room column in some editions on Wednesday, about peacocks that live on the grounds of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, in Morningside Heights, misstated a title of Phillip Foote, after whom one of the peacocks is named. He is a former head of the Cathedral School, which is also on the grounds, not its business manager. (His namesake goes by Phil.)

7:57 p.m. | Updated The economic pie is growing, but the share going to American workers is at a record low. Friday's jobs report is expected to show that Americans are not on their way to getting a bigger cut. Much is at stake in the Labor Department report, which economists predict will reflect unemployment stagnating at 8.5 percent in January. Lackluster job growth could bolster the Republican argument that President Obama's economic policies are leaving American workers behind.

An article on Jan. 26 about possible action in Congress to increase taxes on the rich described imprecisely Senator Charles E. Schumer's record on proposals to raise the tax rate on the income of investment fund managers -- known as ''carried interest'' -- to the ordinary income tax rate from the lower capital gains rate. While Mr. Schumer, a Democrat of New York, did indeed say in 2007 that he would oppose legislation under consideration that year unless it also applied to real estate and energy holdings, his legislative record on the question does not extend ''for years'' prior to that. (More recently, he has voted to close the loophole.)

WASHINGTON - Congress delved deeper into the downfall of MF Global on Thursday, accusing the rating agencies and one of the firm's chief risk officers of failing to sound alarms. At the hearing, the fourth Congressional forum to focus on MF Global, lawmakers homed in on the firm's risky purchases of European sovereign debt and the crisis of confidence that ultimately led to the brokerage's demise and the mysterious disappearance of some $1.2 billion in customer money.

INDIANAPOLIS -- N.F.L. owners, in a brief meeting here Thursday, approved a $200 million loan for the San Francisco 49ers, who hope to soon break ground in Santa Clara, Calif., on a replacement for Candlestick Park. The stadium, which would be across the street from the 49ers' training facility, will probably cost about $1 billion and seat about 68,000 people. The rest of the project will be funded by an $850 million construction loan that Santa Clara approved in December.

A picture caption on Thursday with an appraisal of the career of Don Cornelius, the creator of ''Soul Train,'' who was found dead on Wednesday, gave an incorrect date from the Everett Collection archive for the photograph. The picture, of Mr. Cornelius and the R&B duo Calloway, was from 1989, not 1971.

An obituary on Tuesday about Joseph E. Brooks, the former chairman and chief executive of the Lord & Taylor retail chain, misspelled part of the name of the store where he entered the sales training program after attending Pennsylvania State University and misidentified the city in which it was located. It was Abraham & Straus, not Abraham & Strauss, and it was in Brooklyn, not in Philadelphia.

MARTUCCI--Antoinette. "Nettie", passed away on January 31, 2012. Loving mother, adored grandmother and sister. A superb manager for over 30 years of Joseph Belsky House, a United Cerebral Palsy sponsored, federally funded 76 unit residential apartment building on Lawrence Avenue in Brooklyn; Named for Joseph Belsky, former International President of The Amalgamated Butcher Workmen of North America. Nettie and her family lavished their love and daily concern for the 76 residents of Belsky House and gave unstintingly of their love to them. She was adored and respected and will be sorely missed. Our respect and appreciation to her beloved family for the many years of selfless dedication. Jerome Belson Chairman, UCP of NYC

The identities of several major donors to Restore Our Future, the ''super PAC'' backing Mitt Romney, remain hidden from public view, even after their recent filing with the Federal Election Commission, because their contributions were made through limited liability companies or other entities that seem to exist solely on paper. At 7:08 a.m. on Thursday, the sun rose over Manhattan. The groundhog in the American Museum of Natural History stood erect beside his burrow and gazed unblinking into the flat light. A faint shadow appeared at his feet, but he did not retreat. At the burrow's entrance, his partner peered out and beheld the dimly lit corridor of the Hall of North American Mammals.

The playwright Horton Foote, whose tightly focused anatomies of small-town families have been a staple of Off Broadway since the 1980s, culminating in his nine-hour ''Orphans' Home Cycle'' during the 2009-10 season, will be among the writers produced in the upcoming 2012-13 season at Primary Stages, the theater company announced on Thursday. Three short plays by Foote, who died in 2009 at the age 92, will be performed together July 24-Sept. 15 under the direction of Pam MacKinnon (''Clybourne Park''). The plays, collected under the title ''Harrison, Tx.,'' are ''Blind Date,'' The One-Armed Man'' and ''The Midnight Caller.''

GREGORIADES--Athanasia, 76, died February 1, 2012 in New York City. Born in Skalohori Kozanis, Greece, she emigrated with her family to New York in 1947. She received her B.S. and two M.S. degrees from Hunter College, and taught and worked for the New York City Board of Education. She was a passionate and tireless advocate for Greek causes, human rights, and for social justice, and was a generous supporter of many charities. She is survived by her sister, Paula; her nephews, Alexander, Nicholas, and Alexander; and her niece, Kristine. Services will be held Saturday February 4, 9am at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St.

CBS News cameras were lined up inside the billionaire investor Warren Buffett's office on Wednesday for a new edition of ''Person to Person,'' a celebrity interview show that dates back to the 1950s, when Edward R. Murrow was the host. Newly revived by CBS, ''Person to Person'' will feature Mr. Buffett, the actor George Clooney and the singer Jon Bon Jovi on the episode that will be shown on Wednesday, Feb. 8. The network plans to announce the lineup on Thursday morning.

Winter has finally come to Europe, with extraordinary effect. Rome is under snow - for the first time in 26 years, says the Mail, the British newspaper. Watch an impressive Italian police video on the site of La Repubblica, the Italian daily. Throughout Italy, which is not use to the white stuff, up through the Balkans, and into central Europe, transportation problems multiplied and drivers, in places, abandoned their vehicles. 10:21 a.m. | Updated LAS VEGAS - Most campaigns have a handful of pivotal moments - Barack Obama's race speech in 2008, John McCain's choice of running mate - but the appearance of a team of dark-suited, ramrod straight, hyperprofessional-looking Secret Service agents is an undeniable sign of success. For Mitt Romney, that happened on Thursday, and though it is still early, his campaign will need to manage the potential ramifications carefully. The most important side effect will be on Mr. Romney's interaction with supporters, whose access to the candidate at events is likely to diminish now that agents have been assigned to protect him.

Marcelo Gomes, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will perform as a guest artist with the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden in London on Feb. 9, Ballet Theater announced on Thursday. In his first appearance with the company, Mr. Gomes will dance the role of Oberon in Frederick Ashton's ''Dream'' opposite Alina Cojocaru, a principal dancer with the Royal. Mr. Gomes joined Ballet Theater in 1997. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A chart on Wednesday with an article about the relative stability of the stock markets in January misstated the name of the index whose data it depicted. It is the CBOE Volatility Index, which is based on options for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- not the S.& P. 500 volatility index.

KLEIN--Malcolm. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The New School deeply mourn the passing of master lithographer, Life Trustee, honorary degree recipient, and honorary Board of Governors member at The New School for Public Engagement, Malcolm Klein. As a member of our volunteer community for more than 30 years, Malcolm was a tireless supporter of life-long learning. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Miriam and to his family. David E. Van Zandt, President, The New School Michael J. Johnston, Chair, Board of Trustees

An article on the Personal Tech pages on Jan. 19 about some lesser-known features of Twitter included outdated information for the way in which the site handles the link to a picture from another site. The photograph is displayed beneath a user's post when a viewer clicks the ''view photo'' link; it is no longer shown in the ''details'' pane.

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, the sprawling fantasy role-playing adventure from Bethesda Softworks, won the Big Apple Award for Best Game from the New York Videogame Critics Circle , which announced its first annual prizes on Thursday evening. Logan Cunningham, narrator of the popular downloadable game Bastion, served as host of the awards presentation for about 250 fans at the Cantor Film Center at New York University. Daniel Radosh, a writer for ''The Daily Show,'' presented a comedy segment at the ceremony. Harold Goldberg, a magazine writer and the group's founder, said that 21 New York-area game critics had voted on the awards. In addition to Skyrim, the physics-based puzzle hit Portal 2 won the Herman Melville Award for best writing and the Great White Way Award for best acting. Crysis 2, in which Manhattan has been transformed into a battleground between humans and aliens, took the Manhattan Award for most New York-centric game.
At least 22 children have died in camps in Kabul in the past month, including 14 at the Nasaji Bagrami camp.

An article on Page 24 this weekend about Marines fighting in Afghanistan, using information from a public relations official for the Marines, misstates the given name of one them. He is Maj. Gen. John Toolan, not Michael.

BUTLER--Jacquelin, January 26, 2012, age 80, of lung cancer. No surprise to anyone who knew her. Her generosity knew no bounds. Her intelligence, legendary. Her sense of humour, renowned. She never met a person she didn't make laugh. She was pre-deceased by her husband Frank. She will be missed by her three daughters, Victoria, Wendy and Kimberly, three grandchildren, Jeremy, Caterina and Jake, many friends, and anyone else lucky enough to meet her. She was a hoot. In accordance to her wishes there will be no service. She has been known to say, "do not send flowers, send vodka." (but please don't!)

FINE--Norma of Boston, MA, Sarasota, FL and Hartford VT, passed away February 2, one month short of her 80th birthday. An actress and philanthropist, Ms. Fine pursued many passions with generosity, courage and heart. While raising three children, she both served as volunteer Chairman of Combined Jewish Philanthropies and Israel Bonds for Boston, and taught school. Years of involvement in politics culminated in her service as a senior aide to Boston Mayor Kevin White. After her successful coordination of the National Conference of Mayors, Mayor White appointed her the Chairman of the George Robert White Fund, a public charitable trust of the City of Boston. At age 50, Norma decided to return to her initial love of acting, becoming a successful actress on Boston and regional stages, starring in countless commercials, and making her cinematic debut as Mrs. Goodhall in the film, Cider House Rules. Ms. Fine cared deeply about helping children in need. She endowed a Pediatric Fellowship at the Mass General Hospital, as well as supporting a number of Israeli charities that help children, including Yemin Orde, a youth village in Israel where her daughter, Lauri, worked. The most important children in her life were her eight extraordinary grandchildren, whose triumphs and growing pains she worried over and helped to guide every day. She was predeceased by her husband, Phil David Fine, and her sister Sandra Loew. She is survived by her partner of 19 years, Herb Feinstein, her sister Harriet Jacobson, her daughters, Susan Fine, Lauri Fine Friedman and Debra Fine, and her eight grandchildren, Eyal, Sivan and Daphna Friedman, Allison and Pamela Fine Mishkin and Jordan, Abigail and Phil Fine Schneider. The funeral will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations should made in her honor to Friends of Yemin Orde, 12230 Rockville, MD, 20852.

Goodell said that expansion was not being considered ''at all,'' and that the N.F.L. preferred that teams stayed in their current cities. That raises the question of how the N.F.L. will establish a team in Los Angeles, where two groups are vying to build a stadium. In a television interview Thursday night, Goodell said that if the league were to expand, it would do so by adding two teams rather than just one. Several teams -- including the St. Louis Rams and the Minnesota Vikings -- are dealing with stadium issues, and they are considered candidates to move to Los Angeles, in addition to, among others, the Oakland Raiders and the San Diego Chargers, both of whom also need new stadiums.
