NASS--Roslyn (Tudy) On February 3, 2012 at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Nass. Loving mother of Nancy (Ralph). Adored grandmother of Wendy, and (Edward) Loving great-grandmother of William James and Victoria. She will remain in our hearts forever. Interment Private.

In potentially good news for the ailing United States Postal Service, 2012 is turning into a year of grassroots letter-writing campaigns, like the directly named Facebook group ''Save the U.S. Postal Service by Writing More Letters.'' But at least two schemes to revive the epistolary art have been hatched by accomplished authors. For $5 a month, readers of the Web site The Rumpus can receive a new letter every week or so from writers including Dave Eggers, Jonathan Ames, Aimee Bender and The Rumpus's editor in chief Stephen Elliott, who came up with the idea. With about 1,800 subscribers already signed up, the notes aren't personalized, but they don't exactly read like form letters either. Writer and adult-film actress Lorelei Lee's 15-page missive was hand-written, and included marginal doodles and scratched-out words.

NASS--Roslyn. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of our dear friend and fellow member, Roslyn Nass. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family. Geoffry Handler, President

The Broadway theater owner Jordan Roth on Thursday night assured the cast of the Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''Clybourne Park'' that the show would open on Broadway in April as planned, despite the departure of two of its lead producers, according to a theater press agent close to the show. The New York run of ''Clybourne Park,'' which has been widely viewed as a top contender for the 2012 Tony Award for best play, was threatened this week after one of the lead producers, Scott Rudin, left the project because of a falling-out with its playwright, Bruce Norris. Mr. Rudin, the Tony Award-winning producer of Broadway hits like ''The Book of Mormon,'' said on Wednesday that he would no longer be a part of ''Clybourne Park'' because Mr. Norris, who is also an actor, withdrew this week from a role in a television pilot that Mr. Rudin is producing for HBO, an adaptation of Jonathan Franzen's novel ''The Corrections.''
He was neverwarm in his entire life. Not once. JUMA GUL,an Afghan whose month-old son froze to death recently in Kabul. [A4]

RABINOVITZ--Jason, 90, of Los Angeles, passed away on January 1. Born in Boston on August 17, 1921, he graduated from Boston Latin School and Harvard College and then enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1942 for four years, serving as chief Japanese language officer in the 11th Airborne Division and attaining the rank of captain. After World War II, he attended Harvard Business School, graduating in 1948. A devoted, loving husband and father, he is survived by his cherished wife of 63 years, Frieda Rabinovitz; his daughters Judy of New York City and Abby (and her husband Richard Stuart) of Chilmark, Mass.; his sons Jonathan of Palo Alto, Calif., and Dan (and his wife Effie Chan) of Brookline, Mass.; and his four grandchildren, Conor Rabinovitz of San Francisco, Tia Rabinovitz of Palo Alto, and Callie and Joshua Rabinovitz of Brookline. A long-time executive in the entertainment industry, he retired as Senior Vice President, Finance and Corporate Administration, of MGM/UA Entertainment Co. in 1984. Contributions in his memory may be made either to Boston Latin School Association, 101 Huntington Ave., Suite 200, Boston, MA 02199 or the School of the Museum of Fine Arts Boston, 230 The Fenway, Boston, MA 02115 (Attn: Development Office).

More middle-income consumers are seeking help through formal debt-reduction plans, according to an Atlanta-based credit counseling outfit. In 2007, the average income for clients entering debt-management plans through the agency, CredAbility, was $43,000, and their average credit-card debt was roughly $22,000, said Mark Cole, executive vice president.

10:35 a.m. | Updated The tips are starting to come in, and we are endeavoring to follow up. Even if you wound up at a dead-end, the Caucus still appreciates the effort. That is what crowd-sourcing is all about.

An editorial on Thursday, Dec. 29, on prosecutorial misconduct misstated the open-records policy of the New York County District Attorney's office. The office allows defendants accused of certain low-level offenses to have copies of records in their case files, not in all cases.

8 P.M. (HBO) RIO (2011) Jesse Eisenberg lends his voice to Blu, a domesticated blue macaw thought to be the last of his breed, who is taken from Minnesota to Brazil to hook up with a potential mate, Jewel (Anne Hathaway), in this animated feature from Carlos Saldanha. Once there, he is forced to learn to fly for his life when he is captured by smugglers of exotic birds. Jamie Foxx and will.i.am play a streetwise canary and a cardinal; George Lopez is a paternal toucan (above left, with Blu and Jewel, right); and Tracy Morgan is a spirited bulldog. ''Mr. Saldanha capitalizes on Carnival celebrations for color, offering a feast of tropical pastels, and on winding favela streets for vertiginous chase scenes,'' Andy Webster wrote in The New York Times. ''Dance sequences, set to Sérgio Mendes's musical direction, have a Latin Busby Berkeley meets the June Taylor Dancers delirium.'' He added, ''As kids' movies go, 'Rio' brings a lot to the party.'' 8 P.M. (HGTV) CANDICE TELLS ALL Candice Olson helps a couple turn their converted factory loft with its exposed -- and embarrassingly loud -- plumbing into a space perfect for entertaining. In ''Dear Genevieve,'' at 8:30, Genevieve Gorder finds inspiration in a blanket knitted by the grandmother of a touring performer to transform her living room into a haven she'll want to come home to. In ''Color Splash,'' at 9, David Bromstad adds texture to a living and dining room by adding a dark stone wall, an orange settee and a silver crocodile ottoman. And in ''Interiors, Inc.,'' at 9:30, Jonathan Pierce adds sparkle to a dining room.

If you're a fan of Smith Magazine (and if you're not, you should be) you know about the six-word format that it has helped popularize. Perhaps you've seen Smith's six-word memoir project, or read some of the mom-themed ones that appeared on the New York Times Well blog or taken in Smith readers' musings on love.

INDIANAPOLIS -- The N.F.L. will play more Thursday night games next season, with every team playing at least one Thursday game following a Sunday game and each team having at least one prime-time game, either on Thursday, Sunday or Monday. That will give the league a total of 17 Thursday games, including the season opener and three games on Thanksgiving. Thursday night games will be played every week between Weeks 2 and 15. The NFL Network, which had been airing eight games, will expand its offering to 13 Thursday games, probably an effort by the league to increase the value of the network as it continues to try to negotiate deals with Time Warner Cable and Cablevision to carry the network.

The Carlyle Group, the private equity giant that filed to go public last month, is caving to pressure from investors and regulators over a controversial legal clause in its initial public offering filing. The clause would have prohibited the company's shareholders from filing class-action lawsuits, forcing them into a confidential arbitration process instead. The plan had drawn opposition from investors, lawmakers and the Securities and Exchange Commission, with some worrying that the clause would deprive shareholders of the power to bring claims against the company in the case of wrongdoing.
GAMBERT--Gry, 59, on January 30, 2012. Beloved wife, mother, svigermor, farmor, friend; founder, Baltimore Dharma Group. Memorial on February 4, 2012 at 1pm.

A colleague recently alerted Bucks to a situation she encountered after closing her online account at Blockbuster, which last year was acquired by Dish Network. Because of all the news in recent months about hacked accounts, she thought that deleting her credit card information from the defunct account might be a good idea. But when she went to Blockbuster's Web site, she found she couldn't do that online. So she e-mailed customer service, which e-mailed her a response that said, in effect: Not possible. ''The information we have on file for you is kept for accounting purposes and cannot be removed,'' the e-mail said in part.

Samuel S. Vaughan, who rose from the syndication sales department to lead Doubleday & Company, working with writers as diverse as President Dwight D. Eisenhower, William F. Buckley Jr., Bruce Catton and Fannie Flagg, died on Monday at his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 83. The cause was complications of a stroke, his wife, Jo, said.

The Goldman Sachs stock price was not the only thing to take a beating at the firm last year. Lloyd C. Blankfein, the investment bank's chief executive, also had his pay decline. The company's board granted restricted stock valued at $7 million to Mr. Blankfein, according to a regulatory filing on Friday. The directors, who met this week to determine pay packages, also extended the $7 million award to Gary D. Cohn, the firm's president, and David A. Viniar, the chief financial officer. The value is based on the company's stock price as of Wednesday.

If owls represent wisdom, as folklore dictates, then perhaps Brooklyn and Manhattan are no place for sages. The great horned owl, one of the largest and most powerful raptors in North America, has not successfully nested in either borough since records started being kept over 100 years ago.

Nasty letters from lawmakers. A powerful lobby threatening his very livelihood. Regulatory investigations. These are the things that billionaire hedge fund manager Philip A. Falcone contends with on a near-daily basis. Today, scorekeepers can chalk up another point for the anti-Falcone factions. His hedge fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, lost 46.6 percent last year, as his biggest -- and most controversial -- investment took a beating, according to investors who spoke on condition of anonymity.

LANGWORTHY--Norma. Roundabout Theatre Company sends its deepest sympathies to the family of Norma Langworthy on her passing. She was a true angel of the theatre and a dear friend to this company. Her memory will live on in our hearts and at our theatre always. Todd Haimes and Julia Levy

GREENBERG--Mrs. Muriel C.,of Roslyn, NY and Boca Raton, FL on February 2, 2012. Devoted mother of Claire Epstein, Susan Wels, Carol Herschfeld and Leslie Fleischman. Contact Bernheim Apter Kreitzman at: 973-422-0600 or www.bernheimapterkreitzman.com for more information.

A music review on Wednesday about the second program in ''Sound Reimagined: John Cage at 100,'' the Juilliard School's weeklong tribute to Cage, referred incorrectly to his talk ''Lecture on Nothing,'' using information from a spoken introduction during the concert. Cage himself recalled having given it ''about 1949'' at the Artists' Club in Manhattan. He did not give it in Darmstadt, Germany, in that year.

STEIN--Arthur. The East Hampton Tennis Club mourns the death of Arthur Stein, a long time and highly valued club member. We wish his family comfort and support during this very difficult time. In Sympathy, Joseph Eisler President East Hampton Tennis Club

GREENBERG--Hazel Sara. Born April 23, 1933, died February 2, 2012 peacefully at home in Santa Fe, NM surrounded by loved ones after a valiant four and a half year fight against cancer. Hazel passionately embraced a love for travel, reading, knitting, and art collection. She taught at Midwood High School for nearly 30 years, and then spent ten years as a Director at the American Forum for Global Education. She is survived by three sons, Frederick Rundback, John Rundback and Richard Greenberg; and grandchildren, Matthew Rundback and Alexandra Greenberg; and her very dear friend, Linda Arkin.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Rabbi Marvin Hier, believed to be the only rabbi among the members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences who vote on the Oscars, referred incorrectly at one point to a person who spoke for the Academy about religious figures among the membership. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, Teni Melidonian, a spokeswoman for the Academy, is a woman.

An article last Saturday about air pollution in China misstated a government claim concerning air quality in Beijing, a city that is often blanketed in smog. Officials reported that Beijing had 286 ''blue sky'' days in 2011, and they noted that was the same number as the previous year; they did not say there were 274 such days or describe those days as a record.

COHEN--Robert B.,86, died peacefully on February 1, 2012 at his home in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Harriet Brandwein, cherished father of James and his spouse Lisa, and devoted grandfather of six, Samantha, Robert II, Justin, Michael, Alexander and Jacqueline. He is also survived by his sister Rosalind Stone. He was predeceased by his son Michael and daughter Claudia, and his sister Betty Fast. Robert was a long time Owner and President of Hudson News, the largest airport retailer in the country and major wholesale distributor of magazines and books. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on Friday, February 3, 2012 at The Bergen Performing Arts Center, 30 N Van Brunt Street, Englewood, NJ at 11:30am.

INDIANAPOLIS--The Super Bowl Village allows visitors to throw footballs, take N.F.L. trivia challenges, watch live television and radio broadcasts, and buy anything on earth that can be deep fried and/or stamped with an image of the Lombardi Trophy. It does not offer any opportunities to toss baseballs or shoot baskets, however. When it comes to other spectator sports, the N.F.L. makes the village as closed a shop as possible. Formula race cars with team logos earned an exemption - this is Indianapolis, after all - but only one competitive sport was unusual enough to slip through the cracks and earn a prime patch of real estate under the zip line entrance, practically the very ''button'' of the whole village.

The Miami Marlins did plenty to accommodate Jose Reyes this winter, giving the star shortstop a lucrative contract and moving Hanley Ramirez to third base. But Reyes always knew he would need to make some sacrifices, too.

3:00 p.m. | Updated The long-awaited reunion of Black Sabbath, the seminal British heavy-metal band, has suffered another personnel problem as its drummer, Bill Ward, said that he was feeling ''ostracized'' from the group and would not agree to what he called ''the unsignable contract.''

EINSIDLER--Norma. Died February 2, 2012. Beloved wife of Fred. Devoted mother of Donald and his wife Bonnie, Robert and his wife Risa, Daniel and Richard. Cherished grandmother of Matthew, Justin, Dylan and Dana. Funeral service Sunday February 5, 2012 at 10:30am at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Rd, Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Diabetes Foundation or The American Cancer Society.

Rick Santorum, a former senator from Pennsylvania, has failed to qualify for Indiana's Republican presidential primary, which is scheduled to be held on May 8. Indiana requires presidential candidates to collect 500 signatures from each of the state's nine congressional districts. Mr. Santorum fell short by 24 signatures in one district, according to a report from WIBC Radio.

A cover article this weekend about four bands that formed in 1962, including the Rolling Stones and the Beach Boys, misidentifies which song the Beach Boys opened their set with at the ''T.A.M.I. Show'' in 1964. It was ''Surfin' USA,'' not ''Surfin' Safari.''

GREGORIADES--Athanasia, 76, died February 1, 2012 in New York City. Born in Skalohori Kozanis, Greece, she emigrated with her family to New York in 1947. She received her B.S. and two M.S. degrees from Hunter College, and taught and worked for the New York City Board of Education. She was a passionate and tireless advocate for Greek causes, human rights, and for social justice, and was a generous supporter of many charities. She is survived by her sister, Paula; her nephews, Alexander, Nicholas, and Alexander; and her niece, Kristine. Services will be held Saturday February 4, 9am at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St.

Baruch Spinoza, the 17th-century Dutch thinker, may be among the more enigmatic (and mythologized) philosophers in Western thought, but he also remains one of the most relevant, to his time and to ours. He was an eloquent proponent of a secular, democratic society, and was the strongest advocate for freedom and tolerance in the early modern period. The ultimate goal of his "Theological-Political Treatise" - published anonymously to great alarm in 1670, when it was called by one of its many critics "a book forged in hell by the devil himself"- is enshrined both in the book's subtitle and in the argument of its final chapter: to show that the "freedom of philosophizing" not only can be granted "without detriment to public peace, to piety, and to the right of the sovereign, but also that it must be granted if these are to be preserved."

KLEIN--Malcolm and Miriam, both 91, peacefully, after 66 years of marriage and 86 years of loving friendship, in State College, PA. Miriam passed away on November 17, 2011, after which Malcolm declined rapidly. He passed away on January 31, 2012. Malcolm and Miriam were raised in Rockaway Beach, Queens, and lived in Valley Stream and Greenwich Village. Malcolm was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School. He served four years as a U.S. Navy officer in the central and south Pacific during World War II, retiring as a Commander in the U.S. Navy reserve. He was a leader of New York's printing industry, founder of Weaver Organization and president of such groups as the Navigators and the Lithographers Guild. He served on the Board of Trustees of the New School for Social Research. Miriam was active as a fundraiser for the New School and other charities, from the March of Dimes in the 1950s to the Lighthouse and Sight Loss Center of Central Pennsylvania. She was the life of every party. The Kleins were the beloved parents of Joe and Ken Klein, loving grandparents of Christopher, Terry, Sophie and Theodore, great-grandparents of Zoe and Beatrice. Donations can be made to the Lighthouse, the Sight Loss Center of Central Pennsylvania and the New School for Social Research. Malcolm and Miriam met, and held hands, on the first day of kindergarten. They were inseparable in life and now, in death.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Little Less Crazed at Cameron,'' Feb. 2: The news that student attendance at Duke men's basketball home games has fallen should sound an alarm at all colleges that have oversize sports programs. It pops the bubble that college sports actually have anything to do with college.

3 P.M. (Animal Planet) PUPPY BOWL VIII Some of the cutest bruisers around, rescued from shelters across the country, go in for tackles, fumbles and ''Fido first downs'' (and vie for the title of M.V.P., as in Most Valuable Puppy) at Animal Planet Stadium. Dan Schachner calls plays and penalties in his new role as the Ref; Jill Rappaport provides analysis and commentary. A piglet pep squad cheers from the sidelines, while Meep the Bird tweets the action online. Aerial coverage of the pups is provided by the Ice Breakers blimp and its hamster crew. Sloppier ground-level angles are offered by the ever-popular water-bowl camera; the puppy cam, to watch the action from the players' perspective; and the kiss cam. Not to be missed: the Kitty Halftime Show. The action is repeated at two-hour intervals throughout the afternoon and evening. 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Gov. Martin O'Malley of Maryland, the chairman of the Democratic Governors Association, and Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia, the chairman of the Republican Governors Association, discuss the presidential election. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City, Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana and Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts speculate on the Super Bowl.

''So You're Priced Out. Now What?'' (Jan. 29) described less expensive alternatives to desirable neighborhoods. The Times asked readers to name underrated, affordable neighborhoods. Following are selected comments from nytimes.com: Not sure why Midwood in Brooklyn is constantly overlooked and undervalued. Home to Brooklyn College, one of the best schools in the CUNY system, and DiFara Pizza, this still largely Jewish (with a huge influx of Russians and Ukrainians now) neighborhood is ridiculously safe and loaded with inexpensive shopping and services (I get a weekly massage for $50/hr at a fabulous Chinese spa). It could do with more restaurants, and many are Kosher so closed on Fridays and Saturdays, but over all, great big houses at affordable prices (my husband and I bought a four-bedroom, 2,000-sq.-ft. town home for $550,000 two years ago) and near the subways (B/Q).

IT takes a leap of faith for someone who cannot see to become a cheerleader. ''A lot of them have never seen it, so they don't know what it looks like,'' said Rosalind Wright, the coach of the cheerleading squad at the New York Institute for Special Education in the Bronx. On Jan. 27, the school's team, whose 10 members range from being totally blind to partially impaired, finished first in the annual tournament of the Eastern Athletic Association for the Blind, where Kirsten Luce photographed them in action.

In the same week that Blake Griffin's legend grew larger with a monster dunk (or extremely short-range jump shot) over Kendrick Perkins of Oklahoma City, he announced that he would not defend his slam-dunk title at this year's All-Star festivities. Possibly more than any other player in the league, Griffin has captured the attention of Twitter, where fans, celebrities and fellow players flock to comment on his amazing feats. With the dunk over Perkins in the Los Angeles Clippers' 112-100 victory on Monday and the dunk contest decision Thursday, Griffin became the topic du jour.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''In 5 hours 53 Minutes and Five Riveting Sets, Djokovic Retains Title,'' Jan. 30: After a heart-rending match, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic treated each other with humility, respect and admiration. I'm so pleased that my three young children heard the players' postmatch remarks.

She is survived by her loving husband Harry; her wonderful children Alan and Amy, Linda and Warren; her adoring grandchildren Ross and Caryn, Keith and Marissa, Laura and Bryan, Randi, Daniel and Jordan and her adorable great-grandchild Luke. She was the loving daughter of Rebecca and Albert and loving sister of George and Ray Hyman and Marilyn.

Because of an editing error, the ''30 Seconds With'' column last Sunday, featuring the former Giants tight end Howard Cross, misstated the seasons he played on the Giants' Super Bowl teams. He was with the team for the 1990 and 2000 championships, but not for the 1986 one.

An article last Sunday about Newt Gingrich's vow to stay in the Republican presidential contest referred incorrectly to Paul E. Tsongas, a Massachusetts Democrat who sought his party's presidential nomination in 1992. At the time he ran, Mr. Tsongas was a former -- not sitting -- senator.

NASS--Roslyn (Tudy) On February 3, 2012 at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Jacob Nass. Loving mother of Nancy (Ralph). Adored grandmother of Wendy, and (Edward) Loving great-grandmother of William James and Victoria. She will remain in our hearts forever. Interment Private.

An article on Jan. 15 about the comedian and actor Ricky Gervais misstated part ofthe name of the organization that awards the Golden Globes, the ceremony for which Gervais was host the last two years. It is the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, not Agency.

FAGAN--Fred I.,77, died on January 26th in Key West after a courageous battle with cancer. Mr. Fagan was a 54-year resident of Manhattan. A graduate of the University of Florida, member of Delta Tau Delta Fraternity and Army veteran, he was a retired systems analyst with the City of New York. Memorial contributions may be made to The Nature Conservancy and New York City Opera.

SHAPIRO--William L.,died at his home at Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on February 3rd 2012 after a long illness. He was born in Brooklyn on July 26, 1937, the son of Leon and Ruth Shapiro. He attended Brooklyn Poly Prep and went on to take over the family business as owner-manager of Triangle Sports. A lifetime resident of New York, Bill loved his native city. He was a compassionate businessman who maintained the original Flatbush Avenue store, founded by his grandmother Bessie in 1916, through changing times in Brooklyn. Bill is survived by his dearly loved wife of thirty years, Joan Shapiro, her two sons from a previous marriage, Reed and Ross, their wives Susan and Lucy, and Reed and Sue's three sons. To his stepsons and their wives he was a great friend and benefactor, and to Erik, Devon and Luke he was their beloved Grandpa Bill. A very kind man, he will be deeply missed by his wife and family, friends and employees. Bill requested that his remains be donated to the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. A private memorial service is planned for the near future.

YEONGJU, SOUTH KOREA -- When he looks out from the time-frozen world of Korea's oldest private Confucian academy, Park Seok-hong sees the rest of the country ''turning into a realm of beasts.'' He points to recent news as evidence: young people swearing at elderly passengers in the subway and children jumping to their deaths to escape bullying or the pressure of hyper-competitive school life. ''We may have built our economy, but our morality is on the verge of collapse,'' Mr. Park said. ''We must revitalize it, and this is where we can find an answer.''

To the Sports Editor: The intense fatigue imposed on N.B.A. players by their having to play 5 games in 6 nights and 9 in 12, as did the Chicago Bulls recently because of the season's late start and the condensed schedule, increases the likelihood of injury and subjects fans to watching substandard contests. If the league was less concerned about making money and more about the welfare of its players, fewer games could have been arranged in the interests of higher-level and less-stressful performances.

Here's a sampling of readers' reactions to Anthony Tommasini's article about the opera singer Renée Fleming and the career choices she has made. ''As a people's diva Ms. Fleming is doing exactly what opera stars of an earlier generation did. They brought their art to the people by appearing on 'The Ed Sullivan Show' and 'The Bell Telephone Hour,' starring in musicals (Helen Traubel, Mimi Benzell, Robert Weede), making movies (Risë Stevens, Dorothy Kirsten, Patrice Munsel) and running an opera company (Beverly Sills). What the itinerant New York City Opera needs is a people's diva, like Renée Fleming, to follow in the footsteps of the incomparable Ms. Sills and return the people's opera to the people.''

The cause was a heart attack he had suffered two weeks earlier, said Claris Dodge, a representative of Mr. Fischer's family.

You could start with the famous Louis C.K. interview/mutual therapy session or the episode in which Todd Hanson of The Onion recalls his suicide attempt. Excellent subway companionship.

WITH 2012 being both a lucky Year of the Dragon and a leap, it's not surprising that many of the timepieces introduced at the recent Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie watch fair in Geneva gave major consideration to the calendar, the ''annual'' versus ''perpetual'' designs figuring prominently in the mechanical innovations and aesthetics of many of the exhibition's most exciting timekeepers. (A quick refresher: an annual calendar on an automatic watch usually needs adjusting once a year, at the end of February; a perpetual calendar accounts for February's odd 29th day and needs only a manual nudge every 100 years or so.) Here, an annual from Cartier called the Rotonde continues the luxury house's recent fixation on the round face and contains layered discs indicating the day of the week and month with red markers. The movement, a point of pride for Cartier, is made in-house. Clunky desktop date keepers, meet the competition. Rotonde de Cartier Annual Calendar will be available in April starting at $37,500. BRUCE PASK

''Maybe I am Don Quixote tilting at windmills,'' Heather Peters said Thursday in a telephone interview, a day after winning a $9,867 judgment in small-claims court against American Honda for claimed fuel-economy deficiencies of her 2006 Civic Hybrid. ''But I'm hoping that what I'm doing helps the little guy have a better chance at getting justice.'' She may, however, have little time to savor her victory. Chris Martin, a spokesman at the automaker's headquarters in Torrance, Calif., said Wednesday that the company would appeal.

MINCHIN--Myles Faulkiner, of New York City, NY. Titular Head of the Minchin Family, Annagh, County Tipperary Ireland. Chief of Secretariat Services Division, Department of Political Affairs, Trusteeship and Decolonization, 89 years of age did pass away after short illness at New York Langone Hospital January 25, 2012. The second son of the late Lieutenant Commander Henry Reilly-Falkiner and late Winifred Florence (O'Bryen) Minchin. He was born in County of Portsmouth C.B. England, pre-ceased by his brothers Brian Patrick John and William Abbott. Myles studied at and received his B.A. (1945) and M.A. (1948) from Kings College, UK. He earned honors in both modern Languages and Economics Tripos. In addition to English, he spoke French, Spanish and Portuguese. Just as he finished his studies at university, a unique job-opportunity emerged. The United Nations was forged between two significant conferences: Dumbarton Oaks under Franklin D. Roosevelt (October, 1944) and San Francisco under Harry Truman (June, 1945). Myles joined the Secretariat in 1945 and moved to New York the following year. In 1952, he transferred to the UN Trusteeship Division. Myles had worked with the United Nations since it's inception and had been there for all his working life. His service was recognized in 1983 with the award of the CBE (Companion of the British Empire). He was also a life member of the Association of Former International Civil Servants, United Nations, New York. Myles Faulkner Reilly Minchin hailed from a very long and interesting family dating back to the 1400's. A gentleman always, he will be missed by many, including Patrick McKinley (England) and Dan and Barbara Minchin and family (Ireland), companions/caretakers Barbara Connelly (Shirley, LI) and Sheila Thomas (Brooklyn, NY), friends Raymond Foster, Charles E. Garvey (New Jersey), Donald F. Gross, and Michael Salem (New York). Respects: 2pm, Thursday, February 9, 2012, Memorial Service Mass: St. Thomas Church, Fifth Ave, 1 West 53rd St., New York City. Memorial Tribute to follow at: Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 81st St and Madison Ave, NYC, 4:00-7:00pm.

Although concussions have received most of the attention over the last couple of years, injuries of all sorts can deeply influence the performance of N.H.L. teams. Last season, for example,Islanders players lost 587 games to injuries of all types. The season before, Edmonton led the league with 494 games lost, and no other team was within 100 of the Oilers.

HYMAN--Ardie, died peacefully on February 1, 2012. Loving son of the late Gladys and Mac Hyman, brother of the late Martin Hyman. Beloved husband of Laura for 42 years, devoted father of Joshua, Melissa (Brett), and wonderful Poppy RD to Hannah and Alexa.

WILLIAMS--Camilla. Age 92, January 29, 2012 New York City Opera mourns with profound sadness the passing of one of America's musical heroes, the trailblazing soprano Camilla Williams. On May 15, 1946 at New York City Center, Camilla made her critically-heralded operatic stage debut in NYC Opera's first production of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" marking the first time an African-American woman appeared on stage with a major US opera company. Camilla went on to perform with NYC Opera and other opera companies around the world for 25 years before retiring in 1971 when she began her career as a teacher, becoming the first African-American Professor of Voice at Indiana University. NYC Opera is immeasurably proud to have played an important role in Camilla's career and is forever grateful for her contributions to the art of opera. NYC Opera extends its deepest condolences to Camilla's family, friends, students, and all whose lives were touched by her talent.

The ''Living In'' article last Sunday, about 57th Street in Manhattan, misstated the age of Michael Ramah, a 57th Street resident who lives in a prewar co-op near First Avenue. He is 58, not 68.

WHEN the Warsaw Zoo was bombed during World War II, killing most of the animals, the zookeepers devised a dangerous plan: they decided to use the cages and enclosures to hide more than 300 Jews who were fleeing the Nazis. Their refuge became one of the most successful hide-outs of the war. After I wrote about this true story in ''The Zookeeper's Wife,'' readers shared their outrage with me about the bombing of a zoo, which they regarded almost as a sacrilege. I heard similar outcries in 2003 after the Baghdad Zoo was bombed. We're used to the killing of enemies, but we reserve a special circle of hell for people who set fire to zoos. It's the ultimate massacre of the innocents. The animals are silent victims, supposedly beyond our ideas of good and evil.

DUNBAR--Dr. Frederick. The staff of NERA Economic Consulting mourn the passing of Dr. Frederick Dunbar, a brilliant economist and one of the giants of our firm. Fred was our colleague for 30 years, and he remained a friend to many of us after he joined the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2009. He was one of the architects of NERA's growth for many years, creating our Securities and Mass Torts Practices, providing groundbreaking economic analysis and testimony for clients, and mentoring many of those who went on to leadership positions in the firm. We will sorely miss his sharp intellect, his keen sense of humor, and his deep humanity. Our thoughts are with his friends and family, and especially his wife Helen Mangano. The Board of Directors NERA Economic Consulting

To the Sports Editor: Victoria Azarenka and Maria Sharapova, the Australian Open women's finalists, are great tennis champions. But the shrieks they belt out during their matches are irritating. As a classically trained soprano with a good ear, as well as a big tennis fan, I was curious to find out what musical pitches they actually use.

LAMONT--Rosette Clementine, renowned theatre critic, author, professor and authority on Samuel Beckett and Eugene Ionesco died on January 5, 2012. She was born on February 15, 1927 in Paris, France. She earned her BA from Hunter College and Ph.D. from Yale University. She was a Professor of French and Comparative Literature at CUNY Graduate SchoolDoctoral Program in theatre. She distinguished herself as an envoy for the State Department's Scholar Exchange Program to the U.S.S.R in 1974; visiting professor at the Sorbonne in Paris (1985-1986); a Guggenheim Fellow (1973-1974); a Rockefeller Humanities Fellow (1983-1984); Decorated Chevalier, Officier des Palmes Academiques, Officier des Arts et Lettres in France and named to the Hunter College Hall of Fame. Later in career, she joined the Sarah Law- rence College Theatre Faculty till her retirement. A memorial will take place at Sarah Lawrence College on February 18, 2pm at the Donnelly Film Theater-Heimbold Visual Arts Center in Bronx- ville, NY. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Sarah Lawrence College Theatre Outreach Program. See full obituary ccgfuneralhome.com

ESTABLISHED in 1887 as the first neighborhood of modern Tel Aviv, charming Neve Tzedek still delights with its many old buildings and independent shops. Although the original Jewish pioneers, who moved there more than 60 years before Israel was founded, have long since been replaced by artists and families, the area has retained the feeling of a quaint village. Most stores are on the main drag, Shabazi Street, but a new 22-building shopping complex called HaTachana, housed in a former train station on the outer reaches of Neve Tzedek, has added a dash of excitement to one of the prettiest and calmest areas in Tel Aviv. RACHEL B. DOYLE

LIBRESCO--Len. Husband, father and grandfather, citizen of the world, consummate teacher, in love with ideas, provocateur and pundit, dear to all who knew and loved him, died Thursday, January 12, 2012 at the age of 78. He died as he lived, with courage and humility, drawing upon an inner strength that never failed to inspire and amaze. Len was born and raised in New York City where his education included The BronxHigh School of Science, Queens College, Columbia University, and most importantly, the incredible libraries, museums, theatre, opera, and melting pot of New York City. The child of immigrants, Jenny and Zol, and brother to Emile, he inhaled the ideas and promises that America offered. Len later pursued his doctorate at the University of California, Davis, where he met Marilyn, who would become his wife and partner for the next 43 years. Len earned a BA, two master's degrees, and PhD, abd. He was a student of the world, studying art, languages, history, and most recently, ukulele. There was never a need for an encyclopedia for Len was the Encyclopedia Britannica; Google before there was Google. Len launched his career at the United Nations, and spent over ten years with the Peace Corps directing programs in India, Iran, Micronesia, and the Solomon Islands. Later he served as Executive Director of the International Institute of the East Bay, after a decade as Director of Human Resources for Icore, International in Silicon Valley. Len was a quiet force who offered books, ideas, and encouragement to any who crossed his path. He will be loved and remembered by his wife, his children and their families, his grandchildren, his brother-in-law, his nephew and nieces and their families, and by all he touched and nurtured. For details on a memorial, please contact the family at librescomemorial@gmail.com.

Pat Connaughton, a 6-foot-5 freshman, had 23 points and 11 rebounds as Notre Dame beat Marquette. Connaughton, left, who had been averaging 6.1 points and 4.0 rebounds a game, shot 5 of 8 on 3-pointers. In Louisville's 78-66 win over Rutgers, freshmen starred for both teams. Chane Behanan hit his first 10 shots and had a career-high 23 points for Louisville. Eli Carter of Rutgers scored 24.

The tailored topcoat is reappearing on men interested in stylish dressing. Some of the coats have fake-fur trim; others, flaring collars. But what they all have in common is the fastidious tailored look of a J.C. Leyendecker drawing of the 1920s. Whether this suave reproach to dressing down is going to fly has yet to be seen, although quilted outerwear cut like a sports jacket, bottom row, appears to have gained traction, including versions in gray flannel. And the puffy vest, a mainstay of the weekend uniform for the last 20 years, is neater now, encountered in Midtown in sober gray.

BOYS--Barry, January 23. Distinguished actor, director, teacher. Dedicated to regional theatre and Shakespeare. Survived by son, Edmund Boys. In lieu of memorials, please support your local Occupy movement.

ROSS--Ronald Johnston, born May 1, 1931, in Melbourne, Australia, passed away January 28, 2012, in Greenport, Long Island. Life-long sailor, international ad man extraordinaire. Survived by wife Rosa, daughters Sarah and Samantha, grandchildren Clara and Renaldo. A life well lived. Memorial to be held at a later date.

JetBlue Airways and Hawaiian Airlines announced a partnership last month that will make it easier to travel between Hawaii and the East Coast. Once the systems are combined, JetBlue and Hawaiian Airlines will sync connecting flight times, award frequent-flier points to members of either airline's program and operate code share flights that allow consumers to book through either carrier.
A question in the Streetscapes column last Sunday about the fate of two former automats in Manhattan misspelled the surname of the reader who posed it. He is John Jurayj, not Jurayi.

Funeral services will be held on Monday, February 6, 2012 at 10:00am at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (Opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

GREGORIADES--Athanasia, 76, died February 1, 2012 in New York City. Born in Skalohori Kozanis, Greece, she emigrated with her family to New York in 1947. She received her B.S. and two M.S. degrees from Hunter College, and taught and worked for the New York City Board of Education. She was a passionate and tireless advocate for Greek causes, human rights, and for social justice, and was a generous supporter of many charities. She is survived by her sister, Paula; her nephews, Alexander, Nicholas, and Alexander; and her niece, Kristine. Services will be held Saturday February 4, 9am at the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St.

THE British artist-designers James Russell and Hannah Plumb, collectively known as JamesPlumb, specialize in quirky, sometimes haunting mashups of antique or simply discarded furniture and objects. ''Goodnight Day,'' their exhibition at Blancpain Art Contemporain in Geneva, offers a mini-survey of their Dickensian-punk-bricolage aesthetic. Among the pieces on display is ''To Love and to Cherish,'' a three-seat sofa and two armchairs that are the latest variations on JamesPlumb's Concrete Stitches series. The 19th-century furniture is stripped down to its carved wood frames, into which are inserted pigmented cast-concrete ''cushions.'' Like all the pieces in this series, its title, taken from wedding vows, refers to the marriage of disparate and unlikely materials. ''Goodnight Day'' runs to Feb. 17. PILAR VILADAS

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the casino mogul Sheldon Adelson, a major financial supporter of Newt Gingrich's presidential campaign, referred incorrectly to testimony by an executive from Mr. Adelson's company, Las Vegas Sands Corporation. The executive testified that he himself relayed a message to the Chinese, taking credit for derailing a human rights resolution in Congress; the executive did not say that Mr. Adelson relayed the message.

EPSTEIN--Rose Lansman. A former top executive at Time, Inc, passed away peacefully on February 3, 2012, following a long illness. Born on July 10, 1923, Rose grew up in Queens and graduated from City College. She took an entry level job in Time, Inc.'s accounting department in 1944. She stayed with Time Inc. Magazines for forty-six years, becoming the first female senior executive on the business side. On her retirement in 1990, she was Director of Administration and the third-longest-serving employee in company history. Rose was married to J.A. (Lee) Epstein, founder and former Chairman of Mailmen Incorporated, a direct mail advertising firm. They had two children, Ellen and Larry. Rose spoke extensively around the country on the challenge of being a working mother. She was a noted mentor and often rewarded her employees with gifts bearing a seal declaring, "The Order of the Glowing Rose." She and her husband were founding members of the YM & YWHA of Mid-Westchester and she was a member of the Board of Directors of the City College Fund. Rose is survived by her husband of sixty-five years, Lee Epstein, her daughter Ellen and partner, Ian Brownell, son Larry and daughter-in-law, Karen, and grandchildren, Izzy Maxwell, Michael Epstein and Katie Epstein. A service will be held at noon, Sunday, February 5th at the Sutton Place Synagogue. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to Weill Cornell Medical College, Department of Neurology and Neuroscience, Memory Disorders/Alzheimer's Disease Program, 525 East 68th Street, F-607, New York, NY, 10065.

MORTENSEN--James E.,formerly Vice Chairman and CFO, Young and Rubicam, died at 86 on January 30th in St. Augustine, FL. During WWII, he served in Italy, France and Belgium with the 517 Parachute Regimental Combat Team. After retirement from Y & R, he provided consulting services, only recently leaving the Advisory Board of The NPD Group, and volunteered services to a number of arts organizations in the Tampa Bay area. He strongly supported the Free Clinic in St. Petersburg, playing a major role in establishing an endowment fund. He is survived by his wife, Brenda Verbeck, his son and daughter-in-law, Arthur and Liz Mortensen, brother, Joseph Mortensen of Midland, MI, sisters, Mary Burman of Laramie, WY, Marguerite Bieber of Greeley, Colorado, and a tribe of loving nieces and nephews. Memorial service February 18th 11:00am, St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 1200 Snell Isle Blvd. NE, St. Petersburg, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to St. Petersburg Free Clinic, 863 3rd Avenue N., St. Petersburg FL 33701.

The Mortgages column last Sunday, about consumer complaints against mortgage lenders, misstated the circumstances under which the Better Business Bureau of Metro New York responds to those complaints. It can intervene whether lenders are members or not.

An opinion article on Jan. 29 about the Chilean student activist Camila Vallejo attributed an erroneous distinction to Chile's economy. Though it is one of the wealthiest in Latin America, it is not nearly the largest; Brazil's is.

Dr. Richard K. Olney, a leading physician and pioneer in clinical research on amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, died of the disease on Jan. 27 at his home in Corte Madera, Calif. He was 64. His death was announced by the University of California, San Francisco, where Dr. Olney had been the director of the A.L.S. Treatment and Research Center before learning in 2004 that he himself had the disease.

A CONDOMINIUM at Trump International Hotel and Tower that sold for $19million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. The black-and-gold-clad Trump high-rise,on the southern edge of Central Park, has seemed something of a wallflower in recent years, watching as neighboring buildings racked up multimillion-dollar sales week after week, shattering notions of what people would pay for luxury. But this sale indicatest hat the building, which opened in 1997, is still a player in this rarefied market.

Uncle to Laura Abrahamsen, Robert Abrahamsen and Kristine Bradfield. Former Marine and Seattle Police Officer for 43 years.

The next Big City Book Club selection is Dawn Powell's razor-sharp 1942 satire of the New York media world, ''A Time to Be Born.'' Love, jealousy, petty resentments, rank social climbing and untrammeled ambition -- the novel has it all. Join Ginia Bellafante, the Big City columnist, for a live online discussion of the book on the City Room blog Feb. 21 from 1 to 4 p.m. Taking part in the conversation: Candace Bushnell, the best-selling author who created the ''Sex and the City'' franchise. She'll comment on the book and answer readers' questions.

IT'S no secret the London-based, Nigerian-born designer Duro Olowu loves the raw material of his trade. His exuberant 1970s-style dresses, spliced together from silks he designs himself in an eye-popping array of vintage couture brocades, chiffons and georgettes, are prized for their deft handling of color and pattern. In ''Material,'' an exhibition-cum-pop-up-shop Mr. Olowu has curated at Salon 94's Freeman Gallery, this passion is given free rein. Arranged in a mise-en-scène alongside pieces from his spring 2012 collection will be material-inspired objects and art that have in turn inspired him: drawings by Lorna Simpson; photographs by Juergen Teller (shown here); portraits by the 82-year-old Malian photographer Hamidou Maiga; West African textiles and vintage couture fabrics from Abraham of Switzerland. Handling is encouraged. ''This is not a precious display of precious things,'' Mr. Olowu said. ''It's an opportunity to come and shop, to learn about new people and come away with some new ideas.'' ''Doru Olowu: Material,'' Salon 94 Freemans in Manhattan, Feb. 9 to March 4. NANCY MacDONELL

New York real estate can bring out even the most dormant phobias of potential buyers. With so many options, apartment hunters can easily be paralyzed by decidophobia (yes, it's a real term, and means the fear of making decisions). That doesn't seem to be a problem for the wealthy investors who are wiring millions of dollars to New York to snatch up a piece of 157 West 57th Street - what will be New York City's tallest residential building, with 90 floors overlooking Central Park.

Provisions went into effect late last month requiring airlines and ticket agents to list all mandatory taxes and fees in published airfares and to disclose baggage fees when tickets are purchased. The changes are the final part of the airline consumer rule issued by the Department of Transportation in April, which extended the three-hour tarmac delay limit for domestic flights to smaller airports, and set a four-hour limit for international flights at airports in the United States.

FOOTE--Nelson Northrup, 96, on January 22, 2012. Born into a family of anarchists and free thinkers in rural Nebraska and raised on a farm in western New York, Nelson devoted his life to challenging the status quo and expected to be in jail for it by the time he was thirty. Instead, he became a respected professor of Sociology at Cornell, Chicago and CUNY-Hunter. In 1940 he married Geraldine Roach, and they both spent the next few years working alternately for war agencies in Washington and the CIO in Detroit before returning to Ithaca. In 1951 he was named director of the Family Study Center at the University of Chicago, which published his best known book, Identity and Interpersonal Competence, describing what would later be termed "emotional intelligence". He left academia for General Electric in New York, where he worked on development projects, including the new city of Columbia, MD and initiatives in Trinidad-Tobago. Returning to teaching at Hunter in 1969, he began elucidating a theory of development based on universal professionalization and investment in human potential. His final work can be found at: www.sharingtheearth.net. In 1984 he and Geraldine moved to Mill Valley CA. Geraldine died in 2005. Nelson leaves his son Jefferson of Seattle, daughter Kathleen of Mill Valley, and three grandchildren.

Dec. 22, 2011, Big Corn Island, NicaraguaMy girlfriend and I were in Nicaragua for a week. The last stop on the trip was the Corn Islands, which are a little less than 50 miles from the Caribbean coast. This photo was taken on Big Corn Island, the larger of the two Corn Islands, on Picnic Beach. It was deserted except for these three children and a few fishermen who walked over with them. The limited tourism infrastructure on the islands -- the 10-seat plane we took from Managua looked like a relic from the '50s -- has allowed them to preserve an authenticity and tranquillity that words cannot appropriately describe. JULIAN HARPER, New York City

TAMBAKIS--Virginia, of New York, died February 3. Survived by her husband of 53 years, Dr. Apostolos Tambakis, her two daughters, Dr. Connie Tambakis-Wilson and Christine Tambakis McDonnell Esq., their spouses, Gary and Dennis, her three grandchildren, Virginia Ruth, Roscoe, and Alex, her dearest sister, Christina Spanos, and siblings John, Irene, and George. Virginia dedicated her life to her family, always encouraging them to do their best. She was very proud of her daughters for becoming strong, intelligent, independent, professional women. Virginia loved to entertain and was always the life of the party. She was a woman of impeccable taste and style. She cared and gave generously to her philanthropic endeavors, including the Philoptochos and Hellenic Medical Societies. We are all so blessed to have had Virginia in our lives and she will be forever missed. Viewing: Monday, February 6, 5-9pm, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, New York. Funeral: Tuesday, February 7, 11am, Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Hellenic Medical Society, 60 Plaza, Brooklyn, NY, 11238.

Every few years, parents find new reasons to worry about their teenagers. And while there is no question that some kids continue to experiment with sex and substance abuse, the latest data points to something perhaps more surprising: the current generation is, well, a bit boring when it comes to bad behavior. By several noteworthy measures, today's teenagers are growing increasingly conservative. While marijuana use has recently had an uptick, teenagers are smoking far less pot than their parents did at the same age. In 1980, about 60 percent of high-school seniors had tried marijuana and 9 percent smoked it daily. Among seniors today, according to the University of Michigan's Monitoring the Future survey, which has tracked teenage risk behaviors since 1975, 45.5 percent have tried the drug and 6.6 percent are smoking it frequently ().

BALLEK--Rodney F.,67, of New York City died suddenly on January 31, 2012. He is survived by his daughter Lisa Lonnegren, her husband Mark and his adored two grandchildren, Abby and Eric, all of Rye, NY. A graduate of the University of Connecticut and the Advanced Management Program at Harvard Business School, Rod spent his entire career at Citibank. He joined Citibank as a trainee in 1968. When he retired in 1998 he was the senior executive for corporate risk and portfolio management for North America, Europe and Japan. Rod will be remembered as a devoted father and grandfather. He was a good listener, up for anything, and was known for his exceptional punctuality as well as his warm sense of humor. Services will be private. Donations in Rod's memory may be made to the American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Place, White Plains, NY 10601.

FELD--Adam Graham, of Cincinnati, OH formerly of Brooklyn, NY passed away on February 2nd. He was 49 years of age. After marrying Debbie, he attained a starting position with a CPA firm in Cincinnati, where he rose to partnership in a few years. He loved the "Mets" and music. He was a loving father to Nicole and Joshua. He was an exceptional loving son to his mother Lillian and father Herman (Hy). He was predeceased by his father, brother Ross and sister Susan. He is survived by his children, mother, sister-in-law Ellen, nephews Aaron and Zachary, his aunts, uncles, and their families who greatly enriched his life. Now Adam will live on within our hearts and souls and we will always treasure and celebrate his life. The Feld Family

Someday, N.F.L. news media directors will insert sensors into the sprained ankles of injured players and affix neurological monitors to the scalps of sleepy defensive ends. The devices will transmit data to downloadable tablet applications ($9.99 a month sounds like a fair price), and eager fans will be able to watch in real time as tissue heals and REM sleep gives way to the bleary realization that Tom Coughlin is going to exact financial restitution for his extreme disappointment. Someday, quarterbacks like Tom Brady and Eli Manning will also be able to purchase and program lifelike automatons that can recite dozens of variations on ''I have nothing but respect for my opponent'' and ''We just take things one day at a time.'' Once such technology exists, Super Bowl hype will be fully automated, and we can all go about the business of riding zip lines, catching up on college hoops or taking healthy walks while computers talk to computers about Rob Gronkowski.

HAWES, Rosilla Hornblower. Died on January 27, 2012 at the age of 100. Most beloved mother of Lynden B. Miller, cherished mother-in-law of Leigh M. Miller and adored grandmother of Gifford, Marshall, Ethan, and Christian Miller, their wives and eight great-grandchildren whose lives she enriched with her kind, loving and generous nature and her wide-ranging knowledge of literature, public affairs and history. She was born in New York City in 1911 and attended the Chapin School and Vassar College, class of 1933. She was married in 1935 to Alan R. Breed who died in 1954. In 1979 she married Alexander B. Hawes who died in 1995. She lived in Washington, D.C. for many years before returning to her native New York almost a decade ago. Her New York roots went way back in New York history. Her ancestors ranged from Susannah Rutgers Marshall, a businesswoman in 18th century New Amsterdam, the Architect, Henry Rutgers Marshall, to Judge William B. Hornblower of the New York Court of Appeals, as well as many other New York architects and lawyers. Her family for many generations believed passionately in public service, and dinner conversation when she was growing up always centered on current events and politics. After Vassar, where she majored in sociology and economics, she worked at the National Consumers League, an organization dedicated to helping women in the workplace founded by Frances Perkins. From long family tradition, she was always a passionate Democrat and, as she put it, "a New Yorker to the bone," so she delighted in the public careers of her two grandsons, Gifford Miller, former Speaker of the New York City Council, and Marshall Miller, Chief of the Criminal Division at the United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York. Though not a gardener herself, she was proud of her daughter, Lynden B. Miller, Public Garden Designer, in her role of beautifying the city they both loved. For those lucky enough to know her, she personified a LADY: elegant, gracious, thoughtful, tactful and sympathetic to everyone she met. She spent her life cherishing the many people she loved and supporting New York City causes and institutions like The New York Botanical Garden, The New York Public Library and The Community Service Society. Contributions in her memory could be made to any of those organizations.
The cover article on Jan. 8 about 45 places to go in 2012 misspelled the name of an adventure tour operator on the Samaná Peninsula of the Dominican Republic. It is Bavaro Runners, not Bravaro.

Two of the best work experiences I have ever had were unpaid. One was an internship at a literary and cultural journal in the Philippines, and the other was an internship in a federal prosecutor's office. Neither of my internships violated the law -- one was at a nonprofit in a foreign country, and the other was with the federal government -- but had they been with for-profit entities in the United States, they might have. Assuming an unpaid internship is mutually beneficial and entered into freely by both parties, should such arrangements be illegal? And should scarce government resources be spent on trying to police the large and growing number of unpaid internships? I have my doubts.

TAY BAY HTA, MYANMAR -- When Myanmar announced a cease-fire last month with one of the country's most prominent rebel groups, images of longstanding enemies shaking hands across a table were beamed around the globe and touted as evidence of further reconciliation in a country emerging from decades of military dictatorship and interethnic strife. Now, three weeks after the deal was announced, the leadership of the rebel group is denying that a cease-fire was signed.

FINE--Norma of Boston, MA, Sarasota, FL and Hartford VT, passed away February 2, one month short of her 80th birthday. An actress and philanthropist, Ms. Fine pursued many passions with generosity, courage and heart. While raising three children, she both served as volunteer Chairman of Combined Jewish Philanthropies and Israel Bonds for Boston, and taught school. Years of involvement in politics culminated in her service as a senior aide to Boston Mayor Kevin White. After her successful coordination of the National Conference of Mayors, Mayor White appointed her the Chairman of the George Robert White Fund, a public charitable trust of the City of Boston. At age 50, Norma decided to return to her initial love of acting, becoming a successful actress on Boston and regional stages, starring in countless commercials, and making her cinematic debut as Mrs. Goodhall in the film, Cider House Rules. Ms. Fine cared deeply about helping children in need. She endowed a Pediatric Fellowship at the Mass General Hospital, as well as supporting a number of Israeli charities that help children, including Yemin Orde, a youth village in Israel where her daughter, Lauri, worked. The most important children in her life were her eight extraordinary grandchildren, whose triumphs and growing pains she worried over and helped to guide every day. She was predeceased by her husband, Phil David Fine, and her sister Sandra Loew. She is survived by her partner of 19 years, Herb Feinstein, her sister Harriet Jacobson, her daughters, Susan Fine, Lauri Fine Friedman and Debra Fine, and her eight grandchildren, Eyal, Sivan and Daphna Friedman, Allison and Pamela Fine Mishkin and Jordan, Abigail and Phil Fine Schneider. The funeral will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations should made in her honor to Friends of Yemin Orde, 12230 Rockville, MD, 20852.

COPELAND--Lawrence G. Lawrence G. Copeland, Noted Craftsman, Designer, Educator, and Former POW, Dies at 89. Lawrence G. Copeland, a well-known mid-twentieth-century American silversmith and long-time City College of New York educator, died on January 26 at his home in Boulder, Colorado. He was 89. As a student, craftsman, designer, and teacher, Mr. Copeland interacted with some of the most important personalities of the mid-century American crafts movement and contributed to several of the most prominent craft institutions and enterprises. Lawrence Gill Copeland was born in 1922 in Pittsburgh and raised in Knoxville. He attended Muskingum College before transferring to Ohio State University to pursue his love of art, despite objections from his parents. When World War II intervened in Mr. Copeland's undergraduate education, he served as lead navigator for the 459th Bombardment Group of the 15th Air Force and flew on B-24 "Liberators" before being shot down over Avignon, France in July 1944. He recorded his experience as a Prisoner-of-War at Stalag Luft I in sketches and other artwork in a Red Cross journal. He published that artwork with an accompanying narrative in 2010. Following his liberation, he graduated from Ohio State in 1946. Mr. Copeland earned a Swedish Royal Fellowship to the University of Stockholm for 1947 and 1948 and also studied with Baron Erik Fleming, Court Silversmith to His Majesty the King of Sweden, at Konstfackskolan while in Stockholm. He then studied painting with Emeric Gomery in Paris in 1948 and 1949. Mr. Copeland returned to the United States and earned his Master of Fine Arts degree from Cranbrook Academy of Art in 1951. He quickly found an outlet for his silverwork at New York's now-legendary America House and began his long association with organizations sponsored by leading art patron and philanthropist Aileen Osborn Webb. Frances Wright Caroe, daughter of Frank Lloyd Wright and arts administrator of America House, facilitated his 1951 appointment as an Instructor at the School for American Craftsmen (SAC) at Rochester Institute of Technology. At SAC, Mr. Copeland met his future wife, Mary Cuteri, who was an Instructor in dress design, whom he married in 1953. Mr Copeland became Head of Design for Oneida, Ltd. in 1959. Returning to teaching, Mr. Copeland was appointed a Professor at City College of New York in 1963. He served as Chairman of the Department of Art from 1968 to 1969 but resigned from the post following the 1969 riots and disruptions on campus to return to more active teaching. In 1985, Mr. Copeland retired to Warwick, New York where he designed and built a home before moving to Boulder, Colorado in 2007. Throughout his career, Mr. Copeland contributed to the American crafts movement as both a practitioner and thoughtful leader. His work in silver and pewter displayed dramatic sculptural volumes and delicate abstract details. It was displayed on the international stage as part of a traveling exhibition sponsored by the United States State Department in 1953. When the Museum of Contemporary Crafts (now the Museum of Arts & Design) was established in New York in 1956 by the American Craft Council and Mrs. Webb, he was selected to contribute work to the initial Craftsmanship in a Changing World exhibit. Mr. Copeland also had the distinction of having his work exhibited in the United States Pavilion at the 1958 World's Fair in Brussels, Belgium and has pieces in the permanent collection of the Smithsonian Institution. In addition to his account of his World War II experience, Mr. Copeland authored Fabrication of Silver Hollow Ware which was published in 1959. During his career he was a frequent contributor to American Craft magazine (and its predecessor Craft Horizons), served on the Board of Directors of several professional organizations, including the American Craft Council, was a member of the Selection Committee for the Fulbright Program, and was a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts, London. Mr. Copeland is survived by his wife of 58 years, Mary; his sons, Jeffrey and Ian; his daughter, Mary Louise Copeland; their spouses; and seven grandchildren. Lawrence Copeland moved among notable people and places of the mid-twentieth century crafts movement. While his work is the most tangible testament to his contribution to that movement, his most lasting contribution may well be the thousands of today's craftspeople he taught or influenced as an educator and his support for the creation and early years of what has become New York's Museum of Arts & Design. The family has requested that donations in Mr. Copeland's honor be made to the Collings Foundation, PO Box 248, Stow, MA 01775. M. P. Murphy & Associates Funeral Directors of Boulder is handling arrangements.

The chess column on Jan. 22, about a new study of mathematics that could shed light on why so few women are among the chess elite, misstated part of the study's findings and its conclusion. The study of mathematics performance in 86 countries found that boys outperformed girls in some countries; it did not say that boys always outperformed girls. And the authors, in concluding that math performance is heavily influenced by social and economic factors, noted that performance for girls and boys -- not just for girls -- improves when there is greater gender equality.

Land Rovers began as basic, functional equipment, said Gerry McGovern, the company's head of design since 2004. But with the introduction of the Range Rover models, it became modern and comfortable. Mr. McGovern compared the evolution to that of modern architecture. ''Modern architecture began by copying the factory,'' he said.''Le Corbusier talked about the home as a machine for living. But nobody wants to live in just a machine. It has to be more comfortable.''

GREENBERG--Hazel Sara. Born April 23, 1933, died February 2, 2012 peacefully at home in Santa Fe, NM surrounded by loved ones after a valiant four and a half year fight against cancer. Hazel passionately embraced a love for travel, reading, knitting, and art collection. She taught at Midwood High School for nearly 30 years, and then spent ten years as a Director at the American Forum for Global Education. She is survived by three sons, Frederick Rundback, John Rundback and Richard Greenberg; and grandchildren, Matthew Rundback and Alexandra Greenberg; and her very dear friend, Linda Arkin.

On the first page of Facebook's prospectus for its sale of stock to the public, it pegs the number of its "monthly active users" at a whopping 845 million people. The social networking site arrives at an even more astounding number when it comes to "daily active users": 483 million people.

Belgian imperialism. Now there's an audacious oxymoron - these days, at least [1]. For the last few decades, the Maryland-size kingdom by the North Sea has seemed occupied mainly with keeping its constituent Flemish- and French-speaking parts from splitting in two [2]. But in the second half of the 19th century, Belgium was the little country that could: as the world's "second industrialized nation" (after Britain), it punched above its weight around the globe. With great clout came a giant African colony: the Congo, 80 times the size of its "motherland."

Haley Barbour, Ronald Reagan's former political director, used a graveside tribute for the president's 101st birthday on Monday to warn Republican presidential candidates and voters alike that they are courting defeat by demanding in Reagan's name a conservative purity he did not represent.

On a hot summer day in 1861, Commander Matthew Fontaine Maury and his son Richard, now a junior officer in the Confederate Army, rowed from Rockett's Wharf in Richmond, Va., toward the middle of the James River and set afloat two kegs filled with rifle powder. The kegs bobbed down river toward a buoy, where they became entangled, as intended. But nothing happened.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.- If you believe in signs, they are pointing toward a longish Oscar show. The annual nominees luncheon here on Monday went long, at any rate. The yearly gathering of as many Oscar nominees as will attend (this year 150 showed up) was scheduled to last between noon and 2 p.m. in the International Ballroom of the Beverly Hilton Hotel. But it was 2:08 by the time Ric Robertson, the chief operating officer of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, got around to introducing Brian Grazer and Don Mischer, who will be producing the Feb. 26 Oscar ceremony.

The farmer-writer Wendell Berry will deliver the 41st annual Jefferson Lecture in the Humanities, the National Endowment for the Humanities announced on Monday. The lecture, to be given on April 23 at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, is considered the federal government's most prestigious honor for intellectual achievement in the humanities.

Madonna Soars: Helped by a huge radio and Web push - oh, and a Super Bowl performance, too -- Madonna's new album, "MDNA," has gotten a strong start on the charts. Advance sales pushed it to No. 1 on iTunes's rankings in 35 countries (the album will be released on March 26). And Billboard reports that "Gimme All Your Luvin'," the first single, racked up 2,766 spins on Top 40 stations from its premiere on Friday morning through Sunday night. That was largely due to the support of 95 Clear Channel Communications stations, which played the song every hour, on the hour, and accounted for 79 percent of the song's plays on that format.

In just over three weeks, 129 common dolphins have stranded themselves along 20 miles of Cape Cod beaches. While mass strandings of marine mammals are hardly new in the area -- even the Pilgrims witnessed them -- this series is different. It's the biggest single-species stranding that Cape Cod has ever seen, and the dolphins keep on coming, even though most of the stranding events are over in just one or two days.

Stella McCartney appears in a new video by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, released today. It's worth watching. The subject is animal suffering in the leather industry and the risks to human health and the environment from tanneries. Ms. McCartney, who doesn't use animal skins in her fashion, has worked with PETA in previous campaigns; at Chloé, in the late '90s, she appeared in a video that drew attention to animal suffering in the fur industry. Her bags and shoes, which are made from non-leather materials, have quietly and steadily gained a following. Indeed, accessories have become a substantial business for her company.

When I want to get in touch with my inner healthy person (we've been estranged since mid-December), I do an organic cold-pressed juice fast or a juice/raw food combination cleanse from Marcus Antebi's excellent Juice Press. Until now, he's had few rivals for my affections. But Jamie Graber, a pretty redhead who used to work at Live Live (one of the best spots in town for supplements and packaged raw foods), is giving him a bit of friendly competition with Gingersnap's Organic, her new East Village cafe. Graber offers a few cold-pressed juices, but her main focus is "handcrafted conscious cuisine," or raw, vegan, gluten-free food. Any of you who eat raw know how delicious - or disastrous - this kind of (non) cooking can be. But Graber and her chef have created a menu full of yummy, creatively seasoned offerings, like zucchini almond hummus, carrot-coconut dal and portobello Reuben wraps. Forget those ubiquitous flax seed crackers. At Gingersnap's, the crisps are a little more exotic, with flavors like zaatar, vadouvan and chipotle.

If you watched Eli Manning's reaction to winning a second Super Bowl -- having toppled the Patriots and coverboy quarterback Tom Brady again, having done it in the football city built by his brother, having reduced Bill Belichick to just another defensive coach with one idea too few -- you saw the essence of what makes him Eli Manning. Sure, his smile sparkled amid the celebratory confetti and his daughter Ava was playing with the keys to a most valuable player reward Corvette that he will almost assuredly never drive. But he was as even-keeled in triumph as he is with defensive ends storming his pocket. Whatever stabilizing rudder held course all these years of being Peyton Manning's little brother and Archie Manning's youngest son and quarterback in a city with a spotlight as bright and hot as a sun was holding course now too.

Trending on Twitter in Germany Monday morning - right up there with the #superbowl and New York Giants - was "Grüss Gott," roughly translated as "God's Greetings," and traditionally the way Bavarians and other southern Germans, and most Austrians, greet one another. The greeting has the nation buzzing after the director in a middle school in the southern city of Passau posted a notice banning the more casual "Hallo" from the premises in favor of "Grüss Gott," which she considers to be more polite. (The casual German expression for bye, "Tschüss" has also been jettisoned in favor of the more traditional "Auf Wiedersehen.")

In a twist, an exciting Super Bowl game was matched by a rather ordinary collection of commercials, Stuart Elliott writes. The game usually disappoints, while offering a platform for the most creative ads of the year - why, it's the Super Bowl for commercials! Instead, the ads offered many retread ideas and stars, including the rap jester Flava Flav, chimpanzees dressed as people, Donald J. Trump and talking babies. Among the best ads, he writes, were serious ones from Chrysler, narrated by Clint Eastwood during halftime, and a Best Buy spot about technological innovators.

Svenskt Tenn, Stockholm's iconic design and interiors shop, closed the doors of its flagship boutique at 5 Strandvägen, which opened in 1927, for several months last year for a thorough renovation. Now, to celebrate its reopening - and just in time for Stockholm Design Week - the store kicks off an exhibition of the work of Estrid Ericson, who founded the business in 1924, and her most famous collaborator, the Austrian designer Josef Frank. Visitors will also see new pieces by the Swedish artist Eric Ericson and by the French designer Inga Sempé, whose pewter pitcher, cup and tray recall Estrid Ericson's early career as a pewter designer. And don't miss Svenskt Tenn's newest addition: the most charming tea salon in the city. Not only are the teas, cakes and sandwiches excellent, but tables are set with products from the store. At one end of the room, behind a wall of glass, is a recreation of Ericson's workroom. A woman of impeccable taste, she had a five-cup-a-day tea habit, and no one knew more about setting the perfect table.

Sifting through the archives of 19 Latin American countries is a daunting task. Yet a committee of artists and scholars did just that, in order to remedy the critical lack of knowledge about Latin American photography. The outcome of this extensive research is FOTO/GRÁFICA, an exhibition at Le Bal in Paris (through April 8 at 6 Impasse de la Défense; 33-1-44-70-75-56).The exhibition surveys a century of Latin American history through photography books, spotlighting forgotten works as well as those that never made it beyond limited circles. The director of Le Bal, Diane Dufour, described the complex task of unearthing the books without systematic cultural records: each was as much a material get as a historical discovery. The findings were then narrowed down according to various criteria, including image quality, printing quality, layout.

WASHINGTON - If Mitt Romney thought another thumping of his opponents in Nevada would do the trick, he was mistaken. He produced a victory in the first Western contest that left his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination far behind, struggling with one another for second, third and fourth place. The victory speech by Mr. Romney barely acknowledged their existence.

When a UPS delivery worker shows up at your house, the bulky handheld that he yanks out for you to write your digital signature is known as a ''rugged device.'' Microsoft's older Windows Mobile operating system is running on the vast majority of these devices, but competitors are offering rugged alternatives on newer software, and it's questionable how long Microsoft can fend them off. Rugged devices are designed to tolerate the abuse of being outdoors on a regular basis. They're often sealed to prevent rain, moisture and dust from getting inside, and their cases are sturdy enough to survive falls. Workers in field services like telecom, utilities, oil and gas typically carry these devices. You've seen them in the hands of delivery workers, and you may have seen some healthcare providers carrying rugged handhelds for viewing patient records and vital signs.
