Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief of Goldman Sachs who has become a lightning rod for Wall Street critics, might seem an unlikely advocate for same-sex marriage. But his credentials - a public figure in a conservative industry - could make him a powerful voice for that cause. The Human Rights Campaign, a national organization that promotes equal rights for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people, has persuaded Mr. Blankfein to be its first national corporate spokesman for same-sex marriage, an issue that will come up for a legislative vote in several states this year, including Washington and Maryland. Fred Sainz, an executive with the Human Rights Campaign, said the organization sought Mr. Blankfein, in part, because he is ''an unexpected messenger.''

MINCHIN--Myles Faulkiner, of New York City, NY. Titular Head of the Minchin Family, Annagh, County Tipperary Ireland. Chief of Secretariat Services Division, Department of Political Affairs, Trusteeship and Decolonization, 89 years of age did pass away after short illness at New York Langone Hospital January 25, 2012. The second son of the late Lieutenant Commander Henry Reilly-Falkiner and late Winifred Florence (O'Bryen) Minchin. He was born in County of Portsmouth C.B. England, pre-ceased by his brothers Brian Patrick John and William Abbott. Myles studied at and received his B.A. (1945) and M.A. (1948) from Kings College, UK. He earned honors in both modern Languages and Economics Tripos. In addition to English, he spoke French, Spanish and Portuguese. Just as he finished his studies at university, a unique job-opportunity emerged. The United Nations was forged between two significant conferences: Dumbarton Oaks under Franklin D. Roosevelt (October, 1944) and San Francisco under Harry Truman (June, 1945). Myles joined the Secretariat in 1945 and moved to New York the following year. In 1952, he transferred to the UN Trusteeship Division. Myles had worked with the United Nations since it's inception and had been there for all his working life. His service was recognized in 1983 with the award of the CBE (Companion of the British Empire). He was also a life member of the Association of Former International Civil Servants, United Nations, New York. Myles Faulkner Reilly Minchin hailed from a very long and interesting family dating back to the 1400's. A gentleman always, he will be missed by many, including Patrick McKinley (England) and Dan and Barbara Minchin and family (Ireland), companions/caretakers Barbara Connelly (Shirley, LI) and Sheila Thomas (Brooklyn, NY), friends Raymond Foster, Charles E. Garvey (New Jersey), Donald F. Gross, and Michael Salem (New York). Respects: 2pm, Thursday, February 9, 2012, Memorial Service Mass: St. Thomas Church, Fifth Ave, 1 West 53rd St., New York City. Memorial Tribute to follow at: Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home 81st St and Madison Ave, NYC, 4:00-7:00pm.

A headline and a chart with The Caucus column on Friday about the election prospects of incumbent presidents referred incorrectly to three former presidents. While Harry S. Truman, Lyndon B. Johnson and Gerald R. Ford were incumbents when they ran for president, none of them ever sought ''re-election.'' (Mr. Truman took office upon the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1945 and was elected to a full term in 1948; Mr. Johnson took office after President John F. Kennedy's assassination in 1963 and was elected to a full term in 1964; and Mr. Ford, who succeeded Richard M. Nixon, but was never elected to the vice presidency or presidency, lost his race for president in 1976.)

DONNEr--David, a sweet, gentle, Renaissance man of daunting intellect passed away peacefully at his home in Lake Worth, Fla at the age of 97 after a long vital, vibrant, happy life. He was respected and loved by all who knew him. He was predeceased by his wife of 66 years, Sema Donner, and his nephew David Farber. He is survived by his daughter Deborah Donner Filocomo, and her husband, Peter, his son Barry Donner and grandchildren, Dr. Peter, Eli, Sarah, Daniel, Ezra and Hannah and great grandchildren Chloe and Michael, nieces and nephew Laurie Farber, Robin Farber-Eger, Dr. Robert Farber and cherished companion Evelyn Silvert David was a proud veteran of World War II, landed at Omaha Beach 10 days after D-Day and was wounded at the Battle of St. Lo. David's favorite stories were about his experiences as a French interpreter during his war time service in France. He was passionate about bridge, opera, Shakespeare, public television, classical music, Evelyn and Scrabble, too. He owned and operated a fine men's haberdashery shop in Niagara Falls, NY until his retirement and move to Florida.

With the popularity of music streaming services like Spotify and Pandora, music magazines have had to find compelling ways to keep their readers engaged. On Monday, Spin Media will announce an overhaul for Spin.com, which includes plans for a streaming music player, nine new blogs and Web-only content like news and album reviews. Starting in March, the music player will sit at the top of the page and users can listen to music as they browse through the site.

Research in Motion wants Android programmers to make apps for the BlackBerry PlayBook so badly that it's handing out the tablets for free. All an Android programmer has to do to get one is make a PlayBook app and submit it to RIM's app store, BlackBerry App World, by Feb. 13, said Alec Saunders, vice president of developer relations at RIM, in a posting to Twitter. The reason RIM is seeking Android apps is because it made the PlayBook software system compatible with Android apps.

BORER--Rita Feldt. Born February 11, 1922. Died February 4, 2012. Beloved wife, for 62 years, of the late Dr. Lee Borer, mother of Dr. Jeffrey Borer, mother-in-law of Brondi Borer, grandmother of Justine and Jon, daughter of the late Joseph Feldt and Ella Stark Feldt and sister of the late Selma Feldt. Rita graduated from New York University in 1942, studying fine arts and education, and worked as an art teacher prior to marriage in 1944. Later, she established a high-end practice of interior design which flourished based on her keen esthetic sensibility and her pride in orderly, precise presentation. Though life-long New Yorkers, Rita and Lee entertained friends and family annually at their beautiful villas in the south of France. She imbued her family with a strong appreciation of etiquette, decorum and beauty. Private funeral service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the fund for Restoration of the Brooklyn Jewish Center, Oholei Torah, 667 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, NY 11213.

LONDON -- Some plays are worth defying claustrophobia for. As a capacity audience crowded onto the benches that surrounded the rectangular stage of the tiny black-box space of the Royal Court Jerwood Theater Upstairs, I could feel my chest tightening and my breath growing shorter. It didn't help that layers of white balloons covered (and lowered) the ceiling in molecular formations. I had to admonish myself, as I do in such circumstances, ''Theater critics do not faint on the job - except, on rare occasion, metaphorically.'' And then Nick Payne's ''Constellations'' began, and the room - and my chest - expanded almost immediately. My chest stayed regulation size, but the room seemed to keep getting bigger during the 70 minutes of this two-character drama, which is acted with startling freshness by Sally Hawkins and Rafe Spall. This was altogether appropriate to a work about the limitlessness of physics and the enclosing limitations of human existence.

PEREZ--Carol Nesnow, on February 3, 2012 from respiratory complications of facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD) in Lexington, Massachusetts. Born and raised in Queens, New York, she had a Master's in Education from Northeastern University and was a tireless advocate who helped countless people with disability and disease to live better lives. Carol served as Secretary of the board of the FSH Society, was former Executive Director, FSH Society, and retired, Area Director, Massachusetts Rehabilitation Commission. She is survived by her devoted husband of 55 years, Charles; son Daniel; and his wife Susan; a daughter Rosanne Sterne; and her husband Ned; and grandchildren; Annelise and Clifton Dawson, Gabriella and Camilla Sterne. Those wishing to honor Carol's, memory may make a donation to the FSH Society, 64 Grove Street, Watertown, MA 02472 or online at www.fshsociety.org.

CAHILL--Thomas F. Sr.,passed away Thursday morning, February 2, 2012 at Morristown Medical Center. He was 76. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, he was a resident of New Providence, NJ before moving to Summit, NJ in 1974. He also maintained a home in La Quinta, CA. Mr. Cahill served in the United States Army, mustering out as a Captain. He earned a Bachelors from Seton Hall University in 1957, and a Masters in Finance from Columbia University in 1959. Mr. Cahill had been a Partner on the New York Stock Exchange with the First Manhattan Company for 23 years, in charge of floor operations, before retiring in 1994. Previously he had worked with J. Shields & Co. and Auerbach, Pollak, and Richardson, Inc. He was a member of the Canoe Brook Country Club, the Stock Exchange Luncheon Club, the Buttonwood Club Ballybunion Golf Club in Ireland, and was active in Seton Hall Alumni Association. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Margaret "Marge" Cahill (nee Martin); three sons, Thomas F. Cahill Jr. and his wife Anh of North Salem, NY, Christopher M. Cahill of Sonoma, CA., and Andrew K. Cahill of Summit; and three grandchildren, Tadhg Tomas, Thomas F. VI and Caitlin Cahill. He was preceded in death by his father, Thomas F. Cahill, his mother Mary (nee Keating) Cahill and a sister, Ann Metzheiser. Relatives and friends are invited to call Monday February 6, and Tuesday February 7, 2-4 and 7-9pm at the William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave., Summit. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Wednesday, February 8, 10:45am at St. Teresa of Avila R.C. Church, Summit. Interment will follow at St. Teresa Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Foundation Fighting Blindness, 7168 Columbia Gateway Dr, Suite 100, Columbia, MD 21046 (www.blindness.org) would be appreciated.

REIS--Jane Hines. January 17th. Jane was predeceased by her beloved husband Myron (Mike) and her adored sister Jovce Rose Hines. Jane earned a bachelor's degree from Hunter College and a master's degree from New York University. She was proud of her graduations from both Hunter College High School and the Center for Modern Psychoanalytical Studies. Born in the Bronx Jane moved to Manhattan to study acting. She also pursued careers in teaching English, counseling and psychoanalysis. She retired from the faculty of Seward Park High School in Manhattan. Jane was a spirited, witty, loving friend who excelled in uncovering psychological truth and in forthrightly expressing her feelings. She is mourned by close friends and members of Mike's family. No immediate survivors.

The top category of apps last year was weather, surpassing navigation tools, finance, sports and games. It's no surprise, given extreme events around the world like Japan's tsunami, floods in Thailand, above, and a 50-year drought in East Africa. Closer to home there were the deadly onslaught of 200 tornados in April and extensive East Coast floods from Hurricane Irene in August. Weather apps at their simplest provide real-time data and forecasts, and some offer complex maps, beautiful graphics, news and interesting facts. SHELLY FREIERMAN

An obituary last Monday about the Indian photojournalist Homai Vyarawalla erroneously included two names on a list of people she photographed. Venus Williams returned to competitive tennis for the first time since last August as the United States swept Belarus, 5-0, in their Fed Cup tie in Worcester, Mass. Williams and Liezel Huber posted a 6-1, 6-2 victory in doubles. Williams played for the first time since the United States Open, when she announced that she had Sjogren's Syndrome, an autoimmune disease. Serena Williams clinched the victory with her second singles win of the weekend, defeating Anastasia Yakimova, 5-7, 6-1, 6-1. Christina McHale dominated Darya Kustova, 6-0, 6-1, in just 53 minutes.

''That's ancestral North America out there,'' said Sidney Horenstein, the geologist and environmental educator emeritus of the American Museum of Natural History, gesturing broadly toward the towers of mid-Manhattan. ''Here, we're on this exotic continent that collided with it.'' Exotic is the word. The rock outcrop that emerges like the tip of a geological iceberg from the children's playground in DeWitt Clinton Park, at West 52nd Street and 12th Avenue, is an astonishing work of natural sculpture; utterly sensuous - almost sensual in spots - with smooth curves and bubbly folds and veinous striations that look too organic to have been formed of schist, gneiss and amphibolite.

DUNBAR--Dr. Frederick. The staff of NERA Economic Consulting mourn the passing of Dr. Frederick Dunbar, a brilliant economist and one of the giants of our firm. Fred was our colleague for 30 years, and he remained a friend to many of us after he joined the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2009. He was one of the architects of NERA's growth for many years, creating our Securities and Mass Torts Practices, providing groundbreaking economic analysis and testimony for clients, and mentoring many of those who went on to leadership positions in the firm. We will sorely miss his sharp intellect, his keen sense of humor, and his deep humanity. Our thoughts are with his friends and family, and especially his wife Helen Mangano. The Board of Directors NERA Economic Consulting

Madonna earned praise early on for her halftime performance at the Super Bowl on Sunday night, but it was her guest star M.I.A. who may have stolen the headlines from her by making an obscene gesture during the show. M.I.A, the stage name of the hip-hop performer Maya Arulpragasam, appeared with the rapper Nicki Minaj to sing ''Give Me All Your Luvin','' a new Madonna song that was performed during a medley of the Material Girl's hits. At the end of her verse, M.I.A. stopped just short of singing a vulgar lyric and extended her middle finger to the camera. The television broadcast appeared to go blurry just after this, but not in time to obscure the gesture.

ZINDER--Norton David, 83. Devoted husband for 54 years of the late Marilyn Zinder, father of Stephen and Michael, father in law of Chris and Charlotte, and doting grandfather of his "basketball team" Daniel, Ben, John, Adam, and Matt. Born November 7, 1928, a graduate of Bronx High School of Science (1944), Columbia University (1947), and University of Wisconsin (PhD, 1952) where with Joshua Lederberg he discovered that viruses can carry genes between cells, a fundamental genetic process called transduction. He then joined the Rockefeller University to which he devoted over 50 years of service. He was the John D. Rockefeller Jr. Professor of Genetics Emeritus and had served as Dean of Students for several years. He mentored many graduate students and postdocs and took great pride in their subsequent successes. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences and taught at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, later serving on its Board of Directors. He played an important early role in establishing the NIH human genome project, and was an invited attendee at the 2000 White House ceremony celebrating the draft human genome sequence. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rockefeller University or the charity of your choice. Service at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, February 8, 11:45am, followed by interment at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ.

MATZNER--Stella. Devoted daughter of Laura and Joseph. Beloved wife of Walter for 58 wonderful years. Dedicated sister to Annabelle and Charlotte. Loving mother of Susan and Debbie, and mother-in-law to Alan and Jeffrey. Cherished grandmother to Marissa and Matthew, Jeremy and Brooke, Arielle, Daniel and Matthew. Proud great-grandmother to Isabella and Luke. Her happiest times were when surrounded by family and friends. Stella's life journey was extraordinary. After graduating City College, she embarked on an accounting career that spanned five decades. She was an active member of the National Council of Jewish Women, dedicating countless hours to community service. While fighting a long and difficult battle against lung cancer, Stella never lost her love of life or positive attitude. She was truly an inspiration and role model to all. We are the lucky ones for having her in our lives. Stella will be deeply missed and she will remain in our hearts forever.

9 P.M. (Sundance) L'AMOUR FOU (2011) The French couturier Yves Saint Laurent, above right, may have been surrounded by intense beauty both in the atelier and at home, yet he was said to be joyful only twice a year: on the days a new collection was shown, usually to boisterous acclaim. Twenty-four hours later, the euphoria had evaporated. Pierre Bergé narrates this documentary about Saint Laurent, his partner in business and in life for a half-century until the designer's death in 2008. The ''crazy love'' of the title refers not so much to their relationship but to Saint Laurent's obsessions with objects, from the artworks -- including Picassos, Matisses, Braques and a treasured Brancusi that sold for $483.8 million at a 2009 Christie's auction -- to his passion for collecting perfect houses, one of which had all the rooms named after characters from Proust. ''Much of this stately, rather detached biography,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this documentary from Pierre Thoretton, ''is pornography for the eye (not the body).'' Of Saint Laurent's depression, he added, ''To realize that you may have the world while still feeling as if you have nothing is to experience a closer encounter with the void than most of us are likely to have.'' 6:30 P.M. (HBO2) NAMATH (2012) HBO Sports and NFL Films chronicle the life of Joe Namath, right, starting with his childhood in Beaver Falls, Pa., and his college days playing for Bear Bryant at the University of Alabama. The film extends to his larger-than-life stature on the field with the New York Jets and off, where his movie-star looks and free-wheeling personality earned him the nickname Broadway Joe. Then there was his famous guarantee of a Jets win in Super Bowl III against the heavily favored Baltimore Colts. Namath was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1985. Family members, the former Baltimore Colts coach Don Shula and the actress Ann-Margret weigh in.

A capsule summary on Wednesday for an article about thousands of protesters in Cairo who tried to march on Parliament misstated the action taken by the Muslim Brotherhood in response to the demonstration. As the article and the summary itself correctly noted, they blocked the protesters from reaching Parliament, they did not ''back'' them.

HURA--Stanley. Stanley Hura, of New York, NY passed away on January 24th. He was 74. Stanley is survived by his sister Ann Weronski, brother Edward Hura, lifelong friends Phryne Hayhurst, Beau Maas and Kurt Bieber, and many friends who will miss his singular good humor, generosity of spirit, and the warmth of his voice. Stanley enjoyed a long and successful career--at Lord & Taylor, J.P. Stevens, as contributing editor to Country Living and Good Housekeeping, and in interior design, including the decoration of Governor Mario Cuomo's private residence in Albany. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Stanley's name to God's Love We Deliver, www.glwd.org.

There are trailers made for movies. And television shows. And, lately, for big-budget video games and highly anticipated books. And now, for a print magazine article. ''Coming soon in Esquire,'' one of the trailers begins. Clips of interviews are shown, names of characters are splayed across the screen, and then, in red type, the title is revealed: ''Animals.''

At about 5 p.m. Tuesday on the West Coast, three hours after Facebook filed for one of the most lucrative public offerings in history, its chief executive and founder, Mark Zuckerberg, posted on his Facebook page a photograph of his desk. It showed his computer, which seemed to be open to Facebook, a bottle of Gatorade and a large sign that said ''stay focused and keep shipping,'' an apparent echo of the famous saying of the late Steve Jobs, ''real artists ship.'' The message: Mr. Zuckerberg was not going to let all his billions go to his head. By the end of the night, nearly a hundred people had posted comments. Most were innocuous. But, in what might be a straw in the wind, some of the most popular posts took issue with that sudden wealth, which derives directly from the site's ability to make money from the personal information of its hundreds of millions of users. Let's ignore the man who wrote ''Facebook is fascism incarnate,'' however much his analysis was liked. The same goes for the fellow who wrote ''Mark $uckerberg.'' Maybe that was a joke, however barbed.

She was predeceased by her brother, Paul Jaretzki, and is survived by her sister, Josephine J. Lipman, and her brother, Alfred Jaretzki III. Dotsy taught nursery school in Manhattan and volunteered for many years at the Head Start preschool program in Mamaroneck. Score one for 20th Century Fox, whose low-budget movie ''Chronicle'' turned out a bigger-than-expected crowd at theaters on what is typically one of Hollywood's slowest weekends of the year. ''Chronicle,'' about three teenage boys who learn they have superpowers, was No. 1 at North American theaters, taking in about $22 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. The solid result for ''Chronicle,'' made in-house for a mere $12 million (not easy for a huge studio to do), validates Fox's decision to aggressively aim for elusive male moviegoers -- and on Super Bowl weekend, no less. Notably, Fox relied heavily on Twitter to create buzz, buying zero newspaper ads.

The script for the closing scene of what would become a classic television comedy moment in 1972 had Sammy Davis Jr. -- playing himself -- posing for a snapshot beside the likable bigot Archie Bunker after stopping by the Bunker home to pick up the briefcase he had left in Archie's cab. Not too hilarious -- until John Rich, the director, came up with the idea that just as the camera flashed, Sammy should plant a kiss on Archie's cheek.

SAN FRANCISCO - By my calculation, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's founder and chief executive, owes me about $50. Without me, and the other 844,999,999 people poking, liking and sharing on the site, Facebook would look like a scene from the postapocalyptic movie ''The Day After Tomorrow'': bleak, desolate and really quite sad. (Or MySpace, if that is easier to imagine.) Facebook surely would never be valued at anything close to $100 billion, which it very well could be in its coming initial public offering.

There's a new knitwear label in town called Orley that's as exciting and fresh-looking as any we've seen in some time. The label is led by the brothers Matthew and Alex Orley and their longtime friend (and Matthew's girlfriend) Samantha Florence, and their debut collection, available next fall, features seven sweater styles and a couple of scarves and hats in extremely optimistic colors and "prints." (Technically, they're double-faced wool and cashmere-blend jacquards on polos, cardigans, hoodies and crew-necks.) The brothers, both of whom have design experience - Matthew worked at Thom Browne; Alex at Rag & Bone, first in knits, then in denim - call music their main muse. "There is no 'theme' to the collection, but we were listening to a lot of early psychedelic music - the Velvet Underground and the Zombies, which I think comes through," says Alex. That said, 20th-century art and Algonquin Provincial Park, a vast Canadian nature preserve where the three designers spent their summers, also played a part in Orley's optical-organic aesthetic. With more than a trick or two up their twisted cable and contrast-cuffed sleeves, the Orleys and Florence hope to fill a gap in the market for fashion-driven men's sweaters that are at once directional and high-end (prices range from $425 to $865). "There was just a point where we thought: we're young, we know what we want to do, why wait?" Florence says. Sadly, shoppers must do just that until August, when the collection becomes available at Fivestory in New York and at Union in Los Angeles. Worth it? No doubt.

The Serpentine Gallery in London announced on Tuesday that the architectural firm Herzog & de Meuron and the artist Ai Weiwei -- the brain trust behind the Beijing National Stadium, aka the Bird's Nest -- will collaborate again to create the 2012 Serpentine Gallery Pavilion. The twelfth commission in an annual series of temporary pavilions erected on the gallery's grounds in Hyde Park, the new structure will be a bowl-shaped auditorium carved into the earth and protected by a flat, circular steel roof raised five feet above ground level. The space will be open to use by the public, as well as for speaking engagements and other programmed events.

Olivia Wu, an executive chef with the company, said the silent lunch helps to restore busy, tired minds and "and revives the corporate culture of innovation, community and doing the right thing."

After a small crop of graduates of the Navy's Aviation Survival Training Course had showered, dressed and filed out of the locker room, Petty Officer Second Class Cliff Erickson, one of their instructors, offered a moment of perspective. The officers had just completed a set of underwater exercises designed to sharpen their skills in case an aviation mishap ever put them into the water. They had learned several things. They were officially qualified now for four more years of flight. But the petty officer reminded them that their course was just an orientation for something that, if their luck turned bad, would probably be much worse. "Who thinks that if this happens it is going to be a comfortable environment?" he asked. "Nobody," he answered. "I am not going to lie to you. I teach this for a living, and it's not going to be easy for me if I ever have to do this for real. You will have to fight fear and panic and confusion, and you might be wounded, too."

For the first time in her 16-year career, Diana Vishneva, the Mariinsky and American Ballet Theatre prima ballerina, has hung up her toe shoes to dance a piece by Martha Graham. Next month the Russian starlet will perform Graham's 1947 "Errand Into the Maze," along with two other contemporary works, in New York. The Graham piece is inspired by Ariadne and the Minotaur and is a riff on sexual self-awareness. Vishneva is flat-footed throughout and wears a floaty, quite lyrical dress - a far cry from her usual tutus - a design done for the original Graham production. "In classical roles you don't have the freedom to express deep inner emotions the way I do now," says the 35-year-old, conceding that she could never have taken on the part as a young girl. "Even in Ariadne's weakness, the role of the maid, she is still strong and powerful." For the other two works, "Dialogue" by John Neumeier and "Subject to Change" by Paul Lightfoot and Sol León, she dances in a maroon housedress-like leotard and white Victorian blouson and briefs, respectively. Asked how this new program and new look have been received thus far in Moscow and St. Petersburg, she said cutely: "Taking the roof off." Vishneva and crew arrive at New York City Center on March 14.

Last week, I posted about Ryan Negri, founder of high-end cell-phone vendor Negri Electronics, who has found Google+ to be a better way than Facebook to reach and communicate with customers. In this post I want to describe another reason Mr. Negri thinks Google+ provides a real edge -- and also present the point of view of a business owner who disagrees.

Deborah Voigt withdrew from the Tuesday evening performance of Wagner's "Götterdämmerung" because of illness, the Metropolitan Opera said. Bring-your-own-Swiffer jokes aside, "Swept Away: Dust, Ashes, and Dirt in Contemporary Arts and Design," opening today at the Museum of Arts and Design, is a poignant reminder of the fragile, fleeting nature of art and life. The show is the latest installment in the museum's Materials and Process series, which explores the use, application and salvation of humble and often overlooked materials - including paper and "once living objects" - and their transformation into works of art. Take, for example, the English artist Catherine Bertola's ornate "flocked wallpaper," which she created on site using the contents of the museum's own vacuum cleaners. "Our maintenance crew thought we were crazy," the museum's chief curator, David McFadden, said of this fairly unusual recycling project. Also in the show are the American artist Jim Dingilian's smoke landscapes in a bottle, which have the elusive look of memories, and the Brazilian artist Alexandre Orion's video of his "reverse" graffiti, carved into the soot-saturated walls of São Paolo traffic tunnels.

Our family, including three boys ages 8, 10 and 11 and two cats, is seven months into our year in the woods, and at long last we are snowbound. We've been waiting for this since October! Kim Gordon, a woman who spent the last 30 years crisscrossing the country in a tour bus as the bassist for Sonic Youth, wanted the capsule collection that she designed with the French brand Surface to Air to do two very specific things - mix and match, and fit in the overhead compartment of a bus. "You can't pack that much for the road, and I've always liked the idea of not dressing up for a performance," she says. Made of basics that all pair easily with each other, the 12-piece collection features cropped neon-tangerine pants ("that's a good, bright color to wear on stage," she says), black, brown and snakeskin boots, a soft leather jacket and T-shirts printed with Gordon's own illustrations. "I like balancing things. I'm a mom, too, you know, but I don't always want to look just like that," she says. "It's the idea of finding things that work and are comfortable, but in which you can still feel like you have an identity."

There appears to be a light at the end of the tunnel in Seattle for the Intiman Theater, which in recent years has provided a launching pad for popular stage productions like "Light in the Piazza." It will remain open after meeting a $1 million fund-raising goal in just a few months, The Seattle Times reported. The theater has been under financial duress for a year. Last February it announced that it needed to raise $500,000 in a matter of weeks and another $250,000 by June and also in September to cover unpaid bills and unreported cost overruns and close other gaps. In April the rest of its 2011 season was canceled, the staff was laid off, and Kate Whoriskey left her post as the theater's artistic director.

On Feb. 7, 1984, two Challenger space shuttle astronauts, Capt. Bruce McCandless II and Col.l Robert L. Stewart, performed the first untethered spacewalk during the STS-41B mission. "Free of any lifeline and propelled into the dark void by tiny jets, they became, in effect, the first human satellites, " reported the Feb. 8 New York Times.Astronauts in every previous spacewalk, or extra-vehicular activity, had been attached to the spacecraft by a long cable. Captain McCandless and Colonel Stewart used 300-pound nitrogen-propelled backpacks known as manned maneuvering units to make their way through space. The men made two spacewalks during the mission, the second occurring on Feb. 9. The first lasted 5 hours 55 minutes and the second was 6 hours 17 minutes.

WASHINGTON -- Jack Abramoff hinted Monday that he knows of still more skeletons that are buried on Capitol Hill, but he's not saying where. The disgraced lobbyist said he wouldn't want to make anyone else go through the experience that he and his family suffered after he was imprisoned for three and a half years in one of the biggest political corruption scandals in modern times. ''I can't be the agent of causing someone to go to prison,'' he said during an appearance at the Washington offices of Public Citizen, a nonprofit government watchdog group.

At the grand opening of a Steak 'n Shake Signature in Midtown Manhattan last month, Sardar Biglari, the fast-food chain's chief executive, tried his best to look happy. Tall and well dressed, with slicked-back hair and a Chopard watch, Mr. Biglari seemed every bit the young Wall Street tycoon as he joined his employees in a ribbon-cutting cheer: ''Steak 'n Shake is great! Steak 'n Shake is great!'' It was something of a mood shift for Mr. Biglari, who just three weeks earlier had been defeated in one of the biggest battles of his short career. An upstart investor who has become known for knock-down, drag-out proxy fights, Mr. Biglari, 34, lost an election to the board of Cracker Barrel, the restaurant chain based in Tennessee. The ordeal involved searing letters, a contentious board election and no shortage of harsh words -- the same playbook he used to gain control of Steak 'n Shake in 2008.

DUNBAR--Dr. Frederick. The staff of NERA Economic Consulting mourn the passing of Dr. Frederick Dunbar, a brilliant economist and one of the giants of our firm. Fred was our colleague for 30 years, and he remained a friend to many of us after he joined the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2009. He was one of the architects of NERA's growth for many years, creating our Securities and Mass Torts Practices, providing groundbreaking economic analysis and testimony for clients, and mentoring many of those who went on to leadership positions in the firm. We will sorely miss his sharp intellect, his keen sense of humor, and his deep humanity. Our thoughts are with his friends and family, and especially his wife Helen Mangano. The Board of Directors NERA Economic Consulting

A group of Latin jazz musicians are planning to hold a concert in Los Angeles on the same night as the Grammy Awards to protest the decision that eliminated 31 categories from this year's awards, protest organizers announced Monday. The concert will follow an afternoon rally on Sunday to be held on a street corner outside the Staples Center, where pop music's royalty will be assembled for the flashy annual Grammys bash. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, the organization that controls the Grammy Awards, made a decision last year to consolidate more than a dozen categories and to eliminate other categories without consulting its rank and file members. Last April the academy slashed the categories from 109 to 78, eliminating separate trophies for male and female performers and getting rid of individual awards for genres like Latin jazz, Hawaiian music, zydeco, traditional blues and American Indian music. The cutbacks infuriated musicians from many of those genres that no longer have individual awards, especially Latin jazz artists. A few of those stars will appear at what they are calling the ''Not Those Awards All-Star Latin Jazz Jam'' on Sunday that will be held at the Mama Juana's nightclub. Ray Carrion and his Latin Jazz All Stars will head the bill, along with John Santos, Bobby Matos and Oscar Hernandez.

Stan's life's passion was his family and his love of this country. He was an ardent patriot and always believed in doing the right thing.

Verizon and Redbox have teamed up on a service intended to rival Netflix in allowing consumers to rent physical DVDs and stream movies via the Internet, the companies said Monday. Any broadband customer, even if are outside the Verizon FiOS network, will have access to the new service, said Paul Davis, chief executive of Coinstar Inc., the company that operates the Redbox self-service DVD rental locations.

DONNER--David, a sweet, gentle, Renaissance man of daunting intellect passed away peacefully at his home in Lake Worth, FL at the age of 97 after a long vital, vibrant, happy life. He was respected and loved by all who knew him. He was predeceased by his wife of 66 years, Sema Donner, and his nephew David Farber. He is survived by his daughter Deborah Donner Filocomo, and her husband, Peter, his son Barry Donner and grandchildren, Dr. Peter, Eli, Sarah, Daniel, Ezra and Hannah and great-grandchildren Chloe and Michael, nieces and nephew Laurie Farber, Robin Farber-Eger, Dr. Robert Farber and cherished companion Evelyn Silvert David was a proud veteran of World War II, landed at Omaha Beach 10 days after D-Day and was wounded at the Battle of St. Lo. David's favorite stories were about his experiences as a French interpreter during his war time service in France. He was passionate about bridge, opera, Shakespeare, public television, classical music, Evelyn and Scrabble, too. He owned and operated a fine men's haberdashery shop in Niagara Falls, NY until his retirement and move to Florida.

An editorial in some editions on Saturday about rising college tuition misstated the increase in federal student loan debt. It more than doubled in the past decade from $41 billion to $103 billion, not from $41 million to $103 million.

After 15 years, Deutsche Guggenheim, an outpost of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in the headquarters of Deutsche Bank in Berlin, is closing at the end of the year. The decision to end the partnership between the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and Deutsche Bank was announced in Berlin on Monday morning. Neither the bank nor the Guggenheim gave a concrete reason for the decision, saying only that their contract expires at the end of 2012.

The behind-the-scenes drama between Dominique Strauss-Kahn and his wife, Anne Sinclair, amid a notorious sex scandal - or, at least, a screenwriter's imagining of this drama - will be the subject of a new movie directed by Abel Ferrara, that filmmaker said, though his producer was less certain that this would be his next project. In an interview with the French newspaper Le Monde that ran over the weekend, Mr. Ferrara, the director of ''Bad Lieutenant'' and ''King of New York,'' seemed to confirm months of speculation, saying that he had cast Gerard Depardieu and Isabelle Adjani to play Mr. Strauss-Kahn and Ms. Sinclair in a film to be shot in New York, Washington and France. ''In all spots of power in fact: it's a film about rich and powerful people.'' Mr. Ferrara said, according to an English translation in The Guardian.

SAN FRANCISCO - Google, Facebook, Microsoft and Amazon already turn millions of computers into single clouds of supermachines, managing the flow between personal computers of cat videos, e-mails and the president's recent chat on Google Plus. Millions more of these computer servers figure out what to sell you while you browse the Web. These global systems work only because of something called virtualization, a kind of software that tricks one server into doing the tasks of several. The cost savings and flexibility revolutionized the data management business, since virtualized machines can run on cheap semiconductors.

Amar'e Stoudemire has taken an indefinite leave of absence from the Knicks after the death of his older brother in a traffic accident early Monday morning. His return date is uncertain. Stoudemire's brother Hazell, 35, was killed when his 2007 Cadillac Escalade collided with the rear of a tractor trailer on Highway 27 in Lake Wales, Fla., according to the Florida Highway Patrol. Stoudemire was driving ''at a high rate of speed'' and was trying to pass the tractor trailer, the accident report said. He was not wearing a seatbelt.

An article on Monday about efforts by members of Congress to insert money for favored projects into appropriations legislation misidentified the government position once held by John Paul Woodley Jr., who discussed the criteria for projects of the Army Corps of Engineers. He was assistant secretary of the Army for public works, not a Defense Department undersecretary.

It is one of the most convoluted arrangements in Washington for complying with campaign finance laws - and that is saying something. The four official party committees responsible for electing members to the House and Senate each raise tens of millions of dollars for advertising and other activities on behalf of candidates they have recruited and groomed. The heads of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, the National Republican Congressional Committee, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and the National Republican Senatorial Committee map out budgets and determine generally where their money would best be spent.

ISRAEL--Audrey nee Hollander, age 99, of Morristown, NJ, on February 3, 2012. She was born in New York City on April 24, 1912 to Ruth Rosenfield Hollander and Barnett Hollander, Esq. Her mother was an heiress of the Sunnybrook Distillery and her father practiced law in New York City, London and Paris. Mrs. Israel was educated at St. Hillaries School in Sussex, England and continued her studies in Florence, Rome, and at the Sorbonne in Paris. She was an accomplished portrait photographer. She was a lifelong volunteer including stints as a medical photographer at Cornell Medical School in the mid-1930's, a nurses aide during World War II in a military hospital, a Girl Scout photographer in Summit, NJ, a library volunteer and sorter for the VNA rummage sales in Far Hills, NJ. Besides strong love for her family, her passions included gardening, skiing and ice skating. She married Leon Israel, Jr. in 1935 who died in 1981. Mr. Israel was president of Leon Israel & Bros., a family owned green coffee import and export company and later was Chairman of the Board of ACLI International, a privately held commodities company. Mrs. Israel is survived by two daughters, Judith Heidkamp of Scottsdale, Arizona and Carol Allen of Baltimore, Maryland and six grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to Family Service of Morris County, 62 Elm Street, Morristown, NJ 07960. A service of remembrance will be held at Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street, Chatham, NJ on Saturday, April 7, 2012 at 11am.

The Walt Disney Company may join Univision, the dominant Spanish-language broadcaster in the United States, in starting an English-language cable news channel this year, people with knowledge of the talks between the companies said on Monday. These people described the talks as advanced, though no announcement appeared to be imminent. The Wall Street Journal first reported the talks on Monday.

One of the largest companies that provided home foreclosure services to lenders across the nation, DocX, has been indicted on forgery charges by a Missouri grand jury -- one of the few criminal actions to follow reports of widespread improprieties against homeowners. A grand jury in Boone County, Mo., handed up an indictment Friday accusing DocX of 136 counts of forgery in the preparation of documents used to evict financially strained borrowers from their homes. Lorraine O. Brown, the company's founder and former president, was indicted on the same charges.

6:10 P.M. (TMC) BOTTLE SHOCK (2008) A British wine dealer (Alan Rickman) trying to break into the French oenological establishment heads to the Napa Valley of California in the 1970s in pursuit of American vintages that can stand up to their more established rivals in a blind tasting. Bill Pullman, above with Rachael Taylor, is the San Francisco lawyer turned struggling vintner, fond of quoting Hemingway and intent on turning his bourgeois life into a Steinbeck novel, who just might have the stuff to do it. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this film from Randall Miller, based on a true story, ''an easygoing little movie, made with more affection than skill.'' Still, he added, '' 'Bottle Shock' is unable to figure out what kind of movie it wants to be, and flops around between madcap comedy and rousing drama. To borrow a wine-snob term of art, it lacks structure. Or, to push the idiom a little further, it's a little too sweet, with some pleasantly nutty notes and a baloney finish.'' 4:30 P.M. (HBO2) LOST IN TRANSLATION (2003) An American movie star (Bill Murray) cashing in on his celebrity to make an ad in Japan meets a young woman (Scarlett Johansson) who has been deserted by her husband (Giovanni Ribisi) in this comic melodrama written and directed by Sofia Coppola. As they escape the confines of the Tokyo Hyatt, something like love ensues. Mr. Murray ''supplies the kind of performance that seems so fully realized and effortless that it can easily be mistaken for not acting at all,'' Elvis Mitchell wrote in The Times. ''The corollary of this is that Ms. Coppola's direction is so breezily assured in its awareness of loneliness that the film could potentially be dismissed as self-consciously moody rather than registering as a mood piece. But it's bound to be recognized as a movie worthy of the kind of Oscar attention occasionally given to films that challenge audiences subtly.'' Mr. Murray received a best actor nomination; Ms. Coppola won for best original screenplay.

BERNARD--Harold, S. Ph.D.,ABPP, CGP, DLFAGPA, The American Group Psychotherapy Association, the Group Psychotherapy Foundation and the National Registry of Certified Group Psychotherapists Officers, Boards of Directors and Membership mourn the loss of Dr. Harold S. Bernard, who passed away on February 4, 2012 in Westport, CT. He was a Distinguished Life Fellow, AGPA Past President, Eastern Affiliate Past President and a prolific author and editor on group therapy. His compassionate leadership following the events of 9/11 made it possible for AGPA to help thousands of people affected by this tragedy and paved the way for AGPA to provide ongoing community services to those in need. He was a beloved teacher, mentor, supervisor and leader in the group psychotherapy community. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Bonnie Bernard, and his daughter and son, Nicole and Bradley. A memorial session to celebrate Dr. Bernard's life is planned for New York during the AGPA Annual Institute and Conference at the Sheraton New York Hotel on Friday, March 9th, 6:15-7:30pm. Dr. Bernard's passing is a major loss to our community.

ZINDER--Norton David, 83. Devoted husband for 54 years of the late Marilyn Zinder, father of Stephen and Michael, father in law of Chris and Charlotte, and doting grandfather of his "basketball team" Daniel, Ben, John, Adam, and Matt. Born November 7, 1928, a graduate of Bronx High School of Science (1944), Columbia University (1947), and University of Wisconsin (PhD, 1952) where with Joshua Lederberg he discovered that viruses can carry genes between cells, a fundamental genetic process called transduction. He then joined the Rockefeller University to which he devoted over 50 years of service. He was the John D. Rockefeller Jr. Professor of Genetics Emeritus and had served as Dean of Students for several years. He mentored many graduate students and postdocs and took great pride in their subsequent successes. He was a member of the National Academy of Sciences and taught at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, later serving on its Board of Directors. He played an important early role in establishing the NIH human genome project, and was an invited attendee at the 2000 White House ceremony celebrating the draft human genome sequence. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rockefeller University or the charity of your choice. Service at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, February 8, 11:45am, followed by interment at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ.

When it comes to moving people around in healthy ways, New York City already has a leg up on most cities and towns around the country. The city has sidewalks in all five boroughs; food stores and other shops are within walking distance of where most people live. It is served nearly everywhere by extensive, inexpensive and largely dependable public transportation. City children have long been able to walk, skate or scoot to school, though these days fewer attend schools in the neighborhood.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Sunday about Dr. Richard K. Olney, a pioneer in clinical research on Lou Gehrig's disease, misstated the date of his death. It was Friday, Jan. 27 -- not this past Friday, Feb. 3.

An article on Saturday about disputes between some Republican politicians and some pop musicians about the politicians' use of the musicians' songs in their campaigns misstated the title of a country music song by Lee Greenwood that has been used by some Republicans (without objection from Mr. Greenwood). It is ''God Bless the U.S.A.,'' not ''Proud to Be an American.'' (Those words are from the song's chorus.)

GLASS--Stuart M. 1934-2012, died suddenly at home on February 5. Stuart was born in Brooklyn, the son of Jerome Glass and Esther Glass, and grew up in Lawrence, Long Island. A graduate of Columbia College and Columbia Law School, Stuart practiced law for 30 years, initially as Special Legal Consultant to the Human Resources Agency (Office of the Mayor, City of New York), as Acting In-House Counsel for Columbia University, and then as a sole practitioner. In retirement, he matriculated in New York University's Archival Management and Historical Editing Program and was awarded an Archival Diploma. He specialized in archival projects that required legal expertise. Stuart used his dry wit, deadpan look, and deep appreciation of the human condition to entertain his many friends with endlessly hilarious stories of his life: of reserve military service, of his practice of law, and of his relations with family and friends. His death is an enormous loss. Stuart leaves behind a family that he adored and who adored him: his wife Beverly I. Katz; his daughter Rachel and her husband Lloyd; and two grandchildren, Ariana and Beatrice. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, February 8, 1:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St. Interment follows at Westchester Hills Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to: Congregation Rodeph Sholom, Partnership for Children's Rights (www.pfcr.org) or Chabad Lubavitch of the Upper East Side.

To walk 145th Street in South Jamaica, past red-brick homes with metal awnings and chain-link fences, is to find a storm of immense destructive power still raging. Three years ago, when I wandered this block south of Linden Boulevard in Queens, banks had foreclosed on eight homes. In the years since, banks have filed notice against a half-dozen more owners. Some of those homes sit abandoned, plywood boards nailed across doors and windows, as if to guard against further spread of this plague.

An article on Jan. 19 about a broad-based Web protest of Congressional proposals to rein in online piracy overstated the number of calls routed through Engine Advocacy, a service that helps people call their local members of Congress. While as many as 2,000 callers a second tried to use the service, demand was so heavy that only about 12 calls a second -- not all 2,000 -- were successful.

When ticking off the benefits of physical activity, few of us would include intracellular housecleaning. But a new study suggests that the ability of exercise to speed the removal of garbage from inside our body's cells may be one of its most valuable, if least visible, effects. In the new research, which was published last month in Nature, scientists at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas gathered two groups of mice. One set was normal, with a finely tuned cellular scrubbing system. The other had been bred to have a blunted cleaning system.

MELBOURNE -- The Australian Open, once the weakest of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments, now has two stadiums with retractable roofs and a third one on the way. Player response continues to be positive. ''Of the four Grand Slams, it is the tournament that behaves better toward the players,'' Rafael Nadal said after losing in the men's final last Monday.

JOHNSON--Charles J.,Jr., esteemed partner of the former Brown & Wood (now named Sidley Austin LLP) law firm in New York, and commanding presence in the securities bar before his retirement in 1988, passed away on February 2 at his home in Savannah, GA. He was 80. Mr. Johnson, in 1956, became recognized as one of the nation's preeminent securities lawyers and served as a leader of the firm for more than a decade. Admired by colleagues and clients alike for his warmth and approachability, Mr. Johnson was known for contributing greatly to the firm's growth, in particular, for cultivating its capital markets practice. He was the original author of the acclaimed guide, "Corporate Finance and the Securities Laws," which is an important reference source used by lawyers and bankers across the country. Mr. Johnson is survived by his wife of 58 years, Chris, as well as their two sons, Charles, of Scituate, MA, and Mark, of Burlington, VT, and four grandchildren. All of us who knew Mr. Johnson at Sidley Austin, as well as our clients, would like to extend to his family our appreciation for his tireless service, as well as our condolences for their loss. Mr. Johnson's contributions to the firm, as well as to the legal profession as a whole, are truly extraordinary. We will miss his kindness, wisdom and generosity of spirit. With deepest sympathies, His colleagues at Sidley Austin LLP

When Janet Holwell first joined Weight Watchers seven years ago, she lost 43 pounds in one year and considered the popular commercial weight-loss plan ''miraculous.'' ''I felt like I had found the magic key, the secret that eluded me all of these years,'' said Ms. Holwell, who has maintained most of her weight loss by continuing to adhere to the program.

''The Intouchables,'' the comedy-drama by Olivier Nakache and Eric Toledano that has become one of the most successful films ever at the French box office, will open the 17th edition of Rendez-Vous with French Cinema, the annual program presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and Unifrance Films, it was announced on Monday. This year's program will begin on March 1 at Alice Tully Hall, its press representatives said, with a showing of ''The Intouchables,'' which stars Francois Cluzet as a paralyzed millionaire who forges an unlikely friendship with the Senegalese parolee (Omar Sy) he hired to take care of him. Mr. Nakache, Mr. Toledano and Mr. Cluzet will attend this screening of the film, which the Weinstein Company plans to release in the United States in May.

A music review on Monday about a concert by the Prism Quartet and Music From China, at Weill Recital Hall in Manhattan, referred incorrectly at one point to the composer Lei Liang, whose piece ''Messages of White'' was played. His surname is Liang; he is not ''Mr. Lei.'' The review also misstated the title of a work by Huang Ruo that was performed. It is ''Three Tenses,'' not ''Five Tenses.''

Mr. Fischer made that recording with his own group, not as a sideman with the vibraphonist Cal Tjader.

On the first page of Facebook's prospectus for its sale of stock to the public, it pegs the number of its ''monthly active users'' at a whopping 845 million people. The social networking site arrives at an even more astounding number when it comes to ''daily active users'': 483 million people. Those are some huge numbers. If it is hard to believe that so many people are clicking on facebook.com every day, that's because well, they aren't, exactly. Those eye-popping numbers should have an asterisk next to them.

Yes, it's true that Dwight D. Eisenhower referred to himself as ''a barefoot boy'' in 1945 when he returned home victorious to Abilene, Kan., after World War II. And it was in that image that the architect Frank Gehry found inspiration for the design of the official memorial to Eisenhower for which groundbreaking is expected this year on the Washington Mall. The design shows Eisenhower as a youth gazing out at images of his adult accomplishments against a backdrop of the Kansas plains. But the Eisenhower family objects to the design and is attempting to delay approval of the project in a dispute that has pitted a leading American family against one of the country's most recognized architects. The family says Mr. Gehry should portray Eisenhower as a man in the fullness of his achievements, not as a callow rustic who made good.

President Obama held Silvio Berlusconi at arm's length for three years, treating Italy's flamboyant prime minister - he of the bunga bunga parties and the well-parsed sexual exploits - with a somewhat frozen correctness. The new prime minister, Mario Monti, a sudden darling of the international stage, is widely seen as a tough economist and a staid European bureaucrat with no apparent skeletons in the closet. Signore Monti is now getting the full-court press in Washington, and the hottest ticket in town this week is a dinner with him at the glittering Villa Firenze, home to the Italian ambassador. In my old neighborhood in a patch at the north end of Spokane, Washington, not only was John F. Kennedy a saint, but the family from which he came was viewed as the norm - that is, a brood of nine or more kids, each a year or so apart. Birth control in the mid-1960s was the rhythm method, and its failed efficacy was evident in the size of the clans. "The I-got-rhythm method," my dad called it.

MALE, Maldives - "Dictatorships don't always die when the dictator leaves office," writes Mohamed Nasheed, the leader of the Maldives who was deposed on Tuesday. "The wave of revolutions that toppled autocrats in Tunisia, Egypt, Libya and Yemen last year was certainly cause for hope. But the people of those countries should be aware that, long after the revolutions, powerful networks of regime loyalists can remain behind and can attempt to strangle their nascent democracies. I learned this lesson quickly." Read Mr. Nasheed's full article in IHT Global Opinion and see a video of his story»

One of the most popular and highly regarded television dramas of the past decade, the medical series "House," will come to an end this season, the show's producers and the Fox network announced Wednesday. The decision was cast as the choice of the producers. In a statement, they said, "The producers have always imagined House as an enigmatic creature; he should never be the last one to leave the party. How much better to disappear before the music stops, while there is still some promise and mystique in the air." Read more »

Kiplinger magazine said Wednesday that falsified data on test scores from Claremont McKenna College had not affected the school's rank of 18th on its list of 100 private colleges with the best value. Still, the magazine said it would not reinstate the school to its 2012 rankings.

KABUL, Afghanistan - Inside the family hut, only women and close male relatives were allowed to mourn over the body of the baby boy, Khan Mohammad, who had died earlier that morning. After Andrea Bruce, on assignment for The New York Times, bent over double and eased her way through the low door of the hut, she counted 17 women, including the mother, plus the boy's 10-year-old sister Feroza, and the father, in a one-room house no larger than a normal-size bedroom. It was, she said, even colder inside than outside, where at least there was the weak morning sun.

Procter & Gamble said on Wednesday that it could be forced to re-evaluate the sale of its well-known Pringles brand to Diamond Foods, just hours after Diamond Foods announced that it would have to restate two years of financial earnings amid questionable accounting practices.

A New Mega-Premiere: A week after Madonna blanketed the world with her new song "Gimme All Your Luvin'," MTV is preparing a global, multiplatform unveiling of Taylor Swift's video "Safe & Sound." On Monday at 7:54 p.m., the song, from the film "The Hunger Games," will be shown on MTV's channels around the world, and Ms. Swift will sit for a 30-minute interview with MTV News. At 8 p.m. the video will run on CMT (like MTV, owned by Viacom) and MTV's network of 300 Web outlets around the world. The couture shows end, and the ordering begins for Beatrice Pang, Indré Rockefeller and Henri Deshays, who met at Stanford Business School and recently introduced the new e-commerce site modewalk.com. The concept: make haute couture and Paris ready-to-wear accessible to anyone. Can't make it to Paris? ModeWalk's local couturiers make house calls for measurements. Pricing is all upon request.

Washed in a super dry matte black or blue, the denim - milled by Cone, if you care - is all made from recycled or sustainable cotton, polyester and yarn in Raleigh's factory in North Carolina. "Certain things can make you really happy - a good vanilla cupcake is one. A fun pair of jeans rolled up to the knee is another," Patrick says. Here, the Hip jean paired with a vegetable-dyed wool anorak, quilted vest and shrunken white shirt, which was our second favorite look from the show. Our first? It's true that fashion, by definition, exists in a constant state of flux. But the clothes, not the heads of storied houses, are typically what one expects to change from season to season. In 2011, a dozen big American and European brands ushered in new creative directors - including Olivier Rousteing, who took over at Balmain after Christophe Decarnin's sudden departure; Clare Waight Keller, who was at Pringle of Scotland before Chloé, and Alistair Carr who stepped in to fill her shoes. In perhaps the most surprising move, Opening Ceremony's Humberto Leon and Carol Lim were asked to reinvigorate Kenzo. These designers, and 11 others, will be introducing closely watched debut or sophomore collections during the coming show season, which begins Thursday in New York and ends in Paris on March 7. A sculptural screen of 800 floating metal panels by the artist Harry Bertoia will be returned to its home at 510 Fifth Avenue as part of a legal settlement that was made public on Wednesday. The settlement is a result of a lawsuit filed by preservationists in July accusing the building's owner, Vornado Realty Trust -- abetted by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission - of disregarding restrictions intended to protect the interior. The settlement also provides that the landmarks commission expand its designation of the interior to include a black granite wall that is part of the former vault space.

In a way, Rick Santorum's surprising Missouri-Minnesota-Colorado sweep last night is a lot like Newt Gingrich's win in South Carolina: A victory that reminds us all, once again, that Mitt Romney is a strikingly weak frontrunner, without changing the fact that Romney has a clear path to the nomination and his rivals really don't. The difference, though, is that Santorum is a stronger anti-Romney candidate than the combustible and compromised Gingrich, with wider geographic appeal (as he demonstrated last night) and fewer glaring liabilities. So whereas Romney was able to dispose of Gingrich pretty easily during the brief window where the race seemed to be down to a two-man race between them, if he gets into a two-man race with Santorum he's probably facing a much longer and more grueling contest.

For such a little building, the Lieb House has a notorious history. Designed by the Philadelphia architecture firm of Venturi & Rauch (now Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates) for Nathaniel and Judith Lieb and completed in 1969 in Barnegat Light, N.J., the house - a two-toned, asbestos-shingled box with a giant, Pop Art-influenced number 9 on the front and a huge crescent window on one side - caused outrage even in a neighborhood where clotheslines and telephone poles were essential parts of the landscape. Its living room and kitchen were on the second floor, to take advantage of the views, and its four small bedrooms were tucked into the first floor, where a washer and dryer greeted visitors, glorifying the daily chore of laundering bathing suits and beach towels. Robert Venturi referred to the house as a "banal box," but then he considered this a compliment. Venturi and his associates, including his wife and business partner, the urban planner Denise Scott Brown, have made a career out of celebrating the ordinary, in numerous buildings as well as in the books "Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture" and "Learning From Las Vegas." Scott Brown said of the house's surroundings, "We enjoyed the concrete Madonnas, and understood the dunes." But apparently the architects' approach proved unpopular with the neighbors, one of whom stopped speaking to the Liebs after the house was finished.

Rick Santorum's victories on Tuesday represent his first breakout moments in the Republican presidential contest since he belatedly scraped to the top in Iowa more than a month ago. They certainly give him bragging rights. They will probably earn him a second look from voters who had once dismissed him. They may help him raise money. Down the road, they will add to his delegate count.

Nothing has spawned more discussion since the Giants' Super Bowl victory than the debate over whether it was wise for Ahmad Bradshaw to score the go-ahead touchdown with 57 seconds remaining to give the Giants a four-point lead. As usual, our readers lifted the level of discussion to new and sometimes amusing heights, to the tune of more than 350 comments. Plenty of commenters believed Bradshaw's score was the best move, even as quarterback Eli Manning was yelling at him not to. Others believed running the clock down and kicking a field goal was the way to go. Others took sides on the Patriots' decision to allow Bradshaw to score. In all, it made for a lively discussion.

FLORENCE, Italy -- A judge in Florence continued on Tuesday the house arrest of Francesco Schettino, the captain of the luxury liner that ran aground off the Tuscan coast on Jan. 13, leaving 17 people dead and 15 still unaccounted for. Amid a highly heated public debate in Italy about the shipwreck of the liner, the Costa Concordia, a Florence appeals court rejected both the prosecutors' request to imprison the captain and the request of Captain Schettino's lawyer to have him released.

Some 14 years ago in Paris, a shop specializing in sushi opened for takeout and delivery in the posh 16th Arrondissement. It was not a restaurant. ''Sushi was not so well known in France then, and we also wanted to add our creativity to what the Japanese were doing traditionally,'' said Gregory Marciano, the president of the company, which now has 90 shops and restaurants in Europe. On Saturday it will open its first Sushi Shop in New York, in partnership with Bruno Calvo. The two-story space in Midtown Manhattan, done up in the company's signature neutral tones and black accents, will be for self-service and takeout, with restaurant dining in the evening.

8:02 p.m. | Updated LONDON - Glencore International, the largest commodities trading company in the world, said on Tuesday that it would buy the remaining stake in the mining company Xstrata that it did not already own, in a long-anticipated deal that would create a mining giant with a market value of nearly $90 billion.

LONDON -- Glencore International, the largest commodities trading company in the world, said on Tuesday that it would buy the remaining stake in the mining company Xstrata that it did not already own, in a long-anticipated deal that would create a mining giant with a market value of nearly $90 billion. As commodity prices have soared, the mining industry has quickly consolidated, with leading players looking to capitalize on the rising demand in developing countries like China. In 2011, mining companies announced $168.6 billion of acquisitions, a 26 percent increase over the previous year, according to data from Dealogic.

Georgetown Cupcake, a Washington fixture with a branch in Maryland, is opening a store in SoHo on Saturday. For its Manhattan debut, its regular cupcakes, topped with a generous swirl of icing, will sport local images like subway logos and the Brooklyn Bridge. And some new flavors have been created just for New York: a black-and-white-iced marble cake, an apple-flavored cupcake and a cheesecake version topped with a yellow taxi. Georgetown Cupcake, 111 Mercer Street (Prince Street); (212) 431-4504; georgetowncupcake.com. Cupcakes are $2.75 each, $15 for six and $29 for a dozen. Internet orders are available for shipping or pickup in the store.

A picture on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about a dispute over a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower planned for the Washington Mall was published in error. It showed an older version of the concept for the memorial, not the most recent one. That image can be seen with the article at nytimes.com/arts. And the article referred incompletely to the approval process of the memorial by the United States Commission of Fine Arts. While the commission has approved the memorial's general concept and overall configuration, it has not yet reviewed the central elements of the proposed memorial, including the statue of Eisenhower as a youth, and it has not given final approval to the design as a whole.

An article on Saturday about conservative activists who battle efforts to control sprawl and conserve energy misidentified an entity that ceased paying dues to Iclei, a nonprofit organization that offers advice on environmental sustainability, and withdrew from a national program related to dealing with climate change. It was Albemarle County in Virginia -- not the Thomas Jefferson Planning District Commission in Charlottesville, Va. The article also described the planning commission incorrectly. It involves climate change efforts by counties, not by mayors.

After 11 months of performances on Broadway, ''The Book of Mormon'' reached a milestone last week in its extraordinary box office success fueled by premium ticket pricing: The musical beat the long-running blockbusters ''Wicked'' and ''The Lion King'' to become the top-grossing show in a single week for the first time, even though ''Mormon'' had hundreds of fewer seats to sell to each performance than those two other commercial hits. According to weekly box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League, ''Mormon'' grossed $1,455,329, compared to $1,349,433 for ''Wicked'' and $1,226,681 for ''The Lion King.'' (''The Lion King''actually ranked fourth behind ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' which, like ''Mormon,'' is a relatively new hit that opened on Broadway in 2011; ''Spider-Man'' grossed $1,268,002 last week.)

8:13 p.m. | Updated UBS, the largest Swiss bank, said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit had slumped 76 percent from a year earlier, as money entering its wealth management unit did not make up for a loss in investment banking.

BAGHDAD -- Less than two months after American troops left, the State Department is preparing to slash by as much as half the enormous diplomatic presence it had planned for Iraq, a sharp sign of declining American influence in the country. Officials in Baghdad and Washington said that Ambassador James F. Jeffrey and other senior State Department officials were reconsidering the size and scope of the embassy, where the staff has swelled to nearly 16,000 people, mostly contractors.

John Christopher, a prolific British science fiction writer whose ''Tripods'' trilogy became a perennial favorite among young American readers and inspired a popular BBC television series shown on PBS in the 1980s, died on Friday at his home in Bath, England. He was 89. The cause was complications of bladder cancer, his daughter, Rose Youd, said.

The starting lineups for Tuesday night's game at Madison Square Garden included the fourth-line tough guys Cam Janssen and Eric Boulton for the Devils and Mike Rupp and Brandon Prust for the Rangers, who had 104 career goals and 3,215 penalty minutes among them. As if choreographed, the four dropped their gloves within two seconds, Janssen facing Rupp, Boulton taking on Prust. The pairs pounded each other for a while, clearing the way for the Devils to post a taut 1-0 victory behind goaltender Martin Brodeur.

There appears to be a light at the end of the tunnel in Seattle for the Intiman Theater, which in recent years has provided a launching pad for popular stage productions like ''Light in the Piazza.'' It will remain open after meeting a $1 million fund-raising goal in just a few months, The Seattle Times reported. The theater has been under financial duress for a year. Last February it announced that it needed to raise $500,000 in a matter of weeks and another $250,000 by June and also in September to cover unpaid bills and unreported cost overruns and close other gaps. In April the rest of its 2011 season was canceled, the staff was laid off, and Kate Whoriskey left her post as the theater's artistic director. But as of Monday the Intiman had raised $1,026,263 in pledges since announcing a do-or-die fund-raising campaign in November, the theater's board president, Terry Jones, told The Seattle Times. Under the leadership of a new artistic director, Andrew Russell, the theater is planning a four-play festival in July and August that will feature productions of ''Hedda Gabler,'' ''Romeo and Juliet'' and two other works, to be performed by a 12-person repertory cast.

Richard J. Holwell, the federal judge in Manhattan who presided over the insider trading case of the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam, is stepping down from the bench to set up his own law firm. In an interview, Judge Holwell said that he was resigning effective 5 p.m. on Tuesday, and that he would start his new firm -- Holwell Shuster & Goldberg -- at 6 p.m. He said he has spent the past two weeks working into the night getting out opinions and working on sentencings that he felt obliged to hand down before his departure.

In 2002, at the height of the outcry over the sexual abuse of minors by Roman Catholic priests, the Archbishop of New York, Edward M. Egan, issued a letter to be read at Mass. In it, he offered an apology about the church's handling of sex-abuse cases in New York and in Bridgeport, Conn., where he was previously posted. ''It is clear that today we have a much better understanding of this problem,'' he wrote. ''If in hindsight we also discover that mistakes may have been made as regards prompt removal of priests and assistance to victims, I am deeply sorry.''

SARGENT--John T. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of John T. Sargent. John was a Life Trustee and a greatly devoted advocate for the Library. He joined the Library's Board of Trustees in 1972 and was an active member for many years, chairing our Nominating Committee and serving on our Executive Committee, as well as committees on exhibitions, capital projects, fundraising, and other vital activities. We offer our deep sympathies to John's family and friends. Neil Rudenstine, Chairman Anthony W. Marx, President Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti

The Consumer report on Tuesday, about criticism of changes to the Weight Watchers weight-loss program, described the government's recommendation for daily produce consumption incorrectly. The five to nine servings that people are advised to eat daily involves fruit and vegetables, not just fruit.

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about the effect on federal revenue of a popular investment tax credit for businesses misspelled part of the name of an Omaha company that took advantage of the break. As the article correctly noted, it is Werner Enterprises -- not Warner Enterprises.
CANEVARI--Peter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Peter Canevari., associated with The New York Times from July 1, 1973 until retiring on August 1, 2000.

PRATEL--Joan Francis Davidson, of Manhattan and a long time summer resident of Nantucket Island, died at New York City's Lenox Hill Hospital, just one year ago today (02/08/2011). The cause of death was a stroke due to MRSA. She was 87. An avid collector of Canton and of early American as well as English silver, Joan also had a passion for Yorkshire terriers, art, travel, and social interaction. Fittingly, her favorite author was Jane Austin; her favorite membership, belonging to Nantucket's Wharf Rat Club. The daughter of Alice and Louis S. Davidson Sr. and widow of Richard Pratel, Joan was a loyal and loving daughter, wife, sister, and aunt, survived by her brother, Louis Davidson Jr., and her niece, Rebecca Davidson Packer. We will much miss her splendid memory for family as well as historical anecdotes so reflective of her delight in life at large. Donations may be made to research funds seeking a cure for glaucoma (www.glaucoma-foundation.org/donations) and/or macular degeneration (www.eyesight.org/donations). For Joan the world was a visual cornucopia, one that she could barely see during her last years but nevertheless, one to which she was never blind.

An article on Tuesday about indictments on forgery charges of the loan processing firm DocX and its founder and former president, Lorraine O. Brown, misstated the given name for the lawyer representing the company. He is Scott Rosenblum, not Chris. (The lawyer defending Ms. Brown is Chris Rosenbloom.)

LONG before social media transformed the way Super Bowl commercials were evaluated, USA Today assembled focus groups each year that judged the advertising hits and flops. The results of the USA Today Super Bowl Ad Meter panels, introduced in 1989, became closely watched scorecards that influenced how spots in the game were created. How influential did the Ad Meter become? A Super Bowl advertiser, CareerBuilder, that fared well in the Ad Meter in 2006 placed its account in review when its commercials failed to make the top 10 in the Ad Meter a year later.

Not even Kim Kardashian's 72-day now-you-see-it-now-you-don't marriage to Kris Humphries was enough to reverse the slumping sales of celebrity magazines in the second half of 2011. Single-copy sales of consumer magazines, especially many women's and celebrity publications, dropped 9.96 percent, to 28.9 million from 32.1 million, compared with the second half of 2010, according to a report released Tuesday by the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
