(USA) NFL CHARACTERS UNITE Tony Gonzalez of the Atlanta Falcons, Jimmy Graham of the New Orleans Saints, Hines Ward of the Pittsburgh Steelers (above right, with Carlton Dennis, a student) and Tony Dungy, a former head coach for the Indianapolis Colts and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, discuss the hate and bigotry they overcame as children to find success in pro football. This documentary also follows the men as they work with teenagers mired in similar situations. 1 P.M. (BET) AMERICAN VIOLET (2009) Nicole Beharie is Dee Roberts, a young African-American mother of four who is charged with distributing narcotics in a school zone in her small Texas town and risks going to trial instead of accepting a plea bargain for a crime she insists she didn't commit. Xzibit plays the father of her two youngest children; his desire for custody may be at the root of Dee's predicament. Michael O'Keefe is the local district attorney who is sued for racial discrimination by an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer (Tim Blake Nelson) on Dee's behalf. And Alfre Woodard is her mother. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that this film from Tim Disney, based on real events in 2000, is ''beautifully acted by Ms. Beharie, whose high-strung character is no angel.'' The film was selected as a New York Times Critics' Pick.

The Academy seems to have telegraphed its feelings about musical nominees pretty strongly by picking only two songs this year: ''Man or Muppet,'' by the Bagger's pal Bret McKenzie, and ''Real in Rio,'' by Carlinhos Brown, Siedah Garrett and Sergio Mendes, who got a warm reception at the Oscar luncheon. Now, in an effort to speed up the show, it has apparently decided not to have either of those songs performed live at the telecast -- a repeat of years past. But when news of the song barricade got out, fans of ''The Muppets,'' led by Judd Apatow, got riled up. Mr. Apatow took to Twitter on Tuesday afternoon to advocate for some felt-and-fur singing on the show:

OVERHOLSER--Genevieve, 49, died of a brain aneurysm on February 8. Born in Manhattan, she attended Spence School, Kent, Trinity, Northwestern, RISD and Brown University. Genevieve had a 25 year career in luxury brands including Bottega Veneta, Fendi and Judith Ripka. Genevieve is survived by her parents Annie and Winfred Overholser, sister Octavia, brother Adrian and nephews: Winfred, Garret, Trevor, Brett, and Kenzo. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest on Saturday February 11 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Alzheimer's Foundation.
HERMAN--Bruce. We send our deep sympathy and love to our girl Jennifer and to Lukey, Tay and Carter. The Jarkow, Usdan/Podgainy and Wertheim Families

PARIS -- For all the struggles that Greece has gone through to satisfy its demanding lenders, Europe's troubles are not going away. Because of the various, often incremental, steps European officials have taken during the nearly three-year debt difficulties that began in Greece, the crisis fever has cooled considerably in recent months -- including fears that the euro currency union might suddenly fall apart.

DECISION DELAYED Shareholders hoping to stop the El Paso Corporation's $21.1 billion sale to Kinder Morgan may have to wait awhile. Leo E. Strine Jr., below, the chief chancellor of Delaware's Court of Chancery, said at a hearing on Thursday that he planned to rule on the plaintiffs' request by March 6, when shareholders were scheduled to vote on the deal.

Three musical touchstones that have probably never been associated with President Obama are country, ''raw choral pop'' and REO Speedwagon. Yet those are three of the revelations of a Spotify playlist created by the president's campaign staff, released via a Twitter message Thursday morning. Some of the 28 songs on the list predictably follow the president's tastes, like Al Green's classic ''Let's Stay Together,'' a few seconds of which he sang at a fund-raising event at the Apollo Theater last month. (His 10-second excerpt helped the download sales of Mr. Green's original version jump 490 percent in a week.) Also present are Aretha Franklin (her cover of ''The Weight'' by the Band), the latest single from Bruce Springsteen (''We Take Care of Our Own'') and the Impressions' classic soul number ''Keep on Pushing.''

MARCUS--Stuart, poet, artist and book collector, 57, died suddenly on February 8, 2012. Beloved son of Richard and Helen Marcus and cherished brother of Gwen Marcus and Nancy Alpert. Services on Sunday, February 12th at 12:30pm at Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.
LONDON - At noon on Thursday, less than a day after parting with the England team manager, the Football Association chairman, David Bernstein, faced the news media. He spoke in measured tones.

Mitt Romney began Thursday with a new offensive to link Newt Gingrich and a resurgent Rick Santorum to the Washington establishment. But he will end the day raising hundreds of thousands of dollars from the very same Beltway establishment. At 5 p.m., Mr. Romney will attend an elaborate fund-raiser billed as a ''policy round table'' on issues like education and health care, led by members of his campaign staff and kitchen cabinet, including his policy director, Lanhee Chen, and the former senator Jim Talent, who helps lead the lobbying firm Mercury Public Affairs.

Here are the results of our highly nonscientific and open-ended poll about musicians, dancers and other performers on subway trains, to which well over 100 of you responded. Of those who approved of having performers in the subway system at all (and a majority of the respondents did), 55 percent give money to performers on trains, and 45 percent never do, believing them to be a pox upon the commute. (It should be noted that busking on trains is illegal.) And below are some of the more trenchant comments -- from haters, lovers and even the odd musician.

1:42 p.m. | Updated with more details of who will benefit from the settlement. The big $26 billion mortgage settlement announced Thursday is complex. But it is clear that it will probably be months before individual homeowners know if they'll benefit -- and if so, what they'll need to do.

8:18 p.m. | Updated | The struggling Fox Business Network canceled its entire prime-time programming lineup in one stroke on Thursday. In place of the political talk shows that are currently shown from 8 to 11 p.m., Fox Business will replay its programming shown from 5 to 8 p.m., giving more exposure to three of its best-known anchors.
ESBIN--Jerry. Happy Birthday, Jerry. With Love; All of your crown jewels are shining brightly ...Judy

An article on Thursday about a downward trend in younger Americans' television-watching time misstated in some copies the given name of the wife of Zach Dulli, who commented on his sons' affinity for laptops and cellphones, and gave the wrong age for one of his sons. His wife is Stephanie, not Minky, and his son Huck is 8 months old, not 11 months old. The article also misstated the age of Jay Rishel, who commented on his son's TV-watching habits. Mr. Rishel is 31, not 41.

The Mets' owners have asked the Supreme Court for help in their legal battle to prove they did not turn a blind eye to indications that Bernard L. Madoff had been running a fraud over more than two decades. Last Friday, the owners, Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, asked that the Supreme Court review a lower court ruling that established a formula for what they would owe if they lose their case against the trustee for Madoff's victims.

A music review on Wednesday about the Music of Now Marathon, at Symphony Space in Manhattan, misidentified the curator of the event, which was the opening program in the Composers Now Festival. It was organized by Laura Kaminsky, the artistic director of Symphony Space, not the composer Tania León, who spoke during the marathon and is the artistic director of the festival.

HUTCHINS--Waldo, III, died peacefully on February 7, age 83. Born in New York, NY January 14, 1929, he grew up in Glen Cove, NY, attended the Greenvale School, Deerfield Academy and received his B.A. from Yale University in 1951. After serving in the United States Army during the Korean War, he received his L.L.B. from Columbia University in 1957. He was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1958 and joined the law firm of Sprague, Dwyer, Aspland & Tobin in Mineola, N.Y. where he practiced Estate and Probate Law. He retired from Humes & Wagner, LLP in Locust Valley. He served the villages of Mill Neck and Upper Brookville in various capacities for many years. He is survived by his children John, Fred, Elizabeth and Anne, by his stepchildren John Devendorf, Andree Welsh and Marcia Morrell and his nine grandchildren. His wives Joan (Adams) and Carol (Devendorf) predeceased him. He had a passion for bonsai, Americana and stride piano. He loved his roses and the Adirondacks, where he finished his "46" at the age of 63. His kindness, generosity and sense of fairness will be missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, Tuesday, February 21 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Adirondack Trail Improvement Society, Box 565, Keene Valley, NY 12943 or www.atis-web.com.

Josh Lewin will be introduced soon as the Mets' new radio announcer on WFAN, replacing Wayne Hagin, who had a four-year run as Howie Rose's partner. Hagin replaced Tom McCarthy in 2008. Lewin was a Texas Rangers TV announcer from 2002 to 2010, when his contract was not renewed. He has also called games for the Tigers, the Cubs, the Orioles and Fox Sports. He is a co-host of a sports-talk radio show in Dallas and is the San Diego Chargers' radio play-by-play announcer.

''Stick Fly,'' the Broadway play about an emotionally stormy weekend at the vacation home of an African-American family, will close on Feb. 26 after 24 preview performances and 92 regular performances over about three months , the producers announced on Thursday. The play, by Lydia R. Diamond, will end its run at the Cort Theater at a financial loss for the play's producers, who include the pop-R&B singer Alicia Keys (she also composed music for the show). Ticket sales were modest throughout the run of ''Stick Fly,'' which opened on Dec. 8 to mixed reviews from critics; the production has grossed a total of $3.25 million. The capitalization for mounting the show had not been disclosed; most Broadway plays cost between $2 million and $3 million, plus weekly operating expenses. Philip J. Smith, the chairman of the Shubert Organization, which owns the Cort Theater, said that he expected another show to open at the theater before April 26, the cut-off date for eligibility for the 2012 Tony Awards. ''Stick Fly'' is directed by Kenny Leon (''Fences'') and stars Dule Hill, Mekhi Phifer, Tracie Thoms, Ruben Santiago-Hudson, Rosie Benton, and Condola Rashad, whose performance has been singled out for praise by many critics. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

At a time when it seems that everyone and his brother has a show or podcast about comedians, Sirius XM believes it has found a new wrinkle on the format: a program hosted by Kelly Carlin, the daughter of the famous stand-up George Carlin. On Thursday the satellite radio broadcaster is expected to announce that it will carry ''The Kelly Carlin Show,'' a new monthly program on which Ms. Carlin will speak with comedy personalities about their work and their lives. The first installment, scheduled for Sunday, will feature an interview with Robin Williams and will be heard on Sirius XM's Raw Dog Comedy channel as well as a new channel, Carlin's Corner, that will focus on George Carlin's performances and material.
5:39 p.m. | Updated The drought of deal-making that afflicted 2011 made times a bit tougher for Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, although the private equity giant expects better times ahead.

SOLOMON--Larry, 59, of Trumbull, CT, beloved husband of Barbara, father of Joshua and Zachary, died suddenly on February 5, 2012. Services on Friday, February 10 at 4pm in the Abriola Parkview Funeral Home, 419 White Plains Rd., Trumbull, CT. Visitation: Friday from 11am to 4pm. For details visit: www.abriola.com

MACOMBER--Caroline Morgan, died peacefully in her sleep at home on January 27, 2012 after a sudden illness. She grew up in New York City and attended Chapin, Miss Porter's School and Bryn Mawr College (A.B. cum laude). She and her husband, John, were married in 1955 and have three children: Janet Morgan Macomber Williamson, Elizabeth Currie Macomber and William Butts Macomber II. There are six grandchildren. Her family was always her first priority. She was a wonderful mentor and a very wise counselor to all generations. Her grace and kindness were gifts to everyone who knew her. She was also involved in a variety of educational, cultural and conservation activities primarily in Washington and New York. Most recently these included the Boards of The Phillips Collection in Washington, the Pierpont Morgan Library in New York and the North Haven Conservation Partners in Maine. Former board memberships included the American Museum of Natural History of New York, Miss Porter's School (Chair), Wesleyan University, Union Theological, St. James Church (Senior Warden), Ocean Conservancy and Maine Coast Heritage Trust. She served with great distinction and enormous effectiveness and her contributions to each were long lasting and valued by her fellow trustees. She was truly an accomplished woman. For example, her water colors were much sought after but in her modest way she rarely, if ever, signed them. Her creative gardening skill is shown in the unusually imaginative and colorful gardens she created in Sheep Meadow, the family's summer retreat in North Haven, Maine. And she was never happier than when she was sailing her beloved sailboat, the Allouette in the waters of Maine. A Memorial Service will be planned later this spring at St. James Church in New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to The Morgan Library in New York or The Phillips Collection in Washington.

DRATT--Beatrice, on February 8, 2012. Born April 28, 1922, she was a long time resident of Riverdale and former Assistant to the Vice President of Nursing at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Beloved wife of the late Charles Dratt for 65 years. She is survived by her sisters Estelle Tuchman and Marilyn Buchman and their husbands Eli and Sid, her children Jude, Sherry and Arnie, her grandchildren Tara, Jessica and Andy, and her great grandchildren, Jolie, Jacob, Noah, Alexa and Oliver. Daughter of the late Sam and Ida Weisman and sister of the late Charlotte Lew, her immediate and extended family was the center of her life. Services Friday 11:00am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Hebrew Home for the Aged Development Office, 5901 Palisade Avenue, Bronx, NY 10463.

Famous backing bands are finally getting some respect from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum in Cleveland. At this year's ceremony on April 14 the hall plans to induct six early bands whose leaders are already in: the Blue Caps, the Comets, the Crickets, the Famous Flames, the Midnighters and the Miracles. Joel Peresman, president of the foundation that runs the hall, said the idea of honoring these groups had been discussed for years among people on the 40-member nomination and induction committee, which includes musicians, critics and music industry executives. ''It's been bubbling,'' he said. ''We just figured it was time to make it right.''

The Securities and Exchange Commission has reached a settlement with two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers that will avert a second trial over accusations that they had misled investors as the mortgage market was crumbling. The deal, which is subject to court approval, could be announced on Monday, said two people with direct knowledge of the matter, who requested anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss it publicly.

SCARANGELLO--Doris Krause, of Yonkers, died on February 9, 2012 at age 87. Born on January 12, 1925 to Harry and Caroline (Sprower) Krause. Predeceased by Frank in 2003 and her first husband Arthur McNevin. Survived by her four children; Douglas McNevin; Bonnie Carson; Bruce McNevin and Scott McNevin, their spouses Barbara, Victor, Andrew, Joan and Maryvonne. Also six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Her extended family Thomas Scarangello, Roxanne Donovan, Mary Anne Tighe and Dr. David Hidalgo. Visiting Hours at Whalen and Ball Funeral Home on Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Interment Cypress Hill Cemetery on Saturday, February 11th, at 11am.

If you can't beat them, join them. That seems to be the mind-set of Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, who displayed his sense of humor Thursday when he posted a pair of well-crafted jibes on his Twitter account satirizing the growing hoopla around the organization's shaky finances.

Citigroup's effort to become ''the world's digital bank'' has encountered a snag. A technical bug caused Citi, the nation's fourth largest bank by deposits, to double the charge for customer payments in recent months. Some customers using their iPads to settle their cable bill or mortgage payment, for example, actually paid twice, according to customers and a bank official.

Late last week, in a shadowy Manhattan boardroom, 16 deal makers gathered to lay the groundwork for multibillion-dollar deals that would move the markets - if only they were real. At the first Wall Street Training Valuation Case Competition, aspiring moguls turned synergies into sport, in a deal simulation contest that was equal parts ''American Idol'' and ''Glengarry Glen Ross.''

BERGER--Charlotte, 92, of Kings Point, L.I. and Lauderhill, FL on February 9. Survived by daughter Barbara Seiden, grandchildren, Jenna, Lee, Jennifer, and Wendy; great-grandchildren Arianna, Jordyn, Bennett and Bryce. Donations to Phelan McDermid Foundation (941)485-8000.

The Mikhailovsky Theater of St. Petersburg, Russia, scored a coup last fall by luring two of ballet's biggest stars from the Bolshoi, and it was to have brought them to the United States this summer for a run of shows at Lincoln Center. But those plans have been scrapped, the Mikhailovsky's agent said on Thursday, because American Ballet Theater exercised a no-compete clause involving those very same dancers. Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev also happen to dance with Ballet Theater - Ms. Osipova as a principal and Mr. Vasiliev as a guest. A Ballet Theater spokeswoman did not immediately return a phone message on Thursday. The Mikhailovsky had longstanding plans to perform at the David H. Koch Theater from June 19 to July 1, presenting ''Giselle;'' an evening of works choreographed by its artistic director, Nacho Duato; and Mr. Duato's version of ''Sleeping Beauty.'' The two Russian stars were to have alternated in the casts of ''Giselle'' and ''Sleeping Beauty.'' Meanwhile, Ballet Theater is scheduled to perform at the Metropolitan Opera house on Lincoln Center's plaza around the same time.

A picture caption in the Listings pages last Friday about Björk's live show based on her album ''Biophilia,'' at the New York Hall of Science, misidentified the label under which the album was issued. It is One Little Indian/Nonesuch Records, not One Little Indian/Polydor.

An article on Wednesday about the decision by a federal appeals court panel to overturn a voter-approved initiative banning same-sex marriage in California misstated the surname of a son of one of the same-sex couples who were plaintiffs in the case. It is Spencer Perry, not Spencer Stier. (His parents are Kris Perry and Sandy Stier.)

At the first Wall Street Training Valuation Case Competition, aspiring moguls turned synergies into sport, in a deal simulation contest that was equal parts ''American Idol'' and ''Glengarry Glen Ross.''

The Alibaba Group's publicly traded affiliate, Alibaba.com, has emerged as a potential part of its plan to buy back most of a stake held by Yahoo, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday. Yahoo has been in talks for several months with its Asian partners - Alibaba and Softbank of Japan - on what amounts to a tax-free asset swap worth billions of dollars. Yahoo currently owns about 40 percent of Alibaba and 35 percent of Yahoo Japan, the latter of which is controlled by Softbank.

GOLDRING--Rachel. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her husband David, their children Olivia and Jason, and their family. May her memory be for blessing and may her loved ones be comforted amidst the mourners of our people for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Lois S. Nyren, President

GOLDRING--Rachel. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Rachel Goldring, beloved wife of David and mother of Olivia and Jason. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

KAPELOV--Dudley S. Loved and admired by all who knew him, passed away on February 9, 2011 at the age of 82. He was the loving son of the late Beatrice and Abraham, the beloved husband of the late Harriet, the devoted father of Susan and Steven, and the cherished grandfather of Andy and Hayley. We miss you terribly Papa, but your kind spirit will live on in your children and your grandchildren, and you will forever be in our hearts.

A music review last Friday about a recital by the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, at Carnegie Hall, referred incompletely to ''The Boy From ...,'' a song she performed as an encore. While Stephen Sondheim wrote the lyrics, the music is by Mary Rodgers.

An article on Tuesday about the Georgia Supreme Court's rejecting a law intended to discourage assisted suicide referred incorrectly to the background of Derek Humphry, author of a suicide manual. Although he was born in England, he emigrated to the United States in 1978 and is now a citizen. The article also misstated the title of Mr. Humphry's book. It is ''Final Exit,'' not ''The Final Exit.''

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the ambitious new goals set by the Rick Santorum campaign after his recent electoral victories misstated the location where one of his volunteers was preparing for a rally. The volunteer was in Plano, Tex., not McKinney, Tex.

FURST--Stephen. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Steve, a gentle, kind and loving husband, father and grandfather. Our deepest sympathy to Ruthie, Richard, Jeffrey, Warren and all the grandchildren. Roger, Charlotte and Eric

KRENZEL--Ken, Ph.D. The Board of Directors and Staff of New York Psychotherapy and Counseling Center mourn the passing of Dr. Ken Krenzel on February 9, 2012. Ken served for the past 20 years as a member of our Board of Directors, including the past 19 years as Vice President of the Board. He was a warm, generous, loyal friend and colleague. His dedication and guidance in our treatment of mentally ill adults and emotionally disturbed children will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, and his entire family. Devora Brickman President, Board of Directors, Elliott Klein, Executive Director.

3:04 a.m. | Updated BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. - The news of Whitney Houston's death came a few hours before one of the music industry's most glamorous rites: Clive Davis's annual pre-Grammy party at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. For more than 30 years top artists and executives (and their dates) have hobnobbed there in their black-tie finest and cheered each other on in performances of what might be the next night's big winners.

As the news rapidly spread on Saturday night that Whitney Houston had died in Los Angeles earlier that afternoon, her music industry colleagues and other prominent figures took to their Twitter accounts to register their shock and sadness.

The basketball team at Mount St. Joseph Academy, a small Catholic high school here amid the foothills of the Green Mountains, was flailing through its 2009-10 season when its coach got a call from a stranger in New York.

Alex Morgan strengthened her case for a starting role in this summer's London Olympics by scoring two late goals Saturday night to give the United States women's national team a 2-1 victory over New Zealand in Frisco, Tex.

Shortly before Miguel Adrover's return to the runway tonight after a roughly eight-year absence (not counting the small presentations he has made for a German eco-label called Hessnatur), I stopped backstage to say hello. Mr. Adrover, a designer who sort of looks like Jesus, was studying a model who was wearing what looked like half of a tropical rainforest, with sharp bones protruding from her jaws.

Alexander Wang held his fall show in the usual place, Pier 94, and the set seemed promising enough: a group of mirrored columns arranged in the middle of a semi-dark, rectangular space. After an energy-zapping wait, the show started and the models emerged from the backstage and, bathed in runway light, walked toward the photographers' stand. Then they turned, heading to a far corner of the space.

Data consultants help businesses make sense of an explosion of data - Web traffic and social network comments, as well as software and sensors that monitor shipments, suppliers and customers - to guide decisions, trim costs and lift sales.To exploit the data flood, America will need 140,000 to 190,000 more workers with "deep analytical" expertise and 1.5 million more data-literate managers, whether retrained or hired, writes Steve Lohr. The impact of data abundance extends well beyond business. Read more »

The inspiration for Christian Siriano's fall collection was bats. Specifically, it was "The Vampire Bat," a film from the 1930s. Mr. Siriano explained this to me during an interview for the cover story in this week's Thursday Styles, in which he described the pressure of trying to appeal to fashion critics, who are looking for big ideas in his shows, and to his customers, who tend to want something pleasing to wear.

My Sunday column looks at the debate over the Obama mandate for Catholic-affiliated universities and hospitals to carry insurance that includes contraceptives. I believe we should try to accommodate religious concerns where possible, but I also believe that birth control is far too important to be sacrificed. Read the column and post your thoughts, please.

Army Lt. Col. Daniel L. Davis, who returned in October from his second deployment in Afghanistan, set off a vigorous debate inside and outside the military last week with a provocative article in Armed Forces Journal arguing that military leaders have failed to tell the truth about how badly the war is going. He made multiple appearances on radio and TV; his views were debated on the House floor; and many other officers spoke out, on At War and elsewhere, to commend or condemn him.

After a two-year absence, the BMW M6 coupe and convertible are returning to the German automaker's lineup, with the hardtop scheduled to be unveiled at the Geneva auto show next month. The drop-top variant arrives at the New York auto show about a month later.

SUNDAY'S PUZZLE - Now this is a nice way to end the solving week. Forgive me a little back-patting, but I sailed through this one. That's huge for me, because it's a rebus, and I don't always see those right away.

Mitt Romney won the annual straw poll of conservative activists at the Conservative Political Action Conference, or CPAC, conference officials announced on Saturday in Washington. Mr. Romney received 38 percent of the 3,408 votes cast, compared to 31 percent for Rick Santorum, 15 percent for Newt Gingrich and 12 percent for Representative Ron Paul of Texas, who did not attend the meeting this year.
The poll asked 992 respondents about Medicare and social security.

The danger in making "too much" of Jeremy Lin is obvious. The emerging Asian-American star of the U.S's National Basketball Association is both excellent and unusual: the N.B.A.'s first American-born player of Taiwanese or Chinese descent and only the fourth Asian-American in league history. He is a former Harvard University player and his performance on the court has been phenomenal. On his merits, then, he deserves attention.

The Knicks' Jeremy Lin has scored at least 23 points in each of his last four games, including 38 on Friday night against the Lakers. He has also recorded at least seven assists in each game, and he has been efficient, shooting at least 53 percent from the field each time.

The ongoing discussions of economic policy and principles since the Great Recession struck have, I have to say, been a source of continuing revelation. Again and again one sees people with seemingly sterling credentials -- Federal Reserve presidents, economists with Ph.D.s from good schools -- propounding views that I thought were obvious fallacies, at least to anyone who had studied the subject a bit. And the hits just keep coming.

Investigators said the condition appeared to be caused by a malfunction of the master switch that controls the power windows.

RUBIN--Doris Bernstein, died on Wednesday, February 8th at her home in Scottsdale, AZ. She was born November 21, 1916 to Anna and Abraham Bernstein in NYC. At 18 years of age, while visiting Palestine, she met and married her husband Leon Rubin in 1935. They lived in Palestine for two years then traveled through Europe and came to the United States to live and raise a family. She is survived by her three daughters, Mrs. Joan Gellert, Mrs. Barbara Gellert and Mrs. Vivien Rubin Gilli, nine grandchildren and 17 great-grandchildren. She was a very exceptional lady, and all who knew her loved her. Funeral services will be 1:30pm Sunday February 12, 2012 at Hevreh Synagogue in Great Barrington, MS, burial will follow at Ahavath Shalom Cemetery.

Paul McCartney may have nearly every music-industry honor under the sun, a new marriage and a funnily titled album to promote. But until Thursday he had never been given a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Mr. McCartney became the last member of the Beatles to receive this distinction at a ceremony outside the Capitol Records building in Hollywood, where the stars commemorating that band and its three other members are also located, Reuters reported.

WERTHEIMER--Florrie L.,Attorney, Barnard College class of '50 and NYU Law of '52, died this Friday. She brought humor, wit and style to everything she did. A trial attorney in the male dominated Admiralty Bar, she blazed a path in her high heels between her downtown office and the Southern District Court House until her last days, which was the way she wanted it. Florrie had a life long love affair with France and loved the Arts, great restaurants and celebrating life with close friends and family. She will be greatly missed by her family, her friends and her doggies. Funeral at Frank E. Campbell at Madison and 81st Street, at 4:00pm Sunday, February 12pm. A memorial TBD. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her name to the Deja Foundation.

TISCH--Richard G.,on February 9, 2012. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Drillings), devoted father of Alexander Tisch and Victoria (Howard) Baum, adored grandfather of Jordan and Teddy Baum, brother of Howard Tisch and Lenore Somerstein. Service Sunday, February 12, 10am at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.
WEINBERG--Julie. Lifelong friend and self-made man. We traveled the world together with much laughter. We will miss you. Renee and Murray Nadel

GOLDIN--Bernice. It is with deep sorrow that we record the passing of our esteemed member, Ms. Bernice Goldin, and extend out deepest sympathy to her family. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President for the Board of Governors
SCHLANG--David. A truely wonderful husband, father and grandfather. A dear friend. The Jahrmarkt Family

WERTHEIMER--Florrie. We are deeply shocked and saddened by her sudden passing. She was not only a dynamic, vibrant, and brilliant woman and lawyer; but also an adored and cherished wife and mother. Her keen intellect and quick wit will be remembered by many. Florrie lived and enjoyed her life in New York City and in France, and truly lived it her way. Her love of summers in France with her boats and cars was overshadowed only by her lifelong love for her beloved dogs. Our thoughts and hearts are with Jules, Robin, Larry, Elizabeth, Marcy, and the grandchildren she loved so much. She will truly be missed. Catherine, Fred, Christopher and Freddie.
ELLMAN--Jeanette 81/20-2/11/00 - Wonderful mother, veteran, and inspirer. Joyce and Family

When Magic Johnsonrevealed on Nov. 7, 1991, that he had contracted H.I.V., the stunning announcement rippled across the National Basketball Association and professional sports, and changed the way that H.I.V./AIDS was discussed. Now, more than 20 years later, ESPN and the N.B.A. are preparing a documentary about Mr. Johnson's decision to go public with his diagnosis, from a director who says that he doesn't want to see H.I.V./AIDS disappear from the national conversation. On Friday ESPN Films and NBA Entertainment are expected to announce that they will present the documentary, called ''The Announcement,'' on ESPN starting on March 11. It is directed by the filmmaker and writer Nelson George. (Mr. George has been a contributor to The New York Times.)

Rhea, who took the reins in 2009, misidentified the party that joined Legal Aid in a suit against the authority over suspended payments for housing vouchers. Interment to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation.

LOS ANGELES - As usual, the average movie ticket in the United States cost more last year, but not by much. The National Association of Theater Owners said the average ticket price for 2011 was $7.93, up about 0.5 percent from $7.89 in 2010. It was the 17th year of consecutive annual increases, which started in 1995, when an average ticket cost $4.35, up from $4.08 the year before.

A news analysis article on Thursday about the challenges facing Mitt Romney in gaining the support of the Republican Party base gave an incorrect name for the conference at which all the remaining Republican presidential candidates were to speak. It is the Conservative Political Action Conference, not the Conservative Public Action Conference.

Just in time for Charles Darwin's 203rd birthday on Sunday, the American Museum of Natural History is unveiling the first phase of its online Darwin Manuscripts Project, a collection of more than 15,000 digitized manuscript pages and thousands of other documents drawn from Cambridge University Library, the Biodiversity Heritage Library and other institutions around the world. Among the documents available on the Web site are notes from Darwin's time aboard the HMS Beagle, pocket diaries, early drafts of works like ''The Origin of Species'' (viewable with and without Darwin's revisions), and previously unpublished manuscripts like an ''experiment book'' describing Darwin's original research on plant breeding strategies, begun in 1856. In addition to revealing Darwin's intellectual evolution, the project also reveals Darwin's sometimes less-than-careful treatment of some of his own papers. Today, a first-edition of the ''Origin'' is a highly sought after rare book, but pages of the original manuscript are even rarer, thanks to Darwin's habit of passing them out as scrap paper. Among the 42 full pages known to survive today, a few feature fanciful drawings on the reverse by his son Francis showing birds undreamed of in the Galápagos Islands as well as a soldier on a carrot battling a cavalier on an eggplant. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

LOWE--Dr. Charles Upton. 90, of Cambridge, MA died peacefully on February 9. Pediatrician, researcher and educator, he had a long and distinguished career in academic medicine and public service. Born in Pelham, NY, in 1921 to Joseph and Edith (Rosenfield) Lowe, he attended Horace Mann and earned degrees from Harvard College (cum laude) 1942 and Yale Medical School (cum laude) 1945. After an internship at Children's Hospital, Boston, he became chief resident of pediatrics at Massachusetts General Hospital, where his research led him to discover a sex-linked metabolic disorder known as Lowe Syndrome, OCRL (oculo-cerebro-renal) syndrome. In 1948, he joined the University of Minnesota as a National Research Council Fellow and was later appointed Assistant Professor of Pediatrics. Three years later he joined the faculty of the University of Buffalo, NY, where he became Professor of Medicine and a Buswell Fellow. He spent a two-year sabbatical at the Virus Research Laboratory at Cambridge University, England. From 1965-1968, he was professor of pediatrics and director of the Human Development Center at the University of Florida, Gainesville. While there, he completed a national survey of nutrition among pre-school children and conducted studies on the modification of human metabolism in metabolic diseases. In 1968 he became the Scientific Director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, NIH, Bethesda, MD. He left NICHD to become Special Assistant for Child Health Affairs to the Assistant Secretary of Health in the Ford Administration. He returned to NICHD in 1983, and spent the rest of his career there. One project was working to develop a vaccine for Typhoid fever that took him to Nepal, where he was able to enjoy trekking in the Himalayas and carry on his life-long love of mountain climbing. Among his many contributions while at the NIH, in 1973, he was instrumental in creating an on-site child care center. During his career, Dr. Lowe was awarded many honors, contributed over 100 articles to leading medical and scientific journals, and founded the journal "Pediatric Research" for which he served as editor for 12 years. After retiring in 1994, Charles moved to Cambridge, MA, where he immersed himself in Harvard life, by auditing classes, fundraising, and serving as historian and archivist for Lowell House, his undergraduate residence. Dr. Lowe was a skilled wood worker, astute art collector, and avid gardener. He took special pride in restoration of his historic home in Woods Hole, MA that burned down in an accidental fire. In his retirement he wrote, "Time Out of Mind: An Afghan Adventure," a book about his trip through Afghanistan and India in 1954, illustrated with own photographs. Charles is survived by his beloved wife, Barbara Bitting Frazer, his four loving children, Sarah M. Lowe, (Elisabeth Smith) of Brooklyn, NY, Elizabeth E. Lowe of South Hero, VT, J. Stephen Lowe (Jane Ceraso), of Acton, MA and S. Cambria Lowe (Devin Hess) of Berkeley, CA, three treasured grandchildren Sage, Rory, and Simon, his beloved niece and nephew Ann Bookman of Brookline, MA, and Richard Bookman of Miami, FL, one great-nephew and three great-nieces, and his former wife, Eileen Josten Lowe of Brooklyn, NY. Burial is private. An announcement of a memorial service in Cambridge, MA will be forthcoming. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Partners in Health or Lowe Syndrome Association.

The ratings for ''American Idol'' reversed their course on Thursday night, growing slightly compared to last week, which provided Fox with a win for the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic coveted by advertisers. CBS drew the most viewers over all. An average of 17.9 million people watched ''Idol,'' barely beating last week's total of 17.4 million but the show was also up 4 percent in the 18-to-49 category. Again, not a large gain, but a change from the downward trend that followed earlier episodes. The CBS lineup continued its strong performance as ''The Big Bang Theory'' drew 16.1 million total viewers and beat ''Idol'' with adults 18-to-49 in the half-hour they went head to head, while ''The Mentalist'' had its largest audience of the season with 14.4 million viewers.

An article on Friday about the regional implications of Greece's debt bailout negotiations used an out-of-date figure for the Greek debt level. In the third quarter of 2011, the most recent period for which data are available, Greece's government debt was 159.1 percent of gross domestic product -- not 142 percent. A figure for the fourth quarter has not yet been calculated.

MARCUS--Stuart, poet, artist and book collector, 57, died suddenly on February 8, 2012. Beloved son of Richard and Helen Marcus and cherished brother of Gwen Marcus and Nancy Alpert. Services on Sunday, February 12th at 12:30pm at Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.

GUSSACK--Manya, 87, of White Plains, NY, died February 9, 2012 in hospice and family care at the home of her daughter Lisa, surrounded by all of her family. Manya was born on November 6, 1924, in the Bronx, NY to Isidore and Esther Kanof and was a sister to George and Libby. She married Seymour Gussack in March of 1947 and they had five children by the time they moved to New Rochelle in 1960. Amy, Lisa, Faith, Nina and David were the core and center of Manya's world, and she spent much of her time in her kitchen, a furious center of constant activity, being with her children and their friends, all spinning around her kitchen table. Manya's unique ability to beguile and charm and embrace extended naturally to her daughter-in-law, Snow and to her sons-in-law Kermit, Alan, Robert and Allan. Manya first brought her family to Cape Cod, the place she grew to love more than all others, in the summer of 1959. And now the new generation, Manya's grandchildren, Adam, Sophie Rose, Benjamin, Daniel, Jonathan, Rebecca, Natasha, Jessie and Linda spend their summer vacations at "The Hive", the family house in Eastham. Manya traveled extensively, both on behalf of her husband's international business and particularly for pleasure with her great friend, Belle. Her adopted families in Japan and Israel are mourning her loss as well. Her legion of friends and admirers has grown exponentially over the years and includes three generations. She had the rare ability to walk into any room and galvanize the people there and to be constantly attuned and attentive to the lives and stories of others. In her presence no one ever felt any less than the center of the universe. Her generosity was legendary, her commitment to fun and adventure was unstoppable. And in her latter years, she and Claudette and Nicola, her loving helpers, formed a unit that was happy and fun and full of life. Manya was a true force of nature - a giving, loving, unassuming woman with wisdom and experience and most especially love, to spare and share. There's only one Manya! If you'd like to remember Manya with a charitable contribution, we would suggest two of her favorites, Beit Hatfutsot, The Museum of the Jewish People (www.bh.org.il/) and Jewish Women International (www.jwi.org). The memorial service will be at 12 noon on Sunday, the 12th at daughter Lisa's home in White Plains, NY. Shiva will begin Sunday and continue through Wednesday from 1pm-7pm daily with 7:30pm Minyan also at Lisa's home.
FORREST--Bradley. Time does not lessen our pain. With never ending love Mom, Dad, "T & R"

10 P.M. (Cinemax) PAUL (2011) He looks like any other extraterrestrial, with his otherworldly cast, bald bobble head, big eyes and stick limbs. Until you get to the board shorts and the backpack. In other words, Paul, above, voiced by Seth Rogen and the title character of this comedy from Greg Mottola, is a little green dude. And he comes in peace, man, despite causing havoc while he tries to phone home. Simon Pegg and Nick Frost are the best friends, fresh from a Comic-Con convention in San Diego, who run into Paul as they guide their recreational vehicle toward Area 51, the military base in Nevada where the conspiracy-minded think the government stashes aliens. Jason Bateman is one of the men in black hunting Paul; Kristen Wiig is the love interest who wears a T-shirt depicting Jesus blowing away Darwin; and John Carroll Lynch is her daddy, a member of the Bible and gun club. ''As genial, foolish and demographically engineered as it sounds (hailing all fan boys and girls), 'Paul' is at once a buddy flick and a classic American road movie of self- (and other) discovery, interspersed with buckets of expletives and some startling (especially for a big-studio release) pokes at Christian fundamentalism,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Still, she said, ''Paul proves the weak link.'' There's something predictable about using Mr. Rogen's voice for that body, she added, and ''while Paul seems great conceptually, he's not particularly interesting or surprising.'' 10:30 A.M. Reviving an effort begun years ago to improve low-performing middle schools, New York City is changing tactics and concentrating on improving reading and writing skills. The new plan is the second phase of a campaign started in 2008 by the City Council and the city's Education Department to bolster student performance at 51 of the lowest-performing middle schools. Three years later, the department and Council have rethought their approach and moved on -- to an almost entirely different batch of 18 schools, where they plan to train teachers in literacy instruction for students who read at a third- or fourth-grade level.

Hackers claimed responsibility for knocking the Web site of the Central Intelligence Agency offline on Friday, under the banner of the hacking collective Anonymous. By late Friday afternoon, the site was still unavailable. On Twitter, an account affiliated with Anonymous said it was responsible for the attack, which appeared to be one that involved bombarding the site with traffic until it ground to a halt, rather than an intrusion into the agency's computer systems.

"I've got you, Daphne," one of Tom Pecheux's assistants said as he led Daphne Groeneveld to a seat at the end of a long table backstage at Derek Lam. Her hair was teased, and she was wearing a black sweater sewn with pearls. Someone brought by an orange and red embroidered dickey collar and asked her if she would mind slipping it on before makeup. Pecheux's team was about to turn her into his version of a naughty schoolgirl using a soft veil of Estée Lauder's new Invisible Fluid Makeup, concealer and powder. Eyebrows were groomed and lashes coated with Sumptuous Two Tone Eye-Opening Mascara to apply black on the top and brown on the bottom. Eyes were lined and spread with smoky burgundy and then a sweep of Sugar Cube white - the same shadow that was dotted in the middle of the lips, and covered in Crystal Pink and Vanilla Truffle lipstick. "A lovely girly lip color," is how Pecheux described the effect. He wanted the girls' mouths to look innocent, just as their eyes were lined to make them appear more youthful - rounder - rather than sultry. The hairstylist Orlando Pita channeled the same lady. "She's well bred, a little bit intellectual, eccentric, twisted," he said of his muse spending a semester at an all-girls school. This translated in to hair blow-dried with Phyto Volumizing Mousse and the T3 Featherweight Luxe, back-combed, curled with the T3 SinglePass Whirl and pinned up for daytime, with loose strands let down at the back come night. Up for day, down for evening? She's totally bucking against the norm.
New York

The hairstylist Paul Hanlon is wearing green Converse sneakers as he walks around backstage at Altuzarra. He's as chill as his choice of shoes. Stepping onto the bus in the early morning hours with my students in central Virginia, bound for one of the area's Civil War battlefields, is still my favorite moment of the year. The trip that follows is a chance for us to imagine ourselves as part of a larger community, one extending far back into the past. In those moments, in those still-dewy fields, the distance between the present and past collapses. I suspect it's the same reason that bring hundreds of thousands of people each year to Fredericksburg, Manassas, Richmond, Petersburg and the Shenandoah Valley: We want, we feel compelled even, to understand what happened, why it happened and what it means that it happened.

Yosemite National Park plans to reduce the number of permits it issues to hikers seeking to climb Half Dome peak, one of its most popular destinations, because of safety concerns. The organizers of the Grammy Awards said late on Saturday night that a musical performance in honor of Whitney Houston, who died earlier that day, will be presented on Sunday's awards telecast. The Recording Academy said in a statement that Jennifer Hudson, the "American Idol" finalist, Grammy and Academy Award winner, had been added to the show's lineup to perform the tribute. Ken Ehrlich, the producer of the Grammy show, was quoted by Billboard as saying this performance will "be something respectful." Mr. Ehrlich added: "It's not going to be a full-blown tribute, that's too early and it's too fresh at this moment. It's going to be something respectful to Whitney's memory." Ms. Houston won six Grammys in her career, starting in 1985 with a trophy for best female pop vocal performance for "Saving All My Love For You."

It took traveling to Mexico City and rewatching the director Sergio Leone's "Dollar Trilogy" for this season's inspiration to click together for the designer Scott Sternberg. "I just felt it was time for me to do a little take on western, with a bit of Mexican influence," Sternberg said. "There's a hint of cowboy in my guys. Picture them coming off a mesa or range. They should look like themselves, honest and straightforward."

Trinity Wall Street's announcement in January that it was suspending its vaunted music program, to reassess its place in the ministry and examine alternative sources of financing, shocked many music lovers in New York, parishioners or not. But the church held out promise that, thanks to several special donations, its centerpiece afternoon series - Bach at One, featuring the acclaimed Trinity Choir and Trinity Baroque Orchestra, directed by Julian Wachner - would return for a Lenten series in March.

Emperor Akihito of Japan will undergo heart bypass surgery on Saturday in Tokyo, the emperor's office said Sunday, as reported by the Kyodo news agency. The Imperial Household Agency made the announcement after Akihito, 78, had received a detailed heart examination. Kyodo reported that the catheter angiogram was performed after the emperor "displayed symptoms of a minor ischemic change while recently engaging in light exercise.'' The Mainichi Daily News reported that Akihito, who took the throne in 1989, had an angiogram last February. "At that time,'' the paper said Sunday, "the emperor's doctors found that the artery providing oxygen and nourishment to the heart muscle was narrowing and hardening.'' Read more »

Tehelka has a great rundown of deteriorating conditions at various Commonwealth Games facilities this week, which helps answer questions that may have occurred to many Delhi-dwellers in recent months. (Why isn't the new Siri Fort swimming pool open, anyway? Oh, the heating system failed. Whatever happened to the big Yamuna pool? Oh, it's been empty and completely unused for months.) No system of inspection or maintenance has ever been established for the games' facilities, which cost billions of dollars, because of infighting between departments, Tehelka reports.

An article last Sunday about huge antigovernment protests in Moscow the day before misspelled the surname of a political scientist who spoke at a huge counter-rally organized by the authorities. He is Sergei Kurginyan, not Kurganyan.
Film Neil Genzlinger

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Bradshaw Backs Into a Victory,'' Feb. 6: Giants running back Ahmad Bradshaw reluctantly fell into the end zone during Super Bowl XLVI, although the play called for him to stop short of it. Professional players have had years of conditioning to thrust themselves into any end zone opening. As psychology teaches us, cognitive control cannot necessarily override this.
MONTCLAIR RANCH $719,000

SVENSKT TENN, the Stockholm design and interiors shop, closed its flagship boutique at 5 Strandvagen, which opened in 1927, for several months last year for a renovation. Now, to celebrate its recent reopening, the store kicks off an exhibition of the work of Estrid Ericson, who founded the business in 1924, and her most famous collaborator, the Austrian designer Josef Frank. Visitors will also see new pieces by the Swedish artist Eric Ericson and by the French designer Inga Sempé, whose pewter pitcher, cup and tray recall Ms. Ericson's early career as a pewter designer. And don't miss Svenskt Tenn's newest addition: the most charming tea salon in the city. Not only are the teas, cakes and sandwiches excellent, but tables are set with products from the store. At one end of the room, behind a wall of glass, is a re-creation of the Ericson workroom. A woman of impeccable taste, she had a five-cup-a-day tea habit, and no one knew more about setting the perfect table. STEPHEN WHITLOCK

WILLIAMS--Margaret Spickers. Died peacefully at her home in Westport Connecticut at 2:10pm on January 28, 2012. She is survived by her two sons, Anthony McKay, and his wife Cindy McKay, of Pittsburgh Pennsylvania, and her son, Peter Albert McKay, of Manhattan, New York, and her two grandchildren, Jack Hutchins McKay and Larry Peter McKay, of Pittsburgh Pennsylvania. The only daughter of Dr. William Spickers, and Reed Hutchins Spickers, late of Franklin Lakes, New Jersey. She was born in Paterson New Jersey on January 30, 1920, and passed her summers in Bay Head, New Jersey. In the fall of 1938, she was enrolled at the prestigious American Academy of Dramatic arts, which was then located at the Carnegie Hall in Manhattan, New York, and she was a proud graduate of the class of 1940. In 1940 as an apprentice acting student in summer stock, at the historic Woodstock Playhouse, in Woodstock, New York, she met and fell in love with fellow actor Scott McKay, who had come east, after moving from his birth city of Pleasantville Iowa, to Denver, Colorado. They were married in October 1942. After her 1950 divorce, she encountered her last great love, Warner Bros. actor and author Lawrence Williams in Rome, Italy, whom she married on the Roman Campidoglio, in June 1956. In 1958 she and Larry, bought their house at 8 Newtown Turnpike, Westport Connecticut. They also combined to write a theater version of Larry's Literary Guild winning novel "I, James McNeil Whistler" which was produced at the Hartford Stage Company in Hartford, Connecticut, and then at the historic Provincetown Playhouse in Greenwich Village, NY in 1981. Larry died at their home on January 3, 1983. Maggie then found a new cultural home in 1983, with The Theater Artists Workshop of Westport. Proud of her maternal family of Dunmore East, Waterford County Ireland, she took her Irish family name, Power, as a stage name, Margaret Power. In Ireland in the recent summers, alternating games with short mandatory moments for the music of Richard Wagner she forged her rich and undying bond of love with her grandchildren Jack and Larry. Her sons, Anthony McKay and Peter McKay are planning a memorial service in celebration of her rich and wonderful life scheduled for June 2012. Please contact them for further information as follows: Peter McKay- pam1one@aol.com, Anthony McKay- tmckay@andrew.cmu.edu.

JACOBOWITZ--Stefanie Fran (nee Miller), 44, of Leonia, NJ, died on February 9, 2012. Daughter of Edward Miller and Bena Green and the late Ronnie Miller (Julian) Gaa. She leaves behind husband Marshall and children, Emery, Hannah and Aaron. She is also survived by sisters Jodi Miller and Wendy Miller (Steven) Weigler; niece Radley Weigler; and in-laws William and Rifkie Jacobowitz, Harry (Leslie) Jacobowitz, and Jeff Jacobowitz. Stefanie is remembered by her numerous friends for her sense of humor, loving nature, and constant smile. She loved and was loved every day of her life. Gifts in Stefanie's memory can be made to the National Ovarian Cancer Coalition.

HOFFERT--Dr. Paul Washington, of Tucson, AZ, long time resident of Mamaroneck, NY. Predeceased by his adored, wife, Rosolyn. Survived by his children, Dr. Marvin (Mary), Dr. Renee Gutman (Jonathan), Dr. Deborah (Gary), grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Graduate of Yale School of Medicine in 1945, he was a general and vascular surgeon who took great pride in caring for his patients in Yonkers and the Bronx, NY. His enthusiasm for Jewish practice and scholarship was an inspiration to all who met him. A graveside service will take place at the Riversville Cemetery in Glenville, CT, on February 12, 2012 at 12 noon. Services handled by Schwartz Bros., 800-690-1646 or 718-263-7600. Shiva will be observed on Sunday evening at the home of Rabbi Charles Rudansky, 640 Forest Ave., Mamaroneck, NY and then at his home, 5062 East South Regency Circle, Tucson, AZ 85711. In lieu of gifts, donations can be made to his beloved shul, Congregation Chofetz Chayim, 5150 East Fifth. St. Tucson, AZ 85711.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''By Smallest Margins, a Patriots Legacy Is Being Redefined,'' Feb. 7: I think I can explain Tom Brady's change of fortune. After the Patriots' playoff win over the Broncos, Tim Tebow searched in vain to chat with Brady, who ran off the field right away. When reporters asked him what Brady had said after the game, all Tebow could say was, ''We didn't talk.'' Bad karma doesn't always win out, but it certainly does often enough.

CARTER--Martha Elizabeth Wiedersheim Lloyd, 90, a long time resident of New Canaan, CT and most recently of Meadow Ridge in Redding, CT died on February 7, 2012 after a brief illness. She was the beloved wife of 31 years of William Phelps Carter, who survives her. Her first husband, Charles Ewing Green Lloyd, predeceased her in 1979 after 34 years of marriage. Known as Betty, she grew up in St. Davids, PA, attended the Shipley School and graduated from Chatham Hall in 1939. She was an avid sportswoman and long time member of the Country Club of New Canaan and the Saugatuck Shores Club and served on their boards. She was also a member of the Mill Reef Club in Antigua. She is survived by her sister, Katherine Wiedersheim Petrie of Doylestown, PA and her two children, Suzanne Lloyd Liebolt and Charles Ewing Green Lloyd, Jr., both of New York City. She leaves behind four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren by her first husband and four Carter sons, twelve step grandchildren and two step-great- grandchildren by her second. All adored her. Betty reached across generations. She was energetic and vibrant and kept her keen mind engaged until the end. Her memory was legendary and she was our GPS. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00 am on Friday, February 17, 2012 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT 06840. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to St. Mark's.
Television Kathryn Shattuck

SAVLOV--Jean Kams In loving memory of my mother, Jean Kams Savlov Born on May 5, 1926, to Albert and Ruth Kams in the town of Barre, NY, Jean died of natural causes on February 11, 2011, in Reno, NV. Upon graduating from Elba High School as Valedictorian, she attended the Rochester Business Institute and became a medical secretary. In July, 1951 she married Roy C. Tullius, a Lieutenant in the USAF 372nd Bomb Squadron, who was unfortunately killed during a routine B-29 training exercise over the China Sea in February, 1952. Jean then enrolled in The University of Rochester School of Nursing. She graduated Summa Cum Laude in 1955 and went to work at Strong Memorial Hospital, eventually rising to the position of Head Nurse. It was there that she met and later married Dr. Edwin D. Savlov in 1963. Her only son, Marc Haley Savlov, was born on April 14, 1966, and now lives and works as a writer in Austin, TX. In addition to being a incomparable homemaker, wife, and mother, Jean was also a committed community volunteer: in her son's schools, with The Harrington Cancer Center in Amarillo, TX, and at The Assistance League of Reno/Sparks, NV. Throughout her life she was active with the ACLU, Planned Parenthood, the Southern Poverty Law Center, and many other socially progressive organizations and humanitarian causes. She was also a passionate culinarian and inspired home-gourmet who at one point amassed a library of over 1,400 cookbooks. Her son recalls having to sneak over to the neighbors' house when he was a young boy, the better to enjoy more pedestrian fare such as hot dogs and hamburgers at times when duck a l'orange and veal scallopini were the weekday norm at the Savlov family home. A constant reader of everything from Tennessee Williams to James Patterson and from Erica Jong to P.D. James, Jean was rarely without a book close to hand. Her love of the arts, her warm sense of humor, and her deep empathy for and kindness towards other people touched all who knew her. She was preceded in death by her husband Edwin in 2007, her parents, her sister Elizabeth, and her brother Herbert, a Marine who was killed in action in the Pacific in 1944. She is survived by her son Marc, her stepdaughter Meg Savlov of Seattle, her stepson John Savlov of North Bennington, VT, her grandson Christopher Grisham, and her great-grandson Dorian Grisham. She is greatly missed, and often.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Slap Shot hockey column last Sunday about the dominant play of Pittsburgh Penguins' Evgeni Malkin misstated the given name of one of the National Hockey League offensive talents who has overshadowed Malkin in recent years. He is Daniel Sedin, not Alex.

SANDS--Richard H.,orthodontist and cofounder of renowned New-Conn Orthodontist Study group, died on February 10, at his home in Sarasota, Florida. He was 84. Dr. Sands graduated from Poly Prep High School in Brooklyn, Amherst College, and Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery. Dr. Sands served in the Navy as a nurse and physician's assistant caring for the sick and wounded at the end of and shortly after World War II; a lover of jazz and classical music, Dr. Sands was an accomplished clarinetist and saxophonist, and played in the Navy Swing Dance band. He was devoted to his profession, publishing many papers on new treatments, organizing regional and national conventions, and serving as an officer of numerous professional committees and societies. His military service gave him a love of travel, and he and his family traveled extensively throughout the world both before and after his retirement. He is survived by Joan his beloved wife of 59 years, his daughter, Caren, his two sons, Gordon and Jeffrey, and his seven grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, February 13, at 11:00am at Temple Sinai of Sarasota, 4631 South Lockwood Ridge Road. In lieu of flowers, donations in Dr. Sands' memory may be made to the Neuro Challenge Foundation: www.neurochallenge.org/neu/donations/, 941-926-6413 or 800-NCF-GIVE.

GENERAL MOTORS showed a mildly refreshed GMC Acadia crossover at the Chicago auto show that nevertheless included what G.M. described as a first for the industry. Acadia and Chevrolet Traverse models with power seats will receive a front-center air bag designed to improve protection of front-seat occupants on the far side of the vehicle in a side-impact crash. The air bag will be standard on the Buick Enclave.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption last Sunday with a letter to the sports editor, ''The Sopranos: Players Shriek, Eardrums Ache,'' reversed the pitches of the shrieks of the tennis players Maria Sharapova and Victoria Azarenka. As Marilyn Vondra, the writer of the letter, noted, Sharapova shrieks on high A flat and Azarenka on high G.

AARON--Roger. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the death of our partner Roger S. Aaron, who passed away on Saturday, February 11, 2012 following an illness. Mr. Aaron was 69 years old. He joined Skadden as a summer associate in 1967 and returned as a full-time associate in 1968. Mr. Aaron was promoted to partner in 1975 and rapidly became one of the proteges groomed by Joe Flom to succeed him in leading the firm. He served as the head of the firm's corporate practice for more than two decades and played a leading role on many of the firm's management committees. Mr. Aaron not only preserved the legacy with which he was entrusted, but also played a vital role in the global development of the firm. Skadden would not have become the firm that it is today without Roger Aaron. He helped shape our firm culture and was dedicated not only to his clients and the work, but equally to the firm. Over the years, Mr. Aaron led many of the most significant corporate transactions for the world's largest corporations, including XTO Energy, Compaq Computer, General Motors, Mobil Oil, Univision, U.S. Steel, Pfizer, Time Warner, Daimler and Alcatel. Mr. Aaron graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College in 1964 and received an MBA with high distinction from Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business Administration in 1965. He graduated from Yale Law School in 1968. He has been recognized as a top attorney by such publications as Chambers Global, Chambers USA, The Best Lawyers in America and International Financial Law Review 1000. Who's Who Legal called Mr. Aaron the "dean of the Bar." In addition to his leadership role at the firm and in his field, Mr. Aaron was an active supporter, fundraiser and contributor to his alma maters Dartmouth College and Yale Law School. He served on the boards of directors of the American Jewish Committee, the Burke Rehabilitation Center, the Legal Aid Society, the Rockefeller Center at Dartmouth College, and Teach for America. Mr. Aaron is survived by his wife Virginia (Ginny), sons Peter and Todd, mother Phyllis, sister Caroline, daughter-in-law Jessica and grandsons Nate and Will.
Classical Vivien Schweitzer

WERTHEIMER--Florrie L.,Attorney, Barnard College class of '50 and NYU Law of '52, died this Friday. She brought humor, wit and style to everything she did. Florrie had a life long love affair with France and loved the Arts, great restaurants and celebrating life with close friends and family. She will be greatly missed by her family, her friends and her doggies. Funeral at Frank E. Campbell at Madison and 81st Street, at 4:00pm Sunday, February 12pm. A memorial TBD. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her name to the Deja Foundation.

The Frugal Traveler column last Sunday, about a $100 weekend in Austin, Tex., misstated part of the name of a street that is an Austin night-life hub, where the writer went to hear indie rock at the Mohawk. It is Red River Street, not Road. The article also misstated part of the name of a street where the writer went for a sandwich at Ruby's BBQ. Ruby's is just off Guadalupe Street, not Avenue. It also misstated the number of undergraduates at the University of Texas at Austin. It is about 38,000 -- not about 50,000, which is the total enrollment. And it misstated the surname of a honky-tonk pianist. He is Earl Poole Ball, not Earl Poole Jones.

Interment to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation.

Christian yoga and yoga on the go in a new room at the San Francisco International Airport are proof that the practice of this meditative activity has become increasingly varied. Now, a hotel has embraced a new iteration: paddleboard yoga. Guests of the Aruba Marriott Resort can enroll in floating yoga classes in which students use stand-up paddleboards as platforms for downward dog and table top positions. Ninety-minute classes cost $40 and include 5 to 10 minutes of warm-up paddling.

KLINGENSTEIN--Bernard (Bud), died in Maine on February 8, 2012. Born in New York City to Paul H. and Florence B. Klingenstein on May 21, 1923, he attended Horace Mann School, The Taft School and UNC at Chapel Hill. He served in the U.S. Army Signal Corps. June 29, 1950, Bud married Diane W. Stinchfield. They had three children. Bud worked in sales positions in music, textile and precision weighing equipment industries. His proudest accomplishment was on the founding committee for the Cape Cod Regional Technical High School. He was president of the Cape Cod Hospital Horse Show and trustee for the Holderness School. He's survived by his wife, Dee, and three children, Chuck, Geoff and Ginger; their respective spouses, Sarah, Alixandra and Michael; two grandchildren, Ben and Laura, and his brother, Lee and sister-in-law, Daney. Memorial donations may be made to The Student Scholarship Fund For Bud Klingenstein at Cape Cod Regional Technical High School, 351 Pleasant Lake Avenue, Harwich, MA. 02645

(CBS) THE 54TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS ''Music's Biggest Night'' pulls out the stops with performances by Glen Campbell, this year's recipient of the Recording Academy Lifetime Achievement Award, who will be joined by the Band Perry and Blake Shelton. The program also features Adele, who will sing live for the first time since her surgery five months ago; Paul McCartney, the 2012 MusiCares Person of the Year; Alicia Keys and Bonnie Raitt, in a tribute to Etta James; Chris Brown, Deadmaus, the Foo Fighters, David Guetta and Lil Wayne in a salute to electronica music; and the Beach Boys, who will reunite after more than two decades of not performing together live, backed up by Maroon 5 and Foster the People. Kanye West leads the nominations with seven, followed by Adele, the Foo Fighters and Bruno Mars with six, and Lil Wayne and Skrillex with five. L L Cool J, above with Taylor Swift, hosts this ceremony, broadcast from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. ''Countdown to the Red Carpet'' will be shown at 5 and ''Live From the Red Carpet'' at 6, both on E! 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS The Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum talks about his victories in Colorado, Minnesota and Missouri, and how he intends to maintain momentum. Jack Lew, the White House chief of staff, discusses the economic recovery, the White House budget and tension with Syria and Iran. Mr. Lew will also appear with Sarah Palin on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; with Mr. Santorum on ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC; and with the Republican presidential candidate Representative Ron Paul of Texas on ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS.

BERNARD--Harold, S. Ph.D.,ABPP, CGP, DLFAGPA, The American Group Psychotherapy Association, the Group Psychotherapy Foundation and the National Registry of Certified Group Psychotherapists Officers, Boards of Directors and Membership mourn the loss of Dr. Harold S. Bernard, who passed away on February 4, 2012 in Westport, CT. He was a Distinguished Life Fellow, AGPA Past President, Eastern Affiliate Past President and a prolific author and editor on group therapy. His compassionate leadership following the events of 9/11 made it possible for AGPA to help thousands of people affected by this tragedy and paved the way for AGPA to provide ongoing community services to those in need. He was a beloved teacher, mentor, supervisor and leader in the group psychotherapy community. Our sincerest condolences to his wife, Bonnie Bernard, and his daughter and son, Nicole and Bradley. A memorial session to celebrate Dr. Bernard's life is planned for New York during the AGPA Annual Institute and Conference at the Sheraton New York Hotel on Friday, March 9th, 6:15-7:30pm. Dr. Bernard's passing is a major loss to our community.

BARRY--Walter, 99, pioneer of affordable, rehabilitated housing for low income families passed away at 99 on Monday, February 6, 2012. He would have turned 100 in April 2012. Walter Barry was born on the Lower East Side of Manhattan in 1912 just after his mother-while pregnant with him-emigrated from Russia with his father. He began his working life in Newark as a union organizer for the Congress of Industrial Organizations (the CIO part of the modern AFL-CIO). Walter Barry, founded the Applied Housing Companies with his son Joseph in 1970 and then built thousands of units of affordable housing in Hoboken, New Jersey and other New Jersey cities throughout the 1970's. Barry among those given credit for the rebirth of the city of Hoboken. After his retirement in 1979, the company, then run by his son Joseph Barry, constructed market-rate and luxury housing throughout the state with concentration on the Hoboken and Jersey City waterfront. Today, the company, now called Ironstate, is run by Barry's grandsons, David Barry and Michael Barry, with their sister, Lisa Barry Fleisher, as a partner. They continue the tradition of urban redevelopment in New Jersey and now in New York City, as well. After his retirement, never having gone to college, he attended New York University's School of General Studies and obtained a bachelor's degree. He attended at the same time that his grandchildren were in university. He became active in various causes, including senior citizens issues. He was also much involved in the Jewish Community Center in West Orange. Walter Barry's wife, Marion, died in 1999. Walter is survived by sons Joseph (Gail) and Burt (Marilyn), three grandchildren David (Kira), Michael (Jennifer), and Lisa (Jonathan) Barry Fleisher, as well as nine great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his first cousin, the last of his generation, Molly Klopot of Brooklyn, 93 years of age. A memorial service was held Friday in Livingston at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman.

His dedication and guidance in our treatment of mentally ill adults and emotionally disturbed children will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, and his entire family. An essay on Jan. 29 about Madeleine L'Engle's science-fiction fantasy ''A Wrinkle in Time'' misstated the name of one of the book's characters, a celestial being disguised as an old woman. She is Mrs Whatsit, not Whatsis.The essay also misstated part of the title of a forthcoming biography of L'Engle by Leonard Marcus. It is ''Listening for Madeleine,'' not ''Searching for Madeleine.''

LOWE--Dr. Charles Upton. 90, of Cambridge, MA died peacefully on February 9. Pediatrician, researcher and educator, he had a long and distinguished career in academic medicine and public service. Born in Pelham, NY, in 1921 to Joseph and Edith (Rosenfield) Lowe, he attended Horace Mann and earned degrees from Harvard College (cum laude) 1942 and Yale Medical School (cum laude) 1945. After an internship at Children's Hospital, Boston, he became chief resident of pediatrics at Massachusetts General Hospital, where his research led him to discover a sex-linked metabolic disorder known as Lowe Syndrome, OCRL (oculo-cerebro-renal) syndrome. In 1948, he joined the University of Minnesota as a National Research Council Fellow and was later appointed Assistant Professor of Pediatrics. Three years later he joined the faculty of the University of Buffalo, NY, where he became Professor of Medicine and a Buswell Fellow. He spent a two-year sabbatical at the Virus Research Laboratory at Cambridge University, England. From 1965-1968, he was professor of pediatrics and director of the Human Development Center at the University of Florida, Gainesville. While there, he completed a national survey of nutrition among pre-school children and conducted studies on the modification of human metabolism in metabolic diseases. In 1968 he became the Scientific Director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, NIH, Bethesda, MD. He left NICHD to become Special Assistant for Child Health Affairs to the Assistant Secretary of Health in the Ford Administration. He returned to NICHD in 1983, and spent the rest of his career there. One project was working to develop a vaccine for Typhoid fever that took him to Nepal, where he was able to enjoy trekking in the Himalayas and carry on his life-long love of mountain climbing. Among his many contributions while at the NIH, in 1973, he was instrumental in creating an on-site child care center. During his career, Dr. Lowe was awarded many honors, contributed over 100 articles to leading medical and scientific journals, and founded the journal "Pediatric Research" for which he served as editor for 12 years. After retiring in 1994, Charles moved to Cambridge, MA, where he immersed himself in Harvard life, by auditing classes, fundraising, and serving as historian and archivist for Lowell House, his undergraduate residence. Dr. Lowe was a skilled wood worker, astute art collector, and avid gardener. He took special pride in restoration of his historic home in Woods Hole, MA that burned down in an accidental fire. In his retirement he wrote, "Time Out of Mind: An Afghan Adventure," a book about his trip through Afghanistan and India in 1954, illustrated with own photographs. Charles is survived by his beloved wife, Barbara Bitting Frazer, his four loving children, Sarah M. Lowe, (Elisabeth Smith) of Brooklyn, NY, Elizabeth E. Lowe of South Hero, VT, J. Stephen Lowe (Jane Ceraso), of Acton, MA and S. Cambria Lowe (Devin Hess) of Berkeley, CA, three treasured grandchildren Sage, Rory, and Simon, his beloved niece and nephew Ann Bookman of Brookline, MA, and Richard Bookman of Miami, FL, one great-nephew and three great-nieces, and his former wife, Eileen Josten Lowe of Brooklyn, NY. Burial is private. An announcement of a memorial service in Cambridge, MA will be forthcoming. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Partners in Health or Lowe Syndrome Association.

WERTHEIMER--Florrie. We are deeply shocked and saddened by her sudden passing. She was not only a dynamic, vibrant, and brilliant woman and lawyer; but also an adored and cherished wife and mother. Her keen intellect and quick wit will be remembered by many. Florrie lived and enjoyed her life in New York City and in France, and truly lived it her way. Her love of summers in France with her boats and cars was overshadowed only by her lifelong love for her beloved dogs. Our thoughts and hearts are with Jules, Robin, Larry, Elizabeth, Marcy, and the grandchildren she loved so much. She will truly be missed. Catherine, Fred, Christopher and Freddie.

Since joining NHL Network in July after five years at NESN, Kathryn Tappen has become one of the league's most recognizable faces. Tappen, 30, hosts the nightly highlight show ''NHL Tonight'' and is a co-host for special events, holding her own among former coaches and players like Barry Melrose and Kevin Weekes. Tappen, who grew up in Morristown, N.J., was a member of the cross-country and track teams at Rutgers, where she was an academic all-American and set a team record in the 3,000-meter steeplechase.
