ANDERSON--Edward L. Jr. 83, of La Jolla, CA, formerly of Princeton, NJ on Thursday, February 9, 2012. The cause was stomach cancer. A partner with Tweedy Browne from 1968 until 1983, Ed was an original member of "The Graham Group" with Warren Buffett and took pleasure in the group's annual gatherings and learning from each of the individuals. Ed was active in the field of behavior analysis, human sexuality and childhood education and wants to be remembered for disseminating the research based therapies of Dr. O. Ivar Lovaas for autistic children and as a co-founder of Headsprout, Inc. an education technology company that has taught hundreds of thousands of children to read and was acquired by Newell/Rubbermaid in 2011. A graduate of the University of Chicago, Ed served as President of the Alumni Association and received the University's Alumni Citation Award in 1992. Ed received his doctorate in chemistry from Washington State University in 1952 and worked for the Atomic Energy Commission prior to his investment career. Ed is survived by his partner of 34 years, Joan Elizabeth Parsons. He was predeceased by his wife, Shirley Smith Anderson and is survived by their two beloved sons, David Warren Anderson and his wife Deirdre (Cavanaugh) Anderson of Hingham, MA, Steven Bradley Anderson and his wife, Jennifer (Bork) Anderson of Davis, CA and five grandchildren. A Celebration of Ed's life will take place the weekend of July 20, 2012 at the Chautauqua Institution. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you consider donations to the Chautauqua Foundation at P.O Box 28, Chautauqua, NY 14722.

Nov. 11, 2011, Near Uyuni, BoliviaI was with my girlfriend on a three-day tour of the salt flats near Uyuni, Bolivia. It felt surreal, like we were on a different planet. Because of the vastness and unending white of the flats, I was able to create some fun optical illusions. For this shot, I set up my camera on a tripod, set the timer and stood several feet behind my girlfriend. CHRIS FEROLI, Baltimore

Yosemite National Park plans to reduce the number of permits it issues to hikers seeking to climb Half Dome peak (above), one of its most popular destinations, because of safety concerns. The move comes as a result of the park's own environmental assessment, which also suggests that the park consider removing cables that allow relatively inexperienced climbers access to the summit. The park is reducing the 400 permits it issues daily to 300 in 2013. Partly because of the cables, which were installed in 1919, tens of thousands of hikers climb the steep slope each year, leading to gridlock and safety issues, some of which have resulted in five deaths and a number of injuries in recent years, said Scott Gediman, a spokesman for Yosemite.

WEDGED between the Pacific Ocean and U.S. 101 and split by train tracks where the homeless tend to gather, the Funk Zone -- so named for its scruffy origins, rather than anything musical -- is the gritty side of manicured Santa Barbara, Calif. Originally an industrial base for the aviation and fishing industries, its warehouses and bungalows now house an assortment of surfboard shapers, boutique winemakers and artists. There have always been viable businesses in the area -- Santa Barbara Winery has aged its vintages here for decades -- but a spate of new development is transforming the district from grungy to trendy. The new Indigo Santa Barbara hotel, set to open on the edge of the Funk Zone on Feb. 14, offers a convenient base from which to explore the neighborhood on foot.ELAINE GLUSAC

I'LL never forget the first time I saw the grass at Ebbets Field. It was green. Years of viewing Brooklyn Dodgers games on a tiny black-and-white television screen and poring over newspaper photos and newsreels left me completely unprepared for the obvious: that the real-life field of dreams was a sprawling, verdant carpet punctuated by a kaleidoscope of billboards and fans wielding blue and white pennants. Charles W. Cushman's photographs have the same effect. They are a rich reminder that for all the gritty realism of black-and-white photography, 1940s and '50s New York was also resplendent in vivid color.

KABUL, Afghanistan -- Even dying is being outsourced here. This is a war where traditional military jobs, from mess hall cooks to base guards and convoy drivers, have increasingly been shifted to the private sector. Many American generals and diplomats have private contractors for their personal bodyguards. And along with the risks have come the consequences: More civilian contractors working for American companies than American soldiers died in Afghanistan last year for the first time during the war.

A sure hand, a keen eye, a witty tongue, a deeply loving heart.

LEMBERG--Louis. Interdisciplinary Stem Cell Institute and the Cardiology Division at the University of Miami honors Dr. Louis Lemberg clinical pioneer in the development of implantable "demand" heart pacemakers and in the use of beta blockers for heart attack patients also the University of Miami Medical School longest serving faculty member died at 95. He is survived by his beloved wife Miriam, devoted daughter Paula, two grandsons, and one great-grandson. Also survived by son Jerry from Colorado. Family suggests donations to the Miriam Lemberg Professorship and the Lemberg Chair at the University Of Miami Miller School Of Medicine.

GUSSACK--Manya, 87, of White Plains, NY, died February 9, 2012 in hospice and family care at the home of her daughter Lisa, surrounded by all of her family. Manya was born on November 6, 1924, in the Bronx, NY to Isidore and Esther Kanof and was a sister to George and Libby. She married Seymour Gussack in March of 1947 and they had five children by the time they moved to New Rochelle in 1960. Amy, Lisa, Faith, Nina and David were the core and center of Manya's world, and she spent much of her time in her kitchen, a furious center of constant activity, being with her children and their friends, all spinning around her kitchen table. Manya's unique ability to beguile and charm and embrace extended naturally to her daughter-in-law, Snow and to her sons-in-law Kermit, Alan, Robert and Allan. Manya first brought her family to Cape Cod, the place she grew to love more than all others, in the summer of 1959. And now the new generation, Manya's grandchildren, Adam, Sophie Rose, Benjamin, Daniel, Jonathan, Rebecca, Natasha, Jessie and Linda spend their summer vacations at "The Hive", the family house in Eastham. Manya traveled extensively, both on behalf of her husband's international business and particularly for pleasure with her great friend, Belle. Her adopted families in Japan and Israel are mourning her loss as well. Her legion of friends and admirers has grown exponentially over the years and includes three generations. She had the rare ability to walk into any room and galvanize the people there and to be constantly attuned and attentive to the lives and stories of others. In her presence no one ever felt any less than the center of the universe. Her generosity was legendary, her commitment to fun and adventure was unstoppable. And in her latter years, she and Claudette and Nicola, her loving helpers, formed a unit that was happy and fun and full of life. Manya was a true force of nature - a giving, loving, unassuming woman with wisdom and experience and most especially love, to spare and share. There's only one Manya! If you'd like to remember Manya with a charitable contribution, we would suggest two of her favorites, Beit Hatfutsot, The Museum of the Jewish People (www.bh.org.il/) and Jewish Women International (www.jwi.org). The memorial service will be at 12 noon on Sunday, the 12th at daughter Lisa's home in White Plains, NY. Shiva will begin Sunday and continue through Wednesday from 1pm-7pm daily with 7:30pm Minyan also at Lisa's home.

AARON--Roger Shaw, on February 11, 2011 Age 69. Beloved husband of Ginny, devoted father of Peter and Todd, loving father-in-law of Jessica, adoring grandfather of Nate and Will, most loving son of the indomitable Phyllis; dearly loved brother/brother-in-law of Carolyn and Elliot Ross and Pat and Ed Falkenberg. Roger grew up in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He attended Dartmouth College where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa and Magna Cum Laude, then went on to earn his MBA at Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business, graduating with High Distinction and winning the Walter A. Jacobs Memorial Award for intellectual curiosity and sound judgment. He earned his LLB from Yale Law School in 1968. He was devoted to all his schools throughout his life and reveled in the fact that both his sons chose to attend Dartmouth. For his first job as a lawyer Roger chose a small New York firm, becoming the 19th lawyer at Skadden Arps. The firm currently numbers over 1800 lawyers. An integral part of the firm's growth and management over the last 40 years, he took great pride and pleasure in the institution that Skadden has become. He loved his work, the Skadden family and his close relationship with his mentor Joe Flom. Over the decades Roger rose as a consummate dealmaker while also serving for more than 20 years as the firm's global Corporate Practice Partner, overseeing Skadden's corporate, M&A, Governance, Finance and Restructuring practices. He was a senior member of the firm's Policy Committee as well as a frequent lecturer and panelist. Throughout his career he served on a number of non-profit boards, including Burke Rehabilitation Hospital, The Legal Aid Society, the New York branches of Teach for America and The American Jewish Committee, and was a co-chair of Mt Sinai Hospital's Crystal Ball. He chaired the Yale Law School Fund and was an original member of Dartmouth's President's Leadership Council. He loved skiing, fishing, biking in Aspen and sharing all these activities with his family and friends. Roger Aaron lived his life fully and with great dedication to the things he believed in. He fought his battle with cancer bravely and privately with the help of talented and extremely caring doctors and nurses. Roger was a source of wise counsel and support for a vast network of family, friends and acquaintances. His tremendous generosity, sharp intellect and thoughtful leadership will be dearly missed. Services will be held on Tuesday, February 14 at 11am, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to Mount Sinai Hospital School of Medicine (www.mssm.edu).

Many individuals have written books about New York City's past. In a new one, dozens of authors, anonymous and known, dead and alive, collaborate to tell the tale. ''New York Diaries,'' edited by Teresa Carpenter, draws together diary entries, official records and even datebook jottings spanning 400 years and weaves them into a rich and unusual history of the city. What the widely acclaimed book does not provide is a look at the original documents. Working with Ms. Carpenter's publisher, City Room has gathered images of some of them for viewing online.

Since last June, there have been four major rebellions followed by a series of government crackdowns. According to Joseph Holliday, an analyst at the Institute for the Study of War, a growing number of military defections, partly caused by sectarian divisions, is increasing the violence. The army's rank and file is largely Sunni, like most of the population, while its leadership is mainly Alawite, the minority group of President Bashar al-Assad. 1. JUNE 2011 JISR AL-SHOUGHOUR

An article on Jan. 29 about former Olympic stars who are trying to make comebacks for this year's Games misidentified one event at the Seoul Olympics in which the American swimmer Janet Evans won a gold medal. And a correction in this space last Sunday misstated the year those Games were held. It was in 1988, not 1998, that Evans won the 400-meter individual medley -- not the 1,500-meter freestyle, an event that does not exist for women. (She also won the 400- and 800-meter freestyle.)

A caption for nine photographs on Jan. 29 with the cover article about short winter family getaways misidentified the location of the photograph showing a couple in the water sharing a quiet moment by a waterfall. The photograph, at the far right of the second row, was taken in Guanacaste. (That description should not have been with the first row of pictures, all of which were correctly identified.) And another picture caption with a continuation of the article misspelled part of the name of a hotel and gave the incorrect age for Tristan Toledo, shown with his parents and playing at the kids' club at the hotel. It is the Fontainebleau Miami Beach, not Fontainebleu Miami Beach, and Tristan is 3 1/2, not 4.

The N.H.L. trade deadline is 3 p.m. Eastern on Feb. 27, but if form holds, the really big deals will happen in the days and weeks leading to it. Last season, the trades got going Feb. 9, when Toronto picked up forward Joffrey Lupul from Anaheim for defenseman Francois Beauchemin. A few days later, the Boston Bruins acquired some keys to their title run: forwards Chris Kelly from Ottawa and Rich Peverley from Atlanta, and defenseman Tomas Kaberle from Toronto. The Bruins were loading up for a shot at the Stanley Cup; all their trading partners considered themselves out of playoff contention and were looking to the future.

PLAUT--Rabbi W. Gunther The Central Conference of American Rabbis records with deep sadness the death of Rabbi W. Gunther Plaut, our beloved past President from 1983-1985, who served with distinction pulpits in Chicago, St. Paul and Toronto's Holy Blossom Temple. He was the primary author of "The Torah: A Modern Commentary." Rabbi Plaut will be remembered for his wisdom, leadership and integrity. May God comfort his family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and may his memory be for eternal blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein, President Rabbi Steven Fox, Chief Executive

Loving nana of Julie, Steven, Allison, Taylor and Daniel. Funeral services Sunday, February 12 at 9:30am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Contributions in her memory can be made to The Feinstein Institute for Medical Research, Manhasset, NY.

''OH yes, this shoe was specially made for Anna Piaggi in the '70s, and this one for J. Lo when she was still Jenny on the block, and Rihanna just bought a heap of those so they must be coming back,'' Manolo Blahnik said, referring, respectively, to the striped cutout sandals and the lace-up Timberland-like boots that will soon be available again as part of a tribute exhibition at Lane Crawford in Hong Kong. Through March, in celebration of Mr. Blahnik's 40th anniversary, 10 well-known styles -- this Alexander Calder-inspired flat called Tuberose, from 1981, among them -- will be sold in a gallery shop filled with Manolo memorabilia. ''I don't know years when it comes to my archives,'' Mr. Blahnik said. ''For me, they each have a special time and place, but in fashion they're always now.'' Manolo Blahnik flats, $1,285 exclusively at Lane Crawford, starting Tuesday. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

KIM GORDON, a woman who spent the last 30 years crisscrossing the country in a tour bus as the bassist for Sonic Youth, wanted the capsule collection that she has designed with the French brand Surface to Air to do two very specific things: mix and match, and fit in the overhead compartment of a bus. ''You can't pack that much for the road, and I've always liked the idea of not dressing up for a performance,'' she said. Made of basics that pair easily with one another, the 12-piece collection features cropped neon-tangerine pants (''a good, bright color to wear on stage,'' she said), a soft leather jacket and T-shirts printed with Ms. Gordon's own illustrations. Her favorite item: a silk tank dress with a digital shattered-glass print. ''It's open with slits down the sides,'' she said. ''It's a little narrow and sexy, but you can move your arms, do what you need to do. Girls are going to like that.'' We have no doubt. Surface to Air x Kim Gordon dress, $415. Go to surfacetoair.com. ALEX FRANK

A picture on Jan. 29 with a review of ''Elizabeth the Queen,'' by Sally Bedell Smith, was printed in mirror image. The picture, of Princess Elizabeth in Buckingham Palace in 1946, before she became Queen Elizabeth II, should have shown her sitting to the right of her desk and holding a pen in her right hand. (The reversed image was distributed by Getty Images.)

LEVIN--Dr. Stephen M. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and long-time colleague, Stephen M. Levin, MD, Clinical Professor of the Department of Preventive Medicine of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and Co-Medical Director of the Mount Sinai-Irving J. Selikoff Center for Occupational and Environmental Medicine. Dr. Levin has been a respected member of the Mount Sinai Medical Center for many years and his contributions not only to our organization but to the occupational health community in general are immeasurable. Dr. Levin was what many of us strive to be in occupational medicine: A fierce advocate on behalf of workers and a dedicated, compassionate and gifted physician. He imparted these qualities to the many fellows, residents and medical students whom he taught and mentored. His tireless advocacy for and work with sufferers of asbestos related diseases, WTC related illnesses, and other occupational/environmental conditions was inspiring. Dr. Levin will be remembered for his many contributions in occupational and environmental medicine, including, but not limited to his pioneering work in asbestos related diseases in Libby, MT. His advocacy and unrelenting dedication to thousands of World Trade Center responders who continue to receive health care at Mount Sinai and other clinical centers to this day and his ongoing commitment to promoting worker safety and health not only) in New York State, but on the world stage. Our community was made far better by his presence and his loss will be deeply felt by many. He will be remembered worldwide for his fight against asbestos related diseases, WTC related illnesses, and other occupational/environmental conditions. The Mount Sinai family extends heart-felt condolences to Dr. Levin's loved ones. We are planning to hold a memorial service on Tuesday, February 21, 2012 at 4pm at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine's Stern Auditorium, 1468 Madison Avenue (at E. 100th Street), New York, NY 10029.

PEAKE--Junius W. (Jay), University of Northern Colorado (UNC) Kenneth W. Monfort College of Business Professor of Finance Emeritus and Wall Street visionary, died on January 27, 2012 in Greeley, CO at the age of 80. Jay, an expert in the microstructure of financial markets, led a lifelong quest to improve trading and settlement on Wall Street. In 1976, he proposed screen-based trading, consolidated bids and offers, and minimal price increments in decimals. Following his storied Wall Street career, he taught finance for 14 years at UNC's Monfort School of Business. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Jay Peake Scholarship Fund; c/o University of Northern Colorado Foundation, Campus Box 20, Greeley, CO 80639.

FOR all the icy demeanors on the front row and the oft-repeated rumors of rivalries among editors, fashion insiders are for the most part a tight-knit bunch. ''It's love-hate, it's like a family,'' said Carole Sabas, the New York correspondent for French Vogue. ''They have their fallouts, but nothing is irremediable. It changes each season -- even friendships.''

Designers show clothes during Fashion Week that are often conventional, in hopes of dressing the contemporary woman and pleasing retail buyers. But there is another, rarer side of fashion, when creative minds allow the art world and other influences to enter into their process. There is a rare opportunity to see this play out on the streets of New York. Here are four spectacular examples of people who dress with uncorralled abandon. For them, everything is possible. Many times it's the Eastern and African aesthetic of wrapping, folding or tying cloth on the body, not Western-style tailoring. 1.Louise Doktor, who works at a banking firm, wears a comforter coat, chosen for its color and fabric. 2. A skirt worn as a cape. 3. Two coats buttoned together for the colors, the extra sleeves tied over the shoulder. 4. A sequined curtain as a scarf. 5. On Fifth Avenue, the artist Timothy John wears a bathmat as a jacket, attracted by the nubbly texture. 6. An Indian carpet stitched on both ends and worn vertically one day and horizontally the next. 7. A wall hanging worn as a shawl. 8.Marjorie Stern, a fashion collector, is especially fond of fringe, as her scarves also show. 9. A group that included the fashion consultant Tziporah Salamon (at right). 10. In August, Ms. Salamon wore a lacy jacket and dropped-crotch trousers. Two others liked the lace jackets, too. 11. Tying together 99-cent scarves from the Salvation Army. 12 to 14. Mr. John's collection of jade worn as pendants. 15 and 16. Ms. Salamon's Bakelite bracelets.

LEVIN--Stephen. The New York State September 11th Worker Protection Taskforce and the World Trade Center Responders' Steering Committee acknowledge with sadness the passing of one of their most thoughtful and effective members: Stephen M. Levin, MD. Steve's encyclopedic knowledge of Occupational Medicine and the consequences of World Trade Center exposure in particular, his passionate advocacy, and his consensus building ability contributed greatly and immeasurably helped to shape both bodies' deliberations. We will miss him and extend condolences to his family.

ALBERTO ALESSI, the managing director of Alessi, the Italian manufacturer of high-design objects for the home, must have caffeine in his blood. His paternal grandfather, Giovanni Alessi, founded the company in 1921, making metal products like trays, cruet holders and coffee pots. His maternal grandfather, Alfonso Bialetti, invented and produced the first stovetop espresso pot, the Bialetti Moka Express, in the 1930s. The octagonal aluminum coffee maker became -- and remains -- an Italian kitchen staple and a cultural icon. Last year, Alessi, which produces a number of stovetop espresso pots in stainless steel, brought out an aluminum pot, the Moka Alessi, designed by Alessandro Mendini as a tribute to grandfather Bialetti (and a more affordable alternative to its stainless steel models). Soon (in late March), in addition to the three- and six-cup versions, Moka Alessi will be available in the one-cup version ($42) shown here. It'll be great for those of us who are trying to keep our coffee intake to a minimum in the morning. And its diminutive, toylike proportions should prove irresistible. PILAR VILADAS

WHEN I got into a cab the other morning and told the driver, ''Lincoln Center, please,'' he sort of floored me with his reply. ''You want the fashion shows?'' Actually, I want a week on a deserted island. But a crack like that would have just produced a pair of bloodshot eyes in the rearview and a big fat, ''Huh?'' The guy was perceptive, though. I was on my way to my first show of New York Fashion Week -- ta-da! -- so, I guess that's what I wanted.

BAKST--Alvin Aaron. June 7, 1923 December 31, 2011. The Bakst family and friends are bereaved by the passing of beloved Incline Village, NV and Rancho Mirage, CA thoracic and cardiovascular surgeon, Dr. Alvin A. Bakst, M.D. in the early morning hours of December 31, 2011. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, Alvin Bakst graduated from New York University in 1942 and the New York University Medical College in 1944 before serving in the United States Navy from September 1944 through October 1946 as a Rank Lt. (j.g.) Regimental Surgeon, Fleet Marine Force, Seventh Service Regiment FMF Pac. Dr. Bakst was Chief of Pediatric Cardiac Surgery, Chief of Vascular, Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery at Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital of NY, Chief of Thoracic and Vascular Surgery at Metropolitan Hospital, NY, Director of Cardiovascular and Thoracic Surgery at Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn, NY, Chief of Surgery and Vascular Surgery at John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital, Indio. He was Full Professor of Surgery and Professor of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery, Surgeon in Chief (Cardiac Unit), at New York Medical College, Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital. Dr. Bakst was one of the pioneers in open heart surgery in the 1960's and '70's, and traveled with a team of doctors and nurses to perform the first open heart surgeries in Chile in 1962. He was also a pioneer in pediatric open heart surgery and invented a finger scalpel to facilitate open heart surgery on infants. He created and developed a line of magnet therapy products, including a patented back belt, which he marketed and sold through his Dr. Bakst Magnetics company. He was also the author of "the Cave Man Syndrome, The Evolution of Man's Nutritional Needs", 2010, and an extensive list of many other medical publications. Dr. Bakst was a man of great strength and character and was loved and greatly admired by all who knew him. He was also a philanthropic man who supported many charities. Alvin Bakst is survived by his devoted wife of fifty-eight years, Ellen Bakst, his loving children Sheryl and Stuart Meddin, Peter and Anna Bakst, Kenneth and Suzanne Bakst, Trish Bakst, and Evan and Dina Bakst, and twelve adoring grandchildren. There was a funeral to celebrate the life of Alvin Aaron Bakst on January 2, 2012 at the Forest Lawn Cemetery in Cathedral City, CA.

AARON--Roger. With broken hearts, we mourn the passing of our beloved brother-in-law and uncle. Dear friend since college, font of wisdom, pillar of strength and integrity, brilliant attorney, generous contributor to the community, and steadfast champion of our family. "Uncle Rog" was always there to share our joyous times, extend support wherever needed. How we will miss his greeting, "How are the Falkies?" Our love and open arms to Ginny, whose loss is infinite, his adoring wife of 45 years and tirelessly devoted companion during his courageous battle with illness; to Peter, Todd and Jessica, Nate and Will, Phyllis, Carolyn and Elliot. He touched and inspired so many. His like will not be seen again soon. He will be sorely missed by so many who loved him and especially by us. Rest in peace. The Falkenberg and Mahan family

SCHLANG--David, suddenly on February 9. Our best traveling companion. We will always remember the laughter and the love. Our hearts go out to Matti, Lisa, Julie, and all the family. Cheryl and Bill Hurwitz

GROSS--Charles M.,born in Brooklyn, New York, April, 1932, passed away Saturday morning, February 4, 2012. Son of Nathan and Beatrice; beloved husband of Dr. Rosa B. Ament; father of Kenneth, Karen, Benjamin, and Lauren; father-in-law of Jim and Cherry; grandfather of Adam, Emma, and Ian; great-grandfather of Mia and Madelyn; brother of Martha Weisenhoff; uncle of Richard, Anne, Scott and Sandra; and loyal companion of Sasha. Charles, a talented mechanical engineer retired from Pitney Bowes and served as a consultant for Synectic Medical Products Development and Manufacturing, both located in Connecticut. Charles served in the Military and was an avid skier and photographer. Charlie was a loyal friend who was loved and will be missed. Contributions may be sent in Charlie's name to the Lustgarten Foundation for pancreatic cancer research www.lustgartenfoundation.org.

By my count, there are three main arguments in favor of weak campaign finance rules: Money is speech (so it's unconstitutional to constrain it), money is information (meaning it enables communication with voters, and less money would result in less communication), and money is a signal. By "signal" I mean that a candidate's ability to raise funds indicates whether he has mass appeal, and allows the electorate to gauge the enthusiasm of his backers.

According to the makeup artist Diane Kendal, Thakoon Panichgul really wanted to see lips this season. "A little more sophistication and glamour," said Kendal of the designer's directive, a departure from much of what's been seen so far this season. Kendal translated this into a bright mouth using Nars Heat Wave lipstick set with neon pink pigment, creating an effect that was both "luminous and matte." The rest of the face was kept simple without mascara, only Nars Undressed Multiple spread over the cheekbones, temple, even eyelids, all in an effort to channel a modern Audrey Hepburn.

In his new budget blueprint, President Obama is proposing to tax dividends of the wealthiest taxpayers as ordinary income subject to their top income-tax rate, which was the practice until the Bush administration lowered the rates. The reconstruction of the fishing town of Onagawa, Japan, and the rest of the coast where the tsunami struck last March is a preview of what may be the most critical test that the country will face in the decades ahead: In a country where power rests disproportionately among older people, how does rapidly aging Japan use its dwindling resources to build a society that looks to the future as much as to the past? The evolving debate over the shape of Onagawa's reconstruction underscores how older Japanese, more attached to their land and customs, are wielding disproportionate influence with local governments and hindering Tokyo's stated goal of creating long-term sustainable communities. ''The Walking Dead'' series has been a dominating presence on our graphic books best-seller lists for some time - the most recent trade paperback, Vol. 15, is still No. 1 on that list for this week - but where some of the money from its sales should go is now in dispute. The series writer and creator Robert Kirkman's original collaborator, the artist Tony Moore, filed a lawsuit in Los Angeles Superior Court on Thursday. Mr. Moore claims that Mr. Kirkman has not shared the previously agreed-upon amount of royalty or other payments for the properties they created together, which include ''The Walking Dead,'' ''Brit'' and ''Battle Pope.'' The complaint also alleges that, in 2005, Mr. Kirkman fraudulently persuaded Mr. Moore to assign his rights over to a limited liability corporation controlled by Mr. Kirkman, and that he has not provided access to profit statements for the properties. ''The lawsuit is ridiculous,'' Mr. Kirkman said. ''We each had legal representation seven years ago, and now he is violating the same contract he initiated and approved, and he wants to misrepresent the fees he was paid and continues to be paid for the work he was hired to do. Tony regularly receives payment for the work he did as penciler, inker and for gray tones on the first six issues of 'The Walking Dead' comic series, and he receives royalties for the TV show. To assert otherwise is simply incorrect.''

HALPERN--Cecilia Calderon, age 92, of Manhattan, died February 5, 2012. A graduate of The Spence School, she attended Sarah Lawrence College, Columbia University and the New York School of Interior Design. Married to the late John Michael Halpern for 69 years, she is survived by her children Cecilia Halpern Morgan and John Halpern Jr., five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A woman of remarkable beauty and keen intelligence, she was convivial, beguiling and utterly charming, considerate and kind to all who knew her.

Officials of Ellis Island estimate that as many as one in three Americans can trace their ancestry to immigrants who landed there from overseas. Now, the officials are focusing on the other roughly 200 million newcomers who arrived in the United States before Ellis Island opened its doors or after it stopped becoming a portal for immigrants. The national historic site in New York Harbor is halfway through a transformation into a more inclusive National Museum of Immigration.

AARON--Roger Shaw, on February 11, 2011 Age 69. Beloved husband of Ginny, devoted father of Peter and Todd, loving father-in-law of Jessica, adoring grandfather of Nate and Will, most loving son of the indomitable Phyllis; dearly loved brother/brother-in-law of Carolyn and Elliot Ross and Pat and Ed Falkenberg. Roger grew up in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He attended Dartmouth College where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa and Magna Cum Laude, then went on to earn his MBA at Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business, graduating with High Distinction and winning the Walter A. Jacobs Memorial Award for intellectual curiosity and sound judgment. He earned his LLB from Yale Law School in 1968. He was devoted to all his schools throughout his life and reveled in the fact that both his sons chose to attend Dartmouth. For his first job as a lawyer Roger chose a small New York firm, becoming the 19th lawyer at Skadden Arps. The firm currently numbers over 1800 lawyers. An integral part of the firm's growth and management over the last 40 years, he took great pride and pleasure in the institution that Skadden has become. He loved his work, the Skadden family and his close relationship with his mentor Joe Flom. Over the decades Roger rose as a consummate dealmaker while also serving for more than 20 years as the firm's global Corporate Practice Partner, overseeing Skadden's corporate, M&A, Governance, Finance and Restructuring practices. He was a senior member of the firm's Policy Committee as well as a frequent lecturer and panelist. Throughout his career he served on a number of non-profit boards, including Burke Rehabilitation Hospital, The Legal Aid Society, the New York branches of Teach for America and The American Jewish Committee, and was a co-chair of Mt Sinai Hospital's Crystal Ball. He chaired the Yale Law School Fund and was an original member of Dartmouth's President's Leadership Council. He loved skiing, fishing, biking in Aspen and sharing all these activities with his family and friends. Roger Aaron lived his life fully and with great dedication to the things he believed in. He fought his battle with cancer bravely and privately with the help of talented and extremely caring doctors and nurses. Roger was a source of wise counsel and support for a vast network of family, friends and acquaintances. His tremendous generosity, sharp intellect and thoughtful leadership will be dearly missed. Services will be held on Tuesday, February 14 at 11am, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to Mount Sinai Hospital School of Medicine (www.mssm.edu).

GOLDSMITH--Juliet Kittenplan, beloved wife, sister, aunt, mother and grandmother passed away peacefully on Sunday, February 12 surrounded by her loving family. She was 75. Juliet was born and raised in Scarsdale, NY where she attended Fox Meadow Elementary School and graduated from Scarsdale High School in 1954. Juliet was a graduate of Smith College in 1958. She worked for 25 years as the Director of Public Relations at Weill Cornell Hospital - White Plains Campus. Juliet served as a board member of the Scarsdale Adult School for over 35 years. The lifelong friendships she enjoyed, and her love of the arts and travel which she shared with everyone will be a blessed memory. Juliet is survived by her loving husband of 50 years Bobby, brother Stephen Kittenplan (Gail), son Richard (Linda) and daughter Gillian Rittmaster (Peter) and cherished grandchildren Davis, William, Holly, Samantha and Graham. Funeral service on Tuesday, February 14 at 12:00 Noon, Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

An article on Wednesday about India's renewed efforts to attract foreign investment misstated the name of the organization that hosted a recent address by India's finance minister, Pranab Mukherjee, to American executives. It is the Chicago Council on Global Affairs, not the World Affairs Council of Chicago.

Last week, Arun Thampi, a programmer in Singapore, discovered that the mobile social network Path was surreptitiously copying address book information from users' iPhones without notifying them. David Morin, Path's voluble chief executive, quickly commented on Mr. Thampi's blog that Path's actions were an ''industry best practice.'' He then became uncharacteristically quiet as the Internet disagreed and erupted in outrage. Amid his silence, he did take the time to reply to the actress Alyssa Milano, who was one of hundreds who questioned Path's practices. (His reply to her via Twitter contained his personal e-mail address.)

Whitney Houston, the multimillion-selling singer who emerged in the 1980s as one of her generation's greatest R&B voices only to deteriorate through years of cocaine use and an abusive marriage, died on Saturday in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 48. Her death came as the music industry descended on Los Angeles for the annual celebration of the Grammy Awards. She was to have attended a pre-Grammy party Saturday night being hosted by Clive Davis, the founder of Arista Records, who had been her pop mentor.

Research in Motion can't catch a break. Joining the large crop of businesses and organizations dropping the BlackBerry, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration plans to provide employees with Apple's iPhones and iPads instead. The government agency, based in Washington, cited the steep cost of Research in Motion's software, which is used to secure and manage BlackBerry devices, as the primary reason for the switch, which was first reported Thursday by The Loop. The agency has distributed about 3,000 BlackBerry devices among 20,000 workers, and plans to move to the Apple devices beginning in May.

BROWN--Jean F.,died on Saturday, February 11, 2012 in Queens, NY after a brief illness. Born on February 2, 1918 in Williamsburg, she lived most of her life in Brooklyn but recently resided in Queens. A petite and feisty woman, she raised three children and worked many years at Bankers Trust Company. Her daughter Rosalind Innucci (Nunzio, Sr.), son Angelo Torre (Doreen) and daughter-in-law Linda Brown survive her. Her son, Robert Brown, pre-deceased her. Her grandchildren are Jean Innucci (John Shea), Nunzio Innucci, Jr. (Nina) and Toni Lynn Brown. Her great-grandchildren are Alexandria, Carla and Gianna Innucci. Her grandson, Louis Innucci, pre-deceased her. She was greatly loved and will be sorely missed by her family and many friends.

9:30 A.M. (Flix) THE PREACHER'S WIFE (1996) Denzel Washington, above, plays a trench-coat-and-fedora-clad angel who enters the lives of an urban minister (Courtney B. Vance) facing bankruptcy and the possible demolition of his church, and his neglected wife (Whitney Houston), who also directs the choir, in this update of the 1947 comedy ''The Bishop's Wife,'' starring Cary Grant, David Niven and Loretta Young. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said Ms. Houston, who died on Saturday, ''barely has to act to bring a gritty nobility to the title role of Penny Marshall's sweetly uplifting film.'' All she has to do, he added, ''is sing, and you begin to believe in angels, miracles, happily ever after and all the other corny items that this inspirational comedy spills across the holiday table.'' Among the movie's highlights are Ms. Houston singing gospel with the Georgia Mass Choir and her pop ballad ''I Believe in You and Me.'' Hans Zimmer earned an Oscar nomination for best musical score. 8 P.M. (CW) GOSSIP GIRL Blair (Leighton Meester) plays Cupid and shoots her arrow in the direction of Dan (Penn Badgley, below, with Ms. Meester) and Serena (Blake Lively). Nate (Chace Crawford) finds Lola (Ella Rae Peck) harder and harder to resist, but the feeling may not be mutual. And Georgina (Michelle Trachtenberg) crashes a Valentine's Day party. The band St. Vincent performs. In ''Hart of Dixie,'' at 9, Wade (Wilson Bethel) has Lemon (Jaime King) disguise herself. And George (Scott Porter) asks Zoe (Rachel Bilson) for her medical expertise.

HARPER--Philip Rathbun. 1926 - 2012, beloved friend, former actor, teacher, writer and world traveler, died peacefully after a long illness at his home in Little Compton, Rhode Island, February 9, 2012, at the age of 85. Philip Rathbun Harper was born in Denver, CO. His father, Heber R. Harper, was serving at that time as Chancellor of University of Denver. Phil enlisted in the Navy at age 17 and served until the end of World War II aboard the USS Alabama. After the war on the GI Bill, Phil completed his undergraduate degree at Harvard College and later attended Harvard Law School. Phil worked as a schoolteacher and as a writer for Art World magazine. He studied acting with Sandra Seacat and performed onstage and in such films as Woody Allen's Hannah and Her Sisters and Martin Scorsese's New York Stories, opposite Nick Nolte. Phil maintained a home in New York and traveled widely, cultivating his sense of adventure, his rich and varied friendships and his love of the visual and performing arts. He was an avid squash player and member of the Racquet and Tennis Club for over 50 years. Phil was a lifelong summer resident of Little Compton, as was his mother, the former Rachel Rathbun. Phil is survived by his spouse, Gregory DeJean; his niece Pam Bakal; his nephew Doug Brownlow; and four godchildren. His marriage to the former Jean Boyle ended in divorce. She and her two daughters, Ann and Mia Boyle also survived him. Phil's two younger brothers, David and Reese, predeceased him. A private memorial service will take place in Little Compton, RI, when the roses are in bloom. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hetrick-Martin Institute, 2 Astor Place, New York, NY 10003.

An article on Friday about a rash of tuba thefts from schools in Southern California referred incorrectly to the size of a sousaphone, a type of tuba also being taken. While the sousaphone has a different shape from a tuba, it is not considered a ''smaller tuba.'' The article also misspelled the name of the university in Texas where J.D. Salas teaches tuba. It is Stephen F. Austin State University, not Steven F. Austin State University.

All sorts of merchants, but particularly booksellers, were infuriated by Amazon's effort before the holidays to use real-world shops as showrooms for people to check out items before ordering them more cheaply online. The retailer's refusal to collect sales tax in many states is a persistent grievance. Independent booksellers have even been forced into the novel position of hoping that their onetime foe, Barnes & Noble, survives so that it can serve as a bulwark against Amazon. Publishers, if anything, are more fearful than booksellers. From Amazon's point of view, it does not want to destroy the book business but simply to reinvent it. (Amazon declined to comment.)

AARON--Roger S. The partners of Peter J. Solomon Company mourn the loss of their valued friend, trusted advisor and enthusiastic golfing companion. We extend our deepest sympathy to Roger's wife Ginny, his entire family and the partners and members of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher and Flom.

SAYPOL--Marilyn. Beloved wife of the late Eugene. Devoted mother of John L. and Robert J. Cherished grandmother of Scott, Ariel and Madison. The friendship, comfort, joy and laughter she brought to so many will be remembered forever. Funeral services Tuesday, 10am at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 7500 N. State Rd. 7, Boca Raton, FL.

WEINBERG--Julius, October 6, 1929 - February 9, 2012. Former owner of Crouch and Fitzgerald Corp., a fine luggage store in New York City since 1839. He was devoted to his wife, Arlene, for 62 years, a loving father, grandfather and great-grandfather and a wonderful friend to many. He will be deeply missed.

When MySpace changed ownership last June, it was in free fall. MySpace, the pioneering social media and music site, which at its peak in 2008 was attracting 75.9 million unique visitors a month, was down to about 33 million, according to comScore, and it was bleeding users every month. Tim and Chris Vanderhook, the young investors who bought the site for $35 million from News Corporation - which paid $580 million for it in 2005 - have since been trying to reinvent MySpace, emphasizing its role as a music and entertainment hub. And they finally have some numbers to brag about.

Trinity Wall Street's announcement in January that it was suspending its vaunted music program, to reassess its place in the ministry and examine alternative sources of financing, shocked many music lovers in New York, parishioners or not. But the church held out promise that, thanks to several special donations, its centerpiece afternoon series - Bach at One, featuring the acclaimed Trinity Choir and Trinity Baroque Orchestra, directed by Julian Wachner - would return for a Lenten series in March. Those concerts - rudimentary hourlong services, actually, generally built around Bach cantatas and including brief prayers and poetry readings - will indeed return, Trinity, an Episcopal church, confirmed on Sunday, as part of what Mr. Wachner calls in a statement a ''redefined programmatic vision'' for music and the arts at Trinity. Bach at One will run on Mondays from March 5 through May 7 and will also include a performance of Bach's ''St. John Passion'' on Palm Sunday, April 1, presented ''in its original liturgical context,'' the church says, ''complete with sermon and congregational participation.''

HORN--Douglas S. Passed away February 10, 2012, of Boca Raton, FL formerly of North Woodmere. Loving husband of Maddy. Adored father of Laurence, Steven and Caroline Horn, Helene and Mark Krauss. Cherished grandfather of Bari, Sloane, Lauren, Matthew, Jordan and Alex. Services, Monday 3pm at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn. For details Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

INTERACTIVE A timeline charts the full course of the conflict that began last June. AARON--Roger. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the death of our partner Roger S. Aaron, who passed away on Saturday, February 11, 2012 following an illness. Mr. Aaron was 69 years old. He joined Skadden as a summer associate in 1967 and returned as a full-time associate in 1968. Mr. Aaron was promoted to partner in 1975 and rapidly became one of the proteges groomed by Joe Flom to succeed him in leading the firm. He served as the head of the firm's corporate practice for more than two decades and played a leading role on many of the firm's management committees. Mr. Aaron not only preserved the legacy with which he was entrusted, but also played a vital role in the global development of the firm. Skadden would not have become the firm that it is today without Roger Aaron. He helped shape our firm culture and was dedicated not only to his clients and the work, but equally to the firm. Over the years, Mr. Aaron led many of the most significant corporate transactions for the world's largest corporations, including XTO Energy, Compaq Computer, General Motors, Mobil Oil, Univision, U.S. Steel, Pfizer, Time Warner, Daimler and Alcatel. Mr. Aaron graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College in 1964 and received an MBA with high distinction from Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business Administration in 1965. He graduated from Yale Law School in 1968. He has been recognized as a top attorney by such publications as Chambers Global, Chambers USA, The Best Lawyers in America and International Financial Law Review 1000. Who's Who Legal called Mr. Aaron the "dean of the Bar." In addition to his leadership role at the firm and in his field, Mr. Aaron was an active supporter, fundraiser and contributor to his alma maters Dartmouth College and Yale Law School. He served on the boards of directors of the American Jewish Committee, the Burke Rehabilitation Center, the Legal Aid Society, the Rockefeller Center at Dartmouth College, and Teach for America. Mr. Aaron is survived by his wife Virginia (Ginny), sons Peter and Todd, mother Phyllis, sister Caroline, daughter-in-law Jessica and grandsons Nate and Will.

On Monday, after close to 200 performances, the monologuist Mike Daisey, above, will release a theatrical transcript of his latest one-man show, ''The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,'' through his Web site, mikedaisey.blogspot.com. It will be free to download and in a unique twist, if an aspiring performer should want to mount a production of the show, Mr. Daisey will not ask for monetary compensation. ''The monologue will be released as a PDF, and it comes with very open licenses and you can perform it forever, without paying royalties, wherever you want,'' Mr. Daisey said in a telephone interview. The decision comes from his desire to connect with other theater artists and to help organizations who have inquired about the show and want to adapt the work, which describes his trip to Shenzhen, China, and his meetings with factory workers, including those who make Apple products at Foxconn. Mr. Daisey also said he felt that there was no need to stick to the monologue format and that future performers would be free to use the script in any form they choose, even going so far as to suggest an opera adaptation. He did say that the file would come with a few requests, however, like, ''It would be nice if you let me know where it is happening.'' This does not mean that Mr. Daisey will no longer perform the material after his current engagement at the Public Theater ends on March 4. A short run in Britain is planned for the spring. He also hopes that the free transcript would bring the monologue to another destination: ''I have not managed to get this show to Broadway, but if someone else wants to try, more power to them.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

A dance review on Tuesday about Alexei Ratmansky's ''Don Quixote,'' performed by Pacific Northwest Ballet in Seattle, misstated the surname of the company's ballet master, who plays the title role in some performances. He is Otto Neubert, not Neuber.

DIX--Robert Knight (Bob), January 16 in Redding, CT. Born in Gallatin MO in 1917, he held a Chem. Eng. doctorate from M.I.T. He retired as Sr. Vice President of Exxon Chemical Co. in 1977 to devote time to musical composition. After the death of his wife Mary Murphy Dix he married Marie S. Goff. He is survived by Marie S. Dix, by his children, grand-children and greatgrand-children. A musical celebration will be held in spring. Contact via: www.rkdixmusic.com

As President Obama shifts more fully into campaign mode, he faces the increasingly difficult task of balancing his policy duties as president with his political imperatives as a candidate. The week ahead will test his ability to manage those two roles as the White House and his campaign advisers juggle fund-raising, legislative maneuvering and continuing controversy over health care and religious freedom.

ASLANI-FAR--Abbas (Abby), On February 11, 2012, age 78. Beloved husband of Afsar, devoted father of Adel and Aslan, loving father-in-law of Patricia and Trhea, adoring grandfather of Audrey, Amelia and Phoebe, dearly beloved brother of Aghdas Meshki, Aki Khalili, Mimi Khosrowshahi and Eran Far. Abby grew up in Tehran, Iran and graduated from the University of Tehran School of Medicine. He first came to the United States in 1963 to pursue his medical training, ultimately serving as Chief Resident in Obstetrics and Gynecology at New York University's Bellevue Medical Center. After practicing medicine in Iran briefly following his US training, he moved his family to the United States permanently in 1975, ultimately settling in Ormond Beach, Florida and opening a private medical practice in neighboring Daytona Beach, where he served for nearly 30 years on the staff of Halifax Hospital Medical Center, including a tenure as Chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology. Services will be held on Tuesday, February 14 at 10:30am, at The Woolworth Chapel at The Woodlawn Cemetery, Webster Avenue and East 233rd Street, Bronx, NY. Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in New York City (212-288-3500) is in charge of services.

One of the senior deal-makers at Goldman Sachs is preparing to retire, according to people briefed on the matter, joining a growing number of high-level executives who have left the Wall Street bank in recent months. The retirement of George N. Mattson, a partner and a head of Goldman's global industrials group, may be announced as soon as Monday, these people said. He is regarded as a top producer, with a client list that includes General Motors, General Electric, the United Parcel Service and Caterpillar.

In recent years, the private equity industry has escaped much of the regulatory scrutiny that has been directed toward hedge funds and Wall Street banks. But that appears to be changing. The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a broad examination of the private equity industry, seeking information about the business practices of some of the country's most powerful financial firms.

The Books of The Times review on Tuesday, about ''Autumn in the Heavenly Kingdom: China, the West, and the Epic Story of the Taiping Civil War,'' by Stephen R. Platt, misquoted part of a passage from the book. The passage mentioned Zeng Guofan, a general on the side of the Qing dynasty, not ''General Guofan.'' Guofan was Zeng's given name.

Roger was a true friend and supporter of the work of our agency. Nac extends our deepest sympathy to the Aaron family. Robert Friedman, President Arlene Goldsmith, Executive Director New Alternatives for Children

AARON--Roger. With broken hearts, we mourn the passing of our beloved brother-in-law and uncle. Dear friend since college, font of wisdom, pillar of strength and integrity, brilliant attorney, generous contributor to the community, and steadfast champion of our family. "Uncle Rog" was always there to share our joyous times, extend support wherever needed. How we will miss his greeting, "How are the Falkies?" Our love and open arms to Ginny, whose loss is infinite, his adoring wife of 45 years and tirelessly devoted companion during his courageous battle with illness; to Peter, Todd and Jessica, Nate and Will, Phyllis, Carolyn and Elliot. He touched and inspired so many. His like will not be seen again soon. He will be sorely missed by so many who loved him and especially by us. Rest in peace. The Falkenberg and Mahan family

Last week, Arun Thampi, a programmer in Singapore, discovered that the mobile social network Path was surreptitiously copying address book information from users' iPhones without notifying them. David Morin, Path's voluble chief executive, quickly commented on Mr. Thampi's blog that Path's actions were an ''industry best practice.'' He then became uncharacteristically quiet as the Internet disagreed and erupted in outrage. Amid his silence, he did take the time to reply to the actress Alyssa Milano, who was one of hundreds who questioned Path's practices. (His reply to her via Twitter contained his personal e-mail address.)

VERMYLEN--Nancy Barr, of Saddle River, NJ and Shoreham, NY died peacefully on Saturday, February 11, 2012 at age 91. She is survived by her beloved husband of 66 years, Paul Anthony Vermylen; their seven children: Paul Jr. (Robin), Jay, Peter (Cathleen), David (Stacy), Jessica Vermylen Fiddes (John), Robert (Mary), and Mark (Barbara); twenty-one grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Nancy was a loyal alumna of The Ursuline School, New Rochelle, NY (1938) and Trinity College (now Trinity Washington University, 1942). She was a Past President of the Board of Cerebral Palsy Center of Bergen County, a volunteer in the Valley Hospital Auxiliary and at The Forum School of Waldwick, NJ. Nancy was a long-time parishioner of St. Gabriel's Church in Saddle River where she was a Eucharistic Minister. Funeral arrangements are being made through Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. www.feeneyfuneralhome.com. Visiting hours 2-4pm and 7-9pm Tuesday, February 14 at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood. Funeral Mass 10:00am Wednesday, February 15 at St. Gabriel's Church, 88 East Saddle River Road, Saddle River, NJ. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Children's Therapy Center in Fairlawn, NJ would be appreciated. www.thechildrenstherapycenter.org/donate.html

Whitney Houston, the multimillion-selling singer who emerged in the 1980s as one of her generation's greatest R&B voices only to deteriorate through years of cocaine use and an abusive marriage, died on Saturday in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 48. Her death came as the music industry descended on Los Angeles for the annual celebration of the Grammy Awards. She was to have attended a pre-Grammy party Saturday night being hosted by Clive Davis, the founder of Arista Records, who had been her pop mentor.

MARCUS--Alan, 54, passed away suddenly on February 10, 2012. The beloved husband and father is survived by: his wife Barbara, children Simon and Nomi; parents William and Sylvia; and his siblings Nancy and Robert. He is dearly missed by all who were touched by his tender heart.

CARTER--Martha Elizabeth Wiedersheim Lloyd, 90, a long time resident of New Canaan, CT and most recently of Meadow Ridge in Redding, CT died on February 7, 2012 after a brief illness. She was the beloved wife of 31 years of William Phelps Carter, who survives her. Her first husband, Charles Ewing Green Lloyd, predeceased her in 1979 after 34 years of marriage. Known as Betty, she grew up in St. Davids, PA, attended the Shipley School and graduated from Chatham Hall in 1939. She was an avid sportswoman and long time member of the Country Club of New Canaan and the Saugatuck Shores Club and served on their boards. She was also a member of the Mill Reef Club in Antigua. She is survived by her sister, Katherine Wiedersheim Petrie of Doylestown, PA and her two children, Suzanne Lloyd Liebolt and Charles Ewing Green Lloyd, Jr., both of New York City. She leaves behind four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren by her first husband and four Carter sons, twelve step grandchildren and two step-great- grandchildren by her second. All adored her. Betty reached across generations. She was energetic and vibrant and kept her keen mind engaged until the end. Her memory was legendary and she was our GPS. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00 am on Friday, February 17, 2012 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 111 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan, CT 06840. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to St. Mark's.

Internet users who want to opt out of having their online behavior tracked by marketers have a couple of relatively easy options. They can change the privacy settings in their browser or click on the privacy icon that many display ads carry. To find out what is really going on under the pages of many Web sites and the third-party ad networks they work with, however, users would have to take a more difficult route - reading the privacy policy for each Web site in detail. Buried deep within the legalese used in many privacy policies is information on how Web publishers collect and handle the data they use to show ads to their visitors.

Our deepest sympathies to his wife Ginny, sons Peter and Todd, daughter-in-law Jessica, grandsons Nate and Will, mother Phyllis, sister Caroline, sister-in-law Pat and brother-in-law Ed. Diane & Fin Fogg

TAFLER--Claire S.,of Southbury, CT, beloved wife of the late Abraham, passed on February 9th. Survived by her two sons, David and Michael, daughter-in-law Kitty Macey, and granddaughters Keagan and Katrina. Ms. Tafler was a Supervisor of Home Economics in the New York City school system.

MALE, Maldives -- For much of the world, the Maldives means idyllic and exclusive beach resorts, a kind of G-rated version of Thailand, but for many of the people who live here it has been no paradise. For most of the last three decades, the country's autocratic ruler pursued policies that kept many Maldivians poor while extending a warm welcome to well-heeled foreign tourists, including the likes of Tom Cruise and Madonna. Those visitors helped bankroll the government and have made the Maldives, a sprawl of more than 1,200 islands dotted across the Indian Ocean, the most prosperous country in South Asia.
GOLDSMITH--Juliet K.,our family has lost an expectional member who showed us ever lasting courage by the way she lived her life. We will miss our Jules. With love, Jane & Paul

AARONRoger S. We deeply mourn the loss of our long-time, cherished friend, Roger Aaron. He excelled at everything, and earned the respect, trust and affection of the people he touched. And he touched many as a superb, world-renowned lawyer at the top of his profession, as a critical contributor to the effort and value system that moved Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP from a small, single office New York law firm to the global presence that it is today, as a dedicated family man, as an active participant in numerous important causes, including education, health care and human rights, and as a friend to so many people. To his wife, Ginny, his sons, Peter and Todd, his daughter-in-law, Jessica, his grandsons, Nate and Will, his mother, Phyllis and his sister, Carolyn, we offer our profound condolences. Roger was a great person and a truly good person. We will always carry him in our hearts. Peter and Laurie Atkins

LONDON - Another day, another downgrade. That is fast becoming the refrain for the battered economies of Europe as Moody's Investors Service became the latest international ratings agency to cut its assessments of European sovereign debt.

St Valentine's Day on Feb. 14 is a day of pledges, gifts and mysterious missives from secret admirers. And, for the wealthier types - not to mention dealers in high-end jewelry - it is an occasion when diamonds are the gem du jour, as I write in my Page Two column. Ever since a smart advertising copywriter in 1947 coined the phrase "a diamond is forever" in a campaign for the diamond giant De Beers, the link between super-compressed carbon and eternal amour has been just as enduring.

A California physicist said he was abducted off a street in Beijing this month and was beaten and harshly questioned for 21 hours by public security officers, Andrew Jacobs reported from the Chinese capital. The detention of Ge Xun, 53, a naturalized American who moved to the United States from China in 1986, suggests how far the Chinese government will go in its battle against a freewheeling Internet. Mr. Ge said the agents demanded the password for his Twitter account and questioned him about his membership in an organization that fosters dialogue between Tibetans and Chinese. In a telephone interview from his home in Fremont, California, Mr. Ge said, "The more they beat me, the less I felt like cooperating.'' Read Andrew's full story »

The outcry against Apple, especially about working conditions at some of its suppliers' factories in China, finally became too much to ignore: Apple said Monday that an outside organization had begun to audit conditions at the plants where most of the iPhones, iPads and other Apple products are built.

The Bataan Nuclear Power Plant in the Philippines was intended to be a pioneering model for Southeast Asia. Uranium was flown in from the United States and the powering-up process began in 1986. Then came the Chernobyl disaster, and the plant was mothballed. In 2011, just as years of lobbying by nuclear power advocates appeared to be paying off, the Fukushima disaster occurred. The plant's owners then decided to turn their power plant into a tourist attraction, featuring a tour of the containment building. The plant, which has never generated a watt of electricity, is now producing revenues from tourists, particularly visitors from Japan. Read more »
